text: This is a great place for breakfast regardless of where you live. It's worth the ride or a long walk. I was lucky enough to discover this place thanks to Hotel Broad Ripple. The quinoa bowl was deliscious, just don't forget to add avocado. If you are lucky Mason will sing for you! Oh and this place has Matcha Green Tea and they know how to properly prepare a straight cup of matcha. A true blessing for matcha lovers.

I wouldn't say this is the best Sally's in the area, but it's literally like five minutes away from my house. It's a great place to pick up hairdye and knick knacks.

They offer a membership for 5 dollars that you will get much more in return. You get a membership pricing on certain items and some gifts on certain occasions when you spend a certain amount.

They have a website too for what you can not find in stores. The workers are usually helpful the times I went. The last time the girl offered assistance on picking up colors for my mom and I. I felt she was off on my mom's color a bit, but nothing I couldn't fix up.

I love picking up haircare products from here, but do be careful. I feel some of the products might be a little too old. I had gone to Cali and picked up a bottle of styling product but left it in Cali when I left. So I went to the Sally's back home and picked up the same bottle but the product wasn't clear like the other one. It turned out to be a really nasty yellow color. I wasn't sure if the product was bad or if that's how it was suppose to be.

So I'm going to be a little more cautious picking up some of their generic brands. I do however love picking up their deep conditioning packets that are almost always on sale for .99cents. Great for if you're always dying your hair!

They have tons of products for your nails, hair to do extensions, accessories for hair, and appliances. You might get a good deal here than you would other places on appliances. So it doesn't hurt to check in to see if you can pick up something here than running to the nearest Utla.

Had to go the tourist route and get a cheese streak while in Philly. The hype is well deserved. I loved the sandwich and I'm not a cheese whiz fan but I didn't want to alter the meal. I was not disappointed at all. The food was good, service was quick, price was reasonable and I left there stuffed. I had a mushroom cheese steak and a bottle of water because it was a hot day. I'll try the fries next time because I plan to go back with no hesitation. The area was clean, parking is a challenge but if u get off the beaten path and park in the residential area and walk a block or two you'll be fine. Car was safe no issues or alarming concerns. I love the way both legendary restaurants are in the same area and they are both prosperous. A little friendly competition goes a long way and they have it down to an art. Just think they need to accept credit and debit cards in this day and age. The sandwich was $12 and that's a reasonable amount to use a card for your purchase.

I really like Asian supermarkets and I don't often find major variation in them. They have hard-to-find supplies at good prices and have a fishy smell. This one is near my weekly grocery commute, so I want happy to use it. Plus, it's connected to Tasty Place which I love!

Before trying Joe's Next Door for a lunch break, I was told that the BLT would change my life. That's a pretty high bar of expectation to set, but wooooow... yeah, I loved it. 

Joe's is located right on main street in Carmel, so you can't miss it. Stop in for a wide variety of spices, sauce, frozen meals, wine, sandwiches -- and obviously, meat. 

For lunch I've opted for the BLT twice and the Cuban once. Both were delicious, but they really do work some magic on the BLT. It only takes about 5 minutes for them to make it, and the staff is very friendly. 

Be sure to grab a small bag of Broad Ripple Chip Co with your sandwich... and definitely, opt for the BLT.

I love this place so much that I don't even know where to begin this review.  I have dined or had drinks here at least 25 times over the last five years.  I have never had a less than perfect experience or less than perfect meal.
     Starting with the atmosphere, what can I say that has not been said before?  The place is gorgeous, no really.... it is stunning.  The old converted church is lovely in every possible way and exudes charm from every corner both inside & out.
     This is an elegant establishment and I just don't think we have enough of those in a world that is becoming ever more casual.  Check in with the host, check your coat and hang out at the bar.  They have a nice wine list that will surely have something for your enjoyment.  The bartenders have been the same for years & will create some of the finest cocktails in New Hope - I recommend the classic Martini.  The host will come get you when your table is ready and whisk you away to a romantic dining room on the second floor.  Look around as you climb the stairs, there is a lot to see in this beautiful old church.  
     The grand dining room is large, complete with stunning art and magnificently high ceilings.  The tables for couples will be adorned with red rose petals.  
     The food has always been exceptional, understand it is Southern cooking, Creole to be exact - lots of seafood, lots of classics such as jambalaya & gumbo.  The fresh French baguette they bring over is always warm, flakey in the outside and delicate on the inside.  The service has never been less than five stars.  I always like a little banter with whomever is serving and my last experience here was no exception.  Our server both entertained us with his quick wit and informed us about everything we considered on the menu.
    We both ordered the beet salad with spinach & goat cheese as our starter and as a vegetarian I got the Eggplant Napoleon as my meal.  Creamy, buttery, fresh, flavorful with just the right spice to make an impression - delicious!!!  Naturally dessert had to be ordered and I got the carrot cake, be warned - it is a very large piece and is served with a scoop of homemade ice cream.  I couldn't finish the whole thing & I never leave dessert unfinished on my plate.  
     As I said at the start, I have never had less than a five star experience at Marsha Brown's and will be back again in a few weeks.

My daughter attended summer horse camp here- we picked it because it was closest to our house, but we love it! It's a shady ranch and the owner is super friendly and makes you feel like part of the family. Loved the dogs running around  (Veeda was my favorite) We we're impressed with the level of training they gave and they even provided snacks and breaks during the daily trail rides. I look forward to going back for a sunset trail ride myself!

This store is definitely a store for high schoolers who need books off their book list for the semester. (They also have a used book section that is quite limited - more mystery and romance books than straight up lit.) The books are organized just like the bookstore I used to grab books at when I was a high school student. I still would have bought a book anyway (some books that high school students are assigned are great books! Amerika by Kafka? Never read it. Should read it.), BUT they are cash only! At a book store!! Where a typical purchase is probably more than $10! But cash only. So I put my books back, apologized for not having cash, and walked out (probably never to return). If you're a high school student near Franklin or a parent of such a student, this store is probably great (so long as you have cash on you), but for regular readers/book lovers, it's not a great store. B&N in Cool Springs or Landmark Booksellers are probably better options.

Had so much fun here while visiting my friend in SB!  Right on the pier and they have a deck with great views.  I love how they had different options for wine flights too.  Sat outside and enjoyed the view and some good vino.  Would come back!

Tex-Mex fast food, chain store variety. That being said, it's typically pretty good considering its chain store fast food. For the love of God, get rid of the corporate mandate making employees yell "welcome to moes" every time somebody walks in the door.

Great diner-esque food with a huge pastry bakery case up front. My friend and I were getting hungry and I've seen signs all over for Ponzio's and thought it would be a great time to check it out.

Our first server was a little..odd. But she had to leave half-way through and the next server was ok, but she was semi staring at us once in awhile. This was about 5pm on a Saturday and it was packed. 

To start out, the green bean fries were tasty and the philly cheesesteak spring rolls were super hot, crispy and flavorful. Being as hungry as I was, and knowing I can't actually eat that much I wanted something I could easily heat up the next day as well. Answer- chicken parm with a side of angel hair pasta. Huge portion! Everything was cooked perfectly with a really nice tomato sauce. My friend got a Reuben and loved every bite.  

The menu was large with a copious amount of options. I was deciding between shrimp scampi, strip steak, blackened chicken wrap.. I was on the point of being hangry, but the chicken parm hit the spot.

When I go on vacation, I like to treat myself like it's my birthday!

First step - Make A Reservation! 

This place fills up fast and they will send you reminder text too. I know this is seafood in Nashville but it was literally the best food experience I had while visiting. 

My friend and I arrived from a long flight from NY and had a couple cocktails at Skull's Raimnbow Room before heading over. Yet, Maci our waitress, sold me on this gin, blueberry, egg white cocktail, called Negative Space. Mind Blowing! It's like this girl could read my mind. I am a sucker for gin and egg white cocktail. I could not have been happier. 

The restaurant itself felt modern, clean and spacious. I like to not be elbow to elbow when I am splurging on a meal. 

We started with a dozen oysters. The oyster menu was perfect. It explained the flavor notes for each, of course some of the obscure ones were sold out. Our dinner was pretty late. I would say come as early as you can for the full menu. Also remember to check the boxes for mignonettesauce, horseradish, cocktail sauce and lemon. This was the best way to start the meal. 

They suggested 4-5 plates to share. We ordered 4 after the oysters and it was a lot. But happy we got to try so many of the dishes. 

Poppy's Caviar - was a delicious and light dish 
Octopus salad - So good with the grapes, avocado and crunchy pepitas
Crab Dip -  A really meaty one of the dishes, rich and comforting. Loved the cast iron skillet it was served in
Smoked Trout - a lovely layering of flavors. With the potatoes it became a lot heavier too

We ended up taking some of the crab dip and smoked trout home and it made for the perfect morning chilled breakfast. 

Thanks to our lovely waitress for helping us through the menu and making our experience so enjoyable. I have been singing your praises Henrietta Red, until we meet again!
Been to Nashville twice, been here both times. NY hip, Nashville charm, great love music, awesome vibe, fantastic menu, great food!   This place is a great mix of hip, comfy and lively!

Restaurant week and we waited until the last minute to make reservations.  Cafe Napoli was our one choice and it did not disappoint.  I chose not to order off the restaurant week menu because I love the Penne Vodka and have not had it in a while.  Others in our party order from the pre fixe menu.  Lots of good choices Cioppino, Branzino, Linguine with clam sauce, there were a lot of good choices.  Service was great, it was very busy but we had a good time and really great food.

Love the brunch on sundays and their french onion soup is a must. It's a great atmosphere is so vibrant and bustling that it makes me feel like I might actually be in europe!
Love that they will call when a table is ready for you, so you can go and roam the square until they call. 
Tip: bread bowl is delicious. Is it bad that I always ask to take it to go?

My kids have voted this place their favorite poke bowl in Reno. They like the wonton chip option as a base and loved the sauces. I agree that the sauce choices are fantastic. Mix and match friends!
They don't have octopus or crab as a protein choice. They do have crab salad as a topping. The proteins they give you are a good portion. We like our poke chunky so this place was good for that. Their fish isn't diced up fine and they didn't use the smallest scooper they could find.

Jerry's State Court Cafe gets four stars from me because of its big effort to provide a gluten free menu. The gluten free menu is huge - pancakes and toast for breakfast and a huge variety of sandwiches for lunch and dinner. There is also a gluten free Benedict that I need to go back and try. My kids loved getting gluten free pancakes off the breakfast menu, pretty much never happened before! The country omelet was pretty good and the bacon was crisp, can't go wrong there. There's tons of seating (the old Elmer's on Fairview) for the many people who seemed to be crowding into the place.

Hip ping pong bar with great cocktails. Tables will fill up in advance its best to make reservations. We did see some parties reserve the red room and another area with DJs and their own waiters. Loved the banksy like art and variety of drinks served.

After ten years as Executive Chef for the Century Hospitality Group, Chef Paul Shufelt decided it was time to start up a restaurant of his own. The Workshop Eatery officially opened a couple weeks ago in The Mosaic Centre, Canada's largest net-zero commercial building. Choosing to open up in a sustainable building definitely poses its challenges, but supporting local producers, sustainability, and using seasonal produce are concepts important to Chef Paul. 

The Workshop Eatery is located in the far south neighborhood of Summerside, which can be a fair drive for many in Edmonton. But once you enter the building you're greeted by an open space and living wall, which shows how unique and beautiful the Mosaic Centre really is. As for the restaurant, you're greeted into a space that is warm, rustic and inviting. I love the open concept and the visibility of the kitchen - there's nothing to hide! 

Throughout the different seasons, the menu will consist of roughly 20 staple dishes and a different feature each day. What makes the menu seasonal will be the different accompaniments and sides to a main dish. If you're ever wondering what's on the menu on a particular day, just check the website! It's amazing that they will be updating their online menu daily! 

We started off our meal with a couple of appetizers, first up was the Arancini ($12). The arancini at Workshop changes daily, and the "New York Deli" arancini with deli meats, a balsamic tomato smear, and Nefiss Lazizz Olive Oil was the feature for the day. These fried risotto balls had a golden, crisp exterior, and broke open to reveal a creamy mix of risotto, green peas, and small morsels of meat. I personally prefer my arancini to be rich and cheesy, so these arancini didn't quite deliver for me. 

Next up came the Chicken Liver Parfait ($11) served in a small mason jar with crostinis made from Bon Ton Bakery's Cranberry Raisin Nut Bread. The liver was whipped with a mousse-like texture and topped with a port and Saskatoon berry jam. It was a perfect balance between sweet and savoury, and I loved the different textures that the crostini added to the mixture.

Our last starter for the meal was the Duck Carpaccio ($17) featuring Moosewood Acres cured duck breast, pickled shiitakes, carrots, daikon, a soy reduction and blood orange vinaigrette. I really enjoyed the fragrant orange paired with the duck, and the tang of the vinaigrette, but found that the dish was much too salty. Typically a carpaccio dish features meat that is extremely thinly sliced or pounded thin, but the duck in this carpaccio was thickly sliced. The thick slice combined with the soy reduction was quite salty, so with some adjustments to the cut and seasoning, I would really enjoy this dish!

Just like the arancini, The Workshop Eatery has a feature dish each evening. On the night of our visit Tangle Ridge Lamb Chops were being served with a butternut squash, corn and bacon hash. The lamb chops were moist and tender, and looked beautiful against the brightly coloured hash. The hash itself was naturally sweet but lacking in smokiness which we expected from the bacon. As it turns out, we didn't find much bacon in the hash either, so that could have accounted for the discrepancy. 

For myself I ordered the Duck Duck Couscous (how fun is that to say?!) ($32) which featured beautifully seared Moosewood Acres duck breast on a bed of warm couscous with raisins, almonds, pickled cherries and vanilla parsnip puree. The duck was cooked to a perfect medium, and the lightly sweet couscous was a great companion to the duck. The parsnip puree was also a delightful addition to the dish, and complemented both components on the plate. Although I love lamb, the duck was definitely the winner for me and I would happily order it again. 

When it came down to the desserts, I was torn between two options. The panna cotta at The Workshop Eatery is made with the rooftop honey and would have been my first choice, but I couldn't resist the Croissant Bread Pudding ($9). The flaky croissant pieces are paired with white chocolate and cranberry, giving this dessert some tart notes to balance the sweet. Topped with a generous scoop of Pinocchio's cinnamon ice cream, this was a comforting dessert that I would eat again. 

Taken as a whole, we had a great dinner at The Workshop Eatery: our dishes were good and the service was attentive. If there's one thing I love about The Workshop Eatery, it's their commitment to sustainability and supporting local producers. Their decision to move into the Mosaic Centre means that the drive to their restaurant is long and far for many patrons, but the principles of the building align with the values of the restaurant. It's great to see so many local farmers mentioned throughout the menu, and I think it will be interesting to see how things shift once the growing season in Edmonton comes around.

Who doesn't like to pick their own steak ? I love it! As soo as you walk in they're right there to get your menu selection off to a good start. Our server was a young man named Paul, I like him because he went out of his way to make sure that my wife and daughter were taken care of with their orders from beginning to end. When he initially came over to introduce himself and take our drink order, he knelt right beside me and my daughter looked at me and asked/stated... "Daddy, your face is saying that he committed a Man-Law Violation?! Yes, yes he did... much too close. But no points are deducted when a person is giving great hospitality and service.  Makes me wonder if everything really is BIGGER in Texas.


Let's see how the main coarse goes... 45 minutes later... So I had a 16oz sirloin and it melted like butter! Great steak! The house steak sauce was another story altogether... watered down, very bland and not a good pairing for such an amazing steak. Thanks once again to Paul for rescuing a choice steak with a bottle of A1 steak sauce.

Our appetizers were great as well, thanks Paul for the suggestion of a "Triple Treat" Potato skins, fried pickles (Amanda's favorite) and buffalo wings. My daughter loved her baked potato but was a title puzzled by the chicken tenders because they looked more like chicken nuggets.

Overall, great Job Paul! We live closer to the Wesley Chapel location but this was a great fill-in spot.

First time trying this place. I heard mixed reviews but had to try it for myself. Absolutely love the food. Very clean environment. Staff is friendly and the food came out pretty quick. I will defiantly be coming back and recommending this place to my friends and colleagues.

(Shaking my fist at Camay's review!!)
She went in with the details...lol
But seriously.. This bar almost brings a tear to my eye.. 
(I said almost, dammit!!)
This reminds me of the bars from back in the day.. Smoking is allowed.. The bar and cooler is stocked with plenty of affordable drinks and beer.. Please don't walk in asking for your favorite craft beer...
People sitting at the bar and tables telling the same stories you've might have heard the last time you were there... But it's still entertaining.. 
A jukebox full of good music.. and a kitchen in the back that I've heard have some really good food, although I can't confirm it.. Apparently lunchtime opening isn't an option.. 
Bring a few bucks.. Say hello to Jasmine the bartender. She was pretty pleasant and attentive. and enjoy.. Bars like these are fading and you'll miss them when they're gone..
UYE anyone??
But first, somebody send an I Love Yelp sticker to put on this bar's door..

There's something about thrifting and finding treasures that gives me goosebumps! The thrill of finding the hidden treasure is hard to explain unless you yourself are avid thrifter, a dumpster diver and a price checker! 

I had bookmarked my stops before traveling to Northern Liberties. And Once Worn was definitely in the to do list. As I walked up I could see a SALE rack! Those discounted racks can be the quick fix for sure. It  was my lucky day. I saw it hidden...it was a ..Catherine Malandrino dress!!! Wow! And in black! I tried to contain my glee for the true test. 

Then....dun dun dun...dressing room! The place that is the true decisions maker in my book.  I closed the curtain and the clerk remarked the Velcro that connects the curtain to the wall. Brilliant! I hate it when there's a little gap and people can see in. And then when I slipped the dress on..it was easily a Va-Va-Voom dress!! Fit like a glove! And I have to wear black at work some days. It was also work appropriate, flattering and feminine. There was black on black leopard pattern in the front section down. Gorgeous. 

I felt the need to pay and try to not tempt myself to buy the whole store. The clerk and I chatted for like 15 minutes! She was a total sweetheart! 

I had so much fun I told my friend who's into vintage to check it out! And from what I hear she made out like a bandit! Lulu Guinness was amongst the loot. Another one of my faves! This place is on my list for all future visits!! And I almost wanted to not review and keep it alllllll to myself but I'm too nice! Enjoy and find some treasures!

I have only been to this Starbucks location once or twice when I happened to be in the shopping center.  It's your typical Starbucks, except I don't love the set up.  When you walk in the door there is a table right in front of you, and it seems that the entrance area could get very crowded and confusing during busy time.  While I didn't sit down with my drink, I noticed the few tables around, none appearing to be particularly comfortable or private.  Also, the area where the barista will hand you your finished drink is kind of in the middle of the store, leaving you to stand awkwardly in someone's way.

Regardless, it's Starbucks, and I won't hesitate to go to this location if I'm in the area.

We always have a great time!  We had 1 goal and that was to get the injectable donut holes. We chose to get the three different sauces chocolate, raspberry, and Bavarian cream. They did not disappoint. Our family loved them. Andrew was our server at our bay and he was the best server we have ever had there he gets 10 stars every day.

My only complaint is that it is very expensive and the wait is always crazy long and if you want a reservation you have to pay an additional amount that doesn't go towards your purchase! 

**Olivia and Brianna corner** (the teens thoughts) 

Olivia's favorite sauce was raspberry. The heaters are the best!!

Tried this place after getting a flier. It looks like a restaurant you'd see in Japan.  Lots of Japan motif around.  
    Now about the food.  Wife loved her sesame chicken. I had Pad Woo Sen. Mine was just okay.  I will return and try something else. Price is reasonable. 
    So many places come and go. Will be interesting to see if they make it.

The location of this gym gets 5 stars. The dirty locker rooms that never have paper towels, or even toilet paper, are disgusting. It is hotter than heck in here all of the time. Treadmills have salt on them from people wearing their shoes in. I love to people watch here, but while I love to lift weights, those are a mess too! Either we need to require members to pick up after themselves, or get a cleaning crew on staff. Come on, planet fitness does better than this!

Took a girlfriend here for a massage for her bachelorette party on a Saturday. We arrived a little early but the therapist was really nice and welcoming. She started early on my friend while i sat in the lobby resting. The location was north of State street so it's a bit of a far walk down to downtown. 

My friend loved the massage and was very relaxed.

The star rating does not go high enough for this delightful dining experience. This was amazing food cooked with love and joy. Everything was perfect and amazing don't plan on a rush visit this food is meant to be savored

When I tell people in Philadelphia that I'm Greek-American, invariably one of the first questions I'll get is "What's your favorite Greek restaurant in Philly?" which is quickly followed by "What do you think of South Street Souvlaki?" I have always been at a loss to answer either because I don't eat out often, and when I do it's almost never at a Greek restaurant. Also, as a vegetarian, I just wouldn't go to a restaurant whose name celebrates meat. 

So when my friend Brad mentioned that he'd heard about a new Greek restaurant and would I check it out with him, I was immediately interested. From the initial reviews it sounded legit, more like the food I'd grown up eating at home rather than Greek food catering to American tastes (the many complaints about the lack of lettuce in the Greek salad were a good sign). The menu does still lean more towards the preferences of meat-eaters (gotta give the market what it wants) but there are several vegetarian options. No fish entrees, which seemed like a pretty major omission for a Greek restaurant, but the garidomakaronada sounds like the shrimp Santorini I used to love, which isn't something you find often. 

But anyway, for my first visit the seafood test was the xtopodi (grilled octopus). Because if a Greek restaurant can't do THAT well, it'll never be great. The verdict? It has potential, but I have to admit it's not the way I'm used to having Greek-style octopus. Usually it's cut into pieces (thus more thoroughly cooked), and here the tentacles were served pretty much intact. The flavors were right though, and maybe this is the way it's actually served in Greece? It's tasty so still worth getting, but it's a huge portion so you probably want to have at least 4 people in your party who love octopus if you're going to order this.

I chose the spanakopita as an entree, and that was definitely excellent. The pita was clearly house-made (not ready-made phyllo-dough) and delicious, and the spinach filling was really well done. This definitely stacked up against plenty of the better homemade spanakopita I've had. Brad got the meat-eater's version, the kreatopita (which had chicken, pork and lamb). I've never seen that in a Greek home or restaurant before, so I'm guessing this was made, again, for American tastes. But it must work, because he liked it. Both dishes came with the horiatiki salad - yes, this is what Greek salad is supposed to be like!

Moving beyond the menu, the decor reminded me a lot of the more minimalist Greek tavernas I've been to, though still with a good dose of Greek art and elements (wall tiles, prints, statuettes, etc.) I could heard traditional Greek music over the loudspeaker but the noise level mostly obscured it - the restaurant was PACKED. Lots of big parties, families, etc. Everyone seemed like they were having a great time, and the hosts and servers ran around frantically to make sure that was the case.

So I'm happy to now know a great Greek restaurant in Philly! Well, close enough - a Philly suburb. Since most of the Greeks I know seem to prefer the suburbs anyway, this actually makes sense. In the meantime, I still need to find a good Greek restaurant in the city itself (eventually).

I've been seeing this place all over social media and have been wanting to try it for the longest time!
As luck would have it I go the chance to go this weekend since I was on the south side of Indy. 
I love it! Located in what was the old ice house bar is Dukes and it is set up like a honky tonk bar, neon lights old signs.. the works! 
They also have pretty legit live music and this comes from a person who didn't grow up with country music. 
Awesome service! I hope people understand that that they are making moves with how packed they are, I even had a guy who was hanging out drinking and was helping a friend bus tables.. 
If you go at night the menu is limited but that's ok! Get the whole fried chicken and all the sides and you won't be mad! 
The chicken is cooked to perfection! And had this seasoning on it that is sweet and spicy and I wish I knew what is was, but it tastes great! 
Hash brown waffle is to die for! The hatch Mac is the right amount of spice and the Brussel sprouts were seasoned and charred in just the right way.
Can't wait to go back to try lunch foods

After driving by a million times (give or take a couple), we finally stopped here on a Friday evening for a quick dinner, and we are now fans. 

Based on Yelp reviews we ordered the Bavarian pretzel with Obatzda, the wurst platter and the mussels in beer.  The house-made pretzel had a thick, chewy exterior which was the perfect foil for the richness of the Obatzda.  The deliciousness was further enhanced by Mr. M's micro-brew and my light and bubbly hard cider.   I would have been content to stop right there.  

Mr. M ordered the wurst platter, which he declared excellent (not a surprise given the distinguished pedigree of the wurst).  What really sold him on the meal, however, were the handcut fries and spaetzle, which recalled Mom's recipe.   The mussels were uber-delicious (and comparable to Monk's), and only the rules of decorum prevented me from slurping the remaining broth. 

We loved the intimacy that the low-lighting created in what is not an intimate space.  The service was attentive, efficient and patient with newbies.

I love marias pizza. And I used to love their fries. But lately they have been over cooked. I got an eggplant parm sandwich and it was just blah. No sauce. Soggy eggplant. Pretty sure I found an eyelash on the mozzerella. They are a small family run business and they are friendly but idk what's happening with the quality of the food lately. I hope it gets better.

My boyfriend won a football bet and his prize was to choose dinner. He wanted to go to Seoul Kitchen, but after reading Isabella J's SK review, we decided to try Kimchi Time instead and we're so glad we did! 

The tables were full at 8 pm, which is a testament to their popularity and solid food. The servers were very friendly, but not the most attentive. I did have to flag them a few times but they were especially responsive. 

We ordered the mandu, spicy Korean wings, dolsot bi bam bap, and grilled gal bi - all dishes I highly recommend! They serve everything piping hot, maybe too hot. The wings weren't too spicy in my opinion (I can barely do hot cheetohs). I loved my sweet delicious gal bi. They also provide 5 sides including different kimchi vegetables and sweet mashed potatoes (I asked for extra).  Finish your meal with red bean ice cream and I guarantee you'll leave with a happy belly.

Wow. So good. The best pizza I've had in Florida hands down. 
So I'm from Chicagoland, and have lived in NYC-so I know my pies. This place is legit. 
The crust perfectly charred with that amazing combo of crunchy and chewy. 
The toppings are fresh, delicious, and aside from maybe a bit too much garlic on one the pies (whole cloves-tasty but Wowza) I can find no faults. 
Service was ridiculously friendly, knowledgeable and quite frankly I can't wait to return. 
Now as soon as my tummy settles I'll get to work on the cannoli I brought home. 
This is must do for any foodie in Tampa Bay

The premise is clean organic eating which I love!This establishment is counter service during the day and table service at night. First trip I had the Smoked Salmon & Scrambled BLT it was $14 and it was only ok. I drank the free water on the table. There was a lot of bread and I ended up eating the sandwich open-faced. I wish I had gotten a juice or smoothie to try but after $14 on a sandwich that wasn't an option this time. My coworkers ordered other meal options but no one was blown away. It was just ok.

On my second trip I came for dinner with my family because my sister loves this place and I have to say it has improved since opening. I got the chicken salad sandwich and hot cauliflower. I am in love and wish I could eat it everyday! 

 I will say the ambiance was fabulous and this place is truly adorable! If you think you might be into it, I say just go for it and try to form your own opinions because you might like it more than I did.

There is EiO & The Hive parking right outside but it indicates that there is a 20-minute limit which doesn't seem like enough time.

I absolutely love how she does my eyebrows there. They are typically pretty quick. I'm in and out within 20 mins. I'm not sure if they just warmed food up or something. But this time in the wax room coming from the back was a bit of a unpleasant smell. It cost about 10 bucks to get eyebrows done. They have a list of different services. I have gotten my nails done here and I was very pleased with them.

This coffee shop/bar is a very acquired taste. I like the set up and I like how it has organic and vegan options however if you're not a true coffee lover I would not recommend this. I had the Horchata latte and it wasn't exactly how I expected it, it was a lot stronger and Horchata is very light and sweet, they use organic cacao and I believe that's what overpowers the flavors. I enjoyed my latte, would I order it again I'm not too confident.

I am a regular at Zizzo's, because it has the best brewed coffee in town. I probably go at least 1-2 a week just for a 24oz large coffee for 2.50!! A delicious cup of coffee (or technically three) at this price is unbeatable.

I'm definitely a coffee snob and I care deeply about the roasting. My husband is from Seattle and my mother travels quite often to Colombia. Zizzo's is my favorite because they always have a light roast, medium roast, and dark roast coffee of the day to chose from. 

Let's talk about light roast. I have a deep appreciation for light roast coffee for a couple of reasons. First, it has the highest caffeine content. Second, it's hard to do light roast that has a good prominent flavor. All of Zizzo's light roast coffees are amazing. I personally love the Mexican Altura and the Guatemala Antigua roasts.

The medium roast is the Santa Barbara blend and it's great too. A solid go-to. I'll occasionally get a dark roast, and have never been disappointed. Occasionally they have a Tanzania peaberry, and I can never pass that up.

Their food is okay(but delicious at their other location), the clientele are friendly, they love dogs, and I've never ever had bad service. Tammy is my favorite barista, she seems genuinely happy! 

This was all about the brewed coffee, but their espresso drinks are also really good. I like the Mexican mocha the best. I don't recommend the biscotti, but the other baked goods are fine.

They also give my pup a dog treat, and that makes me happy!  I also forgot to mention they have a few great beers on tap, and a fun system where locals buy each other beers in advance and Zizzo's puts their names on the wall and what someone has purchased for them.

This is our hands down favorite pizza place. We love their crust, breads, and sauce. Even better than ordering their pizza is their dine in experience. We hit brunch here today--they do brunch starting at 10am on the weekends with bottomless mimosas and bloody mary! We came right as they opened. I ordered the soup and a calzone,  he ordered the Megan breakfast sandwich. The general manager, as my soup was taking a little longer than they anticipated (which wasn't long at all), offered us complimentary biscuits with a to die for honey butter. We loved all of it and had a fantastic time! Their facility is clean, professional and very relaxing. Our wait staff was also very good amd timely with our drinks and overall service. I can't say enough good things about this place!

New Year's Eve 2015 was just another night at Basin, and I love that.

We had a reservation, and were seated immediately. FYI there is a specialty cocktail list on a chalkboard above the open kitchen. Our waiter didn't mention it, but we found it anyway. 

I got the duck ragu and he got the yellowfin tuna. The duck was great and I wolfed it down, but the tuna was DIVINE. Buttery, perfectly cooked and served over a Mediterranean kind of salad. Yum, Yum, Yum.

We used a restaurant.com coupon so with one cocktail and two entrees it was only about $40.

Fresh seafood, cheap prices, awesome customer service and tasty desserts; what more do I need!?!

I had an order of Salmon nuggets, Fries and Steamed Broccoli. The nuggets were very light, the broccoli had garlic butter dripped on top and the fries are beer battered. Yummy yummy yummy. My bro had Flounder, Broccoli and Mac & Cheese. I'm not a big fan of their mac and cheese but love that their seafood is not heavily breaded.

Thread lightly with the desserts....I can only confirm that the strawberry cheesecake is delicious, everything else, ehhh, idk.

Oh and you can't eat in; I mean, you can stand and eat by their counter but that's like eating at a bus stop! =|

We live close by and used to love the Cheddar's in Mt. Juliet were we use to live. 

It's Friday night so obviously very crowded. They sat us in section that has 2 parties in it. One table with about 10 people, and the other with about 18. Experience (as a patron and working at restaurants) tells me that, other than the obvious noise, food quality drops drastically when that happens as cooks struggle to get all the food out for that table at the same time, and other orders are either rushed through, or die in the window as they are ignored being the mountain of plates for the party. This is a good test of a kitchen, but let's keep an open mind. 

Our waitress Tiffany was very nice, friendly and helpful. She said she would put our order in before party which she did. Very nice. 
We ordered the Texas cheese fries, and the grown up grilled cheese. I usually have the Monte Cristo but wanted to try something new. Had a Caesar salad for my side. 

We ordered before the big party so our food got out fast. 
The Texas cheese fries were great as expected. No complaints there. 
The grilled cheese had roast beef in it, which tasted very bland and over cooked. The worst part was the cheese. It was sliced cheese which was by far not high end to say the least. 

Caesar salad was fine. Not bad, not great. 
The croissant on salad was awesome and sadly the best part of the meal. 

Not sure we will return. Not good enough for the price and so many other great choices with a 3 mile radius.

Is "too much toast" ever a bad thing? I doubt it! At Toast, in New Orleans, you may suffer from "too much toast" syndrome, but by suffer, I mean benefit greatly from... until you enter into a debilitating food coma 30 minutes after finishing your meal. I love toast (the bread). I love to toast (the bebidas alcoholicas). And I definitely love to Toast (eating brunch at Toast, the restaurant). All three of which, I can do at once, at Toast! On my recent visit there, I ordered the Croque Madame, and instead of the side salad, I substituted a side of bacon because... bacon! It was so good, and so filling, I couldn't finish my meal! I haven't tried the Aebelskivers yet, but can't wait to do so, along with pretty much everything else on their menu, to be honest... I also want to toast to Toast with toast, at Toast... some day soon!

This Bar Louie is pretty awesome!   Great Location right in the heart of International Mall and next to my other fav spot Blue Martini.   Love the look of it inside the booths are round and comfortable. Plenty of seating for you and all of your friends.   Plenty of large screen TVs for watching sports at any angle.   The service is excellent as well.  My meal was very good!  Great place, location and excellent service!  I will be back.

Who doesn't love a good doughnut? I know I do... Especially when they are fresh. I mean, made in front of you fresh. I'm a huge fan of Krispy Kreme and how their donuts come out hot and fresh right off the production line. So on my recent trip to Philly, when I heard about Federal Donuts, I had to give them a try.

Very interesting flavors are available to you. You can get a Cinnamon brown sugar, Strawberry lavender, or Cookies and cream.

Of the 3, I think my favorite was the cinnamon brown sugar. I guess I just love the churro type of combination.

I give Federal Donuts a solid 4 out of 5 stars because I enjoyed the donuts and like the coffee shop kinda vibe. Interestingly, they are also known for their fried chicken sandwiches. It's a great place to try a number of different things.

If it was located anywhere else, this venue would probably earn a three from me but the location and prices cannot be beat. 

We ventured here a few minutes after it opened this morning around 11:15. The outdoor patio right next to the rail were already slowly getting filled up with patrons. We were lucky to secure the last table right next to the rail. Our host was very nice and told us our server would be with us shortly.

Sure enough, our server popped in to get our drink orders. 

The three of us shared a combination of things from the menu.

We ordered the Fried Clam with Tartar Sauce, She Crab Soup Bowl, Grouper Tamales, Super Cajun Grouper Sandwich with Fries (+$0.99 for fries to substitute chips), Tuna Poke Tacos.

My least favorite was probably the fried clams because of the inconsistency of batter to clam ratio. Some pieces were just pieces of batter. That being said, the clam pieces were delicious. 

The grouper tamales were average. The grouper was delicious and so were the sauces they served with it: rojo and salsa verde. I didn't like the masa mixture. I thought it too thick and bland. 

The she crab soup was delicious but super rich. I don't think I could have eaten the entire thing by myself so thankfully it was shared among the three of us. 

The grouper sandwich was delicious and very flavorful. I wasn't a fan of the fries that came with the sandwich. They were cut way too fat and not crispy enough for my liking.

My tuna poke tacos were very flavorful. I really enjoyed the sweet thai chili sauce and cabbage slaw that was underneath the tacos. The fish was generously portioned. 

My boyfriend ordered their Beer of the Month special which was $2.50 for a bottle of Banks Beer. He said the beer was watered down and not flavorful but considering the price, I wasn't surprised. 

Overall, it was a great experience and I can see why people love coming here. I loved sitting right next to the rail enjoying the oceanfront views.

Service was great. Our server got my tuna taco order wrong but was quick to fix the issue and apologize even though we ordered a lot so it's easily misunderstand as another dish on their menu.

Love me some Ruby Slipper, for some reason when in NOLA I only come to this location. Although there is always a wait, they are pretty close to quoted waitlist times.

Once seated the average time from ordering to dining is pretty standard.

The drinks are great and food is good too. I drank my margarita so damn fast I forgot to take a pic of the presentation  but trust me order a Morning Margarita better than coffee..get your day started proper

I mean seriously, if a zoo is free you better believe I am going to visit it! I love this zoo. I have been about 3 times since moving into the city and each time I have gone I have had a great experience. Even though I went on a holiday weekend it wasn't too busy. This place is huge, so you better be prepared to do a lot of walking. I do not recommend wearing heels as I have done in the past. My feet were not happy with me at the end of the day. I think if you can get there when the zoo first opens you'll have better luck with parking. I hate to pay for parking so I usually end up driving around a few minutes in Forest Park to find something close by. The animals are out now for the summer so you should go check them out! You won't be disappointed.

I love love LOVE the bargains at CVS. Although the lines can get pretty long sometimes, they get people on the registers and your wait isn't excruciatingly long. Can't say I've had any problems here. This is the location I've visited often, I'll miss it now that I've moved.

Diner food does not get any better than this!!!! Came here because I had been here before and loved it. This time I had the senior Meat Loaf. It came with 2 sides and the waitress let me have the soup as a side. A great choice as it was Navy Bean soup with big old chunks of ham in it!!! Meat loaf tasted like Mom made it!! Mashed taters and 2 buttermilk drop biscuits made this a scrumptious dinner!!!! I must eat healthy the rest of the week!!!!!! I love this place. Good thing it is in Tampa is for a treat now and then!!!!!!!

This place is so pretty inside. The entrance has a nice waterfall glass. The other decoration throughout is warm and inviting to have a nice sit down meal with great ambiance and comfortable seating.

The staff was polite and helpful. The food was so tasty! Loved the flatbread with cilantro and basil raw onion and butter the combination was delicious.

We ordered dolmades they were not to our complete liking flavor was there but rice was too mushy inside, they cooked them too long or contemplated if they were from a can.

The salad we ordered was shirazi we were disappointed although it looks good we found the flavor not fresh. With dishes like this it should be cut as close to serving as possible not to sit in a big container so it gets funny tastes. The tomatos were too soft and could of been fresh as well cucumbers were not crunchy fresh. If this would of been cut fresh I know we would of loved it but it was not. 

The main meal was delicious. We ordered Persian room special came with filet mignon, chicken filet, koobideh kabob with rice and grilled vegetables. Superb!! Flavors were jumping out of all the different meat choices and cooked perfectly. Rice was great and the grilled charred tomatos were so yum!

Overall this place is great! When we come back we want to order the Tah Dig hope they have it.

This is a seafood lover's spot.  It's cozy, it's crammed, it's quaint, it's cool sh*t.  You're going to want to bring cash, a bottle of wine, and get here early to properly enjoy their array of seafood delights.  They don't take reservations and fill up quick so avoid popping in during prime time when you're starving.  

The calamari I had was great as well as my simple yet tasty salmon.  My wife's seafood casserole looked good (though I'm not a casserole fan) and she devoured it.  

If you're in the mood for seafood and near Queen Village, stop here to eat and grab a beer across the way at New Wave.

I love the updates that this business has made in the past year! Updated deck flooring, landscaping and lights throughout the rooftop. The location is perfect to look at the skyline of Indianapolis and still centrally located in the wonderful fountain square. The menu selection for drinks is extensive  and the appetizers are highly recommendedz

I love flowers, so, therefore, I love Longwood Gardens.  You can easily spend most of your day here viewing the 20 outside gardens and fountains and the 20 inside gardens.  I'll spare you from naming all the flowers that you can see.

Land that was originally owned by William Penn and then sold to an Amish Farmer and then finally sold to the Dupont family in 1906.  

Wear comfortable shoes.  This place should be visited at different times of the year, when the days are warm and sunny and you can see it all, inside and out and then again around the Christmas season, when it is breath taking, with decorations.

Two Restaurants, one a casual cafe and the Terrace restaurant were you can relax with a bit more upscale and flair.

UPDATED REVIEW: well, two days after I posted this they no longer delivered to Treme. Only a mile and a half radius, apparently, because their delivery driver is on bike. This wouldn't be a big deal, but they no longer outsource through grubhub or couchster.

sad day, y'all. i really needed some marg pizza in my life. 

ORIGINAL REVIEW:Oh this PIZZA! i discovered dolce vita when I moved to a part of the city delivery drivers appear to eschew (where's the love for Treme, yall?) Luckily, Dolce Vita not only delivers, but does it quickly for a reasonable fee. 

I pretty constantly get the Margherita pizza, and lord have mercy it is delicious. I'm very fussy about pizza, and this is some of the best available in New Orleans. The sauce is lovely, the basil is fresh, and the crust is tasty. What more could a girl ask for?

The Shanty is where I bought my first legal drink when I turned 21, and its where I've bought a number since. This bar is the closest thing to Cheers in Tucson, and its just an all-around great place to have a beer (HUGE selection for bottles) or hang out with some friends.

The bar has a great feel with the everything from the bar to the tables to the frames on their pictures being plated in copper. It feels kinda old-timey but in a good way. The people are friendly, a bit more mature than what youd find at Maloney's or the like, and there is a large outdoor patio area thats lush with greenery which kinda makes you feel like you're in your own private world outside of Tucson for a little while.

Why 4 stars not 5? The food--or lack thereof. They have no food service, but they do offer popcorn. I would not eat it though, if I were you. They have a popcorn machine at the front of the place and I would guess its fired up like once a week. The popcorn is unsalted, dry, and usually several days old and beyond stale. Really, you'd have to be tanked to eat the stuff. I wish they did a bit more with the whole popcorn thing or just went all out and offered some light fare to go along with your beer.

Overall though, I love this place, and feel I dont go as often as I should. Next time you and your buddies are looking for a place to grab a few drinks, take the Shanty into heavy consideration.

While I was visiting Philadelphia for a conference, a local friend highly suggested this place and brought us here. Now, I'm from North Carolina & we don't have many restaurants that serve authentic Chinese food. Having said that, we have ONE that I've been to and thought it was sooo good. How naive was I?! 

Don't expect any sense of order or cleanliness. It is a very small and probably family-owned restaurant. Oh! And don't be afraid to ask for recommendations since the food titles are not very descriptive. I did, and I loved what our server/owner recommended for me. 

Shiao Lan Kung is not only authentic, but it's DELICIOUS. It was sooooooo good that even when my stomach was full and hurting, I was a happy, full lady. I wish there was one here in NC.  /:

My favorite place for barre in Philly! This studio is clean, modern and makes you feel at home. There is truly no gym-timidation here. I've been coming regularly for months now and love that the girls who work at the front desk always greet you by name. 

Bonus- You can buy cute Alo clothes right from the studio and charge it to your account, they're always running a sale and have competitive prices on the clothes I would buy someplace else but the convenience of it being right at the gym.

This girl loves to cook, so I also took a tour through Philadelphia's Italian Market. You can tell you arrived when you see the storefront's selling (and smelling the) roasted meats, street side veggie stands, spice markets, knick knack stores and casual eateries.

Walking down the street, I thought to myself this is where I would shop. I am more of a gatherer than a "big box store" kinda girl, I like going to the butcher, the specialty market and the produce market to get my special items for my special recipes.

I bought spices, kitchen gadgets and stockings from the local dollar store. I stopped for coffee, a hoagie and was on my way. It was fun and a little something different off the touristy trail.

This was Our first Nashville dining experience while in town for a wedding. My family met here for brunch and got here just in time to order before they eliminate the option of brunch after 11am. I loved the atmosphere and the service was great. Very top notch food as well! Eggs, pancakes, sausage etc were better than expected. I highly recommend the pancakes!

This review is for the Grooming Salon portion of the store only:
I adopted my dog PB from PAWS last year. She was found as a stray and is a total love bug except for her utter hatred of other animals. Since my bathroom is on the 2nd floor of my home and being an older gal she has arthritis I had to find a solution to PBs grooming needs. 
I initially called PetSmart and explained PBs difficulty with other animals and provided her information. The staff was helpful in scheduling PB for the last appointment of the day on one of the store's slower days. Since then she has been coming once a month with this same schedule.She gets her nails ground and a bath and each time seems to have had a pleasant experience. 
I'm disappointed as PBs favorite staff member recently moved on from the store, however, the other staff have been just as helpful with her needs. I do provide reminders at each appointment about her behavior issues with other animals.

This humble establishment was more than acceptable for a sushi joint.  The room is small and decor is simple, but I loved the samurai warrior in the front window.  To start, the saki was perfect and we sat with friends taking saki shots.  The miso soup was delicious! However, they had regular spoons instead of the normal japanese soup spoons, which disappointed me.  The house salad dressing was a bit different.  Not your normal ginger dressing but an odd onion dressing that left little to be desired.  Next came a huge sushi platter that we all ordered.  It came out on a big plate in the shape of a fish (cute).  The fish tasted fresh and the sushi tasted really good (kudos to the chef).  All in all I must say that this place was enjoyable and acceptable.  I've been to better sushi places in other cities but im not sure if you can expect much more in Nashville.

I love historical buildings, and the old world charm associated with them, so when my friend said he actually found an affordable bed & breakfast that is more like a hotel (and supposedly haunted!), I was really stoked. We'd have the best of both worlds: a concierge available for questions and issues like you would have in a hotel, and the coziness of a B&B, both working side by side. They call these types of places boutique hotels for their small size, and their independent character.  We had no idea that they would operate in such an odd manner, though -- nothing like a traditional hotel.  For starters, there is a check-in time, and if you are unable to meet it, they send you this rather terse email with instructions as to where to find your room key, and you're not really told much about the parking.  

We had no choice but to arrive late, considering St. Petersburg is 5 hours away and we were coming on a Friday night, which means, we had to wait until the workday was over to head on the road.  Sure, I feel bad about checking in late, but I had never had it become an issue anywhere, because I normally stay in hotels or motels, and there is someone on-site 24-7.  It was also something out of my control, living all the way in Miami Beach.  My friend and I parked in the lot next door, and we suddenly realized you had to pay to park.  By the way, parking in that lot is not guaranteed, if it's full, find somewhere else to park along the street and lug your bags.  We had never experienced this, ever.  There wasn't even valet parking.  We could not pay for parking any later than 6 a.m. because that was the limit on the machine, and the lot had a tow-away sign, leaving my friend with no option but to set his alarm to 5:30 a.m. and go out to speak to staff and resolve the parking situation...except there was no staff yet at that time, so he was stuck paying by the hour once again.  Eventually, we did sort the parking issue when staff arrived later in the morning, but $10 a day for parking seems steep.  We were also told the minute we checked out, the car had to be removed.  We could not stay parked in the lot for a single minute or we'd get towed.  

The hotel itself is very cute and charming.  There is jazz music playing outside on the porch, so you can sit on the rocking chairs and relax.  The dining room is pretty, and classy, though small, but it is a small hotel after all, so it is meant to be cozy.  Breakfast is included and it is decent: muffins, cereals, tea, milk, orange juice, and other goodies. Don't expect omelettes, bacon, sausage, or a full carving meat station though.  The place is clean, and well-decorated.  We excitedly pushed into our room to check it out, and it was extremely cozy and homey, unlike the typical hotel.  You felt like you were staying in someone's guestroom.  The transom windows and doorknobs were from a time past, and they successfully integrated modern touches like the chandelier decal behind the bed and the flat screen TV.  

The bathroom was my favorite part.  I find it interesting how many people complain about the bathroom being "small", but I did not find it small at all.  Maybe that is because I am not a fan of large bathrooms in the first place, as that means a smaller bedroom, and I don't know about you, but I spend more time in the bedroom than the bathroom, so what is the point of a large bathroom and tiny bedroom? I had no issue with the bathroom, and in fact, was grinning ear to ear when I saw the clawfoot tub because I knew I would enjoy it later.  In fact, the next day I ran out to CVS and bought bubble bath and took a luxurious bath, to the sounds of Ella Fitzgerald on Pandora.  Very classy! All that was missing was the champagne! By the way, if you do want to use the tub, you will need to ask the concierge for a plug for it, but the plug doesn't quite seem to fit the tub.  Also, our cold, moist towels were never replaced and we had to reuse them, so there is definitely room for improvement.

The bed was comfortable, as were the pillows and sheets, but there was this loud "drip drip" sound.  I found the noise was coming from the window unit a/c (the cheap way to provide air conditioning, rather than central air).  I tried to make it colder, change the temperature, the speed, nothing.  I put in earplugs, and I could still hear it, to give you an idea of the loudness.  To say this was irritating is an understatement.  The next morning when I mentioned it to the concierge, he said it was the water dripping from the unit above our room.  When I asked what the solution was, he said none, unless I make him stand outside our window all night long holding a cup.  I understand they underwent an extensive renovation, but they forgot the most important detail a hotel should have: no noise while sleeping.  That is, after all the purpose of a hotel, is it not? It would behoove them to also get central air conditioning in there, to prevent the pesky dripping sounds.

Oops! I started drooling while I was writing this review because I was reliving my experience of eating at Han Dynasty. I heard so many good things about Han Dynasty, so I decided to come the instant I started craving me some good Chinese food. 

I ordered the following:
-Dan Dan Noodles: This is the most popular item, and I understand why. They give you a ton of noodles and they are perfectly seasoned. It's a lot of noodles, so i recommend getting a vegetable dish to supplement and provided added texture.

- Dumplings in chili oil: The dumplings were excellent. The chili oil had so much flavor! 

-Dry pepper chicken: I was dubious about this dish when my husband ordered it, but it was very delicious! There was a ton of flavor packed into this dish. The peppers had a nice kick to it but it wasn't overly spicy. 

The prices for each dish is very reasonable! I feel like I can order a good amount of food without worrying about my wallet! What i love about Han Dynasty is that it's chock full of flavor! It's definitely worth a try in my book!
This family-run donut shop is lovely, literally staffed by the actual family! They went out of their way to bring a special box over for the Bonaparte's Retreat booth at Record Store Day! #delicious

Standing outside for awhile, waiting for the girl who would be my gf, saw a LOT of people going into this place. Some walking out looked happy. 
Couple of pic a nic tables outside on a beautiful November day with some nice looking food being eaten. Couldn't wait. 
We went inside and got in a line about 12 ahead of us. It went fast. Some people just came in for the huge, fresh made, decadent donuts and pastries and coffee. 
It was noon, so we had brunch. Yes, donuts and sandwiches.  
There are stools facing the kitchen, booths along the wall, and it seems like it's a bigger place than it is. 
Placed our order with a very cute freckle faced girl who was patient with our goofy acting selves.
THE FOOD: First up for me...Irish Coffee donut with hot cocoa. Nice soft bite on the donut, tasty, light but sweet frosting. 
Cocoa was just ok.
Waffle fries, a little less done than I like (I like my fried potato foods done a little darker), but hot and good. 
The cheeseburger I had with bacon and a fried egg. It's quite delicious and, although it's little more than slider sized, satisfies the appetite I had. It had great flavor. It says B&B pickle on the menu, I thought it was cucumber slice on the burger, but in any case, added a little fresh crunch and lightness. Of course, the girl who would be my gf took some of my bacon...so there's THAT!
The girl who steals my bacon started with a muffuletta on a toasted, tasty bagel. The meats and cheese were exceptional. Not a lot, but packed with flavor. The olive mix was delicious, and overall, again, small portion, just enough,....but dynamite! She also had a had a kind of Double/Triple chocolate roll. Dark, rich, sweet, chocolate with bits of chocolate on top with some lighter chocolate mousse-like stuff squirted inside. I took 2-3 bites and had a sugar rush like a kid after Halloween. The girl who would be my gf was having a blast fingering the chocolate hole inside, so.... ?? 
She loved it. 
They had a nice late 80's, early 90's mix of music playing which made the girl who fingers the roll hole sing out loud. Maybe it was the sugar. 
Love this place. Not too expensive, 2 sandwiches, 2 donuts, fries, cocoa.. $27 bucks. 
Good atmosphere.

My husband and I have a membership, which makes it cost-effective to pop in for short bursts of time when the weather is bad (too cold, rainy or too hot) or we're in between events or we just want to see a special exhibit. 

We've now been several times over the past year and we've yet to explore everything outside or see all the art inside. 

We love the gardens and the beer garden, in particular. The beer garden is a great place to get a snack and feel like you are on a mini-getaway because of how it's placed on the property. My only complaint is it's a little pricey: $17 for a pretzel with spicy mustard, a lemonade, and a root beer. It's an extra charge for beer cheese, which they didn't have the other day because they said it the batch didn't taste right (thank you for not selling bad product!). They also sell beer and wine in a can, which many people seem to enjoy. 

Take the docent tour of the Lilly House to get more insight into the property. You'll want to see it at Christmas when it is decorated and in the summer when it is in "everyday mode."

Check the website for the exhibits, and if you think you will return again and again, the membership really does pay for itself while you can feel good about supporting the arts in Indy.

I loved the space, the concept, the communal tables, the outdoor heat lamps but the food left something to be desired. 

I did not like any of the three BBQ sauce options. I really actually hated one of them. And that's hard to do to a sauce lover like myself. The meats also were a 3/5 for BBQ standards. The ribs were no good and I heard the same about the brisket. The chicken, sausage and pulled pork were all fine. The pulled pork was really enhanced by the vinegar sauce.

I think that I might like it more as drunk food so perhaps I'll put this on the end-of-the-night list in the future. In fact, that's the reason why I didn't give it a 2.  Maybe they should consider staying open past 12 on Fridays and Saturdays.

I love a good deli. Strike that. Actually, I love a great or very good deli. I didn't find Noshville quite up to that level. Nothing was wrong. Everything was ok. Pretty average. For this, I found it to be overpriced and I think their hours are too limited to suit my needs. I have not had the breakfast, so I can't comment on that.

This is our go-to bagel place in St. Pete. The bagels are always fresh and delicious, and my bar is set pretty high as I grew up in NY with an abundance of great bagel spots. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone and everyone looking for a great bagel; why would you go to a chain place when you could support locals, and the product is infinitely better? The only improvement could be in selection- I would love to see some whole wheat everything bagels, or multigrain styles.

They also sell doughnuts, which are good, very good, and fresh... but not great. Then again, I have been to Doughnut Plant NYC, which was basically life-changing, so again, bar set high. But it's a nice bonus when I'm picking up bagels to bring home a treat. If you're into really soft, light, yeasty doughnuts, you will like these. Husband enjoyed the red velvet cake doughnut.

I can't quit this place!  Love the food and the atmosphere!  Don't be deceived by the line... both times I've been it goes pretty quick and it is worth waiting for!  Plus there is coffee and water while you wait.

Hellas Restaurant has been a longstanding institution in Tarpon Springs, as I remember it being there when I was growing up in Holiday, just one town over.  My wife, our daughter, our sister-in-law and I stopped in for lunch; and, Hellas did not disappoint.

Our daughter had a Cherry Coke, our in-law had a Raspberry Tea, while my wife had a Strawberry Sangria; and, I had a glass of Greek White Wine.  We started with the Saganaki, a staple appetizer; and, we all proclaimed, "Opa" when our server, Simon, lit the cheese on fire.  We all dug in and enjoyed the rich, gooey cheese with freshly baked bread.

We also ordered the Dalmades Appetizer, which was fantastic.  We just cannot seem to find the hot, meat-stuffed grape leaves outside of Hellas; and, no one, I am sure, could come close to the delicious lemony, buttery sauce.  

My wife had the Gyro Platter, which was so large we made two meals out of the leftovers; and, I had the Souvlaki (grilled pork cubes served on Pita, with tzatziki sauce.)   Our daughter tried the Pastitsio; and, she loved it.  And, our Sister-in-law had the Mousaka and enjoyed it very much.

The standout dessert was the Baklava Cheesecake which my wife and our Sister-in-law split.  Our daughter had the Eclair, which was fantastic.  And, I had my favorite Greek dessert, Kataiffi... It is sublime; and, I have only found it at Hellas.

Love this bar, the vibe and basic premise of a dream lived out loud.   Most especially I adore prosecco on tap.   Come for the quirkiness.   

à la minute...

Live bravely to create unknown
inside my mind; outside of time
But watch out world-
when she finally finds
Her own self/worthy.
Writing it down, recreating the sound 
that speaks loudest
in the silence.


Experience your best self.

Found this place on a walk in uptown, and returned later for a dinner, and (spoiler) it was superb.  I've traveled Spain and the rest of Europe, and my spawn has spent a significant time in Spain, and we both loved the Barcelona.

In fact, up to this point, the best tapas I have consumed were not actually in Spain, but Amsterdam at Joselito, where we were so enthused we ordered the entire menu.

With most small plates at Barcelona costing $5-$6, you can order a whole bunch of food to share and enjoy;  the also offer cooked to order paella, with the traditional rice base, and a variation featuring angel hair pasta.  They also have some entrees, and the whole menu is online.

We tried a variety of hot and cold tapas and loved them all.  My favorites were the ones featuring Jamon Serrano, and I liked his version of Patatas with aioli drizzle. 

If you live in New Orleans, you'll find Barcelona a nice change.  You can linger and sample a variety of dishes. Great date nite place.  It's right behind the Walgreens on Carrolton.

Tourists can find the restaurant with a half block walk off the St. Charles streetcar, so when you get tired of deep fried seafood at high prices in the Quarter, hop on the street car and transport yourself temporarily to an evening in Spain.

He has an "order slip" at the table similar to the ones in sushi bars - just read the descriptions on the menu and check off your choices on the paper slip.

Have you seen the movie Tampopo?

It's an old Japanese movie from 1986 and the main theme is about making good Ramen. Everything starts with the broth, and you can tell a broth is good is by watching whether if a customer finishes the whole bowl or not. In Japanese society, it's also very polite to slurp your noodles as this is another sign that the Ramen is good. 

However, in the west, it's very impolite to slurp your noodles as I caught myself doing after receiving my bowl of Ramen. 

Before getting to the good stuff, let's rewind a little bit. 

Found this gem of a place thru Yelp (surprise) as Wifey was searching for a place to eat. Since we were in downtown Reno and we already drove past Sparks, I quickly bookmarked the place to try the next day. That was this Sunday, and we went here on Monday during Memorial Day. Glad they were open since their secondary location was closed. I called them first just to make sure they were open.

Located a couple of miles North of John Ascuaga's Nugget, it was easy to find. It's tucked in a corner of an unassuming strip mall that hasn't been updated since the 70's. It's not much to look at from the outside, but you never judge a book by it's cover...you already know that. 

Once you set foot inside, everything just lightens up as you get whisked away in some part of Japan. The walls are decorated with bamboo panels and the tables and chairs are in perfect harmony with one another. From the decors to the paintings on the wall and even the fine chopsticks that are arranged in a bamboo holder on every table. They even have a section of traditional Japanese tables on a tatami mat where you have to remove your shoes to eat at. The place had a Zen-like vibe to it, and I was digging the tranquility.

Our server, Jackie, was superb as she was warm, friendly, efficient and fast. We had a party of four (Me, Wifey, Son and Mother-in-Law) as we got seated and checked out the menu. I noticed a note on the menu describing the place was established by Chef Yoshi from Japan, who has also worked in China and France perfecting his craft as he wanted to bring the first authentic Ramen experience to Reno. 

Boy has he succeeded. 

We ordered three bowls of Tonkatsu ($7.75) with extra Chasu/Pork ($2.50) and one bowl of vegetarian ($7.75). I also ordered a bowl of Chasu Salad for starters. The broth is described as white, light and creamy extracted from bone marrows that are slowly simmered. (Did your mouth just water?)

Salad was a mixed green with chopped pork, corn, bamboo shoots, soy beans balanced together by a sesame sauce. It was light, tasty and a nice starter course. 

Then came the Ramen. The extra Chasu comes in separate bowl and I quickly realized that all sides comes in their own separate bowls, which made for a nice visual reference. You can also control the portions of how much you want to add. 

Fast forward to me slurping like a slobbering pig.

The broth was light yet tasty. For me, it was an excellent broth since it wasn't too salty unlike some other Ramen places where they sodium content is thru the roof. It was a perfect balance of richness, creaminess and deliciousness, and you can always add some soy sauce or chili powder to your liking. I choose not to add any condiments as I was enjoying the flavor as it was meant to be. The pork was also superb as it was tender and meaty with all the porky goodness that a Bacon-lover would approve of. 

The only negative thing on the Ramen would have to be the noodles itself - some were clumpy and chunky. Ramen noodles are supposed to separate easily and not get stuck together. However, it was a minor detail that I was willing to overlook as I was thoroughly immersed from the broth with my head down slurping like a Nihonjin. 

Like the movie Tampopo, I finished the broth as well as my wife's bowl.

I can't tell you how many times I've come to Pearings. I absolutely love this place, especially to work throughout the day. If I time it right, I come for breakfast, because their breakfast crepes are to die for. I habitually get the Cheech and Chong, because I love that Smoking Goose chorizo and the Spicy sauce. I also love all their coffees and juices. They also have froyo and acai bowls. Really it's a great place to come and hang out or even stop in while your being a tourist downtown. It's right next to Circle Center, so park at the mall parking and walk over!

This place makes amazing breakfast croissant sandwiches!! Croissant was perfectly flaky, FRESH scrambled eggs (not the fake stuff that's poured out of a box!), thick crispy bacon and melty cheese. I opted for the jalapeno croissant, spicy but not too hot.
Donuts are absolutely the best in town too!
Staff are super friendly. I love this place!!

I've been wanting to try this place since it opened, so I'm glad I got a chance to today. The location is prime and the actual decor space is lovely. The wait was only about 30 minutes which is pretty good for breakfast/brunch on a Saturday in Nashville. My friend and I both ordered the Not Bloody Mary which is their own house made Bloody Mary with cucumber and basil and their own tomatoes. Super refreshing but doesn't pair well if you get something sweet like the cinnamon roll or homemade biscuit with honey like we did. Those two items were SO good. The cinnamon roll wasn't too sweet or sticky, it was perfect. The biscuit was cooked perfectly and fell apart like it should have. Not dry at all and the honey to top it was incredible. 

The reason I'm giving this place 4 stars is because of our main meals. My friend got the TN Ham and apple sandwich, which didn't have much flavor and I think it's because he said he wanted it without the honey mustard and got mayo. Bad choice. I think it would've been better with the honey mustard. I got the Dirty Benny, which is essentially eggs Benedict but they use prosciutto and some kind of gravy. Way too salty for me with both the prosciutto and gravy together. The English muffin was also soggy and not crisp at all. But the home fries were soooo good. I love them. Super crisp and flavorful. 

I'd like to come back to this place and try something else, though. Definitely worth it!

I'm so bad at taking pictures - not only did I forget to document my birthday, I also can't show you the beautiful presentation of the food! Anyway. I thoroughly enjoyed my meal there. We went during Devour and enjoyed a 3 course meal. It is an expensive restaurant, but if you are looking for great food in a lovely atmosphere, I'd highly recommend the Meridian. The corn soup is fantastic as is whatever salad I had - just the right amount of dressing. The Salmon was cooked perfectly and my partner enjoyed the short rib. We shared he carrot cake and donuts for dessert. As a bonus, our server was fantastic and very knowledgeable about the wine list!

Passing through Reno and stopped at this Holiday Inn overnight.  IT appears to be a new property.  Public areas and  rooms are spotless.  The hotel is off the Reno Strip, therefore, very quiet.  The rooms have all your basic amenities, including a fridge, microwave, and Keurig coffeemaker. If you've forgotten to pack a standard toiletry, such as a toothbrush, toothpaste, etc., they're happy to give you the item, complimentary.  There's a large breakfast area off the lobby, with a goodly selection of breakfast foods every morning. (I had only a Cinnabon with my coffee.) Water is a always available in the lobby.   Free newspaper in the AM.  You're beloved pets are welcome. If you're in need of just an overnight stay in Reno while on the road, I recommend this Holiday Inn.

Indy's. Best. Wings.

I really don't need to write anymore in this review. I just said it all.

Ok, you want more. I can tell. You twisted my arm.

So I love all the sauce flavors I've tried on the wings... BBQ, Asian Chili, Honey BBQ, Teriyaki. My favorite is the teriyaki. 

Why are the wings so, sooooo good here? Plump, juicy wings smothered in sauce. No skimp here. 

KSR reminds me of restaurants in my hometown. Good, down to earth people work here and eat here. It's a very popular Colts bar. Lots of 'regulars'. The menu has every fried thing imaginable. 

Speaking of fried things... the carrot fries are off the hizzy. Order them.

Need a to go order? They do that. There, you have no excuses to not eat some wings on your favorite sportzball day. 

Tip: Ask for two wet naps. You're going to need them.

This place was pretty busy when I went for a Saturday brunch. Free parking was available at the adjacent parking structure. I like sitting at the counter because you get to witness the bustling and super efficient kitchen. I also like watching my meal being made. For those with purses and bags, there are hooks at the counter so you can hang them! 

As for the food! The orange juice is freshly squeezed so it was a must for me. It can be quite refreshing, especially after a night of drinking in Reno. I opted for the huevos rancheros and my boyfriend the Hawaiian Breakfast plate. 

We both thought that the Hawaiian Breakfast plate was okay. It came with Portuguese sausages (which I usually love but I found these to be a bit bland and salty), fried spam, eggs, and white rice. There was a lot of white rice.
