However, I enjoyed everything about my huevos rancheros. It came in a huge skillet with fried tortillas, eggs, hash browns, pinto beans, cole slaw, and a side of warmed tortillas. The ranchero sauce dousing my dish was flavorful and addicting! Best huevos rancheros I've ever had! The big portion meant I had leftovers to take home but to be honest, they didn't last very long. I immediately microwaved it and ate it a few hours later.

I would definitely recommend stopping by for brunch here!

After my experience here, I have to seriously ask: What are these reviewers smoking?! And...how did this place receive a "People Love Us on Yelp" sticker?! (That must have been stolen from another business)

My friends and I are desserts and boba ADDICTS (seriously), and there's rarely any leftovers when we start indulging in both. But, this place managed to make us stop after one bite, which is unheard of!

Upon walking into this small, lackluster bakery, we had to wait a couple of minutes before someone came from the back to help us (no greeting whatsoever). Given that this was an Asian bakery, and most Asian places are infamous for their (lack of) customer service, we let that go.

Here's where things get a bit awkward. In their display cases, they have a TON of bread, pastries, and other desserts just sitting there for you to indulge in...with your eyes. We tried ordering what we saw, but the cashier kept telling us that it wasn't available. How is it not available when the display case is filled with them? Couldn't he at least take one out of the display case? You don't need to display 10 of the same thing for others to see what it is.

It would have been so much easier if he just told us what was available in the back. Needless to say, their "available" selections were quite LIMITED. There were maybe only 4-5 things we could choose from.

Egg Tart: This place has one of the WORST egg tarts I've ever eaten. One bite out of this FLAVORLESS, STALE pastry, I could barely even force myself to finish the first bite. Egg tarts are supposed to be flaky on the outside and bursting with flavors in the middle. I experienced none of that magical combo. Only thorough disappointment. ): 

Chocolate Mousse-Like Dessert: I don't know what they think chocolate tastes likes, but this certainly isn't how it's supposed to taste like. A spoonful of this gelatin-like dessert is enough to make you vomit in your own mouth. Definitely steer clear if you don't want a vomit party happening in your mouth.

Coconut Custard: This was probably the best out of the three we tried. Though it's far from spectacular, it didn't make us want to spit it out right away. The custard didn't have much flavor, and the bun itself was pretty bland, but at least it didn't have a funny taste to it.

And here comes the icing to the cake...
Boba: We originally came here for boba. Although we weren't expecting the quality we'd find from The Bay Area, we weren't expecting it to be this bad. You could definitely tell that the milk tea was made from a powder packet (one that you can easily buy from an Asian grocery store). The boba was appallingly terrible! It was really hard and tasted like plastic. I LOVE boba, but even I couldn't finish something as terrible as this.

They should rename Honey Bakery to...HORRIBLE BAKERY! I don't remember ever being this disappointed by boba and desserts. After snowboarding all day, we just wanted to enjoy some good desserts and sip on some boba, is that too much to ask for?! ):

Xiang Gourmet is an authentic Hunan restaurant with excellent food that is slightly on the pricier side. They're located right in Center City so the prices are in line with the location.  Portion sizes were large and you could tell the food was higher quality.  I went with a large group so I was able to try a variety of dishes. 

I wouldn't normally order tilapia because it's a bland fish that takes on whatever flavors it's cooked with. However, XG's Whole Tilapia was cooked perfectly and came in a beautiful and bright chili sauce that looked spicier than it actually was. The homemade sticky rice shao mei is an absolute must! So fresh and tasty. I've never had preserved egg before so I jumped at the opportunity to try it. It had a unique mild flavor unlike anything I've had. I really loved it and would order again. Another favorite of mine was the deep fried buns you dip in sweetened condensed milk. They reminded me of beignets; very light and fluffy dough.

My favorite dish was something I normally love to order: diced chicken with chili pepper and peanuts. The peanut flavor really came through in the dish because the peanuts were fried with the chicken.  I also LOVED the spiciness as a lot of other restaurants don't make the chicken itself spicy enough.

The restaurant is beautifully decorated with some really nice design elements. Service was attentive but a few things had to be asked for twice. Highly recommend if you're nearby and don't feel like making the trek to Chinatown!

My South Jersey relatives love to go to this local place for the $12.95 "Sunset Special" ("such a deal!") and for some reason I faintly recalled not liking their food from a long ago lunch and had no desire to ever go again.   After taking mom for cataract surgery recently she was craving the mussels over pasta so I couldn't say no and off we went - frankly, I was not expecting much.

I wasn't terribly hungry and figured I'd be reasonably safe with the Chicken Caesar salad (I know - yawn) and mom ordered her mussels.  All the specials come with soup and salad and I was expecting her soup to be a cup of flavored corn starch a la a typical cheap diner.  I had to eat my thoughts (literally and figuratively) when the vegetable soup came  -tomato based and chock full of fresh veggies- it was tasty so I ordered a cup myself! Add to this some of the best rolls I have ever had - crispy outside, dense and hot and flaky/chewy inside - soooo good with olive oil!

Our food arrived, each sloppy, ginormous plate looking like it could feed a family of four.    My salad had yummy grilled chicken, delicious creamy dressing with undertones of anchovy, tomatoes, cukes, canned black olives (yuck), marinated peppers and a hardboiled egg that had been cut with a steak knife.  I tried a mussel and they were good, the sauce was decent but not very memorable.  There was some wilted, I guess meant to be decorative, purple stuff on the plates that was just sort of scary.

The chef needs to work on details and presentation but the flavors were good, the food was cooked well and I could eat a million of those hot, crispy rolls.  I'd give a 3.5 if I could here, components of the meal were wonderful, others not so much but I would definitely go again.

I really enjoyed Blue Sushi Sake Grill. Our server was good in the beginning, but after we got our food she kind of disappeared. It took a long time for us to get our checks, that is the only reason I didn't give this restaurant 5 stars. The food was amazing, some of the best seafood I've had in Indianapolis. I went with a couple friends and we visited during their happy hour. My friend and I shared the dragon shrimp, mango crab rangoon, blue balls and crispy rice cakes. I loved the mango crab rangoon and the blue balls, they were my favorite. The Blue Balls are tempura fried tofu pockets stuffed with spicy crab mix, served with eel sauce and they are delicious. I ordered the Lion King Roll, it was amazing. I will definitely be back!

How does this place only have 4 reviews? They ROCK!!!!!! If you love country, u will love it. If you don't love country, don't worry they play some hip hop songs too. If you like to line dance, you will LOVE this place. The line dancing classes are very helpful and cheap. The instructor is very thorough and lets you practice many times. Friday nights are great cuz they aren't TOO packed so you can get a spot on the dance floor and they have $1 bud lites. Saturdays get so crazy packed that I can't stand it. So if you like space to move around, stick to Friday. Also at 11pm on weekends, there is a food truck guy outside who grills the BEST chicken sandwiches and hot dogs, etc. The only thing I don't like is i always smell like smoke when I leave. But it's such a good time I don't mind it. And they tend to play the same songs over and over but I just avoid the radio during the week and then i look forward to their music.

I'm between a 3 and a 4 stars for this review, but since Yelp doesn't do half stars I'm giving them a 4 because of the veggie and vegan friendly options.

I work across the street from Sizzle Pie, and end up eating here at least once a week. I really like that they have nine pies ready to go every day that you can just grab a slice from. They heat it up in the oven, and usually takes 5-10 minutes to get your food and be on your way. 3 of the pies are always meat, 3 are veggie, and 3 are always vegan. The vegan mozzarella is surprisingly good, I actually prefer it to the normal dairy cheese. They also have a lot of fun veggie protein options like pepperoni, sausage, and soy curls. Their pie combinations are always changing and are very unique. Definitely the most variety I have seen in a pizza place. 

Only things I don't 100% love is that sometimes the pies are a little greasy and I have to use a few paper towels to mop them off. Also sometimes the crust is a little over baked and it really tough to eat. It's a little hit and miss, sometimes it's totally fine, sometimes it's not.

Overall I'm a big fan because of the variety and options that suit all diets. They also have a bar, nice patio area with firepits and are open late. Worth a visit!

When you talk about hidden gems, Goleta Red Distilling Company immediately comes to mind. It's hidden inside a Goleta industrial business park off Castilian and Cortona Drives. Often the owner Michael will put out a sign at this intersection mentioning tastings that are happening. You'll find a door next to a window with an awning, enter there, then follow the guided signs to their tiny tasting room connected to a massive distillery. 

I originally found out about Goleta Red at a past Official Yelp Event thrown by my predecessor Stephanie W (https://www.yelp.com/biz/oye-sips-samples-and-sweaters-goleta-red-distilling-company-goleta?hrid=a6i2sWY0wVSZElPv8pX4og&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)). Since then, Michael has been active at local festivals, on social media (Instagram and Facebook) and even offers a deal on Axxess card for 2 x 1 spirits! The minute you enter the door, rosy-cheeked Michael befriends you with his wonderful energy and one man show. While this happens to be his business, it is more of his hobby and passion. He provides tastings of all his liquors: Sterling Silver Rum, Solid Gold Rum, Cacao-flavored Rum, Orange Java Overproof Rum, Fiesta Agave Spirit "Tequila," and Goodland Gin. I'm normally not a fan of gin, but the Goodland Gin possesses a beautiful botanical/herbal flavor profile that stands out in any drink. You can even find it at some bars around town! Once you have tasted a pour of each, then Michael offers one of his creative boozy concoctions made with his own spirits.

This past Halloween, my partner and I came in here while he was open for pre-Trick-Or-Treating. We wanted to make that custom a bit more tolerable with the hoards of kids. Michael mixed up a Ghostly Pumpkin and Corpse Reviver 2. Both were super unique and went down easily by being well-balanced. Michael is fun to chat with and is extremely knowledgeable about distilling given that he loves to educate himself and explore novel techniques--whether or not he succeeds or fails. If you haven't already checked this place out, be sure to!

I first had Spice Box on Georgia St. where their food truck was parked on First Friday and loved it. So glad to see that they now have a second location in Fountain Square. We went into the restaurant earlier this week and were impressed at how thought out the space was with cool posters on the ceiling, telephone poles protruding from the walls/ceiling, and just the overall vibe of the place. It is a long, narrow room but the seating was great for us to conduct a business meeting and enjoy lunch.

All things considered, I enjoyed the food at Capri as well as the customer service. I stayed at the adjacent Budget motel that for two nights while on business in Boise (that's another story) and tried Capri for breakfast during BSU's graduation weekend this year. This location is quite festive in the morning, given its proximity to the motel and other businesses on Fairview Avenue. 

Starting with the food, I would rate it 8/10. It was pretty good (slightly greasy), yet palatable. I was so hungry that I really didn't want to waste time eating fast food anywhere on Fairview Ave, so I chose the meat lover's omelette along with a side of hashbrowns and a cup of coffee. I think that I paid a total of $11 before the tip. Very filling, which served its purpose in not keeping me hungry for several hours.

The seating is not bad at all. There is a bar area (where I sat at), as well as side tables on the far left of the dinner wall as well as within the front and toward the right of the venue. The bar area had some very "interesting" conversation from travelers and locals alike, which actually lightened up the mood. The servers were attentive and very sweet, and made sensible recommendations on the food items listed within the menu. 

If the decision came to choose fast food versus this location, I'll take the latter for $500, Alex.

We happened to walk in (on a Sunday afternoon might I add) while he was making fresh batches of the Shoyu Tuna Poke and the Spicy Shoyu Tuna. As soon as I saw the spicy tuna, it was love at first sight. 

I got a brown rice bowl with spicy shoyu tuna and topped it with scallions, pickled ginger, house made eel sauce, sesame seeds and avocado. Holy moly. So delicious. The avocado was nice because it took a little of the heat off, not that I minded how spicy it was. (If you're not a spice lover, get the plain Shoyu Tuna.)

My boyfriend got the burrito with jasmine rice, nori, half shoyu/spicy tuna, kale, avocado and some other goodies. Also delicious. 

Fresh fish - this is huge for me. The fish had zero odor and was a beautiful colour. My only constructive suggestions would be to possibly chop the tuna a little smaller. In Hawaii it's traditionally small cubes - these were bigger chunks. Just a personal preference I guess. And I would love if there were a cold sushi rice option, kind of like a chirashi bowl. Feels a little odd putting my fresh chilled tuna on a base of warm brown rice.

Delicious. Will return. Maybe tomorrow. Highly recommend!

This place lives up to the hype, about the food and the wait. We went on a Wednesday night and waited almost 3 hours. Granted, my boyfriend and I weren't in a rush, the drinks were big, so we parked at the bar and happily hung out while we waited. 

(P.S. The first hour of the wait we went to the Maple Leaf right down the street, a great local dive for live music)  

I got the blackened red fish, my boyfriend got the stuffed catfish w/ crab and hollandaise sauce. The entrees were outstanding, and Jacques-Imos is worth the trek from the French Quarter. This is also a big local spot, which I love. I'm guessing any of the seafood dishes here are excellent. We'll be back.

Been here back in April and we loved the food and on our way home had to stop this time bringing our dog and able to have in the patio area. 
This time I got their honey fried chicken sandwich which is very flavorful and tender, I am not a slaw fan but the slaw on the sandwich was great not to much sauce which I loved. 
So I also ordered what the call the Margarita flight and sever it just like when you go the the brew houses so yummy  
I am an out of towner so you know a place is good when you make a point to come back

Friday night, we were finally able to give Hedge Row a full test. We had been there only for a mid-day snack and that was not enough fully to review. It must be pointed out that Chef Brad Gates is the real deal. He was Union Square's chef de cuisine for 10 years. Also, this restaurant is focused on wood roasting and locally sourcing (to the extent possible). So, for example, some of the veggies came from Silverthorn Farms (one of our favorites). Friday night, we were with four other people and everyone at the table was willing to share. Accordingly, we got lots of different tastes. It was the unanimous judgment of each of us that everything we tasted was excellent! We started with the shrimp hush puppies, wood roasted carrots and wood roasted beets. We had enjoyed the shrimp hush puppies before (on our mid-day snack) and, as before, they were truly delicious. The wood roasting gave the carrots and the beets a lovely flavor. On Chef's recommendation, we moved to the lamb meatballs and each of us enjoyed one. The lamb came from Viking Farms. The flavors in them were extraordinary and were we not saving room for other tastes, we could each have handled more. Next we went to the mains and four were ordered that were shared six ways: the half chicken (Gunthorp Farms), trout (Rushing Waters), salmon (Skuna Bay, Canada) and the pasta with veal bolognese. Jacque Pepin, in a cooking class, had told my spouse that roast chicken is the test for a good chef. It seems so simple, but to do it right is really difficult. Hedge Row DID IT RIGHT! The difficult trick is keeping the breast moist while cooking the thigh fully. Our half chicken was just outstanding. The breast was still moist and not dried out and the dark meat was perfectly cooked. For us, the test on trout is whether the skin is crispy and the trout not overdone. The sauce for the trout included a hint of ginger which gave it an unusual flavor which we all enjoyed. Again, Hedge Row passed with flying colors. The trick on salmon is getting it done enough without overcooking and, once again, the salmon was just done enough. It's accompaniment was Asian in flavor and complemented it very well. It should be noted that with each of these dishes, there is no place to hide mistakes. And there were none that had to be hidden. It is possible that the pasta bolognese is a bit more forgiving, but here the question is the flavor of the veal bolognese (outstanding), the amount of sauce (excellent - not over sauced, a common error) and proper cooking of the pasta. Again, a dish that we all enjoyed. Finally, four of us went off menu for our dessert, ordering either the chocolate or vanilla ice cream and a shot of espresso we could pour over (for our own affagatos). Two of our number ordered the sticky toffee pudding (a mainstay of the lamented R Bistro). The pud was wonderful and our affagatos were just the right, light end to the meal. We paired the first part of the meal with a lovely mid-coast California rose (which was dry and fruit forward). The last half or the meal, I chose a Barbera d'Alba which was a light enough red to go with everything. So our bottom line is whether a restaurant will make our regular rotation. This one definitely is going into the rotation.

I came here on a Sunday evening with one of my best friends. The restaurant was busy, but we got seated without any wait. The host and waiter were pretty friendly. Since neither of us were new to Han Dynasty, we went with our favorite dishes, Dan Dan noodles, Dry pepper style chicken, and string beans with minced pork. The dishes flew out of the kitchen in just about 10-12 minutes, and they all tasted great! I was glad they didn't go too crazy with the salt. This is definitely a great spot to bring visiting friends/family that love spicy/Szechwan food.
Another excellent experience at Oban!  Make a reservation...enjoy the ramen...enjoy the sushi.  It is all good and you can't go wrong.  Love the vibe.

In the past week that I've been living in Seminole Heights- I have visited Nani's twice- once for breakfast and once for lunch.

As with most restaurants in this area, you have to be looking for it to know it's there.  It's very easy to drive by it and think it's an auto shop of sorts.  But, it's definitely worth stopping at.

It's got a small indoor seating area, and a patio area as well (which I imagine will be nice once the weather is better).  Their cuban bread is to die for- I had it both as a grilled cheese for lunch, and as a "toast" on the side of my eggs for breakfast. 

I don't drink coffee, but my friend was raving about how good it was.  

The service is friendly- I really like that it's a small local owned sandwich shop.  

I do wish they had fountain sodas instead of cans, but that's just because I love a good fountain diet coke with lunch.  

With this being walking distance from my house, I look forward to many more trips!

McKay's is the best used book store I've ever been to.  I love it.  It's well organized, clean, and the staff is very helpful.  I've heard they give good prices for used books, but I've never taken any there.  They also have a huge section of used video games for every system you can think of.  Upstairs you'll find a huge music section with CDs and vinyl.  I'm a huge fan.

I love Starbucks coffee. I love the way it tastes and I love the way it smells. But, they are NOT all the same. Some are consistently good and some are flops. This one is one of the best. Take this morning, for instance. I had a nice conversation with the very personable lady at the counter regarding our kids. (She showed me a pic of one her sons - pulled it out of her apron pocket - love that!) Then I waited for my decaf frappucino. The girl making the drink put one down only it was slightly wrong (caramel instead of coffee) so she took it back and tried again. Evidently, she wasn't able to get it right so she had the guy working there do it. The guy made it (and it was perfection, btw - so many places don't know to blend the ice until smooth and you end up with ice chunks blocking your straw) and I thanked him and was just about on my way when the girl who had tried making it let me know she had comped my drink since it took a little long. Wait? What? I wasn't even upset about it nor did I complain and they took it upon themselves to comp my drink? In the words of DJ Lance Rock on Yo Gabba Gabba, "That was Awwwwesommmmme!" Seriously, most places don't do anything to correct wrongs unless you complain. This was sincerely most appreciated and it dawned on me that I have always gotten primo service at this particular Starbucks. Bravo!

Love the humane society. They are clean, professional, and one of those facilities where you actually wonder "Was my pet happier there than at home alone with us? Will she miss her friends?"

The staff and volunteers are fantastic. The animals get great spaces, enrichment and are well cared for. This is a fantastic shelter and the adoption process was very simple, affordable and easy.

They also have a great affordable pet shop on site where the proceeds all go back to support the shelter. I was thrilled to hear this and actually bought food and goodies there and found them to be cheaper than pet shops anyways!

It is slightly out of the way, being almost in St. Albert, but it is well worth the trek and whatever your need, they can help you out. I'd wholeheartedly support you going today to check out their amazing selection of furry friends!

This place was fantastic!!  I cannot say enough good things about it.  The restaurant is a staple of Indy, and whether you are here visiting or live here...you have to check it out.  I would recommend reservations.  However, if you do not make them and they are full...the bar area is lively and fun and you can either wait  there and have a drink or eat there.  The Jumbo Shrimp Cocktail is a must.  I love spicy and boy did it clear out the sinuses.  I thought another person in our party was going to fall over it was so hot for them.  Side note...you can buy the cocktail sauce in a bottle from the restaurant.  Every one in our party got a steak.  The ribeye was wonderful and melted in your mouth.  A buddy gave the filet the same review.  Each steak came with a side and a soup.  I had the lobster bisque...so chunky with large lobster pieces I didn't know what i was eating...again it was great.  I had the mashed potatoes as a side...pretty good as well.  The meal was so filling...would go back often if I could.  As an added side note...the Dalai Lama was also dining at St. Elmo's the night we were there...very cool.  He would not steer you wrong!!  Check it out!

OK rest of world, we are now officially complete here in Goleta. We have a quartet of breweries, a winery and now we have the triple crown jewel of a fully functional distillery . Yes, its true, we have Goleta Red distillery right in the heart of the deepest, darkest industrial estate Goleta has to offer. Heck, you can hardly find this place even when you know where it is let alone if you are a first time visitor. But hey, persevere, and you will be rewarded with the fine libations and excellent conversations that are always present at Goleta Red :-) The owner/distiller Michael Craig is a savant as well as being an all around great guy. I learned so much about distilling and spirits as a whole just hanging with him for a couple hours, it was so well worth the visit!! If you love your spirits and have have itch for an awesome Gin and Tonic, stop by Goleta Red, you'll definitely be glad you did :-)

Haven't been here in years and a friend threw her kid a birthday party here. The kids had a blast! It was so much fun and I as weird as it sounds it would probably be a good mommy hang out with your other mommy friends eat a pizza and drink wine while your kids run a muck place... so you can catch like 30 minutes to yourself LOL 

It's totally understaffed and unloved inside but what chuck e cheese isn't? The part I like the most is that they are high on security. You and your kid are uniquely marked and have to be together when exiting. It's fun it's cheap who doesn't like that? there are always coupons and an easy place for you to let your kids blow off some steam and run around. =)

I am really excited about this place! I had my intro meeting on Monday 4/1 with Wes where he spend about 45 minutes showing me around, explaining how their classes work, etc. He broke it down and made it less intimidating to go to a new gym. I signed up for the 1 month trial membership and have already used it 2x! These work outs are HARD. Especially for a newbie, but I love the pace, it is new everyday, they have two options lean and cross fit. This is nice because it always gives options. The people are not rude, always help you out, the others that go there are welcoming as you're in and out in ONE HOUR!! They have a beautifully designed yoga room, clean bathrooms, showers, and an area for your kiddos to hang out while you work out. I hope this becomes a new lifestyle for me. So far so good!

This is one of two Dottie's locations in Philadelphia and it's fabulous. This small donut shop offers a wide variety of all-vegan donuts that will knock your socks off. I brought a dozen to my non-vegan quasi-in-laws and all of them loved the donuts, including the picky children.

In particular, the chocolate pistachio ($3), the Boston Creme ($3) and the coffee cake (which is one of the few non-donut offerings they have) were wonderful.

These donuts also hold up well. They still tasted good even 48 hours later, whereas I've found most other donuts are stale within a few hours.

If you've had the vegan donuts at places like Donut Friend or Donatsu in LA, or Glam Doll in Minneapolis, expect similar quality at Dottie's. 

Also, Dottie's is way better than famous (but mediocre) places like Voodoo Donuts, Mighty-O and Dun-well in Portland, Seattle and NYC, respectively.

We've been to Texas de Brazil locations in Fort Lauderdale, Hallandale Beach, Miami-Doral and now Tampa, and they all have what it takes to keep people like us returning: beautiful place, great service and outstanding food. We've asked some staff at various locations about their restaurants, and each share the same response about quality food, presentation and service. They know if they do thier best together, it shows and customers will return. If not, they'll never come back.

Concentrating now on the Tampa location, it's a beautiful, spacious and well-laid out restaurant, spotless, nicely appointed and easy to maneuver. I suggest you try a signature Brazilian drink, the caipirinha. They are a bit sweet, very refreshing and some will think you are speaking Portuguese after the second drink. They pack a jujitsu punch! 

The salad bar is like none I've seen before. It is amazingly huge, full of 60+ delicious high-quality goodies from various types of lettuce and greens, plenty of salads, garnishes, olive selections, shrimp, exotic veggies, sushi, about 10 cheeses, various razor-thin prosciutto and salamis, breads and on and on. Lobster Bisque and wonderful side dishes are right there to load at will.  The attendants keep the salad bar meticulously clean, fully stocked and always looking like a postcard. (You have a "salad bar only" option, if you'd prefer to graze further and pass on the meat entree selections).

Now on the the headliners: grilled meats that are served until you decide to stop eating, or simply explode. Each selection is skewered onto long swords, cooked to perfection, then transported throughout the restaurant by gauchos looking for your nod. They'll provide whatever you'd like, as much as you'd like, as often as you'd like. Every cut of beef, filet mignon, sirloin, prime rib, pork roast, chicken, lamb chops, sausages, beef ribs...it keeps coming until you surrender, and it's worth every tender bite. The grill team are clearly Masters.

If there is any room at all in your body, any of the desserts will leave you intensely satisfied and shaking your head wondering how you ate all that you did.

In spite of what you may think, this really isn't a place for gluttons or those loading their plates and juggling back to the table. This is a class operation serving top quality food and drinks with impeccable service, and well worth the price. This is a very special family of restaurants that I'll bet you'll love.

So back again to Louis!!   I love this place.  Except this time a few things were way off!!    They cooked other people's steaks who wanted medium rare.  To way over done.   Like medium well.  Barely any color in the middle!!

The other ordered Filet.  Which was suppose to be medium rare.   It was still kicking!!   Finally I ordered the rabbit so did my dad!!   It was over done dry and so much salt that I couldn't eat it!!   I hope you guys get your stuff back together!!

Is it fair to rate a place strictly on your first visit and one slice of pizza? Maybe not, but if you go to Paulie's for no other reason, go for the General Tso pizza. 

My friend was raving about it so of course we had to give it a shot. At the time of our arrival, there wasn't any General Tso slices available to pop in the oven and serve. Despite the fact that our group didn't want to buy an entire pie, they happily made one up and let us buy individual slices. 

So the General Tso slice is unique and combines two of my loves: pizza and Chinese food. Just an aside, I could only imagine the amazingness of this combo as cold leftovers. Back to the slice, it was large, and covered with General Tso's chicken, extra sauce, broccoli and pepper flakes. It was sweet, spicy, carby and cheesy. Now that's a synergy!

I loved every unique bite of my experience. I could go back to Paulie's to sample their other menu options but they certainly have a show stopper with the General Tso.

It's the slightly upscale version of Winner's. What can I say? If I walk in to a store like this and see something I love staring me in the face, I'll go for it, but I'm not one to spend hours digging through racks of crap on the off chance a gem will appear. 

My mum did snag some new running shoes and a nice cardigan, and I got a gift for my forthcoming niece and a few baby things for myself. The shoe department is also the best I've seen from a store of this type. 

Will I make a special trip to shop here? No, probably not, but if I'm in the area, there's no reason I wouldn't stop in.

My kids and I love this place! We've been coming for a couple years now. They have to long walls of choices. Your typical stuff, plates, bowls, mugs, figurines, cups, etc. Of all shapes and sizes. And costs of course range greatly, from $6-$50, with most things in the $10-$20 range. Their painting fee is $8 a person, but on Mondays it's $1, and they always have coupons and deals on their website. There's never a reason for you to pay full price for everything. The room is really big and airy and not closed in, which I greatly appreciate. Painted Zebra is so tiny I feel like I'm suffocating. Not so here. The manager Travis is the nicest guy. Really helpful with everything and very pleasant affect. 

The only downside: the chocolate store right next door that my kids always sucker me into stopping by ;) 

My kids and I only do this kind of thing twice a year, because it is kinda pricey, but we'd never go anywhere else when we do.

If you love margaritas you might as well come here, duuuuuuuuuh! 
Downfall: you will get boozy because you logically reason to yourself: "let's just get the pitcher, it's so much more economical!"
And I adore their specialty margaritas as I'm always looking for inventiveness in the drink.

It can get loud/busy/crowded in there which can be good energy for a fun night out, but not so much a stare-into-each-others-eyes romantic of whispering sweet nothings. Although the lighting is romantic (read: dark).

I stopped in here today for the first time after having it on my "To Try" for years! After a long morning walk on the Monon, an iced coffee sounded fabulous to start off my morning. I popped in here with my stroller (the ramp is super helpful for this!). Their coffee menu is impressive as is their machinery. I almost went with the Dirty Hippie (chai tea + espresso) but went with an Iced Latte on a lark. It was SO delicious and refreshing. I usually don't finish all of my coffee drinks, but I slurped up all of this yummy treat. The fun twisty straw was a bonus! 

I also ordered a turkey panini with a side of cottage cheese for some nosh and it was very good. Sliced turkey deli meat, avocado, herby mayo, tomato on crispy wheat bread made this sandwich one to remember!

I loved sitting out on their patio, cooling off, enjoying my meal and catching the sights of mid-morning Broad Ripple. It made for a very pleasant morning. I am not sure WHY it took me so long to visit, but I am so glad I did; and I'll definitely be back!

Another awesome find in Chester County! The owner is so nice and very knowledgeable about the wines they have. My mom and I came here with a friend and we each did a wine flight. You can mix types of wine and you get 4 total, which equals about a glass and a half of wine. My favorite that I tried was the pinot grigio. We ended up getting a bottle of it and a bottle of the Reserve Cab Sav (which is not available in flights). I loved the Cab Sav too! 

The owner gave us some free samples of their wine slushie and OMG were they amazing! They were the perfect treat and not too sweet. I definitely want to come back and get them again.

Overall, this is a super fun and cozy winery! They do different events on the weekends, so be sure to check out their website!

Came here for Tacos. We're hoping to eat in but they were takeout only. Took like 30 minutes to get our food  BUT food was very good. Had pastor & chicken tacos, a chicken quesadilla and the chille renos tamale. LOVED the food. But wouldn't come here again just because the wait was so long..

Love Arni's! It's a great, reasonably priced experience for all. Their lunch specials are great deals! We went for lunch on my birthday to sit outside on their patio and have pizza. Breadsticks are yummy! Pizza is yummy! And oh my, the toffee dessert is to die for and I don't even like toffee! Can't go wrong to visit here summer or winter. The dining room and bar seating is great too.

I have been coming to Molly's for lunch when I started working at ARAMARK in April. I love that they are the same owners as Iovine Produce, which I go to every week to get my groceries. I haven't tried much on the menu, because I always go with the market summer salad. Seriously, this salad is heaven. FRESH veggies, fruit. feta cheese and a ridiculous strawberry chipotle dressing that I could probably drink its so delish. Also, the portions are huge so your almost guaranteed leftovers for lunch the next day.

I went in 2 weeks ago for my usual salad, and somehow was charged $5 more than should have been when I looked at my cc transcript. When I reached out to let them know, let's just say that the owners took care of the issue, and more. I was sent a wonderful apology email thanking me for my patronage. I am sure these people are doing pretty well and didn't think they would care about one customer, but it really is the exact opposite. I was made to feel like I was the most important customer that they have and I really will never forget that.

The food is excellent, the service is good, and above all, the customer service is nothing short of perfect.

I had an excellent dining experience here on 08-25-2011.   Maximo's always had a good reputation, but I had not eaten here in 20 years, so I wasn't quite sure what to expect.

We arrived at 7:00 pm on a Thursday, and the place was pretty empty.  We had reservations but were told we could sit wherever we wanted.  We opted for the very first booth (2-top) situated on the left wall as you walk in.  We were seated immediately and greated by our server (Erin).  Our drinks arrived in a jiffy, along with some delicious hot bread.

The restaurant is narrow but you don't get the feeling like you're sitting right on top of the table next to you.  The decor is upscale and the stained wooden ceilings are a nice touch.  There are pictures everywhere but they don't take away from the dining experience.

For an appetizer, we had the Sicilian shrimp which was grilled and wrapped in prosciutto.  They give you four nice sized prawns, so it's worth the money.  My entree selection was the Osso Buco, which is a veal shank cooked on the bone.  It is the house specialty and is absolutely delicious.  You don't need a knife because the veal is so tender than you can eat it with a fork.  As is customary, they give you a tiny appetizer fork so that you can eat the marrow from inside the bone.  I know this may sound a little weird to some, but don't knock it till you try it.  Although not as tasty as the veal itself, the marrow was very rich and had a buttery texture.

We also had the fire roaseted seafood entree, which consisted of gulf shrimp, large scallops and fish (grouper).  I love scallops and shrimp, but the grouper stole the show on this plate.  The habernero infused olive oil really kicks it up a notch, but not to the point where you don't taste the seafood and appreciate it for what it is.

For dessert, we had the tiramisu beacuse it's made in house and it doesn't get any fresher than that.  Although not my favorite dessert, I prefer in house desserts to those that are store bought or shipped to the restaurant.

Lastly, I'd like to commend my server Erin.  She was extremly attentive (without being intrusive) and very helpful with the menu choices.  Her personality make her perfectly suited for her job and she is a definite asset to Maximo's.  It's readily apparent when a person truly enjoys their job and Erin fits the bill.  

Thanks for making our dining experience here a memorable one.

We went out last night, and my daughter ordered something off of their seasonal menu from last season that she loves - caramella, or something like that. Looks like a specialty ravioli.  Luckily, they had a few leftover even though its off the menu now, and my daughter was soooo excited.  At the end of the meal, the manager came out with another serving, boxed up to take home, because he heard how happy daughter was.  That was a class act.

I'm going to be upfront about my dislike of the parking situation in Down Town Tampa.  So when I got to the location, finding parking was hard! I ended up across the street at the parking structure for the Glazer Children's Museum, which was charging a singular priced parking due to Phantom Of the Opera going on at the Straz. 

The walk to Anise wasn't bad, the lights were in my favor, and the scenery was nice with all the Christmas lights glowing in the early evening.  What I found distasteful, was the host- a young man in his early 20's, with light brown hair- wasn't paying attention to the door, he was head down over his phone, likely texting or checking Facebook. I had to speak up to get his attention. Only then did he let me know where my party was.  

My party was that, a company Christmas party, about 25 people in attendance, drinks and appetizers provided by the venue. I have to admit, though I was a bit concerned over the offerings, I was actually quite happy with the flavours! We had curried chicken wings, curried deviled wings with lobster and vegitarian paninin.  All were delicious! I -LOVED- the deviled eggs, there was just something about them, they were TOTALLY off the chart. 

The decor is amazing! I loved the bookcases in the bar area, the hydropinic greens in the lobby and the light fixtures that hung down from the high ceilings. This place has character! I can't wait to visit again, and am hoping that Anna will be my guide next time because I have a feeling I'd be out of my league!

Hats off to the Tender with the amazing dreads, Jarod(?) Sorry if I got the name wrong. He was really warm and friendly, totally LOVED his attitude!

I love the handmade corn tortillas, but still think that the meats could be better. Esp. #1, which was just chopped steak - fine enough but not well seasoned and nothing else in it! Also had the number 8, grilled chicken with some veg -- filling, but still not amazing. Good enough - 3 stars.

So I just don't get it. Most of the people I talk to love the UC. Unfortunately, I am not one of them. 

I think I have a pretty good sense of taste in general. I'm not sure if this place is more authentic of a German beer than I like? Or I just do not know, but the Zwickel I've heard people rave about just doesn't do it for me. I've had about five of their beers and I've enjoyed them, but I would not ask for another. 

What they have going for them - the patio. The patio is amazing! 5 stars. I respect the indoor seating, like the access to foosball, and it's comfy cozy on the inside, quiet enough to have a great conversation, yadda yadda....but did I mention the patio. Five stars to the patio. 

A little disappointed about their business 101. My friend and I wanted to drink on the porch and I thought it was a perfect opportunity to fill my growler and give UC another chance. I will digress here...

Six Row was closed for the day (Six Row is my favorite...shout out to 6 Row who gets worse reviews than UC but has a friendlier more knowledgeable bartender in Isaac and much better (and worse) beer offerings. Agreed that the flavors at 6Row are polarizing - they strike out or hit home runs. But hey, St. Louis loved Marc McGwire for doing that, and St. Louis should show some more love to 6Row and the best bartender the city has. 

...and return to my original thought here. They did not have a cap for my growler and told me to go to Schlafly. (I was on my bike so filling it up and not capping it wasn't really an option). Seems like bad business to me, no? The server was nice, but there I was with a twenty dollar bill and they whiffed on not having something so simple as a cap and then whiffed again with their less than creative solutions. Oh, I just remembered they told me to go to Schlafly, get a cap from them, and come back - - a solution they had implemented before. 

A "solution" I should say. It's disappointing that this problem has come up for them in the past and they have not resolved it. 

Tisk Tisk. 

If only I could get beer from 6Row, 4Hands, Schalfly, ITAP, Budweiser, or Culinaria and bring it to their Patio. ...then this place would be 5 stars (and there would be more consistency with the lousy business strategy idea I flirted with above).

Great pizzas, garlic knots and soup. We eat lunch here regularly (or have it delivered). Always hot and great. I love plain cheese, veggie or meatball and onion pizza. My coworkers love the bacon ranch and say it is one of the greatest pizzas ever. 
Enjoy.

Can a sister get some A/C? I don't know if that's typical that it's so hot in there but it seems like I'm always sweating like crazy when I sit down in this place which makes eating much harder to me. This place is divey and right near my house so I want to love it. The food I've tried has been middle of the road bar food but it's obviously a local favorite so maybe I need to find the right stuff on the menu. A dude outside yelled at us when we pulled in the first time about parking which was apparently in a bad spot we didn't notice any signs about. No big deal, we'll move, but whoever was hammered sitting outside that yelled at us really started the first visit off on the wrong foot and ticked us off. The next visits we found street parking but it is obviously challenging sometimes in the area to find a spot when it's busier. TVs are a plus for sports so I'm sure there will be many more visits and hopefully the experience will get better. The cocktails at least have been good and the staff seem great. I'm sitting middle of the road crossing fingers it turns from 3 to 5 stars with more visits.

OMGeeeeeee!!!! I'm so full, I need a nap. Stopped at this GEM of a deli traveling from San Antonio to Chicago (thanks to reading YELP reviews) and I'm so happy we did!  Hubs had the Delta Bayo (garlic peppered roasted pork & pepper jack with tomato, grilled onions and smoky spicy Delta sauce).  I had an original roast beef (hot) smothered in cheddar and Italian vinegar oil. Kids had: 7th street Sicilian and a turkey and cheese... The deli is right in a cute neighborhood with a hometown feel (very close to the 44/55 highway though so it's easy to get to).  Lunchtime was super busy with a line out the door but SO worth it!  The staff was extremely friendly and very helpful with the menu items as well. Love this place!! :)
Cute little coffee shop in ybor off of 7th Avenue. Love the decor and different items they have for sale.  Definitely check it out whenever you are around the area!!

Another great addition to the East Passyunk square area , my partner actually brought me here for a late breakfast I have to say it was a great experience ! Love the flannel decor and vintage styles to the establishment  very outdoorsy vibe . THE FOOD /DRINKS I ordered the FLANNELBENNY
: country time farm's pork roll, pimento cheese, 2 poached eggs & hollandaise on cornbread, delicious! I've never had poached eggs on cornbread ITS A MUST, and to drink I had the Dulce de leche latte again amazing. I can't wait to revisit I hear they are well known for their fried chicken!!

Forget what you thought about pizza. Unlimited toppings, an awesome ambiance, and a community-centered environment is a great package. During a work trip to Nashville, I went to this place twice! 

Both times, I arrived right before the evening rush. Even if you get caught in a long line, it is SO worth it!

Nestled on a quiet block, this restaurant was quiet when we entered, then bustling with patrons (on a Tuesday night)! Here, you can enjoy movies and music (See Above the Rim and hear Outkast) while enjoying delicious pizza, whether vegan or carnivore. 

I had a husky pizza with 'California Love' and 'Smokin Herb'. My colleagues and I met one of the awesome owners, and even got a photo opp! 

They also feature local beers and even have a Slim + Husky's house lager.

They will be opening a shop with their famous cinnamon rolls called The Rollout. I can't wait to visit again.

Talk about a neighborhood watering hole worth visiting! Was in town and wanted a little late night eats and saw this spot was right around the corner. The crowd outside looked inviting, so went on in. It was a different and cozy environment, but I loved the fact, that they cooked your food right there! Had a wonderful burger and a good beer. There was a guy playing live music that was cool. A great dive bar, will definitely visit again when I'm back in town!

Empire State is my lunch treat spot. When I want a tasty adult sized sandwich, I come here. The food is always fresh and delicious, and orders come out incredibly fast. The meats are freah and flavorful and I never leave hungry. I recently tried the Bronx Bomber and was blown away. It was huge and I could taste each distinct meat flavor, it was incredible!! I also love the pickle that comes with the sandwiches. I've tried the fresh baked cookies and a few apps, you literally cannot go wrong here. On eof my many goals in life is to eat my way across this vast menu. They also offer a punch card, and a reward for checking in on Yelp!!

Not so much.
I just need to trust my instinct when I walk into places and just don't feel it.  Until you get inside, you have no idea what their theme is...it's apparently a wine bar, but...I was smacked in the face by the smell of BBQ.
They wanted $4 for a Miller Lite, $7 for a Guinness.  I knew that if they were boasting THE BEST BLOODY IN NEW HOPE that they probably wanted your first born and $14.  I saw one of these so-called best bloodys and it was not impressive.
My biggest gripe?  The service!  We go to sit down and the bartender abruptly says "someone's sitting there." and walks away kind of calling over her shoulder 'you can sit at one of those tables' - nah thanks...just stopped in for a drink...were about to leave but people moved over to accommodate us.
We sat for another 5 minutes or so...finally we order two Miller Lites.  They seriously were playing Madonna's Like a Prayer album front to back...that was so strange for me...I love me some Cherish, but with the corny "wine" decor and that album, I thought I was on a the set of a 1989 sitcom. 
We ask for the check and the bartender can barely hide her disdain with a thin lipped smile and a "only those two Miller Lites?" Yes honey, get me the fug outta here!


Only one women's room and it was fairly empty for a holiday weekend.  The dining room was maybe at 1/4 capacity yet I heard the server make a couple wait to be seating "so the kitchen can catch up" - I'm glad I won't be returning to see how they can catch up with a full house!

Oh God. 

Where to even begin. Chinese buffet? More like Russian roulette. 

At least two times during our lunch visit, each person at the table spit something out because it tasted spoiled or extremely questionable. 

I'm not usually a buffet person (unless it's Everest, which is in a different class), but it was New Year's Day, I was incredibly hungover, and I figured I couldn't hate myself any more than I already did, so bring on seven plates of fried rice.

Plain and simple: this place is NOT good. It's just not. At buffets like this, you always have the questionable stuff. The way-too-perfect looking desserts that don't taste like anything and for some reason are ALL topped with rainbow sprinkles. The mystery chicken floating in liquid MSG. Whatever. I can take a pass on those if the staples are decent. But man, this place was gross.

Using the same tongs for every different sushi roll? Gross. The fishy smell of the sushi? Gross. The weird, black, hair-like things on some of the fish? WTF. It was like someone touched it with a dirty glove or didn't wash it properly. It was nasty. 

My mom tried the oysters and spit them out. Her friend tried the kimchee and spit it out because it was completely soft and tasted rotten. 

The crab rangoon weren't even worth taking. Super tiny and they tasted stale and reheated. Even the fried rice sucked. How do you mess up fried rice?

On top of the crummy quality of the food, they were understaffed. I felt terrible for our waitress carrying literally 20 stacked plates back at a time because there were no other servers. They were always out of something we needed - like silverware. 

And what grinds my gears most about these buffets is the automatic upcharge when they decide to put out crab legs. No way would I touch seafood from here, so why do I have to pay $15.99 for lunch when I don't even want crab legs? Though admittedly, my mom ate enough of them for all of us.

2 stars because miraculously I'm not throwing up today. Would not return.

The PERFECT idea of a vegan restaurant that your entire group can enjoy. The food was absolutely delicious and their menu is genius. One side of the menu is totally vegan and the other side features meat, but the meals are identical - just with substitutes. And they are priced the same, love it! I think out of our group of 7 everyone loved what they ordered. The portions are huge for the price and our service was great. The restaurant does get a little loud, but its also a bar and has fun arcade games. I would definitely recommend it!

This ice cream shop is very small and very hidden, but the flavors are out of this world!!!!!! (:

So I know Lick has their ice cream in a lot of local shops, but by having a small venue for customers to come in is really nice. 
The shop owner let us try their homemade flavors, which were so creamy and delicious. She was very nice, and very quick with the service.
This was my first visit and I got the affogato. You can have any of their ice cream that they're serving mixed with freshly brewed coffee - safe to say, as a coffee and ice cream lover, the mix was INCREDIBLE! 

I will return soon!!

I've been to the different Park Ave coffee's and I do like this one. This one reminds me when I'm running, "you can make it, just one more mile, Park Ave is on the next street." Yeah. Yeah.  Call me Ms. Coffee Addict but I run for those lattes. Hmmm. I wonder if they have a shirt for that yet? The turtle lattes and raspberry mocha (keep in mind I loathe raspberry as well) these lattes are a coffee lovers dream. They are not overly frothy and cooled down like some other places I've been. The whole coffee is hot, almost needs to cool down a minute and remind me to savor every moment of that deliciousness. 


On to the next secret. Gooey Butter Cake. 75 flavors worth! Eeek! I think I can't even make 75 meals. So my secret is when people want a taste of home, I come here and mail them gooey butter cake. Sure I know how to make it, I am local after all, but mine does not taste like Park Ave. have fun enjoying your millions of combinations. I hope your not like my husband who can't decide quickly at all.

11 11 is on a list of great restaurants that hails from the same restaurant group, the Hamilton family. 

I've never had a bad meal here. 

The elegant little patio, even heated all year round, makes you feel like you've stumbled upon somewhere secret. 

However once you enter the large space you realize it's a sizable operation. 

The artichoke bottoms are my favorite appetizer. I love how the Italian sausage spices pair with the meatiness of the artichoke heart. 

The poached pear and fig flatbread is delightful, and the sweetness stands up well on the flatbread vessel, but not over sweet! 

Despite the eclectic entree offerings, I gravitate back to the salmon, some of the best prepared fish in the city. 

Highly recommend this to anyone down toward the city. It's often on my short list of city dining spots to recommend.

I was a fan of South Street Philly Bagels before I ever stepped in the door. They very shrewdly sell their bagels to Whole Foods stores in the region. Check out the bagels at Whole Foods Fairmount. They are from South Street.

I am a huge fan of their pumpernickel swirl bagel. Just the right chewiness and flavor. I love that these bagels are made the correct way unlike so many Philly area bagels.

Upon finally going there I ordered two sun dried tomato bagels to cut, freeze and toast later. They did not disappoint. A just right sun dried tomato taste and crunch. They need to send these out to Whole Foods too!

I have nothing but praise for this place. Back when this space was Big Moe's Coffee Shop, I'd come here to do homework and soak in a bit of ambiance. Now that it's a taproom, I love it even more! Wonderful and varied selection of beers, and the staff are super friendly and awesome about giving you a taster before you commit. There are the usual options, such as beer flight, pint, growler, etc. - but they also allow you to purchase small 5 oz glasses of beer, which is nice if you want just a smidge more beer or one extra for your flight, but don't want to drink a full beer. Mulled wine was another one of their offerings the day we visited, and it was warm, smooth, and spiced just enough. 

For the beer: the Vernal Minthe Stout was yum! I didn't think I'd like it, but it turned out to be my favorite - it tasted like a thin mint! The blackberry barleywine was also nice, with just enough fruitiness and not overly sweet. The lychee IPA was also quite nice. 

They don't actually serve food other than popcorn and pretzels, but food trucks apparently make an appearance there (a sandwich truck was there the night we stopped by).  For a taproom, it is pretty family friendly - the grounds lend themselves well for little ones to move about, and they are cool about bringing in outside food. There is plenty of seating both indoors and out, so you're bound to find an area that's comfortable for you and your kiddos. 

The indoor area is lovely, but if weather permits, I highly recommend enjoying your drink outdoors. They have a beautiful little courtyard, complete with some interesting forged iron and corn hole (which we played while we were there).

It's such a huge museum! So many rooms and floors! Definitely worth spending half a day! Would definitely love to come back and look/read everything at ease without a time limit. It is well organized and the security are the friendliest.

I came here for restaurant week for the first time, and I loved it! They had some really great restaurant week options, and you could also add on certain dishes and add a half glass wine pairing with the prixe fixed meal. 

I ordered the burrata, the beer can chicken and the Boston cream cake for dessert. The beer can chicken was amazing, especially since I had never heard of it before. The chicken was so moist. We also added the oysters and the half wine pairing to our meal. I think they still have great quality of food even during restaurant week, but I would want to try the menu not during restaurant week too!

I've been meaning to try this spot for years. I've heard it is more authentic than other carribean spots in Nashville. I ordered brown stew chicken, cabbage and rice and peas. Portions are worth the price, it was enough for lunch and dinner.  The brown stew chicken was good, but I won't say it was my favorite version I've tried. The cabbage was the best part! I'm not a cabbage lover but theirs was so flavorful and cooked perfectly. The guy who helped me, maybe the owner, was very nice and engaging. I had to knock off one star for the rice and peas being mushy, which was a shame because it's one of my favorite sides.

You can find Il Bel Lago at 11631 Olive Blvd, St Louis, MO 63141 in a suburb called Creve Coeur almost due West of St Louis as the crow flies. The restaurant is in a protruding part of a shopping center almost hidden by lit trees (not sure if it's due to the holidays or if they're always lit). Entrance is to the right as you go around the corner and parking is in the lot out front. The interior is upscale with an elegance usually reserved for fine dining, but the atmosphere had a younger, frenetic feel that I found quite refreshing. Apparently the restaurant's original name was Bellagio but there was some dispute with the owner's of the hotel that ended in a name change - lucky for me the food retained it's very good quality.

This is perhaps the best meal I've had throughout several visits to St Louis on business the last few years. Sue T (a friend and coworker) and  her husband Carl graciously took me to Il Bel Lago and introduced me to the chef, Frank Giovanni. Afterwards we were sent a nice "combo" style appetizer that featured a delicious lobster ravioli and a  veal tortellini with shitake mushrooms and peas. The flavors were both unusual and offered great contrast to each other.

As I always do, I tried some of the local craft brews rather than going with wine - in this case the Schlafly's Pale Ale won the lottery as my initial try - honestly I didn't care for it much, preferring the hoppy bitterness of an IPA - this was a bit too lagerish to me with a bit of an oily mouth-feel that didn't work for me. I also ordered a Caesar salad that had an anchovy nicely sandwiched in parmesan crustini. For my second brew I switched to a standby Ranger IPA.

For dinner I ordered the Spaghetti Gamberi, Cozze & Vongole - homemade spaghetti (almost an angel hair) with gulf shrimp, fresh mussels and clams in a white wine light san marzano sauce. This was quite delicious with a good amount of fresh garlic that provided little bursts of flavors as you eat the pasta and sauce. Also, the shrimp were quite large and filling - absolutely love this dish.

We forwent the dessert but ended up with these little chocolate and creme (with some type of booze) parfaits that were quite good. Not on the menu, I think they called them chocolate cows or something similar?

Service at Il Bel Lago is quite exceptional - our server was knowledgeable, courteous and quick to deliver. We couldn't have asked for or expected better. Thank you Sue and Carl for introducing me to this place - I hope to be back!

I really love this place! Stopped by on a Friday night.  Made a reservation via opentable and was taken in right away to our table next to the bar.  We ordered several cocktails and margaritas (all of them were really good), a beef taco and ceviche.  Everything came in fast,  the waiter was very friendly and attentive.  Everything tasted great.  We were alerted when kitchen was closing.  Which occurs at 10:30 pm at night.  The only reason why I ranked it 4 instead of 5 stars was due to somewhat expensive price points.  The tequila sampler with less than a shot each (3 samples) was $25, the food and the cocktails are relatively pricier than average in this area.

Hands down, the best Greek food in Tucson. I am perplexed by some of the reviews concerning bad service. We have always been treated like family here. I know one of the owner's life story! The food is fantastic. I love Saganaki and it's served the right way here. Cooked in clarified butter first, then flamed table side. I can't describe the salty deliciousness! The fried calamari is done in olive oil, which adds to the flavor. It's always melt in your mouth tender. For entrees we always share. One order is the Garithes Pasalimani. Simply put, prawns sauteed in olive oil with fresh garlic, herbs, tomatoes and topped with Feta cheese. Whoever said that seafood and cheese doesn't go together needs to try this dish! I am very picky about any kind of seafood and I have never had a watery or fishy prawn here. Trust me, if I had, my review would be far different. Second, the classic gyros platter. Delicious, perfectly seasoned and rotisserie roasted gyros meat paired with wonderful pita, tzatziki sauce and the usual accompaniments. We usually order a Greek wine and the server's recommendations have never led us wrong. The baklava is simply everything it should be. Fresh phyllo, honey and nuts. The perfect way to end a Greek meal. A few years ago, we moved to the bar after dinner for drinks. I taught the bartender how to make a Grasshopper! Wonderful local place that we have patronized for years. Always fantastic food and service. For real Greek food in Tucson, I highly recommend Athens on Fourth.

Great place! I'm down for wine and cheese probably 90% of anytime, but this place is a smart concept of picking your wines, cheeses, and meats and just letting them do the work of putting them together and adding the extra that you don't think about. Can't really remember all that they added but I loved the candied pecans and orange pieces with a nice smelly cheese and our semi dry Riesling. 
You think that this place is tiny just from walking in and seeing the space they have to choose your foods but when you walk outside and around the corner, they have this huge backyard and upstairs with tons of seating and a really chill vibe. My friend and I were there on a Monday night and there was a musician with a pretty decent sized crowd. 
Love this place, coming back soon when the cold weather stays.

My little sister and I frequent this location and we love it. We always go through the drive thru and we have never had a problem. The people who work the drive thru are extremely polite and nice. Great job to whoever does the hiring there. The coffee is delicious as it is most Starbucks. Quick and friendly service every time always equals a 5 star review from me! Great job!

I LOVE this place!

I wandered in here about a month ago and fell in love. Natalie and Kathy are like long-lost friends that make everyone feel like they're welcome.

Had a wonderful evening of landshark, manicures, pedicures and great conversation.

The clothes are unique and AWESOME and the little accessories in the back by Kathy are outstanding!

Can't wait to go back!

My friends and I called just minutes before arriving at Harvest, and we were seated almost immediately. It is a modern/fine dining feel, but can be casual as well. There was live music playing on a Friday night. Our server was very engaging and personable. This restaurant is similar to Seasons 52, for the menu changes every 3 months with dishes inspired by season, but they have way more to offer on the menu that I can remember. The main difference to note is that they have a green concept with farm to table style using fresh and organic ingredients from over 70 local farmers markets. Not only that, but are eco-friendly in regards to using recycled products for other purposes in the restaurant. Also, each item on the menu is 500 calories or less, or slightly more as noted with a little plus sign. Aside it being healthier ingredients being put into your body, doesn't mean it is necessarily healthy. Plug in an app or two, a meal and dessert, drinks..you're looking at a 2000+ calorie meal. But who cares its dinner, and you're meant to indulge. So indulge..

All the food was proportioned pretty well. The flat bread was thin, but very large and came free with Yelp check in. It was yummy and shareable between 4 people. Spinach and Kale dip was creamy and delicious. I had the duck pot stickers, and I personally thought they were over fried and sort of bland. I did not care for the cranberry, and other sauce it was accompanied with. I absolutely loved the pumpkin ravioli. It is a sweet and savory dish, and very well balanced. Desserts are in shooter glasses and $3 each. Our server came to the table with a little tray displaying all desserts to choose from, always a great tactic. If you want one, which of course you do, she hands it to you right there. Genius! I'll take another. They are mostly a mousse, with a a little crumb or cake texture at the bottom.

The only negative was that the food did take a little longer to come out, but overall I thought it was a nice experience. I will come back again.

Fantastic! I came while on work trip from the suggestion of my husband and love all of the style and atmosphere. I got a few bottles to take home with me and the staff was super nice and helpful to give suggestions too. Grab a friend and a board game, and go when you are nearby!

This is our 100th review! Woot, woot.

I came to Agustin Kitchen for lunch with a friend today and had an absolutely delightful experience. We sat inside and highly enjoyed the modern, clean, and inviting decor. While the specials sounded delicious, I ordered the chicken chopped salad and my friend had the veggie burger. Both were completely amazing! The salad has dried papaya, grains (buckwheat I think), slivered almonds, cheese....and the champagne vinegarette was perfectly emulsed. YUM. The veggie burger on the new summer menu has a curry aioli, which really stands out. With filling entrees around $10-14, eating here at lunchtime is an excellent choice for the budget conscious foodie. I love that the atmosphere, waitstaff, food, plating and all the parts of this restaurant are unassuming and authentic. For a place as award winning as this, it welcomes all kinds of clientele and makes everyone feel at home. Totally on point! 

Looking forward to coming back for brunch...I saw a killer looking Bloody Mary on the way out....

I have been to numerous Bread Companies, and always love their food - however it always seems the Bread Co in Brentwood can not get their act together.

It takes them forever to answer the phone, estimated wait times are always longer then you are first told, and it seems like the orders are always messed up in small ways. Like asking for no tomato and they are all over my meal - every time!!!

Also their staff always seems like they don't want to be there. Yes, I know it is work - and all of us wish we didn't have to...but a simple smile can go a long way!

In the end I always try to go to either the one in the Loop or in Webster Groves - the people are always friendly, they get my orders right, out faster then said and the locations always seem cleaner.

I love this place! If you need a GIANT sweet fix - make sure to get their Cleopatra sundae or their chocolate covered bacon. So good!

If you are a fan of beets, which I am, I advice you to get their beet salad. It is ALOT of beets and ALOt of goat cheese, but oh so good!

The only catch to it is I feel like everything is a little over priced, but I will pay a little extra for great food and wonderful service :)

After three years in Nashville, I finally made it to this crazy popular spot. It was pretty crowded, but even on a Saturday if you come a little early (okay, a lot early) you can get a table with minimal wait. I loved the gin drink - think it was called the Expectation. Or something that starts with an E. very refreshing and cucumbery. The artichoke dip is solid, but really, how do you screw that up? My ahi was tasty, but nothing spectacular. Service was a little slow, possibly because it was so friendly. I'd go back were it not that I really don't care to wait for stuff. Maybe on my next blue hair 5 pm dinner special.
This restaurant is directly across my work so we come here often. Food is great. I love the ramen dishes especially.

My significant other loves teppanyaki, and I have to admit, I do too.  So, last night, we were in Reno for one night due to an early flight in the morning, we decided to try Ichiban since it has very good reviews, and we were staying at the Whitney Peak Hotel across the street.  

Sadly, the restaurant is in Harrah's, so you do have to brave a bit of cigarette smoke upon arrival, but once inside the restaurant, you do not notice this at all.   Regarding the restaurant itself, it is quite small - only about 8 teppanyaki tables, but the biggest teppanyaki tables I've ever seen.  They seat 12 people at each table.  Definitely great if you have a big group, other teppanyaki restaurants usually only seat 8.

So, if you've been to a Benihana or local place, you pretty much get the same set up.  Soup, salad, shrimp appetizer, entree with vegetables, fried or steamed rice and ice cream.   But we found Ichiban takes most of these to a new level.  They even make it feel more upscale by starting with warm towels to wash your hands.

Now onto the food.  The soup was coined as "miso" but I dislike miso soup and rather enjoyed this one.  Next, the salad was cucumbers soaked in some delicious sweet rice vinegar with a few strands of imitation crab.  I rather enjoyed this twist!  Next they don't just do shrimp appetizer, they offer calamari as well.  We both had the shrimp and were pleasantly surprised by the sauce they put on them and that they were mixed with snow peas - SO DELICIOUS!  The chef then made the mixed veggies, which was a bit of onion, bean sprouts, carrots, etc.  They were actually very tasty.

For the entrees, they were pretty standard, we had shrimp, lobster and scallops with fried rice.  All was very good and we left stuffed and satisfied.   We skipped dessert.

Couple of notes, this was a very long experience.  Because the tables are large, this was a full two + hour experience.  Don't be in a rush, you will get frustrated.  Another note, the chef's here were probably the best we've seen.  They had really unique tricks and knife skills.  We even saw one juggling with two things on fire at a table across the way.

Cute little ice cream spot in the Santa Barbara Public Market. The girl working was super friendly and provided us with all the samples we wanted to try. They were all pretty good, but we ended up getting a double scoop of the wildberry crisp and the honey almond crunch. I loved the flavor of the wildberry and the little crisp balls added a fun texture. The honey almond crunch had a strong honey flavor that my bf was a big fan of. The scoops are generous and definitely a good portion to share between two people.

I've never actually been to Wrap Shack, but I've gotten takeout before. I got a smoothie and a vegan volcano wrap. I usually hate veggie wraps, because I generally don't like cold roasted vegetables in bread (really, that's a lame excuse for a sandwich) but this was not that!! It was broccoli, carrots, onion, zucchini, and black bean hummus, and it had a lot of flavor and texture going for it. It was a cold sandwich that was actually intended to be eaten cold. I love that it was already vegan, and I didn't have to remove cheese from my order and thus remove any shred of flavor I had a shot at. Good choice for delivery or a quick takeout order.

I have seen the signs, the paper on the windows, and the very large store front staring back at me at Southgate Mall for months now.  My curiosity peaked yesterday as I walked by and saw people running around, setting up, doors open, but customers unable to go in.  And now.....Finally.  Its here.  Crate and Barrell's opening day!  

     I was greeted by two very friendly girls handing out Scratch and Wins at the entrance with the possibility of winning $20,000 (yes that is the correct amount of zeros!) in the store.  I won $10.  Every little bit helps!  Especially when you have a love of furniture and house "stuff" like I do.  This store is HUGE!  They have attempted to set it up into sections that flow into each other.....upholstery, bedding, desks, dining, into kitchen, appliances, holiday, decor.  There is a lot to look at here and a lot of different styles.  The furniture is bright in some selections, muted in others, leather, fabric, sofas, sectionals, double chairs, single chairs.  Truly, there is so much and something for every taste.  I was very impressed with how many item tags I looked at and found "North American sourced" and "Eco friendly".  One "leather" chair in particular that I liked was actually made of Soy!  I am always wary of box stores as I am on a "buy local" or at least "buy North American" lifestyle, so I am very happy to find a furniture store that I can customize and find things at right in the middle of a mall!  
    I ended up leaving with some tea light holders and a placemat for a hallway table upstairs.  I also left with future plans of buying a rug, curtains, a desk and a living room chair one day.  Prices are mid-range for furniture and some items can run a bit high (700-2100 for a living room chair, $500-$3000 for a dining room table) but they seem to be of a good quality, although I cannot say for sure until my dog has slept on it, I have spilled a drink on it, and it has met my vacuum many many times.  Hopefully that will happen in the future to a particular green double chair I have my eye on.  
    The check out process was a bit painful but I chalk it up completely to first day kinks.  Their debit was down (it happens to everyone!!) so I had to leave and come back with cash.  No biggie!  I left with 40$ worth of stuff for $30 thanks to my 10$ gift card!  There is also a wedding registry and if I believed in wedding registries, this would be a place I would register!  But I do not believe in registries, so, if anyone at my wedding is reading this, gift certificates to this store would be very welcome gifts if you planned on getting us anything.  :)

People know me for my high heels and penchant for expensive cookies. I like being just so fresh, so clean, and generally take my sangria on a Southern California patio with my ladies in maxi dresses and wedges. Don't hate. It's just how I work hard to roll. 

But, I grew up in the mountains and camping with my family. I can build a fire, I can build a fort, I can shoot a gun, and I'll bet I could chop some wood if I absolutely had to. If the apocalypse was upon us, you'd want my tasty cast iron pan skills all up in your shelter making mean ass cowboy stew. Just sayin. 

The girlfriends and I decide that we should take a break from our status quo and start a new tradition: Gourmet Camping once a year- and so, the 2014 crew of myself, The Polish Princess of P.O.P., The Master Chef Selary and The Sexy School Teacher took a trip up North for a couple days. We packed the car all by ourselves too. (Keep reading for actual campsite info-hey, story telling is a camping tradition right?) 

The menu? Gourmet indeed. From fire kissed meatballs wrapped in onions over bacon cheese hash followed by marshmallows stuffed with rolos toasted into cookie smores to crepes with blueberries and paninis with mozzarella and spinach: WE dines like the queens of the forest. We made campfire pie oven biscuits and corn on the cob with roasted tri tip stew and mini apple pies. 

Our tent was a virtual nest-we made micheladas and sangria and played card games by lantern light. We checked in Saturday and stayed till Monday AM. 

It all sounds lovely, and it was-except for a few things: 

The drought: Not the campsites fault at all-but it was dry as a bone out there. The allure of the creeks and rivers caused us to make a reservation there-but they were at least a 5 mile drive to find, a disappointing turn of events. The campsite this dry is very dirty and dusty. Any other time and with more moisture it would have been perfect because of the big oak trees and shade and greenery-but California just isn't surviving this situation very well. 

Expensive ass firewood. 6 dollars for a small bundle. They don't want you bringing in outside wood-so its a racket. 

There was a water pump, but no showers, bathrooms were okay. We could smell them though so EW.  About 20 miles inland from Santa Barbara so it was in the 80's and pretty humid-I dont suggest it at all for summer months.
