The fried catfish was very good too, but my wife wasn't as jazzed about it as I was.  Great flavor, but not as crisp as she likes.  We finished off with their bread pudding.  Again, it was eye closing, lean back in your seat, delicious.  

I'll be going back for sure.

This is my second time visiting the Gulch Nail Bar. The first time I just got a regular old plain nail polish manicure...it lasted about 1 day before I chipped them. This time around I went with a dip nail polish manicure, as I've heart people rave about them! We went with the Nail Bar because there was no wait, everywhere else in town that we called was PACKED full, and you needed a reservation...so it was definitely nice to just walk in and receive the services right away.

They turned out looking very nice, I was quite happy with the quality of them. On to the price of them, it was $50 for just the manicure part (no massage fluff stuff), an extra $5 if you need a removal process before hand, and then of course tip. It's a bit steep in my opinion, but I also don't regularly get my nails done so I'm not sure of the comparison to other nail places.

On a customer service stand point, the nail technician was fairly nice, but the receptionist was a bit impatient with me when I was trying to pick out a color. If i'm going to spend $70+ on my nails...I want it to be a color that I love, soooo I need my time, lol. But overall, it was a pleasant business and I got a pretty long lasting manicure.

Repeat Guest - this Review Update is for my 6th & 7th Stays, in 2014

A well-deserved 5 stars! I am a repeat guest at this hotel -- I stayed here numerous times in 2013 and 2014 for stays averaging 10 days each, and some as long as 2 weeks each. This curent review is for my last two stays, each in 2014. As always, I am giving this hotel 5 stars for these most recent stays.

I love this hotel, and that is why I have kept returning here since my first stay in 2013. It is alwys my first choice for my stays in the French Quarter.

As I've related before in my earlier review, I find the staffers to be friendly, helpful and competent, the management to be very responsive and responsible, and willing and able to be held accountable (which is rare in business nowadays!), and I find the hotel property itself, including the lobby, the elevators and stairwells, the hallways on each floor, and the rooms, and bathrooms, to be extremely good for a hotel in the Quarter in this price range.

Better yet, each of the rooms in which I have stayed across my multiple stays has been very large and spacious, and I have found all parts of the property to be very well-maintained and clean, and yet the property still bears a very large degree of Old World comfort, charm and ambiance, which I enjoy very much.

BTW, the WiFi, which is free, seems to work great in all parts of the hotel; I have never had any WiFi problems at all across my stays in numerous different rooms loacated across the span of the hotel property, and the bandwidth and speed are also very good.

I also find the housekeeping staff to be very cooperative and helpful, and respectful. I prefer a very green approach to all of my hotel stays, and thus I do NOT want my room cleaned every day, nor do I want my bedsheets and bathroom towels changed every day, for I find such practices to be very wasteful. I also have no need for someone to make my bed (i.e., tidy my bedsheets). Thus, for each of my 7 stays so far at this hotel I have advised the front desk and housekeeping of my preferences, and I have asked for no daily visits to the room by the housekeeper, and I assure them that if and when I DO want a housekeeper to visit my room (and even then, primarily to empty the trash cans), then I will, when such a day arrives, remove the DO NOT DISTURB sign from the outer doorknob on my room. So far, to date, the housekeeping staff has honored this request/agreement religiously, and NOT ONCE has a housekeeping staffer ever knocked on my door in violation of the DO NOT DISTURB sign. I am quite impressed with this almost fanatical ability to respect my request for near-zero housekeeping visits!

I normally NEVER mention the names of particular staffers in my reviews of hotels, restaurants and pubs, but I am about to make an exception, one which I also made when I wrote a review for this hotel last year, wherein I wish to again mention two staffers in particular (although ALL of the staffers here have earned my undying appreciation):

The first staffer whom I wish to mention is Todd Theriot, the Guest Services Manager, whom I have contacted (sometimes by phone, usually via email) prior to each of my earlier stays to ask for an early check-in and a refrigerator in my room, and also for other favors at times (e.g., to stitch together into one contiguous stay in the same room three separate contiguous reservations), and he has always been very helpful and he and his staff have always come through flawlessly in terms of fulfilling those requests. I am amazed at his helpfulness, and that of his staff.

The second staffer whom I wish to mention is Robert, who is a bellman/doorman at this property (he has been working at this property for a great many years). He is unfailingly cheerful, helpful and gracious, and manages to greet me every time that I enter or leave the hotel during his shift. And, he is very helpful and generous in other ways: I normally eat very healthfully, but during a late 2013 stay here, I developed a craving for jelly donuts (I get such a craving about twice a year. ....), and I had happened to mention to Robert that I was unable to find jelly donuts anywhere in or near the French Quarter. Well, the next morning, as I returned from my early-AM walk, Robert stopped me and handed me a bag containing jelly donuts -- he had stopped at a well-known donut shop in another part of the city on his way to work, just to buy me the jelly donuts that I had been craving, which he presented to me as a gift! I was quite awed by this gesture, and very grateful! He has since done this for me, each time entirely unsolicited, during each of my 2014 stays as well.

Before ending this review, I wish to extend my sincere and heartfelt thanks to all of the staff and management at this hotel for all their fine efforts and care during all of my past stays (there were 7 or 8 of them)! Thank you!

*Please note, I was sampling root alcohol when I was inside of here.And that alone is capable of construing and greatly affecting my feeling for this place. especially when there's a DJ spinning good music in the background, and an art wall to go along with the theme of the booze.*

But with the above thrown into consideration, hot damn is this place awesome. I've been checking it out since around the time of it's beginning. But it took me a while to find it on here just because of the fact that I affectionately call it Compass just because of what it logo and sign remind me of (I guess I'm a dork too - http://wwwdelivery.superstock.com/WI/223/1538/PreviewComp/SuperStock_1538R-47673.jpg).

Overall the store is an interesting treasure trove to walk through. It's filled to the brim with interesting books, cool shoes, soap. nice looking bags, addicting T Shirts, and other cool trends of fashion. But to be honest the main flaw to a lot of the items on the whole can be the price tag. While I love and am sold on the idea of owning a Chewbacca and Moustache Logo T Shirt, I'm not necessarily sold on the idea of owning them for $34 a shirt. And that's just the basics.

But at least that price tag does go to a valuable message statement. And here's only part of it -

"Our story begins in Philadelphia, a city of Brotherly Love, do-it-yourself initiatives, and collectives of inspired artmakers. Since 2006, Art In The Age of Mechanical Reproduction has existed as a vehicle through which modern thinkers marry reverence for enlightened ideals with the mandate to reach more minds in an ever-fickle urban scene. Our community of free thinkers and artistic innovators delivers inspiration and aspiration back to The People."

And that's the exact idea that runs rampant inside of it. It gives local artists a shot and supports free thought on every given occasion. And it does it ten fold during First Friday since it's in Old City. You'll enjoy a fine beverage such as root alcohol and check out a DJ just like I did. And there's worthy theme of art or history (or both on the wall), and plenty of interesting fashion to take in. And it is Idea's like all of the above that are worth supporting in the long haul.

I hate to do this, but it has to happen. We still come to the deli every few weeks for lunch meat, and the store is now pretty well stocked with local goodies. The products continue to be great. The lunch meat prices are great, and the other goods range from moderate to pricey. We still haven't had sandwiches, but we've earned a free one with our Flock card so I'm sure we'll cash in soon.

The reason that I have to drop a star is the service :( Efficiency and urgency are sorely lacking. The last two times I've been in, I've timed how long it takes to cut the meat, and it's been 13 minutes and over 20 minutes. I just don't have that much time to dedicate to lunch meat, and I could get Boar's Head so much more quickly from the grocery store. In the spirit of the family business, some of the kids are employees, but I struggle with this, too. I think the kids are perfectly nice and normal for their ages, but I'm not sure that having them behind the counter is the best choice in terms of professionalism. I'll leave it at that.

We'll still make regular trips (a 3 star review is A-OK, after all), but I would love to see things improve in the customer service department. This isn't enough to keep me away, but it might be for some people.

I really enjoyed a solo dinner here during a recent business trip. The sofa and coffee table setting where I was seated was comfortable, but a bit awkward for dining. The food and service were both terrific and I am glad I chose this restaurant. It was a lovely evening - a good book, very good drinks and unusual and delicious food.

Trader Joe's, you will get a five star review when you build a parking garage to accommodate all of us who rely on your for our groceries.  I love this place.  You have the best selection of meats and veggies and all these amazing litte TJs-only treats.  However, might I suggest building more stores in Nashville?  Or the aforementioned parking garage?  Unless I come in here with the early birds there isn't a chance of making it in here on the weekend.  I'm happy to get up and get my shopping done, and the excellent customer service is a nice compliment to my morning crankiness.  However, seriously work on the parking issue!  Sure you're paying a bit more for some items but I will gladly fork over more funds for quality food.  So if you are new to TJs, remember: shop at odd times, be prepared to vulture for parking, and you will pay more than kroger.  However, the experience is totally worth it.

Why 4 stars? Because I appreciate the level of hipsterness here.

   ---   ---   ---

I'm a vicarious hipster, in that, I love their taste in coffee, beer, food, music, and their ability to set up shop in a struggling area. 

New Orleans is full of questionable hoods, and the Joint was definitely up there with the most interesting. It looks like a giant bomb went off across the street within the last 6 months. In any other city, this would not be a place to be walking around, but NOLA plays by different rules.

I had the pulled pork, brisket, mac, and potato salad. It was all well above average, but not quite touching the "Holy Mother of God" status. I eat BBQ as often as my body can take it, and trying the best of the city is usually a required stop on any new place that I visit. I'm glad I stopped at The Joint as my last stop before leaving this foodie-heaven of a city. 

As a whole, New Orleans lived up to the hype. I'll be back.

Perhaps the BEST chain submarine?  I discovered JMS on a work road trip in Sarasota almost a decade ago and loved it!

Way too far from me, later they opened a location in Oldsmar, just west of the flea market.  I found many excuses to make the drive on weekends.  Then finally, they opened a few locations right near me.

A bit more expensive, but one gets what one pays for, right?  Service or quality is never a question at any JM location that I have experienced.  They run a tight ship.

All of their subs are great, but the #13 Italian is what got me hooked and brings me back.  Try it "Mike's Way" - fully veg dressed, with lots of oil/vinegar, and sprinkled with dried herbs.

This particular #13 sub evokes some great memories from the many Mom & Pop sub joints over the years, especially in the Gateway area.

I've tried their hot subs as well.  None have ever disappointed.

But if somewhere in your past, you remember a great, cold, Italian-style submarine, made with that special oil/vinegar/herbs treatment?

Please give the JM's #13 sub a try!

We loved visiting this brewery on a recent weekend getaway to Nashville. The atmosphere was casual and welcoming, with plenty of indoor and outdoor seating. There was a delicious variety of beers on tap, and there was even a countertop video game (for free!).

We settled on a flight with three of New Heights Sours (all delicious) and a local cider (also tasty). 

The beers were so good, we ended up taking home a four-pack plus one more single to share with friends from home. 

Our teens were with us and purchased sodas, and I noticed smaller kids as well as a few dogs, so definitely family friendly.

We were looking to eat brunch and all the places we chose were either closed on Sunday or stopped serving food before we got there. We came across this place by accident because we got tired of searching and I love oysters, so we gave it a go.

To cut the the chase, it's just okay. For a city known for its food and drinks, the bar is pretty high when it comes to expectations and I can't say I was very impressed with the oysters and cocktails. I did appreciate that they had happy hour specials and the saints game playing though. 

I got the oyster trio (a three oyster sampler of their Rockefeller, Cajun and charbroiled oyster). I got it as a happy hour special to taste them and see which one I wanted to order a dozen of. I decided against it because they just weren't that good. All 3 were very watery and rubbery and just....okay. 

The crab cakes, red beans and rice and the gumbo were delicious. The crab cakes were so good that we kept ordering them. Definitely try them if you go! 

My Pimms cup cocktail was good but not anything is order again, just a bit too much cucumber for my liking. The hurricane was decent as well, but they went a little too heavy on the grapefruit juice (at least that's what it tasted like). 

Overall, I think it was pretty decent but not a strong contender in a city full of amazing food.

WB Pizza 

A friend told me the WB Pizza offered a ton of vegan options! 

Located close to the broad ripple area, I finically had a chance to try their pizza. 

From the outside you may be a little skeptical in which it is located in a small strip mall near a liquor store and not much else. 

WB pizza is a local business and has been around for a good amount of time, since 1999. It's always great to support locally run businesses. It is a small restaurant, but has plenty of tables to accommodate big groups if needed. 

Their menu has so many options, including vegan cheese and newly added vegan "meats". They also have a large selection of beer for all of the beer lovers out there. 

We ordered the breadsticks with some of their garlic butter which is vegan and cheese (non vegan) for the others at the table. 

The breadsticks were to die for. Honestly they were my favorite, even compared to the pizza. They were warm, small in size, with a slight crisp, and baked just right. 
(See pictured below).

The pizza we had was "the vegan" with no cheese. However they do offer vegan cheese for an upcharge. We also ordered another speciality pizza that had meat and cheese, which I can't speak of since I don't eat those things. 

I was impressed with the pizza and the amount of veggies on top but I wish the actual base of the pizza would have been cooked more because it was a very flimsy pizza. I would have preferred a little more spice of some sort. I liked the taste, but was disappointed when the check came out...

Two pizzas (12'') and breadsticks, a piece of vegan chocolate cake for almost 80 dollars, not including a tip. Now that is ridiculous!! 

I do have to admit that the vegan chocolate cake really made up for the cost because the cake was AMAZING! I mean it too! It was moist, light, and the frosting was delicious. This came close to being my favorite over the breadsticks. 

The trick is to make your own pizza and add few toppings that you want because the speciality pizzas DON'T state their price on the menu and have a lot of toppings on them which are totaled to the same price as a custom pizza. I get that the ingredients are fresh and everything is homemade, but pizza ingredients aren't that expensive and I know this because I have made my own many times at home. 

If you want to support a local business and want fresh cooked pizza at a high price, visit WB Pizza. 

I am unsure if I will return due to the shock I was in with the cost of the pizza mainly due to the fact that the menu is very misleading. I would definitely return for vegan desserts and breadsticks though!!!

Im so saaaaddd. I was hyped about the fries bc they re always fresh her NOT TODAY. They were old and unloved. Disappointed bc my triple cheeseburger was hotter than a flame! 

Keystone McDonald's is my favorite. Its near our house.  Very rarely do we have bad service. Today not only were my fries cold and salty but I ordered ice cream, that they forgot. Bean had to go inside to get it. Today's service just felt like a Monday. Slow & not quite into the groove. 

The manager apologized and thanked us for coming in. . . to get our ice .

Ugh. WTF goes on with this bar? I knew it was one of the oldest bars in Philly, rumored to have entertained Bowie in the 70s, so I had to at least stop in. Mistake. All I kind figure is that this used to be a dive that someone is trying to class-up. Not working. The weird newly upholstered floral booths are taking a stab at "family resturaunt", the bar and selection says "dive," the constant Sinatra soundtrack the night I was in, and the older female bartender wearing two different earrings (one a pearl, one a long, dangly feather) scream South Philly, and my wine was skunked. 

I'm all about different types, different strokes for different folks, but for the love of God, decide what you are and do it right. This unholy mishmash is a disgrace.

Omg I love this pizza. We found a reason to come to the area just to get some garlic knots and a slice of pizza. Great flavor, thin New York style pizza and fresh toppings. Not much else to say as they do this well and I will return!

I do not enjoy any aspect of going to the gym. I don't feel a sense of accomplishment after sweating from a jog on the tread mill. That's not me, and that's okay because Planet Fitness has members of all shapes and sizes and fitness levels. My favorite part is that there isn't that weird, musky gym smell. The place is clean, and super organized. There's tons of thread mills, and ellipticals, and strange machines I have no idea how to use. Not to mention tanning booths. 

I joined while they had their promo going which only cost me $1 to join and the monthly fee is $10. If you're home visiting from college or are even here for a couple weeks it's totally worth joining since it's considerably cheaper than most gym's guest passes. If you live you're life on a crazy schedule, this place is for you. It's open 24/7 Monday-Friday and has decent hours on the weekends. 

There's a strict no grunting policy which I love. I just don't understand how grunting "rawwrwww" or "uuuhhhhg" will help anyone lift more weight but what do I know, I hate going to the gym! The best part is the lunk alarm. Every so often someone drops a weight which in itself can be embarrassing. At Planet Fitness an alarm sounds. So if you find yourself dropping a weight, just take a bow because you'll have a whole audience gawking at you.

Fav spot to bring the kids for a guilt-free treat! Their fresh juice is amazing, lots of flavors and reasonable price. This spot is unique because they also are combined with a small active wear boutique, cute idea! The employees there are so sweet and they probably would of let my kids try all the samples they had (And my kids love it). Their ice cream is gluten-free, vegan, soy-free, & dairy-free. They have lots of toppings to choose from and the portion size is massive! We also had their s'mores donut and it was so gooey and delicious! I like this place because it keeps me on track with my healthy lifestyle but allows me to treats my kids. Flavors are 10/10.
Atmosphere 10/10, lots of natural night, table tops and a bar area by the window. 
Parking is 8/10, parking lot is small but I've never been here when it's been super busy.
100% love this place! We will be back for more treats!

Cool riverside park walk along the park and river. This Hillsborough River flow along the location make the strolling or jogging very desirable. The scenery ever changes along the river make this prime location. The house along the park has clear view toward the river and the park. 

We were here because live orchestra music in the park. Because it close to holiday, they play the Christmas and holiday music. Very pleasant. The park also is a home for canoeing and rolling boat area. There was boat parade when we visited the park. Children are roaming like not limit. 

There plenty tree cover for open air concert. The gazebo serve as a stage for the presentation. Love the Santa make available to the kid and old kid like me. It was great to see old friends from Yelp in a surprise meeting in the park.

I enjoyed my recent visit here.  It was Easter Sunday and our party of four wanted dinner.   

We were seated right away-the place was 90% occupied so not a bad sign.  The food was really good and the service was friendly, but kind of slow.

I had a cup of gumbo to start and it was really good, while I had the crabcake appetizer for my entrée and it was as well, albeit very small.  The waiter did advise me of the size ahead of time.  Others enjoyed the steak, pork belly tacos and everything else.   Really good flavor and spice with all dishes.

An open restaurant with a lot of charm-would love to try them for brunch someday.

Lovely family owned restaurant with fabulous Lebanese food!  We had the chicken swarma platter, fattoush salad, Mediterranean appetizer plate, and both desserts!  The staff is very friendly the atmosphere is relaxed and clean.  Don't let the strip mall exterior fool you this place is a gem!

Hands down this is my favorite Indian buffet in the Tampa Bay Area. The outside is very unassuming, connected to a gas station close to WestShore Plaza. But I can tell you that as soon as you step out of your parked car you can smell the amazing food. Once you enter it's easy to forget you are connected to a gas station. The decor is beautiful. The dining space itself is a little small so make sure you get there early or else you WILL end up in a line outside the door. The buffet has plenty of options for the meat eater, the vegetarian, and the vegan alike. The lunch buffet also includes 2 dessert options and a section where fresh bread is being prepared and given to each table. The staff were friendly and attentive to our needs. Food in the buffet was constantly being replenished. This place is a must try for Indian food lovers and we will definitely be returning.

I love you Guy Fieri, but not on this pick.

You are usually on point about your recommendations, but we found these carnitas to be a bit dry.  Flavorful, but dry....Ordered the carnitas combo plate w beans, rice, n a generous portion of yummy guacamole.  So I have nothing else to say except this was just a so-so dish.

Had a sit down dinner here with about 50 other guests last week. We began with cocktail hour and munched on upscale pigs in blankets, beef flatbread, cheese and more! I was very impressed by the quality of the snacks and then later on, the quality of the food.

For my entree, I picked the spinach stuffed chicken in a cream sauce. The chicken was cooked perfectly, and the sauce had just enough flavor. Dessert was basic cheesecake, which was a good size portion and very rich.

The view is what I truly loved about this place - hard to believe I was in South Jersey.

Stand alone pink little shack of a building.

You make your purchase outside. Do not enter, they will open a window.  

The display is not that visually appealing because it is suffocating due to the limited space.  What my eyes turned to first were the tartes because they seemed to be the focal point and took up the most space in the "display".  

Chocolate chip coconut macaroon: $0.50 - no plus or minus - just standard.

Pecan sweet potato tarte: $5.75 - This was quite lovely.  The sweet potato balanced it out so that it isn't overpowering with what would've been a whole lot of molasses.  This really is one of the better tartes that I have tried. 

The other items didn't interest me but I will definitely be coming back to try their other tartes.  

Parking: street metered

I decided to go back here with a fellow fried chicken connoisseur. We were not disapointed. One thing I love about the place is the consistency out of the kitchen. Everything we ordered was hot out of the kitchen. I had my usual fried chicken, beans, and greens, and my dining companion fried chicken with the carbo plate of mashed potatoes, mac and cheese, and green beans.It was all wonderful, not to mention the cornbread with extra dollops of butter. A go-to place for me.

I have only been here twice so far but I absolutely love this place. First time I came in I got a few tacos (wanted to try the steak, chicken, and chorizo) and all were perfectly delicious. This last time I went in I got another chorizo taco and I tried the carne asada torta which I was also very pleased with. It was about double the size of the torta's I have tried in the past, which I will admit has only been a couple, but I couldn't even finish it (which while I hate wasting food this is better than not getting enough). Everyone is always friendly and there are so many other items on their menu I would like to try and plan on making this is a regular place I eat at when visiting Reno.

Love the history of Belle Meade, their enormous contribution to horses/ horse racing, and I enjoyed learning about the family & business dynamics about all key players in this entire saga. The landscape is beautiful, the wine is only so-so. The employees leading the mansion tour make it fun & informative. If you want to get away from all the country music driven stuff from downtown Nashville this is a great place to do so.

First time here!

Awesome casino in NOLA! During my friend's bachelorette weekend we hit this spot up on our last night. So much fun!! Live dj in the actual casino was playing some major throwbacks that really had the crowd hyped!! Great way to get people to spend more haha. We visited the nightclub inside and had an epic night! So much fun!!! I'm not a gambler so I can't review the slot, machines, etc but I really loved the life inside this casino!!! Way better than any of the ones I visited in Vegas. If you want a fun night that's also close to bourbon for you must visit Harrah's! Thank me later!

I wish my kids were small again..This place is awesome..thank goodness I have a grandbaby girl..I will shop around here again and again...
LOVE THIS STORE...

Weekend before last, we stopped at Stack 'n' Sizzle Restaurant for breakfast. I had never been before, but saw some menu items that looked tasty. 

When we arrived, the restaurant was about 3/4 full. We had to wait a couple minutes, but we were seated shortly after our arrival. Our server greeted us and got everybody coffee. We all placed our order and then we had quite a wait for our food. It took nearly 45 minutes to get our food. The kitchen was moving very slow. The restaurant filled up, but the food should have came sooner than that. After the long wait, we were all quite hungry. The food that was delivered all looked and tasted good. I only had a meat lovers omelette, but it was quite tasty. My buddies said all of their food was good. The portions were quite large given the price. 

Overall, the food was quite good, but the service needed a little help. It was nearly an hour and a half before we could get out of there. It only took us about 15 minutes to eat, and then another 25 or so to get our check paid. The menu looks good and the prices are  very reasonable. I will return to check out other menu items, but hope the service gets better.

Butcher's is a beautiful and new fast-casual BBQ place! Like every BBQ place, I wanted everything on the menu. The pick 3 meats and 2 sides platter was the perfect option. The brisket was slightly dry but when I added the housemade chipotle BBQ sauce it tasted good! The half chicken fell off the bone and went really well with the house made honey BBQ sauce. The ribs had nice flavor to them and also fell of the bone. For the sides I had mac and cheese which was good but not my preference for mac n cheese. I just prefer baked mac and cheese but I know other people like a more saucy mac. I loved Butcher's collard greens because I make mine pretty damn close to how they make theirs. They're clearly cooked in pork of some sort (a must), have a little kick and a hint of vinegar. They cook theirs down more (which is a total preference thing) but had a great balance of flavor. Butcher's sauces definetly have more vinegar in them so if you like Carolina BBQ...this place is for you. 

Our service was great and the staff was so friendly! Took the time to answer any question. In terms of the price and quantity of food, you can't beat it! Split the 3 meat and 2 sides platter with one other person and we still had so much leftover. All of our food was only $20!

Loved this place, the service was excellent with our waitress very helpful with suggestions and and questions we had, I got the shrimp and carnitas tacos and would easily get both again. I also got their Mexican old fashion which was one of the best I ever had!!!!! If you're on fairmont you should def head over here

Being a beer geek, I needed to find at least one brewery while in Florida.  The problem is, I had heard very little that was positive about Florida's micro brews.  I found a good one here though!

The atmosphere is typical of a good brewery.  
-Their tanks, which come from the Bass brewery, are visible to the whole restaurant.  
-There is an old world feel inside.  
-The outside of the building is complete with their beer logos.
-Their Great American Beer Festival medals are visible behind the bar.  -The pictures on the wall show some local history and are fun to peruse while you wait. 
-I love the dart area!  I think breweries need to have non-electronic dart boards.  This one even was decorated with grain bags that completed the brewery feel - almost like you were actually in the work area.  
-The patio was wonderful!  It looks over an old neighborhood (at least I think by the looks of it).  Being from Minnesota, I really enjoyed the misting fans they had located on the patio.  It cooled down a HOT July evening!

We started out with a beer sampler, that came complete with 8 of their 10 beers (the others were currently out) and their root beer and cherry cream soda.  The root beer was one of the best I have ever tasted!  Their Old Elephant Foot IPA had good hop flavor at 80 ibu's and was easy to drink.  The Iron Rat Stout was awesome!  It was hoppy and had the right bite to accompany the dark, smooth deliciousness.  The Wild Warthog Weizen was good as well.  Just the right banana flavor, but not overwhelming (good patio beer).  One Night Stand Pale Ale is a hoppy, yet light (yellow) American Pale Ale.  It was great for the hot Tampa weather - light without sacrificing the great flavor of hops!  Unfortunately they were out of the Red Eye which seems to be the most popular beer there.

On to food.  We had a delicious pizza that came complete with 4 cheeses and a HOP pesto!!!!!  Great flavor, and even left that hop bitterness on your palate after you were finished.  We had bread pudding for desert.  It was good, but not like the midwest.  The highlight of this desert was the porter-soaked raisins!

Service was great!  Our server was busy, but never hesitated to help.  He even filled root beer growlers for us before we left.  I forgot his name now, but props to you awesome Tampa Bay Brewing Company guy!

Unfortunately, they were out of the T-shirt I wanted to take home, and the silly Florida liquor laws don't allow them to sell beer in a growler.  However, this is not their fault.

Great place to stop if you need good beer in Tampa!  I will be back if I am ever in Tampa again!

25 in house beers on tap - 7 of those are sours.  

First the beers-  their simco IPA is good - I am a hop head from so ca so bring on the IBU's.   Nice hop smell and bitterness coming through from the hops.  

Sours - I am new to them but try their sampler 9$ for any 4 - good pours allow you to taste multiple.  I loved the sour orange peel - definite pucker and great orange tangy taste. 

Milk stout. -  Mmm their peanut butter ms was great - awesome taste, also enjoyed the coffee stout which had balanced coffee nose and taste.  

Atmosphere is great - big fans keep it feeling cool, lots of games, a few TVs, good music in background.   They have a lounge attached to main bar with tables and a few couches.  Believe it or not wifey and I come here to study and the background noise (and beers) help us focus :)

The staff is very good - friendly, lots of beer knowledge and always a smile. 

They have an outside area out back you can bring dogs to and do have movies playing out back on a big screen on certain nights.  Pizza, wings served inside but we have not tried those yet.  Tours avail - check group on for deals.  

All in all this is worth the drive to spend a few hours at tailgate !!!!

The walk-up window is part of the charm.  If you are too lazy to get out of your car to get ice cream maybe you should go to McDonalds.

Graham Central Station is my favorite, I love S'mores too, they both use a graham cracker ice cream base that is deliciously different.  

Service is always friendly.  A happy place to grab a snack!

I absolutely LOVE this SUPER Target! I drive 45mins. just to come to this Target. I love that they have shampoo, conditioner etc. at this Target that I used to order online from Sephora. Plus when I use my Target card I get 5% off each time.

I had been to Fette Sau for drinks before, but decided to get a full meal here on Valentine's weekend. My logic was that you should only eat messy BBQ with someone who really loves you, right? We got nearly a pound of smoked brisket with mac and cheese and delicious baked beans. A side of soft biscuits was tossed in, and there were several different pre-made sauces on each table. The meat was really great, and the sides were soo savory, heavy, and just what you would expect from a place like this.

My recommendation is to get a little bit less food than you think you need, because it is going to be very filling. They also have happy hour food specials - a great deal if you want something on the small side.

Again, the place is super casual, but a great spot to go to with friends. The picnic table seating and good beer selection are a perfect setting for a night out. The entrance to Fette Sau is especially beautiful - as it looks like you are walking into the front door of someone's country home.

Frankie's on Fairview, sometimes I just want to scream with frustration over you.  How do I rank "almost"?  Seriously, this is making me crazy.

Dinner started a few months ago, and since then the Reverend, I and sometimes others have visited three evenings.  Since it's a new offering, I wanted to give time for the restaurant to settle and even out.  Except it hasn't.

First visit:  Gnocchi and the milanese pork chop.  Gnocchi was definitely freshly made and had a nice texture.  Pork chop was great....except no applesauce which is the Reverend's favorite pork chop topping.  The gnocchi were swimming in an orange-ish sauce and rooted in a bed of melted cheese.  The sauce was...odd.  Was it a vodka rose, perhaps?  No, marinara we were told.  Marinara is red and robust, not orange and...odd.  Service was great.

Second visit:  Went with the chicken parmesan and again, the Rev wanted the pork chop. This time he had grieved the loss of applesauce and moved on. Both entrees were solid.  Yay! No weird orange sauce. Perhaps it was just an off night.  I ordered the wedge salad with my meal. It promised lots of Maytag bleu cheese.  What came out was...odd. There was a huge slice of iceberg, bacon crumbles, tomato, and crumbles of bleu cheese. No dressing.  The problem is that the iceberg (lack of? bland?) flavor overcame everything else, so it tasted just like eating plain lettuce.  Again, service was great, and this time they took my salad back, added some mayonnaise to the bleu cheese to form a basic dressing. Good save.  With that base added the bleu cheese flavor came through beautifully.  

Third visit: Calamari, bacon mac & cheese, herbed chicken breasts, guess who got the pork chop (he is a man who knows what he likes) and lastly the linguine bolognese.  Calamari had a berry glaze drizzled on it which was ...odd.  Bacon mac & cheese was fine, it was a small ramekin as it's an appetizer.  Chicken earned rave reviews, tender, flavorful.   Pork chop again was consistently very good.  

Now for the linguine.  Everyone, please repeat after me:

"Sauce with meat is not the same as Bolognese".  

Thank you.  Also, the return of the strange orange sauce, this time with meat and carrots, which made the orange multi-dimensional.   

This time service was WAY off. Clearly no front of house management or line management.  No, they were not busy, there were 4 total tables and 2 servers.  Meals took a very long time to come out. First time we asked, we were told they were coming. Second time we asked, we were told the pork chops took longer to cook.  Wait staff: Never blame the food ordered for the delay.  Then our waiter disappeared.  Our glasses became empty. Bread was gone. Tummies growled.  Hurrah! Food arrives.  Drinks are refilled! We are back in the land of the living!  Except, no.  After that we were left to our own devices.  *sigh* Finally we were checked in on, got to-go boxes for what we didn't eat.  

Made the mistake of ordering a dessert, because hey, how long could that take to come out?  I can tell you: 12.5 very long minutes with dirty dishes covering our table.  No sign of our waiter.  When dessert did come out, it came with the check, which never got picked up.  Seriously.  Oh, and the dirty dishes weren't cleared when dessert arrived, so we had to stack it and eat around them.  Finally we went up and handed a random person our check with payment. We were asked how it was.  We replied "very long and we sat with dirty dishes for a good part of that".  "Sorry!"  Yah.  $100 check and "Sorry!" Hm.

See here's the thing: Some things they do very well. Pork chop is consistently solid,even without the applesauce.  Chicken dishes were great. Then there is the stuff that is just ... odd.  Some I get are creative choices, but then there's orange marinara and salad without dressing.  The thing is: It's not a cheap meal. They're clearly shooting for a higher end experience. They just don't execute well often enough to give us pause. We MAY be back for dinner.  It's definitely not top-of-list anymore, though. 

Breakfast, by the way, still rocks the house.  Very good, and usually well managed service.  

Frankie's, we want to love you, really.  We are going to have to settle though for just "A-OK".  We like you, we just think you're a little odd and off.

This review has been a long time coming as my husband and I frequent the last drop mostly every weekend for "fancy" coffees aka not keurig. My usual go tos are the cafe mocha or the cappuccino while my husband usually gets an espresso. I knew I liked this place, but after being in Paris for a week and falling in love with the cafe lifestyle, the last drop had a whole new meaning for me. While it's definitely not a Parisian cafe, they have a few seats outside where I tend to sit when I bring my dog for the walk over, and have yummy croissants, bagels and sandwiches if you're looking for more than just coffee. As another reviewer noted, the baristas are not as friendly as say, Starbucks, but I'd rather not have someone in my face while I'm waiting for my coffee to be made. I'll probably be back this Saturday for a cafe mocha...

We decided to try Monell's because I had a hankering for good ole southern food! Got the chicken and dumplings, green beans, and corn casserole with s side of chocolate cake. Loved that there was a healthy serving of chicken. Green  beans was nice and tender, and what's not to love about corn casserole. But that cake! So moist and delicious! Getting in-and-out and parking can be a challenge, but just avoid congested lunch hours.

When we arrived on a Thursday evening around 7, the line was already forming down the street. We were skeptical but turns out this place is absolutely worth the wait! We started with a hurricane each and crawfish hush puppies. These guys were FILLED with crawfish. Just wish the order was larger! My sister, who isn't crazy about oysters, ordered a half dozen of the chargrilled oysters just because of the reviews she had heard about them. Turned out they were her favorite meal of our whole vacation. She loved these! She also had the soup of the day - corn and shrimp bisque. She said it was good but not great. My mom got the crab cake platter - lots of crab with little filler. My dad got a combo with grilled sausage, sausage gumbo, jambalaya and red beans and rice. He enjoyed everything but his favorite was the grilled sausage! For me, the seafood gumbo. It was delicious. Great flavor without being overly salty and had huge chunks of seafood. 

The only reason it's not 5 stars - the drink prices. My hurricane was more than my entree! It's not that the Hurricanes were necessarily expensive at $7 but that price is not in proportion with the food prices.

My sister in-law wanted her birthday dinner to coincide with "Feeling BLUE my twenties are through" theme that offered a fun atmosphere to celebrate with family and friends. 
Besh is a CASINO steakhouse with casual-business-semi-formal attire, moderate to noisy noise level, and expensive wine and foods. 

Tip 1: Children are not permitted. 21 and older and bring a valid photo ID. 
Tip 2: You will not be seated until your entire party arrives. 
Tip 3: The restrooms are not located inside of the restaurant but in the casino area. 
Tip 4: Reservations are preferred especially for large parties. 
Tip 5: Offers valet parking.

We had a pre-set menu $75.00 per person for our party of sixteen that included: * rating below
-House made Natchitoches Meat Pies with buttermilk ranch dressing ***
-Crispy fried Oysters ***
-Besh Barbecue Shrimp ****
Entree
-Pan fried Catfish ***
Topped with shrimp, crab, asparagus, whipped bernaise 
        OR
-14oz. Prime Rib with fries ****
Dessert
Brenden's Bread Pudding ****

I am not a huge fan of fried food so I sampled the meat pies, fried oysters, and barbecue shrimp and they were flavorful. I should have known better than to order anything but steak at a steakhouse. The pan fried catfish was good but had too much going on for my taste. I would have preferred it alone and the toppings on the side. I did have some of my brother's Prime Rib cooked medium well and it was delicious- tender and juicy. The Brenden Bread Pudding was absolutely delicious especially if you love pecans. 

Our server Anthony was friendly and attended to our table as needed. We ended dinner with singing Happy Birthday and indulging in her custom made Blue Dog birthday cake. The chef was gracious enough to slice the cake as many of us were full and took it to go. 

Overall for the price I have had better food but it was a good experience to try at least once. 

Support local business! NOLA
Great hotel with free breakfast and dinner, which I loved! They also offer a cocktail special with free drinks for guests. The location is pretty ideal and the room was nice and comfortable.

Everytime we visit New Orleans, we find something different to do and see in the French Quarter.  The architecture is stunning and never fails to amaze anew.  And the history, oh the history.  Every brick and piece of wood probably could tell a hundred tales.

One 24-hour period over Christmas, for instance, we saw many lovely decorations on various buildings and houses.  We ate at two new (to us) restaurants.  We took a voodoo tour.  We explored Fifi's, a most excellent wig shop.  We got caught up in the aftermath of the Saints' victory celebration.

I will never tire of this place.  Already looking forward to my next visit here.

Fantastic cupcakes.  I tried the Hot Cocoa (marshmallow filled chocolate cake with cocoa buttercream, mini marshmallows and a chocolate straw) and the Vanilla Squared (vanilla cake with vanilla buttercream & colorful sparkling sugar).  Loved them both equally.

I bought 6 intending to split them with someone but was left to all of them by myself over the course of a weekend.  Definitely have to up my cardio next week to make up for this binge.

The store is very clean and spacious with ample seating.  Makes a great place for dessert after shopping, dining or the Movie Tavern.

This was my first time at this location and I can say that I love it. To me, all the In-n-Out's are the same! Not in a bad way of course. More like, every location has great customer service, great food, and great atmosphere. I've also realized that all the locations are built the same. Which is convenient for me, so I don't have to learn where everything is! 

Just like the other location I reviewed, it gets really busy here.

So happy that a place like this exists in Tucson! If you love and appreciate beer you'll find a great selection on tap, insanely vast, beautiful and well-organized sales of beer by the bottle, tasting events, and a friendly, knowledgeable staff. Numero dos on the things I like about T&B list is the fact that I can bring my child in (hallelujah) and he usually finds a friend! There are high counters, tables and the bar (of course) for seating and wine on tap, too. Food option? Whatever truck is parked outside. No outdoor area but with the truck generator going, it's probably no big loss. Close to art galleries and other fun downtown/4th ave. stuff, T&B gets super packed (with hipsters and 20-somethings) at times but remains mellow and chill in the afternoon. Please, oh please, open something more eastward?

I just love Panera, everything is quick and tasty.  Cinnamon crunch bagel w/ hazelnut cream cheese, sausage & gouda quiche, Italian combo sandwich, baked potato soup... the list goes on.  My oh my I think I'm salivating.

Panera is just one of those staple places where you know you can go and get a fresh, comfort meal.  Perhaps I feel this way because it was the grab-and-go location of choice for my family growing up, but I just know I can always rely on Panera to provide healthier options than other quick food places.  I love the Fuji Apple Chicken salad, but also am a fan of the seasonal mediterranean salad.  You can't really go wrong with the soups.  The chicken noodle, chicken and wild rice, and tomato are my favorites.  I also love the bakery selections.  The large chocolate chip cookies are always a solid choice and my husband is a big fan of the cherry pastries.  I was able to work for a bit on my laptop today next to a fire they had going in the dining area which was perfect for in between events!

Time capsule, time capsule! Syrenka Luncheonette's decor is first what will strike you as you walk in the door. It's shades of brown and 70's all over. This is some real back in time stuff here.  

A la carte or platter prices are listed up on the old school Coca Cola menu board. Polish specialties are served cafeteria style from warming trays, but not by stereotypical lunch ladies by any means; beautiful stylish Polish ladies have been behind the counter at our every visit. There lies the only real evidence that we're not grubbin in '77 or so...

Maybe prices have gone up a bit since the 70's, but damn do we get a tray full of good eatin' for the both of us together for under fifteen dollas. I'm sayin, we have made animals outta ourselves splitting: the golabki, kielbasy, bigos, mashed beets, an order of pierogi, and two drinks...all for fourteen seventy somethin? Good deally.

If you want your order of pierogi fried (they're cooked after you order), you'll have to order them that way with onions and sour cream, if you wannem. I forgot to order them fried, so I was initially a little disappointed when I realized my omission and the potato and cheese dumplings were served only boiled and buttery, but when getting down to eating them, I didn't really miss the crisp.  In this state they went so well with the buttery, sweet and earthy mashed beets. I'm repeating the word, "buttery," cause there's a lot of this happenin here. We've repeatedly ordered that buttery buttery combo again. 

The porky sauerkrauty hunter's stew that is bigos was pretty good, not my most favorite bigos ever, but obviously went well with the kielbasy, it did. Definitely dug the giant golabki- tender cabbage leaves stuffed with rice and beef... tasty, tasty stuff in tangy tomato sauce. I loves golabki, and that's a good one. 

On subsequent visits we've enjoyed mushroom soup and some potato pancakes (tasty but greasy), too. 

All in all, I'd say that Syrenka's is A-OK all the way: Tasty, hearty food for good prices is the key. I dig this time capsule of a Polish cafeteria. 
Butt-buuh-butttery time capsule, time capsule!

I stayed at Silver Legacy so many times it's ridiculous. I love the rooms and the front desk staff for the most part has always been amazing. I feel safe staying here especially when going to the elevator to get to my my room as they have security The makes sure your suppose to be there. Nothing wrong with that in my book hotel should really do this to prevent seedy character from roaming around.

 They have many restaurants my favorite being Sterlings they have an amazing Sunday Brunch with all the delicious fixings..lol. They also have Flavor's Buffet which is just okay and another that l can't remember the name.

 My last stay here was quite lack luster though. I stayed here with a few friends and family. My first room I checked into the air didn't work, so I was put in another room this time the TV didn't work and the toilet didn't flush. They placed me in another room no problem. They upgraded me and everything was great until I get back to my room to go to sleep at 2:30am. Around 3:20am I hear the people next door to me fighting and I don't mean just yelling back and front like it was physical. I hear the man screaming for help and telling his ole lady to stop hitting him she was out of control the walls banging etc.. I call the front desk they send security up immediately to remove the woman. Front text comp'd my first night for the inconvenience which was nice. They following day they put me in a even a better room " Spa Room" which was a very kind even though I never asked to be moved, but hey! I was going to be here a few more nights.

 I would have given 5 stars but, after checking out and my bank calling me 2 days after I checked out of Silver Legacy they charged my card 2 extra nights after checkout. I called and they front desk manager fixed right away and apologized.

Well, how surprising for the good!!! My kids and I have a ritual where once in a great while we will drive until we hit somewhere we know nothing about and where none of us has been.  I am glad to say this is the place!!!!! YUM!
We drove down Grant Road and this is where we ended up.  We ordered crab puffs, Chinese egg rolls, the beef pho, chicken pho, and my son ordered rice with chicken. Pork, and shrimp in it.  My daughter and i's pho was delicious!! My daughter could not stop commenting on how great the broth is and I happen to agree!
The rice(com) was so lovely.  The rice wasn't overly greasy and light and yet perfectly cooked.  The crab puffs I liked because it wasn't heavy and they were petite.  My daughter, Zoie, loved the Chinese egg rolls were crisp and vegetarian.  
This place is a whole in the wall but it is the real deal.  We are stoked to have found this place.  Just remember truly hole in the wall.  And here is the overall thing to sum it up: Yum!!!!!!!

There is just something so comforting about Cracker Barrel!  The food does taste like your grandmother made it!
Tonight I ordered the country plate with ham, green bean and mashed potatoes - my favorite!   Mt husband ordered the roast beef dinner & he got 3 sides with his!  No complaints at all about the yummy food!
The service left a little to be desired.  We had to hunt her down for drink refills. 
Let's not forget the cornbread & biscuits!  We actually save them for last and eat them with jam or apple butter.....a great dessert!
Of course we have to stop & look in the gift shop.  I love all the nostalgia!   We couldn't resist buying a tin of Duets.  Great old fashioned candy!

Good food, friendly people, homemade tortillas, great prices, and some unique menu items. I regret not stopping sooner. 

For a recent dinner we had a lengua taco (not bad), a shrimp taco (delicious sauce and homemade slaw), a pork belly taco (not bad, but it was tender cubes of pork. I  was expecting a slab.) and I simply had to try the pork rind taco (yum!).

My companion had the asada burrito and loved it. The sauce, cheese, rice, and perfectly marinated steak combined with the homemade tortilla was a winner.

We will be going back without a doubt.

Soho Juice has the best acai bowls I've ever had. I live in a bigger city than St. Pete and thought I'd find a better place there, but I haven't. So I make sure to stop by Soho Juice when I'm in St. Pete. 

I think the Cloud 9 bowl is particularly good and unique, although I have enjoyed all the ones I've tried. You may think the price is a little high for the large size, but it's a large serving, you can eat half and put the rest in the freezer for another time. 

I'm glad they also serve toast to provide a little variety. Also love that it's easy to get vegan food here!

You cannot beat the service here! It is a bit on the pricey side but with all of the attention to detail, style and service, you will get your money worth. I have been several times and loved everything I purchased. I even had them add some patches to one slick denim vest I got as a gift (that also purchased here) and they did a great job at a fair price. 

It is a cool shop to wonder through even if not buying right away. I have also seen one of the owners, Beau, offering plenty of good local advice on places to go and eat to interested visitors. Great business and SB ambassadors!! We will be back for sure.

If they build them, I will eat there. This Chipotle is one of the larger ones that I have been to. There is plenty of sitting and on nicer weather there is a patio outside to eat at. The menu is simple and straight to the point. I love the fact that even though it seems like the menu has few items, the number of yummy Gluten Free options in which I can chose from. This Chipotle also has three adult beverages, beer, patron, and some sort of margarita. 

All and all, the staff was friendly, the food was good, and I can eat here. I will definitely find my way back here to satisfy my Chipotle fix.

I have a problem.

I have been thinking about the vegetable samosas from Desi Chaat House a lot.  It is causing a serious interruption in my daily functioning.

Sometimes I will be in the middle of a conversation and I will pretend to get a call so that I can go outside, hail a cab, and go to Desi Chaat house for the samosas.  I return, sometimes an hour later, and attempt to continue the conversation as if nothing had happened.  My friends think I'm on drugs and my girlfriend is accusing me of having an affair but they don't know how much I love these samosas.

But Brad, why not introduce these people to Desi Chaat house?  

The answer is simple, hypothetical question-asker...it is because I am a man who's mind is rife with delusional paranoia.  I fear that my friends and loved ones, knowing my weakness, will buy out the samosas before I am able to get to the restaurant and they will sell them to me at ridiculous markups.  Like a hopeless addict, I will be enslaved to the wills of those I once trusted. 

Illogical? yes.  Impossible?  Nope.

...ok back to reviewing.

When you order them, they will offer to pour chickpeas over them.  Let them do this.  

The best way I could describe the chaat is...wacky.  It is a peculiar mix of sweet, spicy, creamy, and aromatics.  I've had the vegetable samosa and mumbai chaat and both are good.

The chicken roll and lamb roll make an excellent lunch.  The meat is tender and seasoned extremely well.  I highly recommend these items.  For a very vegetarian-leaning culture, India sure makes some excellent meat dishes.

On top of it all, the staff is ridiculously friendly and always asking for feedback on how they can improve.  It is tasty, inexpensive, unique, and has the best veggie samosas in Philadelphia.

Note: I like veggie samosas a lot more than most people so bear that in mind when you consider this review.

I don't have one bad thing to say on my first visit. Friendly server, not crowded, loved my food and coffee was good. Had the BLT eggs Benedict. It was wonderful, not drenched in Hollandaise, but a nice lemony arugula, perfect egg, crisp bacon and delicious toasted bread. They have calories listed on menu, which is helpful, as well. This is a great kept secret in Green Hills! Will be back!

Have you ever heard of that clothing line called "Young, Fabulous and Broke"?
The funny thing about that clothing line is that it's actually freakin' expensive.  If you are young, fabulous and broke there's no way in hell you'd be able to afford it.
If you fit this criteria you should instead go promptly to Ziezo.
I have loved this store since I first became a budding fashionista.
I don't shop nearly as much as I used to when I was in high school, but I popped in the other day before seeing a movie at the Tivoli.
Their selection is still edgy, very contemporary, well priced, FUN, and different.  They have things that I just don't find in other places.
I think of the boring rounds that I have taken at the Galleria and am kicking myself for not coming back to Ziezo.  Well, now I remember it's there and will be coming back for sure!

coming from an Arab, Aloosh has the best middle eastern food in philly so far! I love the atmosphere, i love the food and the hookah is pretty good! Im not a huge fan of hookah bars, due to prices and the food is usually mediocre, not at Aloosh! Also try the hummus with beef, to die for!

Folks, how many of you are tired of the same mass-produced sausages and deli meats from the big supermarkets? 

I was searching for an authentic alternative to the fake-smoked selections of sausages I normally have to settle for, and found this small gold mine in Berry Hill that's tucked back in a little plaza on Thompson Lane across from Guitar Center. This place is really small, but the unique selections of ethnic deli meats and sausages makes this place a monster of the midway!

The sausages at Aleksey's are genuinely smoked, and you'll find several European and Russian meat products to choose from. They take pride in their especially large deli selection, and I guarantee you won't find familiar name brand products in this meat case. I've had to ask what many of these meats are, and these folks are very friendly and willing to assist and educate you.

Today I asked for salami and tried a recommended spicy selection, and it was outstanding! I would love to try one of everything just to educate my palette! They carry a nice selection of canned goods and other non-perishables that you would expect to find in international markets, and they do it in a pretty small space. I want to reiterate that it's the ethnic meat selection that's the star of the show!

Markets like this are what you would normally find in multinational communities like NYC, and we're very fortunate to have a place like Aleksey's in the Nashville area. Please stop by and give these folks the opportunity to introduce you to a whole new world of ethnic flavors!

"You HAVE family in Santa Barbara that I don't know about?!"

My husband was shocked. 

That's how you keep it interesting and fresh! who says you stop discovering things about each other once you're married? ;-)

To be honest, I've been a bad cousin. No matter how many times we've gone down to SoCal, I've never really made it a point to connect with my long lost cousin. (it's been a decade!) 

Fast forward to last weekend when he recommended Los Agaves. We arrived first with my parents and were welcomed with a very PACKED and noisy Saturday night atmosphere. It was self explanatory: fall in line, order at the counter, grab your utensils and sit yourself at a free table. We needed assistance since there were 6 of us.

We only waited a short while until they showed up and it was quite the reunion! We kept ourselves busy while waiting for our food, stuffing our faces with the fresh made chips and varieties of salsa. You're a spice wuss? good luck. Even the most "mild" salsa has a pretty good kick to it. I'm def a wuss (wah, wah) but the green avocado salsa was thick and had a nice flavor to it, that I couldn't stop at just one chip!

Soon after, the real party came: massive steak burrito mojado ($10.95), several tacos del mar ($13.50) and grilled chicken fajitas ($16.25). I really loved the sweet mangoes that topped my fish tacos and that chipotle sauce worked its magic! All plates come with a nice heaping of Mexican rice and side salad. My mom and husband enjoyed their margaritas, but declared that the blood orange margarita had a better taste than the regular one. I was just jealous, since I couldn't partake because of lent :(

Los Agaves gave us a pleasant experience and definitely lived up to its reputation as an upscale Mexican restaurant. I love the generous portions too! I'm curious to try one of their Molcajetes next time I'm in Santa Barbara and I wouldn't let another 10 years pass by before I see my cousin again.

Overall I really like this Whole Foods Market. It is not as large as some of their other stores, such as the amazing mega WFM in Oxnard, but also not as tiny as the store in Hillcrest for my SD friends out there. 

I love going to the Buzz Hive, an intimate bar with great beer and wine selections, food made to order and large TVs that play most of the popular sporting events. 

Whole Foods is one of my go to markets for vitamin & herbal supplements and natural, organic beauty products. For my curly-haired guys and gals, they carry the incomparable, Kinky Curly line of hair products that will make even the tightest and most unruly of curls look defined, soft and amazing. 

I also enjoy ordering fish from the Seafood Dept and having them prepare it for me on my lunch or dinner breaks. They have some wonderful seasoning options. I recommend Tilapia (Blackened) and Shrimp (Grilled w/ Garlic Butter), mmm! On Fridays, fresh Oysters are only a $1 per piece and they'll shuck them for you. I love to order a dozen and take them over to the Buzz Hive to enjoy with a glass of white wine. 

The cheese shop is incredible. So many great frommages to choose from. Don't be shy about asking the staff for recommendations and/or samples. They are pros and generally are happy to oblige. Here's a pro tip: Look for the little basket in the cheese section for the ends and pieces of cheese. You can find some fabulous high end cheeses at perfect portions for one or two people that are very reasonably priced. I like to buy a few and take them on a picnic or to the Buzz Hive to enjoy with a big, bold red. 

I could go on and on but I don't want to spoil the fun of you discovering all the cool things about this location. 

Why not four stars? Sometimes customer service can be a miss. There have been less than cordial staff at the juice bar and in the meat dept, who strangely I haven't seen working there in a while so perhaps the problem has resolved itself, who really put a damper on the shopping experience. Also, I have heard that Whole Foods has a stellar return policy, however, the one time that I sought to use it to seek an exchange and/or refund for being given an entirely different pizza than we ordered with an ingredient that I am allergic to (Hubs didn't check the inside of the box before he got home. We called and the pizza dept said to let the manager know the next time that we were there) - we did and the manager at the front desk refused to honor it. Bummer. We've never ordered pizza from WF since and that was over two years ago. 

Other than that, it's a great market and we shop there regularly. If anyone at corporate is reading, a second location on the Eastside would thrive! With customers coming from Montecito, the Riviera, Downtown, the Funk Zone and the Eastside - I think it would be a hit! Check out the space where Fresh Market used to be on Milpas Street.

I love trying out new spots.  I've been here twice, once for drinks, once for dinner.  There's a lot of good beer here, some with prices from reasonable to outrageous.  Still, the selection gives you options no matter what your goal is, from sipping at heavy stout to drinking cheap pounders.  I really liked that they give you a pint glass even when you order can beer.  

There is a nice, long wooden bar which is the best spot at The Blind Pig.  They have a few TVs, and this is a good place to catch the Phillies.  There's also outdoor seating, which is fantastic if the weather cooperates.  

The food menu is standard; average.  There is nothing that jumps out, although lots of people rave about the Thanksgiving balls: deep fried turkey and mash potatoes served with gravy.  

There was one special that I was intrigued by: Alligator sausage.  It was a 70-30 blend made with pork, and the meat was delicious and flavorful, like a more gamey chorizo.  It was served on a small white roll with a salad on the side.  The bread was terrible.  Is it too much to ask for Amaroso or Sarcone in Philadelphia?  The salad was okay; forgettable.  

Emily ordered a beat salad and wasn't thrilled either.  The menu, overall, just seems to have little or no effort.  The service was ok, but not on par with other spots I usually visit.

Bottom Line: I like the can beer selection, even if some are overpriced.  The draft list offers good options, but the food is nothing special.  The Blind Pig needs to find it's niche to survive, because right now, there is not much going on.  Nothing bad either, but that's usually not enough.

I love this place so much! Definitely one of my favorite places to get salad on Temple's campus. The owner is a Temple grad, and most of the food is locally sourced. I always order a create your own salad, I.T is a little expensive. However, I believe the price is worth I.T as the food is local and absolutely delicious! The wait time for food is fast, and is always awesome. I love coming here!

I write this review because I am terrified that this place will disappear, as many of my other favorite places close to work tend to do. First of all, I can't believe it took me this long to discover it. Even though I've only eaten here twice, it was twice in one day, so take that for what it's worth. 

To say the menu is extensive is an understatement - everyone in my party, both times I went, was able to find something to eat and enjoy (some after a great deal of debate), including a 10-year-old.  The bánh mì was exceedingly fresh; the sushi was excellent, hard to beat at its 2 for $10.95 price, and the presentation was lovely (try the Valentine roll to see what I mean).

I did learn that I can't eat in regularly for lunch as the service is slow for lunch standards, but they do offer takeout. Subway is right next door, but with a sandwich like their bánh mì, I don't foresee any further need for Subway on my quick lunches.

When five separate people all told me I had to try Village Whiskey in Philadelphia, I knew this place had to be something. And I was right! If you love whiskey, this is your spot. It's a bit small, but I've been back twice and lucked out with a barstool every time.

We started off with the whiskey flights, there's three options, we went with the Rickhouse and were quite satisfied. I've had the Village Burger, and it's a good burger, but it won't rewrite your universe. What might, are the duck-fat fries. I live in a different city also known for fantastic food, and as much as I've scoured, we do not have fries cooked in duck-fat. I should open a food truck and serve them, because they are amazing!

Finally, there's a huge menu of whiskies. Try the Redbreast if you need a place to start. Any time I've ordered it, the bartender has always been impressed. 

Next time I'm in Philly, I'm definitely headed back to Village Whiskey.

Curtis says he can't find anything to complain about and I totally agree.  We always come to La Pagode, especially when we are craving their Beef Satay soup.  The mix of flavors in that wonderfully made soup keeps us coming back for more.  We also love their Ginger Beef; forget the rice (which you can order) we just want the beef.  The Deep Fried Squid is also awesome.  The best thing to do is oder many different items and share them with friends and family; the portions are pretty big and you'll have trouble finishing it off by yourself.  We even have trouble finishing off our soup bowls, which happen to be the size of our heads.  It's a great place to get together with the people you care about and catch up over lots of good food.  The menu is pretty big and that can be a little overwhelming only because everything sounds so good.  Curtis and I were waiting for our soup one day and we were looking at the take-out menu; listing off all the different dishes we haven't tried yet made us so hungry.  Oh and if you want to order any appetizers the spring rolls, green onion cakes and the deep fried shrimp rolls are super good.  If you want to come to La Pagode I suggest you not eat for days so that you can eat a lot of really good food when your at the restaurant, or come with a large party and try a bit of everyones food.

My bf and I were regulars at this place for YEARS! We loved it! We probably ate there at least every other weekend!  It was our favorite spot from the time it first came to Cherry Hill until we broke up, about 6 years ago. Tried to go there with other people and recapture the magic... but it just wasn't there. (Could have been the company I was with... I don't know!) LOL Anyway, The place had fallen off CONSIDERABLY, and was mediocre at best.

Fast forward to 2010... well, my bf and I have reconciled. Decided to go back to the Silver Diner and see if things had improved any. Sadly, no. It's as if they just stopped caring. 

They still have their Crabcake melts which are actually SCRUMPTIOUS. Their fries are pretty good, and I never had a bad coke there yet. I think the place just feels LAZY to me, like everyone in there is in need of a nap or is just waking from one. It's just a nonchalant, half-assed effort.. none of the energy of the first few years after it opened.

Granted, it could be ME. My tastes have changed a lot over the years. I'll be fair and give them a 3. If you had asked me about 6 years ago, I would have said a 4 or possibly a 5.

Still an ok place to go while  you're waiting for your movie to start at Loews.

a solid 4.5 stars 

i was meeting a few friends for cocktails and conshohocken was the convenient midway point. upon a trusted recommendation, the gypsy saloon was where we found ourselves.

tucked away on a hilly side street in west conshohocken, we walked into a warm and cozy, dimly-lit adorable little spot with a heck of a lot of ambiance and were immediately greeted by a gracious and gorgeously wonderful woman, who we later learned was the owner, Kim. after finding out it was our first time in, she led us to the bar and set us up with a round of drinks on the house...completely unnecessary but so very nice. they offer decent wines by the glass and consistently generous pours...i hate a place that is stingy with their wine. there looked to be decent beers on tap as well.

we were standing near the bar trying to maneuver jackets-purses-wineglasses all while staying out of the way of the waitstaff, when a really nice gentleman offered us the empty seat at his table for our use. we struck up a conversation with him and his table mates and were soon laughing and chatting, nothing like talking about rufies to break the ice...point being, that the patrons here were very relaxed and friendly...everyone was having a lovely time and enjoying themselves...great vibe. when a few seats opened up at the bar, again, easy conversation flowed with the people seated next to us.

when Kim explained to us how everything on the menu is made to order, we decided to have a bite to eat and were able to snag a table  - shout out to Heather who was lovely and took great care of us. 

we ordered a few small plates - the blue cheese flatbread with roasted red grapes and caramelized onions was really delicious; the eggplant rollatini was perfectly tender and delicate; the calamari served with sliced banana peppers and a side of chili basil aioli was fantastic and addictive.

Kim made it a point to stop by the table and check in with us - of course we raved and she graciously offered us dessert, again on the house; again, completely unnecessary, but so very appreciated...notice a pattern here?

all in all, i think we found a sweet spot in west conshie...we'll be back, gypsy

The pies here are amazing and the staff was so helpful.

I needed to buy a couple mini pies for Pi Day in March. I ordered everything over the phone, which was fast and easy. When I arrived the morning of Pi Day to pick them up, everything was ready and waiting for me. Each pie was individually wrapped and labeled and put into carriers to keep them in place.

We had everything from apple to chess to peach. My office loved them and I'd definitely use them again for any pies I wanted to buy. Great local bakery.

Great deli, ordered the tongue special. Loaded with thin slices of tender tongue, slaw, cheese and thousand island dressing on rye bread. They offer either seeded or unseeded rye which is nice since I love rye but not caraway. I stopped by on a weekday at lunch time so was able to snag a spot in their shared lot and the line wasn't too bad. 

They do carry a lot of cool and tasty specialty groceries. In the back they also  have a great selection of craft beers. Not the biggest selection but a very well thought out one.

Originally built in 1929, the restored historic Lovett Barn is now home to a trattoria that caters to homemade Italian cuisine. http://www.lastallarestaurant.com/menus/lastalla_dinner_menu.pdf

The pasta's and sauces are homemade, the prices are a little on the high side.  The dinner menu priced for two, can be split in half for one and add $3.00.  The clams casino are very good and seasoned perfectly with red pepper, onion and bacon.  

The Marsala dishes are exceptional, with your choice of chicken or veal.  They offer a large list of ways to have your chicken or veal, like Francese, parmigiano, saltimbocca and so on.

The choices of pasta entrees could drive you insane, you name it, they make it.  The choices for both lunch and dinner is a wide selection from the appetizers to the salads and the great variety of entrees.  The antipasto choices are more than most Italian restaurants offer.

Check them out at and while visiting their site, check out their calendar for discounts and half price bottle of wine nights.  They serve a Sunday buffet which is a great and tasty value.

LOVE THIS PLACE!! I have been to In N Out countless times, I should probably just set up a tent in the parking lot. I usually get a cheeseburger with EXTRA grilled onions and lettuce :) ooohhh boy IS THIS BURGER DELICIOUS! I also order the animal style fried with extra grilled onions and extra thousand island sauce. What do they put into this spread? It's seriously so addicting, I can literally put this spread on my ramen and it would still be tasty! Love this place, would come back again. like today. and tomorrow. and the next day. and the next day. and so on.

We had an excellent experience at this location! 

I'm particularly found of the downtown location, so I never thought to look to see if there were other locations near me. Turns out, there is! This is a fairly new location, opened December of 14' I believe. 

Same menu as downtown with all your favs like The Shewman (Peanut butter on your burger? Yes. It's awesome.) I was a little crestfallen to see that the beer selection was, in my opinion, a little limited in brew house standards, but we each found a beer to love and pair with our burgers. 

The restaurant itself was very clean. A decent sized parking lot is also a huge plus. It's a little tucked away behind some other businesses, so unless you knew it was there you might not see it. 

I'm grateful to have this gem on the Southside and look forward to meeting many a friends here!

We haven't been this pleasantly surprised in a while! Cute little historic place in this town that has been recently re-invested in. New condos next door, people walking around outside. Nice little town. The inn overlooks the river which you can enjoy. Nice outside seating, live music outside. We didn't know they had outdoor seating so we sat in the tavern and ordered a late lunch. Everyone here was friendly and I honestly didn't expect the food to be as fresh and delicious as it was! We ordered the fish and chips - fish was tender and fresh, perfectly crusted and fried with no oily residue, the portobello mushroom sandwich - had hummus, goat cheese and baby arugula on ciabatta bread -delicious! And the BLT salad - I am a bacon lover and it has sufficient bacon sprinkled all over the edge salad, succulent blue cheese and a homemade blue cheese dressing. Enjoyed every bite annnd tried everyone else's order - we all enjoyed lunch and would definitely be back! Highly recommend!

I've driven by this place since it was built (2005), and I've never stopped.  "Wings and Rice" struck me as an odd combination, and the name is uninspiring - it's kind of like having a sandwich shop called "Sandwiches." But, I'm glad I got lunch there last week.  This is a hidden gem!
