I got ten wings (spicy teriyaki and spicy Italian), and a huge order of fried rice.  Everything was excellent.

Something I love about the wings is that they're meaty, but not too fatty.  Some wings places (Buffalo WW - I'm looking at you) have really fatty wings.  These are just right and perfectly cooked.  The sauces were a bit bland, so I'll try other flavors next time.

They also have cheesesteak sandwiches and egg rolls!  Lots more to try out, but I'll definitely be back for the wings.

I should state that I do try to buy local, a lot. I love Summit Hut. I also love REI. Both are different. Both offer me the things I need. I make huge purchases at SH and I also buy from REI. I love both. 

I am a co-op member of REI and like to purchase things especially with their very cool 20% off coupons and outlet store discounts. I've even attended some REI bike and GPS free. classes. I enjoy browsing REI even if I don't always buy because they have so many goodies. I am an avid outdoors person and the gadgets and trinkets they offer make me want to set up a survival camp in the wild and live off the land- REI can make that possible. They can also just get your water bottles for a day hike or nice clothing for anytime of the season. They have a bike repair service. And REI has an amazing return policy. 

"REI = Return Everything Indeed." Well no, it doesn't mean that. But if you attend one of the REI yard sales they have, you'll see that they do take back everything and often can turn around and sell it. I bought an REI tent once, was unhappy with the condensation it produced (akin to a sweat bath) and they offered ideas to make it work until I just had it returned, full refund. 

I find the prices high but manageable if you have a coupon. And the co-op membership means a yearly dividend.. As my outdoor needs increase, I am so glad for so much outdoorsy shops in Tucson to help me with my passion.

The first time I came here I wasn't a fan as the sandwiches lacked a bit of flavor, but that was a few years ago and things have definitely changed. I've been here several more times now and it is actually very good. The bread is soft and a little crusty on the outside, the meat portions are nice, and the flavors are great. My only gripe is that you get charged extra for peppers, mushrooms, etc. Kind of a small issue really but it adds up quickly on your bill. They do have pepperoncinis and sweet peppers at the table though which I personally love. Service is always friendly and reasonably fast.

When you randomly come across the legendary Baby Badness smoking a cigar outside of an interesting looking Rittenhouse Square bar, you instantly have to stop in and find out out what they're about. Especially when she was hospitable enough to honor McThrill Rule #347 (http://www.yelp.com/biz/mexican-post-philadelphia-2?hrid=B0Xyx41uJbg_Vc3JEYUSKg#src:self). And when upon entry you discover a bar & restaurant with impeccable exposed brick wall, a solid cocktail & draft beer menu, that is also a cheese lovers paradise that's operated by some experienced mongers, you succeed in finding divine paradise.

I only give the low end of 4.5 stars for now because finding the chance to savor menu items like a cheeseburger with bone marrow and Cabot cloth bound cheddar, a foie gras with potato asparagus salad and a sherry vinegar syrup, and Georgia shrimp on a bed of hand made fettuccine will elevate it higher (and that's not even with factoring the incredible sounding brunch items!). 

But what I did find was an impeccable cheese plate selection that's organized by a monger extraordinaire who has a background in working with Le Bec Fin and Per Se. And they even have the classic Le Bec Fin cheese cart which was a gift to them tfrom Chef Perrier! For us it delivered grand offerings like St. Angel, Scharfer Max, Selles Sur Cher, and Bonne Bouche. But between the extensive knowledge of both Michael and Alex, you're bound to be treated to something impressive.

add in a plentiful assortment of classic and new school cocktails, a solid selection of wines, and a solid list of bottled and draft beers that are noteworthy even if they are a touch overpriced, and you have a Rittenhouse Square hot spot that's worthy of a visit!

I recently discovered Halo Farms a few weeks back during one of our weekend trips on the way back from Hoagie Haven. My buddy, Joe was a long time fan telling me about the halo pub (Still haven't gone yet.) and noted it was on the way back- suffice to say we stopped by and I absolutely loaded up. Since my first, I've been back 2-3 times and have slowly made my way through most of their drink offerings, and a number of their pints as well.

Let me start by saying, i absolutely love just about everything I've had from Halo, some things ive had better of, but some, there's no comparison- (Two words: Chocolate milk, if you've had better, you'd best DM me the details so i can go try some for myself- because my first experience with it was orgasmic- I was a blind man seeing for the first time.) But even the most "meh" drink, cant be argued with, fact of the matter is halo is damn good for what it is, and is ridiculously cheap, while also being far healthier putting equivalent offerings (Especially in its price bracket.)

As stated above, the chocolate milk is to die for, literally, the look on my face after we were driving away me tearing into it for the first time had Joe busting a gut, its a miracle we didn't crash- me sitting there like an 8 year old with a school carton just absorbing a quarter gallon of milk going "JOSEPH WHY HAVE YOU BEEN HOLDING OUT ON ME" its less than 2.50 per half gallon and is in earnest the best chocolate milk I've ever had.

For their normal milk, i opted for their 4% which was extremely creamy, a bit healthier than equivalent milk, but no life-changing experience- still good, and a decent price for what it is.

Their Apple Cider is better than their juice, and both are priced roughly the same, apple juice is still quite good, and packed with a decent amount of nutrition, great good cheap stuff as per usual.

Orange juice was okay, same deal, nothing to write home about, but really decent, and cheap to boot.

Aides had some low points- Fruit punch is fantastic, orangeaide was quite good. Easyaide, which was also orange, was underwhelming- like a more watery version of the regular orange. Grape was middle of the road, okay but if def had better. and Lemonaide really depends on your preference, this is some hardcore fresh squeeze tasting stuff, very tart- perfect if your into that, me personally? Im a giant sourpuss when it comes to sweet vs tart- but its still quite good even if not my preference and i still finished it the day of.

Their iced tea is decent as well- and competitively priced the same as the aide's 89 cents, its very similar to icy tea, which is a little bit more expensive- couldn't say which I prefer.|

The Ice Creams were a weird experience for me, ive tried Butter Pecan, Cookies and Cream, Normal Vanilla (Which is really Bourbon), Taihetian Vanilla, Choco-Peanutbutter, and Peanutbutter (Vanilla + peanutbutter). I question myself saying this right now, but i honestly feel like the toppings or twists on these take away from the ice cream themselves, the original vanilla was the best of the bunch. Not a fan of the peanut butter used in both variants, rest was middling.

All in all Halo Farms is a fantastic cheap alternative for drink options, while also providing higher nutritional value compared to alternatives, the one downside of this is the lack of preservatives- meaning there's a lot more urgency in getting items to the fridge than usual.

Flavor & Presentation 4.5/5   |   Service & Speed 4/5   |   Price & Proportion  5/5

Overall 4.5/5

Legitimate hotpot here in Goleta. Amazing flavors and good service. The only thing that's a little off are the prices, but there's only a few other places to get hotpot and they're all similar in price.

Ordered the Szechuan lamb hotpot and the flavor of the broth was authentic, full of flavor and the classic numbingness. 

For hotpot lovers, this is the place to be. For someone that's never had hotpot before, try it here.

Congrats to Ash & Elm on their gorgeous new space. My husband and I stopped to check out their new digs and were seriously impressed. We got a flight of ciders and all were really good (favorite was Olmo, a "dry, tart, and lively" cider). We also got a snack of the latkes with lox - these were terrific! Crispy potato pancakes with smoked salmon and a creamy dill sour cream. Our server, Jaclyn, was so friendly and nice. We love this place and will return anytime we're in the area.

I absolutely love the concept for Depot! It's in a gorgeous building, and I fell in love with the interior as soon as I walked in. We were seated upstairs near the window. It was a great atmosphere to start off a meal with! 

We started off with a couple of brews and an order of poutine. We were not disappointed! My amber ale was perfection. I couldn't have asked for anything more. The rotisserie chicken was pretty good overall. It was moist and seasoned well, but didn't blow me away. 

Whether you're looking to grab a drink after work, eating with a group of friends, or looking to have casual date, The Depot is great for any occasion!

VIP grand opening!

OK, I will not go into great detail about the food, since this was a grand opening, so they were just serving selected samples.  Good ribs, good pizza, some decent flatbreads.  The rest of the food was so-so, but do know that this was being prepared for a large number of people, and their full menu is varied and looks interesting.

The space itself is gorgeous -- much more "upscale" than I anticipated.  The bar is lovely, and their beers are brewed on the spot (although some were a little bitter).  The outdoor seating area is small, but really, really lovely.  Waitstaff was super-friendly and helpful -- seemed proud of what they were serving.

This should do very well downtown.

When in beautiful Nashville, this is a place you must try! I love it! We went on a Saturday morning and enjoyed the nice view that surrounded this place! Let's just say you have to be willing to wait to enjoy this place, we had to wait about an hour to get in but it was well worth it. Try the sweet potato pancakes! The bacon for me was a little burned but maybe it was just a bad batch? I didn't want to risk getting butt bacon so I just dealt with it. Other than that the place is crowded and just a typical pancake house setting. The service was excellent! Southern Hospitality at its best!

After enjoying the Maplewood coffee crawl, we ended our morning with a late brunch at Schlafly.  

We opted to sit outside and enjoy the wonderful spring air under their tent covered patio, it was great to finally get some good weather after such a rainy week.

They have a brunch menu, but sometimes you feel like an egg and sometimes you don't.  Today I didn't and the only other brunch items were biscuits or waffles.  The Hummus appetizer caught my eye, partially because of the kalamata olives and I love hummus.  The hubby went for their Eggs Your Way with seasoned potatoes and an English muffin, for just $5!  

Our service was great and the food came out fast.  The hubby's plate looked just like I expected, he enjoyed it.  Mine was a generous portion of fresh made hummus, so much better than anything you could ever buy in the store, topped with feta, kalamata olives and red onions served with curry crackers and flatbread pita.  The hummus was very good, a little salty but good.  The flatbread was awesome!  So soft and warm and went together great with their hummus.  I wasn't too keen on the curry crackers.

I need to go back for beer soon, the Perry Cider sounded good and they have their seasonal Raspberry Hefeweizen on tap too!

Spent the day in Dunedin and while window shopping down Main Street we stumbled across this location of Strachen's. My siblings and parents frequent the Palm Harbor location and rave about it. Specifically the yummy yummy sauce. Spotting this location we had to stop and try something. 

The ice cream is homemade and they have a huge variety of flavors to choose from. They also have sundaes, floats, shakes and desserts. My daughter and I are chocolate ice cream fans so it was a kiddie cup of chocolate ice cream for her and a waffle bowl of chocolate ice cream for me... I went out on a limb and added the yummy yummy sauce I've heard so much about. 

If you happen to have your 4 legged friend with you, which we did, with every purchase you can get a doggie ice cream cone. The dog loved his pooch sized cone which was plain vanilla soft serve on a small wafer cone. 

The human ice cream was smooth and perfectly chocolate. The yummy yummy sauce was like caramel and butterscotch got married and the result was yummy yummy sauce. Both of us finished every last bite. Next time we're on Main Street we know where to go for dessert!

I never knew a tofu wrap could taste so good. 

My friend told me about how good their "chicken" burgers were at this vegetarian spot. But as I was browsing through the menu, I was looking for something more light , so I opted for the wrap. It was a curried tofu wrap, but what I loved about it was the creamy white bean puree spread they used. It balanced out the curry and was a match made in veggie heaven. 

I also got the BFG drink and it was a super refreshing smoothie . Not too sweet and green - which is what I was craving at the moment. I thought it was kind of expensive, but I felt like I was paying for quality , which was definitely met! 

I'd definitely return for a quick lunch again, next time I'm in Philly

I was introduced to this buffet by a mutual friend fellow yelper.  First of all the price is amazing!!! Second of all the food is fantastic!!! I love the fact that they have an okay sushi bar on top of their hibachi grill and then their buffet lines.  They have everything from raw oysters, cocktail shrimp, fried catfish, American choices, ice cream and amazing other mini desserts like the strawberry cheesecake cups.  
The service here is actually fantastic they are wonderful about making sure dirty plates are promptly removed and always keep the drinks filled.
I would have to say the only major things that they need assistance with is their bathrooms and caution signs hah.  Their bathrooms have been dirty every time if have ever been.  Always go to the potty before going to the restaurant.  Also, their pop machine is right near the bathroom entrance and there is never a caution wet sign, my little guy busted his bottom there.  Just be very cautious around the pop machines.  All minor compared to the quality of the food and service!!! This is my go to cheap Chinese Buffett!!!!!!!!

The wine? Good. The tasting room? Chaotic and small with the feel of my grandmothers home.

Saturday busy with kids and dogs running amuck. The dogs I can handle but the kids were throwing corks, playing between the bar our legs and making more noise than the bachelorettes. Cute and quirky little place that looks as if it was put together with stuff from my garage. The music is a iTouch playing Pandora (nothing wrong with any of that) and played through a Bose SoundDock. The place is very noisy so maybe the music does not matter but it looks cheap and lowbrow. A lounge are with love seat and chair is the only sitting area with some high tops and the bar to stand around. It's cramped in here. There is a private tasting room with large, dining room table but it was closed off. Would be great to have a sofa in there too for overflow and there were less than 20 of us in there.

The wine is worth trying. I enjoyed the Pinot only, Purist Flight for $15. After the kids (and parents hopefully) were sent to bed and I could hear myself think, I asked the two staffers behind the bar, "What makes Drake special?" and "Why should I like it?". With so many Santa Barbara County wines to taste in the Funk Zone, I wanted to know more about Drake. The extremely friendly and knowledgeable explained the wine maker, Mark, had worked on some large Pinot projects for other, area companies and that this was a family company with a love of wine. Their story went on and made me fell like I was part of something different. This little winery produces some good stuff. 

While the wine definitely deserve a repet visit, I'll hold off all week until Fried Chicken and Waffles with Pinot Fridays. Yep. Apparently it's a real thing on the first and third Fridays through the summer and I'll be back to eat my fill. And for that, the review of the tasting room bumped up a notch.

The wine is good but I'm not a huge fan of the room. Perhaps it will grow on me. Just keep your kids at home please.
Cheers Drake

It's huge, it's awesome, it's open! South Philadelphia has been my usual wine and spirits stomping ground, but now my liver is really in for it with this gem open in the neighborhood.  The wine selection is amazing, as is pretty much the entire selection of every liquor.  The first day they were open I bought a bottle of St. Germain, a handle of Bacardi select, and a bottle of wine, for under $65, so the prices are pretty lovely as well.  The staff was super helpful and knowledgeable of the product and store layout. 

This is more than a step up, this is a whole escalator up from the liquor store we used to have to deal with in Northern Liberties.  Mad Dog varieties have been replaced with fine wines and spirits.  There's short-term parking on a Girard, and a parking lot behind the store.  It's like they actually care about their customers!

I am going to dream of these beignets and marmalade. Oh, that marmalade. They were definitely the star of the show for me, but let's get to the nitty gritty.  

The restaurant itself is wedged in a strip mall in the far reaches of the north side. I am a downtown girl, so getting me to the north side takes a lot of convincing. I have to say, this was worth it. The decor is bright and airy and the food is fantastic. 

We started with the beignets (have I mentioned how great these were?) and then I moved on to Simply Salmon. The salmon tasted fresh and it had a great seasoning rub on it. It was laid on a bed of greens, garlic, mushrooms, and asparagus. So good. Whenever I can have an excuse to pretty much eat a few whole cloves of garlic, it's a good day. My plate priced out around $13 and it was well worth the asking price. You could go in here for a simple breakfast and spend under $10, or get a little fancy and push it to $20-25. I feel like it would be a great experience either way.

My husband surprised me with a weekend in Philly at this boutique hotel. It was our first time there, but we absolutely loved it. The room was huge with a big bathroom complete with tub and shower, kitchen, living room and bedroom. The bed was very comfortable and we enjoyed our stay. All of the staff we dealt with was very friendly and helpful. Based on previous reviews, we didn't waste our time with the breakfast so I can't speak to that, but we did enjoy the cookies the couple of nights we were there which were very fresh and delicious. Also, the location is close enough to all the action of center city but also in a quiet neighborhood which is a nice balance. I definitely will be returning to the Morris House.

I am not an expert on Fishtown or beer gardens, so I have no idea whether Frankford Hall is a good fit for the neighborhood, and I couldn't tell you whether Stephen Starr executed the "authentic German beer garden" concept with fidelity. 

I can tell you that there are certain things that go along with the Stephen Starr territory. For example, prices. Everything costs about a dollar more than you think it should cost. But you're paying for the experience of being In A Stephen Starr Restaurant, and you have sort of agreed implicitly to do that by, well, walking into a Stephen Starr restaurant. If that's not your thing, then don't go to Stephen Starr restaurants, dude.

Anyway, I like the beer garden concept. I like being in the open air a lot. It was nice and breezy! I also liked the "pay as you go" concept of going to the counter to order beers and food myself. The vegetarian fare was delicious- I loved my sausage and the red cabbage that comes on the side and the potato pancakes, while quite different from the latkes I make at home, were flavorful and generously topped with sour cream and chives. 

But the beer and pretzels is what really did it for me. I started with a Franziskaner Hefeweizen and then moved on to Bitburger, which suited the food much better. I also tried the My Antonia which was great! Eight bucks for a pretzel is steep, but they are enormous, and wow, THAT MUSTARD!!! 

When we left around 10, there was a line out the door and it was definitely more of a bridge-and-tunnel Old City crowd. So if you want to avoid that, just go there earlier in the night like we did. We arrived around 7:30 and had no trouble getting a table. 

This isn't a place I will go to frequently- it's on the other side of town and it's expensive. But for a change of pace, we definitely made a good choice to visit Frankford Hall.

I love this bridge, but that's probably because its not a part of my commute. Whenever I'm on this bridge I'm usually headed somewhere fun like fishing, MD Market, or to the Trop. The main reason I like it is because of the views of the water. I love to fish, and nothing gets me amped for my trip like driving over this bridge. I dunno, it kinda sets the mood or something? Anyway, the traffic does suck, and unfortunately I have been caught in that a few times. The view of downtown and the city coming back is pretty cool. There is also some nice scenery in spots on the way to St Pete as well. People do speed down this thing at night, so be careful/keep right.

I would rate Taqueria Feliz a 3.5. I've now been here twice now. The first visit was a bit subpar and lackluster, but the second time definitely made up for it. 

What we ordered:
Flight of tacos: The tacos were pre-created but it was everything I wanted for being the indecisive person I am. Three tacos came in one order and included a steak, fish, and shrimp. I think the best of all of them was the shrimp, but they were all really tasty. I love when tacos have a lot of veggies on top and fruit salsa. Mango salsa is my favorite especially when it's atop something spicy.

Ceviche: This ceviche is unlike any kind I've had before. I only had a bite.  I feel like most ceviche is mostly "cooked" with lime juice and is essentially raw seafood. This version was different- it was tomato based. The base of the ceviche was shrimp but instead of tasting very citrusy, it was topped with a cocktail sauce. The horseradish gave the seafood a nice kick and some flavor, without it being overbearing.

My friend had the brussel sprout tacos, but I didn't try them. She says she has dreams about them so I imagine they are delicious. I'm hit or miss with Brussels so I probably wouldn't order them, but if you love them. ORDER THEM IMMEDIATELY.

What I didn't like

The salsa: It's not that I didn't like it; I just didn't care for it. I'm just not a fan of the heavy chipotle flavored salsa. I like it more tomato and mild. It wasn't overly spicy.

All in all, I would go back to Taqueria Feliz. The tacos were great, the portions are about average and the atmosphere is fun. If you're in the heart of downtown Manayunk and in the food for Mexican, head to Taqueria Feliz (just don't get the sangria, you might be disappointed).

Went here for a girl's night, and it was a fantastic choice! Ocean sauce is definitely the way to go. Tonight one of the fish choices was grouper, which my friend and I got. We both agreed that this was one of the best meals we've ever had: the flavor of the fish in the sauce is to die for; add crawfish, shrimp and crabmeat, you just don't want the meal to end! Our other friends got the chicken Tyler and the veal ocean and absolutely loved them. We ordered the oysters as an appetizer, which was okay. The main courses though are what you want to come here for. Try this place out!

I subtracted a star because this community park has zero water fountains to drink from. My friend, Mike, and I were so thirsty we almost drank from the showpiece fountain. Other than that, St Pete Pier is a lovely park next to the Yacht Club. There is plenty of seating and a grand view of the ocean. There are Artist booths, but only one was open. We went for a nighttime laser light show and I do believe we saw the future. Our grandchildren will not know what fireworks are because the lighted, flying drones can make fireworks in 3-D. It was an amazing opportunity. The pier sponsors many community events and has a History Museum.

Great sushi coming from a person who loves sushi.  I specifically love sashimi and theirs did not disappoint.  They had yellowtail and premium yellowtail, called kanpachi.  Oh my gosh!  It was so fresh and the flavor is so buttery.  It's very different from the regular yellowtail called hamachi.  It was unique, so do yourself a favor and try it!!

The wife and I dropped in for a quick slice while walking around the area.  We sat at the bar and the bartender was very nice and gave me such amazing news when I told her I was celiac...They had gluten-free pizza!!!!  It was forever ago I had good pizza.  Celiac pretty much destroyed my ability to love all things pizza.  Not only was it free of gluten, but the crust was good, the sauce was good, the cheese was good, the pepperoni was good... it was damn good!  My wife got a slice of the NY pizza and that looked impressive.  She said it was spot on.  They also had gluten-free beer!!!  Going to church with Grandma paid off!  It was like I went back in time to when I was ignorant to how wheat was destroying my insides, but without destroying my insides.  I noticed some of the dinner plates others were getting and portions looked huge.  I'll be back here the next time I visit my grandparents.  Great service and great pizza is not to be missed.

I could die here. It's practically a beauty haven. I've been here only twice in 3-4 years because I live in Toronto, ON. But I adore this shop!

The girls who work here are stellar and the most helpful. They make skin care and make up WAY less intimidating and are so well informed about their products. This shop has amazing integrity and give people samples to make sure a product works and also promote trying out everything in the shop. They serve on you hand and foot but obviously LOVE WHAT THEY DO. So refreshing!

If I lived in Edmonton, I'd practically live here. I definitely think I'll take them up on their offer and have some items shipped over to me because I just LOVE support an amazing local shop!

When I leave here, I have ZERO shoppers remorse because I know I bought products which I'll love and know that I supported a business worth every penny(or nickel).

ONE OF THE BEST BEAUTY SHOPS EVER.

If you're looking for a great little run store in the South Tampa area, Fit Niche is the place!

I love how they heavily carry Brooks gear, my favorite, and are very friendly and helpful when it comes to measuring gait and style to help you find the right running shoe!

The staff and management is VERY friendly and willing to answer any questions about gear or even running in general!

They also have a fun run every week evening around 7pm on Thursdays where they meet right in front of their store!

I have routinely had very good experiences when staying at this location. I find the staff to be attentive, professional and accomodating when possible. 

This location is very close to the Causeway bridge. Essentially you can be headed on the Northshore if you miss your turn for the building. The hotel is located inside of an office building. I find this to be a positive for several reasons. Other patrons are primarily adults, some are business travelers and the rooms are not as worn as mainstream properties. In addition to this, the property is pretty quiet, which I prefer. The beds are very comfortable and the tvs are flat screens. Rooms have a city view or lake view and corner rooms have plenty of windows which I love. 

This location is about a 15 - 20 minute drive to downtown New Orleans and it is 5-10 minutes from many area restaurants. PF Changs, Bravos, Le Madeleine, Drago's, Crazy Johnnie's, Phil's Grill, Red Lobster, Andrea's, Shogun and Acme Oyster House are very close. Ito is also down the street from Lakeside Shopping Mall which is one the major shopping malls in the metropolitan area. 

I would recommend this to anyone with the exception that by doing so, I am letting the cat out of the bag.

I stopped eating at Fuzzy's because we were often given cold food, rude service and it just plain wasn't good anymore to me. But my daughter loves them and I grudgingly agreed to a dinner there only to find a great menu of corn items that were simply delicious. Food was hot tonight and the service was not bad., I'm happy to say Fuzzy's is no longer in my list of places to avoid. If I have more than one experience like this I would even recommend them.

The thing about Fuzzy's is it really is just a sweet little place to hang out. They have sports on most of the time. They have taco night. They have  trivia night. It tries to be and wants to be a great place. They just need to maintain quality food and I think they will co to us on in this area for a long time to come.

Since it had been several years since we had visited Bravo we thought we would stop on our way home after visiting a couple of local wineries. We liked it before but now we love it! Everything from start to finish was top notch. Brittney, our server, was next level good. She was attentive and offered some valuable suggestions on the dishes that we ordered. The last time we had the same level of service was when we had dinner at Prime 47. We were also checked on by two managers which was a nice change of pace when compared to similar experiences we have had when visiting other restaurants of comparable caliber. We started with the Pecorino Cheese dip with clover honey; I would not be surprised if it was the best appetizers on the menu. That was followed by Shrimp+Lobster Fettuccine for me and Lobster Ravioli for my wife. If I had the opportunity to eat there seven days in a row I would ask to be seated in Brittney's section and order the Same starter and entree every day. It was that good. We will absolutely be going back. Next weekend if I can talk my wife into it:)

I've been here a few times when I come to Tampa because my stepmom loves this place. I think it's an overall good place. Fun with live music. Large and a lot of indoor and outdoor seating. Good size menu. Fun drinks. It just doesn't speak to me though as the food isn't all that amazing. Good, but not amazing compared to the numerous unique restaurants that Tampa has to offer.

Don't let me sway you though. You'll likely have a good time and enjoy your night out with friends over some drinks and food.

It was an unseasonably hot day (100 degrees and humid) during our recent visit. We were on our way back to the streetcar, and thence to our lodgings. My older companion was beat from the heat and needed something to eat and drink without further walking and exploring. The "food court" sign on the JAX building raised our hopes that we would find something appealing.

Were I by myself, I would have departed and hunted around Decatur Street for someplace more intriguing, but given the situation, I guided my companion to a seat, scanned the menu at Hotsy's, and ordered half of a muffaletta sandwich, which we split, and a couple of beverages. A muffaletta is an New Orleans version of an Italian "hoagie" of "sub sandwich," consisting of Italian meats, cheese, and a layer of chopped olive salad topping on a special loaf of white bread that is round and soft.

The sandwich turned out to be a good choice. Its size was just right for the state of our appetites (my companion LOVED it), but it seemed expensive given the restrained portion of meat, cheese and topping on the bread.

The sandwich by itself earns three stars. However, its price, and the uninspiring food court choices and environment pull this down to a two star rating.

Public bathrooms are available on the first floor. They were...rank.

One of the best Children's museums I have ever been to!  It was my 2nd time at PLEASE TOUCH and my 6-yr old Godson LOVES this place.   He spent the majority of the time there in the construction play area.  I think that is his forte!  He loves construction trucks very much, but not as much as Thomas the Train & Friends and this construction playground is pretty amazing with lots of working tools/machines like a conveyor belt, time clock, and bricks...well OK,  bricks are not really parts that move but these bricks kept this 6-yr old busy for at LEAST 3 hours!!!  It was a real bitch trying to get him outta the place!!!  

We were lucky enough to have been in line with really nice people who gave us a coupon for free entrances...Philly moms ROCK!!!!

Oh yeah, we went on Presidents Day Weekend and it was packed like a MF yet this 6-yr old had the best time and even made a few friends!!!

Note to parents, please make sure you stay with your kid, sometimes we encounter a few bullies (very few but they exist) whose parents are too tired and sitting their asses on the benches not paying any attention to what their child is doing!

Pictures to come soon!

Health Mutt is a very awesome, neighborhood pet store featuring all natural pet treats and foods, along with some terrific pet toys, accessories, and grooming services for the Fido's and Fluffy's in your life. 

I am a huge lover of four-legged pets, but unfortunately I lost my favorite feline to degenerative kidney failure a while back. With my crazy travel and work schedule it's not fair for me to take on the responsibility of saving a new shelter pet, but then constantly be putting my little buddy into the kennel when I'm on the road. Instead I depend upon the generosity of my business partner to let me sit on the floor and play with his two dogs whenever we work from his house.

SIDE BAR COMMENT:  I recently purchased a Seminole Heights Unites "Fires Die - Community Lives" t-shirt to support the employees of Domani Bistro and A Modern Line furniture store, following the devastating fire which destroyed the restaurant and damaged the furniture store next door. 100% of the proceeds, after the raw cost of the garment, are donated to the employees, so this is a really good cause -- http://heightsunites.bigcartel.com/product/fires-die-community-lives-t-shirt. Earlier this week I received an email saying that the t-shirts were ready for pickup at Health Mutt in Seminole Heights. Turns out that the owner of the pet store is a big supporter of Seminole Heights' businesses, and was instrumental in creating the local team to support these two businesses and their staffs. Very cool!!!

OK, BACK TO OUR STORY:  Health Mutt sits just a few blocks east of Florida Avenue at the intersection of Hanna and Central Avenues, right in the heart of Seminole Heights. I parked out front, and wandered into the store to take a look around. My plan was to pick up my t-shirt, and also find some doggie treats for my business partner's two dogs, Izzi and Belle.

Bill likes to say that Izzi and Belle are sisters from different mothers since Izzi is a pomeranian, and Belle is a black Lab, but their personalities are like twin sisters. I'm often showered with dog love and affection the moment that I walk in his front door, and I have to play with them and give them treats before they let Bill and I get down to work.

Charlie from Health Mutt was a huge help in navigating my way through the myriad of dog treat options, and I ended up buying a box of all-natural Cloud Star "Wag more bark less" baked applewood-smoked bacon dog treats which will keep me on the good side of Izzi and Belle for the next few weeks. I also picked up some appropriately-sized Barkworthies Bully stick chew thingies which are much better than those nasty ol' rawhide chews.

While Charlie was getting my t-shirt from the back room, I had the chance to watch one of the staff bathing and grooming a few dogs, and was very impressed by her attention to the dogs and her gentle demeanor. 

The store is packed with healthy and great quality food and treats, and there were all sorts of toys, collars, harnesses, leashes, and bedding just waiting for you to take home. Super friendly people, and you can tell that they really enjoy working with pets and their owners. Great little find in the middle of Seminole Heights.

Delicious food, amazing stuff, with hipster vibes, Vegetarian and Vegan-friendly

I don't know why we have waited until the end of our trip to visit this place. Big mistake. This place is my most favorite place to eat! Finally, a place where we all (carnivores and vegans) could enjoy amazing food and great atmosphere. 

We got:
Blueberry pancake - my friend who loves pancakes and believe me, he ordered probably hundreds of them on different places, said that this pancake was the best from all he has ever had - fluffy, light, delicious. He probably dreams about this pancake until today.
He also got a Mexican breakfast plate with scrambled eggs and he loved it too.

Quiona & Eggs - my other friend, who took us to this place, got some of the specials this time. He is trying to go for healthier choices, and he didn't regret at all, he loved it.

I went for Vegan curry scramble with both quinoa and tofu - delicious, creamy, healthy, light. I truly wish we have you in NYC!

We also got some vegan baked sweetness, unfortunately i don't remember the name. But I still remember how delicious it was - especially with coffee.  

Staff was very friendly, happy and helpful.

Indoor and outdoor seating (beautiful patio and if you get lucky, you can meet a cat, who likes to hang out there :-) and WiFi are perfect for those with laptops. 

We love this place and when we are back in NOLA, this is the first stop :-)

PS: Even the restroom is extraordinary :-)

I'm really sorry to rain on everyone's parade and go against consensus, but although Spruce Street Harbor Park is just what the area needed, I don't think it lives up to the hype.

Hammocks are great and all, but they are already pretty gross after the whole neighborhood has tried them out. And how can you have beer and food with no restrooms? Perhaps this is another ploy by the city to raise money through the issuance of public urination fines.

I love how they repurposed the boxcars or what appears to be outdated shipping containers, but the overall layout looks like a politician designed it and tried too hard to appeal to hipsters. Again, sorry to rain on the parade, but I think people will realize that this park is average after the novelty wears off.

First of all, it was surprisingly hard to find a place to eat at that didn't close at 2 or didn't stay closed til 4 pm. What is up with that? So my boyfriend and I wanted to go to On Swann but they had just closed. We thought we just couldn't find the right door. So we walked around the area and came across this gem. It's such a cute date spot. He loved his Bloody Mary, and my Bellini was so good! 

I couldn't decide between four things and our server Kevin gave me an amazing recommendation! I got a mixed skillet of the clams and mussels and they were by far the best I've ever had! They had this amazing Smokey flavor I just can't get over!!

My boyfriend had pasta, he's Sicilian himself and said it was the best he's had at any restaurant and perfectly al dente! We'll definitely be back! I'll honestly probably get the same thing because it was so delicious. :)

THIS is why I love Yelp!! Local finds outside of the touristy places. While sating in Bywater we came across this gem. You wouldn't know it from the outside, but when you walk in you are immediately impressed by the warm decor. 

You walk straight into their beautiful wine store. They also have cheeses & meats which the manager explained can be made into a charcuterie board... YUM!

Once you walk through the store they have a HUGE patio area. Upstairs is the coolest bar! This is where we chose to spend our time. The bartender was AWESOME! She explained different drinks as well as specials, food, and local info. My husband had a gin fizz which he had never had before. He loved it!

They have weekly specials as well as entertainment. I would highly suggest a visit while visiting NOLA. I'm sure glad we did!

I drive by Kennett all the time.  Four times in fact the day we finally stopped in this weekend.  My girlfriend and I were there early (5ish) as we were attending a beer drinking event that evening, so we wanted to fill our bellies.  Well, one of us was pretty full of chips prior to the meal, but you get the point...

I love hand pumped, cask, firkin whatever you call it beer.  It makes any beer 20% better.  So props to Kennett on this.  Doesn't even matter what was in there, but at the time it was a cask-conditioned Yards ESA and all was good in the world.

As mentioned it was early, so the dinner crowd hadn't arrived yet.  Comfortable interior with maybe one or two other tables occupied at the time.  A guy who I assume was an owner chatted with one table as he prepped for the evening.  Very welcoming and they seem to care about their business.  Having owners/employees who actually give a damn means a lot.

This translated to the food.  Had the porchetta pizza.  The pork was super, super tender.  So much so you forgot it was on the pizza after you took a bite as no effort was needed to chew the stuff.  Also because it wasn't greatly falvorful, a subtle flavor that was nice albeit could've used a little more kick.  Just my opinion.  Also tried the lamb burger which was described by my Turkish girlfriend as tasting like a Turkish kofte which is some high praise.  She ate it with a knife and fork.

I will be back, that marrow on the regular burger is screaming my name.  "Briannn...I want to be in *your* boneessss..."

I don't usually rate Taco 
Bell but I really like this one!! 
Very friendly staff and FREE Senior Coke!!
Very clean too. Food is nice and hot and quick service!! Got to love the Bell :)

Solid place for casual yat-food.  Love the turkey and andouille gumbo.  Good onion rings and top notch po-boys.  Try the hamburger steak!  Good service. The guy that owns Rock-n-Bowl owns College Inn, and he's often hanging out at the bar along with a bunch of other yats.  He'll thank you personally as you leave, which is a nice touch.

I love coming here for $3 pint night on Wednesday. It's quiet, secluded, and away from all things Broad and/or Ripply. I love it here. They have a wonderful selection of rotating beers and the bar service is just fantastic.

Super upset, the only reason my fiancee and I went to this resturant was because I love dessert and the smore skillit was AMAZING! Now its off the dang menu.
    My servers have always been really friendly, not very attentive, but certinaly the only reason i can really give this place even a star. The food is ok, its glorified bar food but with a high price. My fiancee got the sasquach burger which was a buger between two grilled sandwiches on texas toast! that was cool, but other than that the food is not worth going. Its very loud since its mainy a bar with a little booth dining room connected so you hear bar goers and the loud tvs the entire meal. Not worth the gas.

This was our first food stop in Nashville for lunch-this is cafeteria style eating and we heard it was a great spot and must try, so we swung by to try it out! The line is long and out the door but moves quick. They have limited options throughout the week on their menu so I'd look in advance before going. Since it is cafeteria style you feel a bit more rushed but a place like this is expected to have that feel. My friends and I ordered the chicken and dumplings, catfish, turnip greens, banana pudding, and Mac and cheese. Chicken and dumplings was good just too watery. The turnip greens were absolutely amazing! I need more of that in my life! My friends loved the desserts and said they were the best part of the course. The sides such as the mac were good but small portions for the prices you paid. We enjoyed the food and would come back again but throughout our Nashville experience we had some better food experiences for the pricing too.

This place does a great Saturday brunch, especially on a nice day when you can eat outdoors.

The outdoor patio was lovely.   We enjoyed the sunshine and sampled many, many mimosa, using the egg dishes to sop up the alcohol.  The staff was just attentive enough to keep us refilled, but to not bug us when we lingered after the food and drink was done.  Food was fine, although not gourmet, but the prices were reasonable for south Tampa, and there was parking, unlike at Datz.

Nice big dog park with a water fountain for drinking and plenty of shade on hot days. The leash hooks are a nice addition instead of carrying a leash around. There are plenty of free poop bags and people are pretty good about picking up after their dogs. 
There isn't a small dog area and it's usually occupied by medium and big dogs so If you have a small dog that doesn't like to play, this isn't the dog park for you. That said, they humans tend to be pretty attentive here and there were a few "tussles" that humans broke up (even if it wasn't their dog involved) and everyone went back to playing. The lack of helicopter dog parents was refreshing as it is normal for dogs to bark when playing!  I especially love that this park doesn't discriminate against pitties or other bully breeds.

We are season pass members and have been for quite some time.  So we attend every home game...which can get pretty hot in the Summer months.  Over the years we've shared our fair amount of good versus bad experiences with this place and the staff.  We sit in the 300 section because we love the view of the entire field but the concession lines no matter where you sit are always so long and slow.  The staff or volunteers that they get to run these areas need to step it up.  What is frustrating more than anything is that they don't have specific lines at every service kiosk just for refills.  After purchasing your souvenir mug that is refillable, they should have areas where you can go just get them refilled and not have to stand in the LONG lines again just for a refill.  They did change up some of the food options and places for this football season, which is nice but they are all located on the lower level which does nothing for the upper level fans unless you want to travel down to the lower level and deal with that crowd.

Let me start by saying the steaks are on point. They use quality meats and know how to cook them to perfection. The other dishes and desserts on the other hand don't all match in quality. I dinned at Rococo on business with 3 other people. We got the opportunity to sample a large portion of their menu and a few fabulous wines. I like the traditional steakhouse menu with modern local dishes, it's a good combo and believe me there is NO shortage of options. In fact there may be too many options. We started with wine, the entire book of wine, there is something for EVERYONE and ANYONE, typical of a traditional steak house. After more time than I'd have preferred we settled on a universal red. Next the appetizers and salad. We went with the octopus bacon and special beet salad. The beet salad was amazing, the goat cheese mouse and Marcona Almonds were a perfect complement to the beets! Plus, we ordered two for the table and they portioned and plated the salad accordingly, which is always nice. The octopus on the other hand was prepared well but paired oddly. The capers and the puree seamed to fight the octopus. While this is typically a favorite of mine, it left me wanting more. (Or perhaps it was simply over shadowed by the beet salad.) The steaks arrived and were promptly devoured soon there after. The mushrooms were done beautifully and I liked the combination of fungi. But, the mac and cheese was nothing to write home about. It looked and tasted like a supped up box of Velveeta Shells and Cheese, not that I was looking for lobster or anything mind blowing, but a bit of texture and a bit more of a flavor profile would have been nice. We finished with two desserts, the first I cannot recall as I did not act fast enough to taste and the second a chocolate Crème Brulee, one of my all time favorites. If you are a lover of Crème Brulee you will understand my disappointment with the following sequence of events. I picked up my spoon, eager to tap the surface of the dish and watch the caramelized top crack in a most unpredictable pattern. Excited for the first bite, by far the best bite of the dish, you only finish the dish because you are hopefully that you will get a second bite as wonderful as the first, deep down knowing that was THE BITE. To my dismay, no crack! With dim lighting and since the dish is brown, I couldn't tell, did I miss the noise? Is the layer so thin it melted in my mouth? So I did what any adventurous eater does, took a bite, and another. It was cold mush. Just Crème, no Brulee. The staff sent out a new dish and was kind enough to take it off the bill, but the second did not satisfy, I still had the taste of the limp and cold first round in my mind.  I'll most likely go back, but with a little caution. They have the most important ingredient down pat and I guess that's what's most important. 

Side Note: Great décor and service, intimate and inviting, a surprise on this side of downtown.

So I had taken a break from Deg Thai...not on purpose though. It was only because the stars didn't align for us to visit for a bit, but that recently came to an end.

I've always raved about how awesome this food truck is -- even during my time away. But like all things, one does start to wonder if the quality will diminish over time.

Great news...it hasn't! I've had the pleasure of catching up with the infamous green truck twice in the last few weeks. The food is still super fantastic, and served piping hot. I took a first-timer with me on one of those visits, and the super-picky eater loved it too!

It looks like they've added even more dishes to their menu, but I'm still sticking with my tofu Basil Stir Fry -- damn it's good.

It's good to see the owner, Jay, still cooking his native food. He even stopped long enough to say "hello". Plus his wife has rejoined the DT team, and she's always smiling.

Consistent and delicious food, and awesome customer service...what more could you ask for?!?

I'm writing reviews for the Anheuser-Busch tour as well as the Coors tour at the same time. So if you're interested to see how they compare... check out my other review.

I did this tour with my lovely lady during my first trip to St. Louis. We arrived and had to wait a few minutes for our tour to begin. Once it did, we had a nice lady that walked us around the brewery and explained their business. This included a short stint on a little bus. It ended at a tasting room where they allowed you a couple small glasses of the (Anheuser-Busch) brew of your choice.

Everything was very well organized and had a good flow to it. I learned a lot about the process and would highly recommend it to others. Might be a good thing to do on a cold day as there were some rooms that got toasty!

After seeing  another yelper post the truffle arugula pizza I knew I had to try it.  We ordered takeout because of covid and this was hands down one of my favorite wood fired pizzas! I love truffle and this pizza had a truffle honey glaze on it that tasted fantastic! The balance of the truffle and wild mushrooms with the arugula was perfect. 

I am looking forward to trying more pizzas and hopefully enjoying the indoor dining soon!

One of the best parts of my trip to Tampa.

The sign said welcome so I walked on in. Evelyn, the Studio Manager found me a few minutes later, welcomed me and showed me around. She gave me a brief run down of the ovens and the 750 pounds of molten glass they use each week. She explained about the casts they use and the colors they add and what happens to all the broken leftovers. She even offered to show me how they "charge" the ovens, adding additional material after pieces have been made.

She was bright and energetic and friendly and capable of slinging 50 pounds sacks of chemicals easier than you'd ever suppose.

They were having an open house a couple days after I visited that the kids would have loved but sadly California to Florida is a pretty serious drive so we had to pass.

And peek behind the studio and take a look at that spectacular tree house. It was all I could do to resist running over for an inner child satisfying, up close and personal kind of a look.

From appetizer to pizza, EXCELLENT!!!! We had a great experience at Talayna's and Pie. Now, this place is another totally different style fabulous pizza of STL!!!!

The dough is kind of like Naan! Wow, We've never had the dough like that! Oven-baked and they put fresh and high quality toppings. 

White Anchovy - Appetizer. WONDERFUL! I never new fresh Anchovy taste like that great!! It's completely different from can. SOOOO GOOD! Salted just right, and it came as salad style.

Funghi pizza - No tomato sauce. Fresh chunck of mushroom and tasty cheese. Great combination!!

Today's special - It was Pesto, Mini tomato, Cheese and Anchovy. SPECTACULAR!! We wish they put this on the everyday menu!!!

We sat outside seating. Beer, outside breeze, tasty pizza,,,,,  Awesome pizza place. LOVE IT!!!!!!!!!!!!

I love bubble tea, and last time I was here, they were closed due to Chinese New Year. I'm not sure if they close every Chinese New Year but just FYI. The price for the bubble tea was cheaper than the other places I've been to. However, I'm not sure if they brew the tea fresh or not. I've got honey dew milk tea with bubbles and I had to pay $1 to add flavor of honey dew.

This is a really nice Starbucks. I love the modern look and feel of it since they renovated about a year ago. They also have the exclusive Reserve Roastery blends (only a fraction of Starbucks locations offer these) so if you really like specialty blends/ exotic beans, you can find them here. I give it three stars though, because they are so slow every time I come here. I'd say I wait on average one minute for my drink at most Starbucks locations, but every time I come here I'm consistently waiting 4 or more minutes. Doesn't seem like a lot, but it feels like an eternity when other locations (and other coffee joints) have a much quicker speed of delivery. It's puzzling that they're so slow because they always have 5 or 6 employees in there that appear to just be getting in the way of one another behind the counter.

I love This place. The ambiance is classy. The food is great. My favorite is the table side guacamole. They make it fresh right in front of you. I've had big parties here. I've always been happy with everything.

My wife and I love Anatolia. The food is great, and the portions are just the right amount without making you feel stuffed. In fact, it leaves enough room for the freshly made baklava, and a Turkish coffee. Whenever we have family or friends visit, we love to take them there. It's a real treat to have a place like this in Nashville.

La Familiga has been in operation since 1976. That's 40 years from 2016, math majors. Let me start by tipping my figurative hat to such success in a tough restaurant industry. 

Their 40th anniversary rollback menu and pricing was actually what drew me in for my recent visit. I had recalled enjoying my experience about a decade ago, but this restaurant is far from hip and trendy and has likely missed its way back on to my very deep "to-eat" list.

On the other hand, it is a traditionally, upscale experience. The main dining room has a nostalgic antique feel. In all honesty, so did a lot of the other clientele. I say this not as a slight but as an observation. During the course of our meal, my husband and I were discussing how odd it is that an establishment of such stature only has 87 (now 88) reviews on Yelp. The older, more classically dignified demographic may be a factor. 

The other reason for their staying power is that the food is damn good. Nothing else will keep you afloat like an exemplarily meal. 

Going off of other Yelper's recommendations, we started by picking a bottle of wine from the holy bible of vino. We ended up with a lovely Chianti that paired perfectly with our dinner. 

As millennials, we went a non-traditional approach in ordering and started with pasta dishes instead of salads. As others had mentioned the pesto gnocchi is excellent but different. I believe the difference is the potato and ricotta blend that causes the texture to be a little lighter. The pesto sauce was creamy but did not drown the dumpling blend. My husband's penne arribata was simple but exemplified what the dish should be. A little kick, some chunks of tomato and a top of fresh basil.

We decided to split two entrees: the Vitello Papa Sena (veal of the picante, mandolese and capri variety) and the Filetto all Familiga. I haven't had such tender veal cutlets in a while. Each sauce was different yet complimentary of each other. The white wine sauce paired with prosciutto and mozzarella for the mandolese was ultimately my favorite. Although the butter in picante and white wine with spinach and pepper topped with mozzarella of the capri were certainly enjoyable.  The Filetto was prepared in a wine sauce but more in a gravy styling. It put a nice Italian touch on a classic cut of steak. Of course, it was prepared to the temperature of our liking and completely on point.

Expecting a traditional dessert menu, we were a little surprised when a tray of three options (that we've had previously never heard of) were presented to us. The Zuppa Inglese (an Italian dessert layering custard and sponge cake...thanks, Wiki) was the most intriguing. Consisting of a rum soaked cake with a light, fluffy yet crisp meringue-like topping, it hit the spot with a little post-dinner sweetness.

For this particular experience, the portions seemed to match the 1976 pricing, which is not necessarily a bad thing as I walked away content versus crammed. Perhaps if we ate like it was 1976, American waists would be more in line with a healthy standard, but I digress. 

While there are a million and one new restaurants in Philadelphia that are far more trendy than La Familiga, this is the spot to go if you are looking for an upscale Italian dining experience.

Writer's note: after initially submitting this a 4 star review, I can't honestly give a reason that it shouldn't be a 5 star review. I don't typically give 5s out for infrequent visits or promotional menus, however there is absolutely no reason a star should be deducted due to my personal Yelp "rules."

Nicely designed coffeehouse (lovely octagonal tiled floor, wood paneled coffee bar, large french doors). Coffee was decent. 

My problem was with the sea of laptops that stared back at me from every table. Yes, the wifi is free, but we're in F***ING NEW ORLEANS, one of the most beautiful, visually arresting cities in the world, with some of the most interesting/artsy people you'll ever meet, and you're staring at a F***ING COMPUTER SCREEN! Try disconnecting for a half hour and watch the world (or at least the tourists) pass you by.  Talk to the person sitting at the next table. Read a book or a newspaper. Anything but a digital screen. Sheesh.

My first review update comes with good reason, and that's because they got rid of the terribad musical act! This makes Dunders far more tolerable than it was previously, and actually a great place to have a brew and a bite!

The advantage of the bierhaus-style tables means it's great for groups as well, and you can hear multiple conversations and jump back and forth between them. Plus they have every kind of mustard on the planet, so if that's your thing you'll be able to try all of them.

The crowd is everything from USF grad students to hipsters of both variety (ironic and non-ironic). But get there earlier if you want something more than a sandwich, as they shut a bunch of the kitchen down at 10pm, thus meaning you can't get your schnitzel fix after that hour. 

A pretty authentic kind of place that's beloved by it's loyal customers... and now I'm a much bigger fan than I was before!
it's so wonderful that you can visit an art museum for free. the grounds are really lovely to walk on. if you are a member you get into a lot of  special exhibits free and parking is free.

I came here with a friend on a busy Saturday afternoon, and we were seated almost immediately. The service was prompt and friendly, coming with ample suggestions for drinks. I went with the Bakersfield Margarita with salt and shared the queso with a friend. The margarita was quite lovely, the perfect amount of lime balanced with the smoothness of their tequila. Though I did get a massive headache afterwards, this does tell me they don't skimp on the buzz. The queso was pretty decent, though it is a bit different than the fare typically offered in quesos in the southwest. This particular appetizer is quite chunky with an ooziness that is quite delectable. I'm not quite sure it's the best combination with the margarita I got, quite a bit more oily than the two of us bargained for.

Ambience was cool, with a nouveux-industrial feeling: open ceiling, concrete, and wood block bars with warm lighting. It has a great corner location and felt quite welcoming. Pretty dim, considering the mood lighting, but fitting for the atmosphere.

Came for high tea (which is available any day of the week, just book ahead!). Was immediately welcomed into the friendly tea house with grandma chic decor and whimsically mismatched furniture. The waitress invited us behind the counter to smell and the teas, it took awhile as there are so many options! We added the savory option to our tea choosing from a quiche or bread pudding. I chose the bread pudding with herbs, mushroom and kale. It was wonderfully reminiscent of stuffing. Im taking one star off here are we waited about 30minutes until this dish arrived. Otherwise the tea service was fantastic. The scones were delicious, i couldn't  get enough of the clotted cream and jam. Everything is made from a scratch, including the bread for the cucumber sandwiches. Cally herself came by to recommend eating the meringue with clotted cream, it was delicious! Although I think that cream could make everything delicious. The high tea was $40, which is cheaper than other high tea options in town. I would return for the lovely atmosphere and delicious scones

Compared to other Qdoba restaurants this one has very sad staff. They are not friendly nor talk to you while making your food. They were all talking to themselves and seemed bothered.  I love the food but the service today was below normal for Qdoba.

I want to like this place, I really do! I've been a few times and love the atmosphere. Perhaps I need to come for the coffee, but the food is just "meh" to me. I guess I'm always surprised by how long it actually takes. Every time I've been here, I've been the only one in line, but for some reason, my wait for food has consistently been over 20 minutes (last time, it was nearly thirty. 

I get the whole "take it slow" and "make it right" mindsets... but throwing a panini on shouldn't take so long! The prices for food are a bit steep too, considering what you get. It's a good place to grab a cup of coffee and get some work done, but unless you've got a lot of time to spare and a small appetite, I'd leave it at the coffee.

I've been a sucker for Hello Kitty and kitschy Asian items since I was a child. A visit to South Korea to visit relative when I was 8 just added fuel to the fire which explains why this 31 year old woman owns a Hello Kitty bathrobe. Being an adult certainly doesn't mean that you have to be mature at all times, right?

Happy Japan is cute specialty store with new digs in the cozy Berry Hill neighborhood. I never visited their previous location was on Gallatin Road but from sheer neighborhood cred, this new location must be a total upgrade for them. Being nestled next to See Spot Eat and Pied Piper Creamery makes a lot of sense as kiddos are sure to drag their moms in here post snack and anyone who will purchase their pup gourmet baked goods is likely to give this place a while too. (I'm clearly one of those people) I loved the layout of the store which happens to be a little cottage and walked through the 4 rooms that comprise the retail area with ease and curiosity.

In the main area, I enjoyed sifting through the Asian candies, cookies, and other treats. The prices are fair especially because these goods had to be imported. One of the rooms featured Anime items along with a collection of stuffed animals and figures. Another room showcased gear for wanna-be Harajuku girls that included wigs, platform shoes, and dresses. Why do I want a blue wig now? Because. In the 4th room, various trinkets ranging from magnets or books to cooking utensils and paper goods were displayed. 

I enjoyed the store but kept thinking that there would be more? I just didn't feel inspired enough to purchase anything. I'll definitely come back to check on their inventory and for gift items.

I'm a sucker for aesthetics so I'll admit this place had me at its window displays. But seriously, can you blame me? A few weeks after it opened, I ventured in bright-eyed, bushy-tailed. 

Verdict: At least they have nice staff and nice decor. 

Honestly I wasn't clear on the difference between Parisian crepes and Japanese-style ones but I hope what I tasted at T-swirl isn't representative of the latter. We split their lychee romantic crepe with raspberry and rose cream. Sounds lovely, right? Well, fellas, don't count on this to woo your lady friends because it was anything but romantic. Actually it was more of a sad romance gone bad. 

First, I don't know if the crepes here are supposed to be made fresh because ours definitely wasn't. It might be different if served with ice cream but this one isn't. Maybe you're saying, okay, so what? Well, read on. 

The crepe came out flat with a smidgen of cream, torn bits of canned lychee sparsely spread on top, two visible raspberries and maybe one pistachio grounded to pieces (see pic). Half way through we'd already forgotten what we ordered because there was nothing left but a thin layer of cream. Was it 40% off? No, but it probably should've been because it felt like 40% of it was missing. If you're coming here, at least don't get this. For $7, my friend would've made something better - and I doubt he even cooks. 

Ok maybe I'm being slightly dramatic (not really). Maybe we messed up and went with the only bad option on the menu. Maybe they were running out of ingredients. But as much as I'd like to think all of that, I'm just not convinced to give it another chance anytime soon.

I fell in love with Cycle Brewing three years ago at Peg's Cantina. When they opened this brewery downtown, I was ecstatic. 

I love their beers, namely Coffee n Cream Porter. I'm a fan of some of the IPAs too. I also love that their pricing is consistent so you always know what you're getting into price-wise, no surprises. 

The guy that work here are attentive. The decor is interesting, and the interior is clean. 

My only complaint is this cash only business.  Who carries cash anymore?!

Came here for breakfast and highly recommend the super sweet bananas foster waffle. The breakfast bar features the New Orleans signature alligator sausage which is very tender and a bit spicy. The prices seem fairly reasonable for the neighborhood and location. The server was great and called her customers loves and beautiful, but others seemed less charming--so as with all places, it's hit or miss.

Shopping at Target!!! I am a TRUE fan of Target..this is a large store.
I usually go to the Super Target in Smyrna LaVerne Area, but this one is closer to my home if I cut through the Woodmont neighborhood. I love to see the large homes on my drive over to the Target and the shopping center.
There is a lot of additional shops located at the Shopping center so when I go to Target I usually stop at other stores also.
This store is large, clean with a friendly staff. The shelves are always fully stocked and the store is clean. The bathrooms are clean. I can always find what I am looking for and they always have plenty of open lanes for checking out.

I love this Target store...!!! do you ?

I absolutely love Jimmy John's. Each sub shop I've been to has always been the same, right down to the motto, "subs so fast you'll freak." It's nothing fancy and what you see is what you get. There's catchy phrases on the wall, bright neon signs, and day old bread for 50 cents. 

I can walk in, order my #3 Tuna on white, with jalapeno chips and know all is right in the world. We had a friendly conversation with the franchise owner who gave us a brief history of Jimmy John's (as if I didn't know-I am from Illinois after all) and me, my sister and my Christian sat down for what would be my first decent lunch in Reno. It's so sad that it had to a fast food place like Jimmy John's but thank goodness it always has been reliable and good to me for the last ten years. 

My sandwich was perfect to say the least. The bread was fluffy and hot, and the meat, lettuce, tomato and mayo had a consistent and even ratio. I personally like to shove jalapeno chips to my sandwiches to add a crunchy texture to my sandwiches and Jimmy John's kettle cooked chips make a perfect addition. I obsess over their sandwiches and if they had any in the Bay Area, I'd probably be their best customer in the history of Jimmy John's.

Came here for happy hour (Sun-Fri 3-6pm) and ordered 2 sliders. One was oktoberfest, their special, and the other was the woodstock. Both were great! I felt the bun was a bit on the cold side, but the innards were just fine (meat, cheese, bacon). I cannot say which one I enjoyed more, since they were both so great. I love their honey ketchup. The portion size of the 2 sliders was just enough for a light dinner.

The staff at this location are some of the friendliest staff I've ever had at a hotel, and they were truly the only silver lining in this experience (apart from the beds actually being very comfortable). They were extremely welcoming, accommodating, knowledgeable and friendly. 

Upon arriving, we were dropped off on 7th Ave. by our Uber and the entrance was nowhere to be found. After a long cross-country trip, this was a very poor first impression. The 7th Ave entrance requires a key card, which you have to check in first obviously to obtain. We ended up lugging our carryons around the entire block looking for an entrance until we stumbled across a stranger and asked if he was staying at the hotel. He then informed us that if we walked up the ramp to the parking area, main entrance would be at the end of the 2nd floor parking. Consider yourself informed. 

Unfortunately, the lovely people who work here are not enough to make up for the fact that this location is not in a great part of town - with the trolley line running right next to the hotel, getting woken up multiple times throughout the night to what sounded like large dumpsters rolling down the street was extremely disturbing and I was exhausted my entire trip due to the trolley noise, as well as the air conditioning system that sounded like a plane taking off every 15 minutes to maintain the temperature. The extremely thin walls did nothing to mask the very loud fellow guests that were yelling and wandering down the halls very late into the evening (past midnight) and early in the morning either. If you're a light sleeper, consider yourself warned. They do provide earplugs which is a nice gesture, but when you have to get up early for meetings, it was a risk I couldn't take of not hearing the alarm.

I will definitely stay in the Hilton downtown next time I'm in town for work and avoid this place at all costs.

3.5 Stars...here's why:

I spent an entire afternoon strolling up and down Talbot Street, and I was impressed by the artists who were there as well as the variety of mediums that were for sale.  I bought art and also had henna done on my hands, which I thought was pretty cool too.  I had a lovely afternoon at the Talbot Street Art Fair.  However, I do have two critiques:

(01) Prior to coming, I checked their website to see if pets were allowed, but I saw nothing.  I brought my dachshund in tow, but when we arrived, there was a wishy-washy sign that discouraged you from bringing your dog, yet I saw people with their dogs all around.  I was confused: why no definite answer?  Now, my puppy did no harm at the art fair, and I didn't feel as if her presence was a big deal for the fair-goers.  In fact, many people asked to pet her, and one of the artisans even held her while I chose and purchased a piece from him.  Still, I think the organizers should make up their mind about this specific issue in order to prevent confusion.

(02) Nicey Treat was there, which was awesome and refreshing on a warm, sunny day, but why not bring in some more food trucks?  It's not like Indianapolis has a shortage of them!  With an art fair that is so anticipated and popular, I would have loved to see more than Pineapple Delight and popcorn. Save that for the State Fair.  Besides, food is art.  Showcase it with some tasty stuff!

Will I come back next year?  Yes.  Will I bring my Dachshund? Most likely, if the organizers can make up their minds.

First Watch corp customer svc reads these reviews and takes note.  They reached out and invited me back.   I tried the carrot cake pancake - yummo - and the key west eggcrepe which was also tasty.  They're always busy, the servers are friendly, but we still had to ask for our included toast and have my daughters bacon re-fired because she asked for limp and got crispy.  I'm a fan, I love the many options, that you can get breakfast or lunch and the price is right.  I will be back - Enjoy!

I love this place.  Really.  I'd like to date it--at least one night a week, maybe 3 times as long it isn't TOO needy. It can even have other girlfriends--I like it so much that this time, I would be willing to share.  

I regularly order their products from Green Bean--which is great, but there's something about going to the store and considering ALL the possibilities. Last night, I met friends in the cellar for a little wine, chatting and snacks.  Can anyone say Steak Tartare?  Made right there?  So fresh and delicious...and well, my dog might have just thought that was the best leftover ever--ok, maybe tied with a steak from St. Elmos, but hey, he's a dog.  What does he know?  The cellar is great--a little rustic in design and some fun wine and food to consider as you are spending some time there.  Turns out the more wine I drink, the more I buy.  You think I would have learned this from those promotions where they give you champagne in a department store and next thing I know, I've got 10 new pairs of shoes. 

Okay, so let's see.  Good wine, check.  Amazing selection from the butcher--I was really excited to see Andouille sausage--it's a bit hard to find and being a southern girl, it's a staple in a lot of my favorite recipes so that's a score.  Delicious bacon without the 'crud'...great smoked pork chops and brisket...and much, much more.  Fun pastas, breads, dips and spreads...and even pig ears for the dog.  Pretty sure I  feel a dinner party coming on.  See you soon, Goose.
Pupusería Metapaneca is a recently opened Salvadoran restaurant at Agora Plaza. I loved their loroco pupusas. Very clean space. Staff only speak Spanish.

Really good, solid food, and the nicest servers and staff ever. Love it here so much. It's easy to park, the food is fresh and quick, and the service is the best. The grilled cinnamon bun is like a grown up version of the honey buns in cellophane I used to eat as a kid, haha. Big improvement. And it is fairly priced, I thought. One of the best kept secrets in the area!

I have had this spot bookmarked for a while.  So I am happy to check it off my Santa Barbara bookmark list.  Unfortunately I came here in the evening and was not able to take in the beautiful views but my experience was still amazing.  They were near closing so it was not very busy.  We had the shop to ourselves for most of the visit.   My party of 4 tried 3 Signature Tasting: 2 whites and 3 reds, and 1 White Tasting: 4 whites.  

The owner of the shop was very knowledgeable of his wines and the wine making process.  Before the evening was over well all had a better understanding and appreciation of wine.   If you are interested in joining a wine club you should check out this spot. 

The atmosphere was relaxing and laid back (the wine may have had something to do with this), they provided great customer service and I would love to go back during the day to try more wine and take in the view.

This place is a staple in Indianapolis over in the international marketplace. Most people who have been around the city long enough and explore ethnic food have tried this joint. Now with so many other vietnamese restaurants opening all around the city, there is a lot of competition. I think that Saigon still fares pretty decently to the others in town. For one, the menu is extensive. Most vietnamese dishes that one would seek in larger more diverse metro areas are present on this menu. Secondly, the portions are very fair for the price. Taste is good imo, however, the quality of the meat is questionable. My wife is much more on the meat picky and mostly vegetarian spectrum than myself, but the way she qualifies a vietnamese cuisine is based on grilled meat quality (as she is a bún lover). I agree with her most of the time, and on saigons behalf, I agree- meat quality mediocre at best. Otherwise, definitely worth trying out.

Again I am not a fan of Mexican food, but apparently all of my friends love it. We stopped here for lunch before heading to the Bike Expo at the Gateway Center. I had the buffet, which was very nice and clean. Tacos, burritos, tostitos, and some other thing that was rolled up and fried. You can also build a nacho platter which is what I did. They only have Pepsi products, huge downer if you are a Diet Coke fan (which I am). Our waitress was so friendly and funny, I tipped her nicely just because of her personality....

Amazing place, full of all kinds of whimsical things from the broken down antique doors with knobs like I've never seen in my life, to perfectly preserved butterflies in shadow boxes, to chandeliers, tandem bikes, garden sculptures...you could look around for ages. Loved browsing here, just regretted we were on vacation and couldn't take more home with us!

The hubby and I are about to become parents, and last night, after having some maternity photos taken, we stopped by Burger Republic on our way home to try it out. I love that they offer some healthier alternatives than straight ground beef (i.e. ground turkey, chicken, veggie burgers, etc.). While the husband ordered a Hawaiian burger and fries, I opted for the Burger Republic made with ground turkey and a side salad.
