I'm not much of a burger gal, but I've gotta say I really liked the one I had here. The service was a little slow (they seemed to be slammed with not quite enough servers on duty), but the fries were hot and fresh. (Come on! I'm pregnant, and they smelled good.) My side salad was made with spinach, which was a bonus since I kinda hate iceberg lettuce. Obviously, I can't comment on the beers, but what I saw on the menu looked good.

Overall, I'm glad this joint moved into our neck of the woods, and I'm sure we'll be back one night when we have a hankering for a solid burger.

Mostly I come here because of the movie theater.

Sometimes I come here to shop.

Once in awhile I come here to eat.

Rarely do I combine two of the above activities here at the Summit, but it's pretty dead handy when I do.  My favorite stores are the Apple and Old Navy stores.  I love the little doggie park and the mini putt putt green they have at that end of the mall. Just a nice extra thoughtful touch.

Unlike other people, I am not one of those people who delight in leisurely walking from shop to shop, spending 45 minutes here, 25 minutes there, and dangling multiple shopping bags from my arm, leaving red marks on my skin.  

That is not my idea of fun; therefore the idea of walking from store to store doesn't bother me.  I tend to just go where I need to go, zero in on what I need to buy, and then get the heck out of there.  That's why this kind of open layout is just fine by me.

As much as I'm  here I figured I should write a review.

This is a pretty nice store as far as grocery stores go. I've always had great experiences with their very friendly staff, and they have good prices.  Of course, being 15 minutes walking distance from my house with self-service a gas station available definitely gives it brownie points in my book.  Their sushi station is very fun, and I know a lot of my neighbors appreciate the Starbucks.  

I love that they have a wellness machine in the store.  With a family history of high blood pressure, I like checking mine every once and a while and seeing my BMI makes me stick to my exercise a bit more regularly.   I also love their online coupons.  I haven't gotten into couponing (yet, there are lots of coupon queens who come to the store and their tiny grocery bills are rather tempting), but Fry's online coupons tailored to my previous food purchases is an easy way to save some money

I do have an issue with their customer service over the phone.  I've called a few times to check if they have certain items or to ask about sales and events. I seem to always get wrong answers or the staff have no idea what I'm talking about.   Better off just going on your own if you can.

Their produce selection can also be abyssal at certain days/times.  I've gone in to find them out of literally over half their produce.  Kinda frustrating, but understandable I guess on busy days. I always try to shop earlier in the day now.

Felicitous is a homey coffee shop off of Fowler with plenty of indoor and outdoor seating.  I specifically went looking for Felicitous, as I'd heard great things, and was glad I found it.  I especially love all  of the creative drinks, since I'm not a plain coffee drinker.  I really enjoyed my Honey Bear at Felicitous, although, I was surprised that it was an additional $.50 to add a bit of cinnamon.  I tried the quiche and thought it was just fair and probably wouldn't get it again.
For parking, there is a small private parking lot in the front.
The pricing was a little higher than what I'd normally buy, but I like the creativity and know I'll be back.

Wow.  Won't spend a lot of time on the food. Everyone knows chick-fil-A has great food.  We good a ton of food but personally I got the deluxe spicy chicken sandwich with bacon and a lemonade. 

Now, the service I received there was TOP NOTCH. Probably the best service I received in any establishment.  Sean the operational manager is the person that help me.  And after he took my order i had to personally thank his for his superb customer service and professionalism.  Now it didn't stop there.  My niece misread the menu.  She wanted the deluxe spicy chicken sandwich, but she just asked for spicy chicken sandwich.  Sean came over to our table, we addressed our concern and got her the additional items to complete her sandwich.  

On the way out he assisted my mother with her drink as she walked with her walker.  Also, he held the door for her and just took care of everyone. Now I would love to say it was just for my family. But I saw I'm treat every person in the restaurant with the same kindness and respect.  

Sean is the example of what a great person and worker looks like.  You can tell it wasn't him acting.  It was his genuinely being him. Please pass along me and my families (and the other customers he assisted, even though they won't thank him) appreciation.

holy mackerel - i ate mackerel! er, uh, faux mackerel, that is...but whatever. 

just saying (writing?) those words sounds so funny to me as someone who not only hasn't eaten meat (yes, fish IS meat) in 20 years, but even when i did, i never ate mackerel. oh, and i also ate scallops, chicken and duck - all faux, of course, but oh how my boyfriend wishes they were the real deal!

actually, the bf is the one who suggested we give this restaurant a try (um, over 2 years ago...), and i can honestly say that he enjoyed every bite of our meal as much as i did, even for a meat eater. we decided to dine upstairs in the sit down restaurant which had a lovely ambiance, and opted for a la carte over the buffet. i am tempted to get that next time as i now want to try EVERYTHING on their menu! 

we started with the chicken satay and the scallops wrapped in bok choy. from the moment the finely designed plates were set upon our table i just *knew* we were in for a treat. when the incredibly affable manager (!) came to retrieve our if-this-wasn't-a-classy-establishment-we-would-have-licked-them-clean dishes, we couldn't stop gushing about how amazing everything was so far - and we still had our entrées on the way.

the bf ordered the grilled mackerel, served with chickpeas and vegetables in an orange walnut sauce, and while i chose the pan-roasted duck with sweet potato and greens in a ginger peanut sauce, we, of course, shared both. consider me WOWed! literally, we were oohing and aahing with every bite, and i'm surprised i didn't end up having a meg ryan moment in the middle of the restaurant. 

it took a lot of discipline, but we managed to stop ourselves from finishing and save some for leftovers in order that we could sample a few of the vegan desserts we'd heard so much about. the cheesecake? eh, if you're not vegan, don't bother. but the carrot cake? whoa good! highly recommend.

not sure why it took me so long to finally give govinda's a try, but since this most amazing experience just a few weeks ago, i have already gotten takeout from govinda's to go, not once, but twice!! the first time i went solo and got myself the golden tofu wrap. i was curious to see how they did tofu after having only sampled faux meats on my first visit. they done good. 

having raved about it to the [rather jealous] bf, he surprised me the following week with 2 different treats for us to share: the sabji wrap (no protein, just deliciously seasoned veggies, rice & cheese) and a chicken salad sandwich. as far as soy chix salads i have had, this one was unique in that it was a chunkier style, not shredded as it is typically served, tho the wheat roll used was kinda subway grade. while both were quite tasty...we preferred the sabji as it was more flavorful...and in a wrap.

at this rate, i'm happily on pace to conquer every item on both the sit down and G2G menus by the end of 2009. gotta make up for lost time!

I had lunch at Rumba after a ton of yard work, and ate way more than I needed. Happy hour is pretty long, so 2 for 1 margaritas really knocked me out. What I'm trying to say is that my productive Saturday ended here. I loved that they brought out corn fritters for the table - they were delicious. I have a penchant for hush puppies, so they got me there. For an entree, I had coconut shrimp which was great. 

The atmosphere is nice for what they could do. I sat on the patio, shaded by palms and loved how they had a tiki bar in the middle. Unfortunately this is an odd location for an island themed restaurant, since the view is a busy street. I would expect it to sit by the water, but I still enjoyed my time here.
We bought a lovely leather couch and chair on sale. The couch was, however, damaged when it arrived at our home, but Brett did replace it so we were pleased.

Nestled in Ardmore West Shopping Center, this has become my savior every workday morning.  Danny welcomes me as I walk in the door and even before I get to the counter, he already is preparing my medium hazlenut coffee with cream and sugar.  I love this place!

It was a hella hot day and my friends were showing me around Philly when we stumbled upon this cart! Such a treat--I love blueberry-flavored things and the Blueberry Ice Cream Sandwich ($4.50) was AMAZEBALLS! Whatever cardamom grahams is, I like it! Rich in flavor, love the texture of the whole thing...this gourmet ice cream sandwich was such a treat!

It's definitely it's own style of pizza, and after trying it, I wonder why there aren't more Detroit style pizza joints.  I love all types of pizza:  Chicago, New York, pan, hand tossed, whatever.  Now I can add Detroit to near the top of the list.  

This place has amazing pizza.  The crust is amazing.  It's crusty, buttery, thick, but not overwhelming.  The cheese is ridiculous.  I'd say off the chain perhaps, but Guy on the food network just killed that phrase for me.  Regardless, it is some of the best I've ever had on a pizza, and LOVE that they push it out so every edge has that perfectly burnt cheese crispness to it.  The sauce is not too sweet, and on top of the cheese.  I just wish there was bit more of it, or next time I should get some extra on the side.  

I have been here several times, and plan on being a regular.

Great venue for concerts. Plenty of parking. Recommend parking across the street at Music City Center, which is $15 vs. $25 at the arena. This is the home of our beloved Nashville Predators. There is a ton of eating and drinking options. There is plenty of security. The place is clean. You will have a great experience here.

just realized I've never reviewed one of the bars I spend most of my time out in. I love it here! lol warts and all && there are a few of sometimes (borderline) out of control regulars who make it hard. but I love them too! 

they have free food a lot. saints games and holidays are a good time to hit that up. they've got pool too if you're into that (one table). 

I love the pac man game. lol I sit there for hours nursing a whiskey ginger (that is -ahem- three dollars for a double. like what?) because I don't want to get up and die. should I even admit this on Yelp? 

the convenience store across the street has solid fried food and sandwiches if you need that on your way home.

Went here late date night after the movies. It was perfect timing. They have 1/2 off appetizers after 10pm. I love a deal. We got the buffalo dip, nachos, and buffalo strips. The food was great. Service was mediocre. The waitstaff at this location needs to be more professional. I understand it was later in the evening but foul language is never acceptable.

My first time eating Ethiopian!! I was a little nervous because I've heard the food can be a little on the sour side. I went with a couple of friends and we ate family style. 

We got their veggie platter and the chicken, lamb, and beef tibs. It was very flavorful and delicious! I loved all the little side vegetables that came with the meat. You eat with your hands, so make sure you wash your hands before your eat! The sour dough is soft and not too sour tasting. It also serves as a delicious edible delivery device. :) :)

The people were friendly and the restaurant was relatively clean. It wasn't too noisy either. I saw a few people casually studying here too. I will definitely be coming back again!!

The best place for a massage I have found. There are so many great options, it's fun to try different types. The staff is consistently super friendly and love the environment. Pedis are a little pricey but they do a great job.

These are some of the best donuts in Nashville!  I had a brioche yeast donut and an old fashioned donut to compare the styles, and I loved them both! In my experience, donut shops only usually excel at one or the other.

They're not cheap ($3.50 each, these are like gourmet donuts people) but two of them filled me up so much I skipped lunch. So they're ample, high quality, and delicious to boot.  I much prefer these over Five Daughters, in a heartbeat; it's obvious they take flavor combinations and even complexity to heart over creating a sugar bomb.

They remind me a bit of Blue Star Donuts in Portland, a famous line out there... but I like these better.  I can't wait to get my hands on more of these!

A local favorite of mine. Love coming in here for dinner or a business lunch. Always great service. It's got a small town feel and flair to it that keeps me coming back. Having some good beers on tap and solid wine list help that as well.

Jambalya Pasta....  Oh where do I begin?  This tasty treat is what got me in here in the first place. It's also what keeps me coming back even though I rarely even order it any more since i've found so many other delicious dishes on the extensive menu. The Pasta is always cooked spot on for me. The flavor is deep and rich and the spice is just enough to make you sweat a little. I have asked for it to be a bit spicier before and they obliged and I shot fire out of my face as a result. 

Lots of great salads and sammiches too! My moms loves the fish n chips and my girl loves the Prime Rib. 

There is a really nice outdoor seating area that you can choose to use. I like to sit out there on cool evenings and enjoy a cigar with my wine. Not much better than that!

Quit going to those awful chain stores down the street. There is never a wait here and you're getting fresh food made by someone who cares. Chef Raz'z personality is what changes this review from a 4 to a 5. Personal attention goes a long way with me!

This is by far my favorite brunch place in all of Philadelphia... and this is coming from a total brunch snob.
I've been here many times and each time I get overwhelmed by the menu options. They are so many great choices. If you have a sweet tooth like me, I recommend the Berrylicious French Toast - its what I got the first time I came and fell in love with this place. My favorite salad is the pesto, pineapple, arugula salad (I forgot the official name). 
This place does get very crowded on weekends, but the owner is amazing and super friendly and will accommodate all your needs. 
I speak so highly of this place - every really needs to try it out!

I'm always up for checking out a new food truck, but because I'm a vegetarian, this one was not one of the trucks that I sought out intentionally.  However, Chop Shop is, and they were at City Garden with 2 Girls 4 Wheels a few days ago.  My boyfriend is a meat and potatoes kind of guy, not a sushi guy, so he decided to order from here instead.  Because I hate to be left out, even though I got my food from Chop Shop, I had to have their grilled cheese too.

All of their main offerings (pulled pork sandwich, cheesesteak, chili, brats, slinger) are under 6 dollars, and the grilled cheese, advertised as having a hint of sweet flavor, and with a dipping sauce, is only 4 dollars.  They also have chips (some weird brand with a rapper's face on them...kind of strange), gooey butter cake, and soda.  My boyfriend ordered the pulled pork sandwich, which he didn't like that much, and while I liked the grilled cheese, it was kind of basic.  What set it apart was the sweet flavor that came through every few bites, probably from the bread, and it was cooked very well.  The dipping sauce was marinara, which I found to be quite odd.  I love the concept of a dipping sauce, but who wants marinara on their grilled cheese?  I would love to see them add a pesto, aioli, garlic butter...that would definitely bring me back.  Also, how about some fries or something?  Some people don't like rap on their radios or on their potato chip bags!

I'm a big food truck supporter, but overall, the experience was just ok for me.  The prices are reasonable, the grilled cheese was well cooked, and I think there is potential here.  Maybe I'm not their target clientele (I don't eat meat), but I'd love to see more vegetarian options, or at least some different dipping sauce and side options.

I love Panera/Bread Co! Food is really good and pretty healthy if you're looking for a fast food type of thing that's beyond just a sandwich. The bread bowls are seriously fantastic in both taste and the amount you get for the price you pay. My favorites are tomato, baked potato and chicken orzo. Not really a fan of their clam chowder.

As for the sandwiches, all the paninis are tasty and I really like the turkey on tomato basil bread. All of their salads are great too! Big fan of the Asian sesame chicken and Thai chopped chicken, really amazing taste profiles for a salad.

The breads, bagels and treats are really good too! I highly recommend the asiago bagel and the red velvet cookie. Can't complain much about anything but I have to say that this location gets pretty busy during the lunch hour. And of course since they make their stuff fresh everyday there isn't really much left to buy towards the end of the day. Sometimes their baguettes aren't as big as other locations too.

Service is outstanding most days but I guess they have their off days too because sometimes they can get pretty snappy. Overall though, this Bread Co is one of the best I've been to.

This was easily the highlight of my visit to Nashville. General admission is $17, and it's worth every penny. 

it's not a very big museum, but it's full of stuff. There's stations to listen to his music, and there's a back room that shows a film about Cash and features his work. 

There's so many things on display. There's a ton of outfits, hats, and boots that he wore on TV or in concert. His gear from his time in the military is there, furniture from their home is there. There's hand written lyrics sheets and love letters and the awards he received. There's even a door from prison on display there. I love Johnny Cash, and it was awesome to get to see some of this stuff first hand.

I also really liked that there's no guide, so you can stroll and read at your leisure. I like the no-pressure situation. 

On the way out, there's also a gift shop. There's shirts, books, albums, jewelry, and all kinds of things boasting his picture or his lyrics. I ended up buying my girlfriend a bar of soap that smelled like mint called Aloe, I'm Johnny Splash, because two puns are better than one. 

There's also a cafe here. We didn't get a chance to pay it a visit, but I think it's pretty cool. If I was from the area, no doubt I'd hang out there more often. 

If you're a fan of Cash or of country and rock music, be sure to stop here next time you're in Nashville.

Really cool vibe here but honestly I don't care for the pizza. I have been here a few times and have never been wowed. The crust is too thick and doughy/chewy for my taste. 

I did used to like to come here for an appetizer that was absolutely amazing for any olive lover, it's was an olive cheese bread. But they no longer have it on the menu! So upset they got rid of my favorite thing! No clue why, it was delicious. 

The mellow mushroom soup is pretty good. Last time I came here with a group I had mushroom soup and wings, cause like I said before I don't like the main attraction, the pizza lol. The wings and soup and other various sides are good. They also have a nice beer selection. Service is a hit or miss but in my experience typically it's slow.

Molasses bacon rimmed glasses was the highlight to my Bloody Mary.  Been to Farm and Fisherman's a handful of times. Each time we enjoyed our Meal, their Menu is creative and rotates, nice add to the area. Here's the scoop on my most recent visit: 

We were seated by a large family who were gathered there for some type of celebration so we requested a table by the window and they moved us. No issue.

Ambience is nice. Big and open inside. Nice layout, appeals to a great variety of age ranges, the brunch crowd was pretty mixed. 

To date, I've tried lunch, dinner, and drinks at happy hour here. It's not remotely bad by any means, but it's also just not remarkable. I would venture to say it's a tad overrated. But again, happy that there's a location like F&F in this area - we needed it. 

Pros: The food is fresh. Service is warm and friendly. Menu is creative. Love the farm to table concept.

Cons: Portions are small, prices do not match serving size. Food was good, combo of flavors just haven't made their mark for me.

Today we came for Sunday brunch. We ordered the Chef's Breakfast which are smaller portions of breakfast/lunch items served on a wooden board with a beer and a shot of bourbon. The menu varies each week. For $22 this was the most bang for your buck here. Our board came with a southwest omelette, huevos rancheros, breakfast pizza and the turkey Rueben - all good. We also ordered a Bloody Mary (I think it was called the bloody pig because it came with bacon) I LOVE bacon so it was a bit disheartening when I discovered a thin, half slice broken into pieces in the drink. The rim was really good, bacon crumbled molasses - different, tasty.

The turkey reuben was my favorite on the board, and despite the inconsistency in texture (some parts of the meat tough & dry, some tender) it still packed the complexity in flavor the other dishes lacked.

quality: food's fantastic. Cooked well and it seems like they only use the best ingredients and proteins. If on imagination and execution, however: I was satiated but not truly impressed. My food was good but lacked flavor. And for the price I am paying, I am expecting more. Just saying. 

Bloody Marys.. nothing out of this world. One whole slice of thick bacon would have been awesome. They clearly used lots of spice, so points there, but it also overpowered the other flavors and left us with an upset tummy all day..

We finished off with the cinnamon donut holes. They were really good!

There's some genuine effort here that deserves to be commended with your dollars on behalf of the staff, and I'm at least curious to try other parts of the menu later this year.

Great concept and potential here though. Looking to revisit in a few months and update.

Since my initial review, I've been back here quite a bit and thus felt the need to update. 

Initially, I wanted to hate this place mostly due to the fact that it's insanely trendy and hipster-y...and also because the service initially wasn't the best. And the pasta didn't blow me away mostly due to it being too under-cooked at first. There are aspects of Pastaria which are still not 100% perfect but let's face it, no one is perfect. (Although Taste is damn close, lol.) But I do feel as though they've improved a lot since I first went.

Took my parents here for dinner when they came into town and their minds = blown. My old man couldn't get enough of their Brussels sprouts, and he loved their bolognese pasta too. My mom ordered the pasta dish with the apples in it and couldn't get enough of the combination (I must admit, it's pretty effing good.) My sister liked their pizza too. My friend came here with me and had the pepper cheese pasta dish and asked them to go light on the pepper. Now I order that dish the way she did because before, it was wayyy too peppery. It's just right when you order it like this, unless pepper is yo thang. My dad and I enjoyed the "Primitivo" zinfandel wine they have here too, and my mom enjoyed their Bellini cocktail. 

So why no 5th star? OK, here's my beef with them: their policies. Like how they won't take reservations, and they won't seat partial parties. I get it. They have their reasons. But there are hundreds of other restaurants that DO take reservations and DO seat partial parties. And they are successful! Until they start doing those two things, I must withhold my fifth and final star, unfortunately. But that doesn't mean I won't go there anymore. I'll just plan to go there late at night or really really early so I can definitely get a table. And I'll have to coordinate better with my friends, which can be difficult especially when we're all driving from completely different towns and are unsure of the highway traffic and road construction, etc, etc.! Just really annoying and mostly an inconvenience because when I wanted to take my family there, they told me I couldn't get a reservation even for a party of 7 people or more. Wtf. My friend wasn't there yet either as something came up with her work and she had to call her boss on the fly, so I had to ask the server (not the hostess) if I could save the seat next to me for her. He said it was OK with him, lol, so it worked out. But they gave me so much crap when I asked to hold the seat for her. It's not like she was going to be an hour late and there were already five of us there. Jeez.
I think it would piss me off a whole lot less if they weren't so snooty about it over the phone and in person. If they said, "I'm so sorry, but please feel free to grab a drink/appetizer at the bar, grab a seat and make yourself at home while you wait." That would be nice. If only they actually read this shit and took into account people's feedback. If only!

But... also glad to know there is always the option of getting fresh pasta to go and fresh sauce as well. And gelato! I mean, shit, when I feel inclined to cook and actually do my own dishes, I will make a quick stop here and grab shit and go to avoid the stress of not having a reservation.

In summation:

- my friends & parents love this joint
- amazingly delish food & wine & desserts
- can get said food & dessert to go if needed and cook at home
- service is improving significantly
- free fucking parking, FUCK yea (ask them to validate your ticket when you leave)
- their policies still suck
- Sean still hates it here, sadly
- I feel like a fatass afterwards...but sooo worth it!

I'm planning to bring Sean's parents to Pastaria next week, and I hope they don't mind eating early-ish to avoid waiting.

Nada is one of my go to spots in Cincy and also now in Indy!  The food is super tasty as are the cocktails.  We recently stopped in for dinner before a concert since we knew it would be a solid pick.  
Our server was friendly and seemed to be enjoying her shift.  I find that to be such a nice thing when you're dining out...it can definitely make the mood of dinner more pleasant.  
The salsas are all great as is the guacamole too!  And of course the queso is a must if you love melted cheese like most cool people do!  The chips are thick but fresh and except for the fact that they fill you up quicker than you might want, are solid vehicles for the dips and salsas!  Grab a kale and mushroom taco too!  You will not be disappointed.  Oh, and the potatoes, beans & rice, and chicken enchiladas are also high points in my opinion.  
I wish this location had a better patio but due to the location it isn't feasible I guess.  None the less I am glad to see that Indianapolis now has a Nada to visit.

From what I have heard this place is listed as one of the top ten restaurants, however I have to say I am a little disappointed. While the service was phenomenal, the food was just meh compared to other places I have eaten in the city on this trip. Specially, the gumbo was strangely like mushroom gravy (did not even come with rice). The foie gras had an interesting creole twist, and the filet was prepared correctly but not too impressed with the rest of the dish. It was actually quite salty. We tried bread pudding soufflé as well but again was not the experience of food I had been thinking it would be. Love the atmosphere and I am sure this is up many people's alley. I was a little disappointed. Thanks for reading.

My husband and I met some friends here last night for dinner and trivia. I ordered the veggie burger with a gluten free bun (#newyearsresolutions) and fries. I sadly drank water and everyone else had beer or mixed drinks. I like that the drinks were all served in mason jars. It was very fitting with the cute, vintage tables & twinkle lights. Our server was really nice and our drinks were never empty. I personally really loved the veggie burger. I've never had a veggie burger made with beets but I want more! The bun tasted great but was a little more dense than a regular bun. Still, it didn't have the weird taste of some GF breads. It was just impossible to pick up and eat without the burger squishing out onto my plate. I do wish I could have eaten this like an actual burger and not with a fork, but it was still really tasty. There were other things on the menu that were tempting and my husband's pretzels looked awesome. Trivia was really fun and we will definitely be back!

I am so happy that whomever runs their social media over at Coffee House Five invited me to check them out. Upon entering you are greeted with smiles, pleasant demeanors, and super helpful staff. This is a fabulous spot on the Southside of Indy worth checking out. They have such a clean and open space for meeting with loved ones, working remotely, or just enjoying some time solo. I went in today with my 9 month old and everyone was super helpful and sweet. I love being able to go out and work remotely while having my baby accompany me without having to deal with attitude from people simple because I am there with my baby. She was so sweet and didn't get fussy until I was packing us up to leave so you know this space has great energies if the baby was cool, calm, and collected!

 The best part about this particular coffee house is they are a for benefit coffee house. They actually provide couples counseling and addiction counseling. I was so impressed I had to support them as much as I could by purchasing an egg sandwich, chocolate muffin, latté, sticker, and a t-shirt. It's not very often I find a place that moves me such as they have. If you find yourself on the Southside of Indy please stop in to check them out!

I really want to like this place.  I do.  I love brewpubs, and the place is gorgeous inside.  It felt very comfortable, and I was ready to buy a pint glass (a habit if I like a place) on the way in.  We were seated in what is normally an outside area, if it's not cold as hell out.  It Iooked nice in there, and the tenting, heat lamps, and fireplace made a nice winter backup.

I'll even cover the rest of what I liked, before I rip this place a new one.  The beers I had are decent, not spectacular, but still pretty good in range and flavor.  The beer battered fries are damn good, and I ate a lot, which is odd, since I don't enjoy fries that much.  The roast beef sandwich was fantastic, and everything I'd want that little slice of comfort food to be, complete with au jus that didn't taste like cheap fat on the side.

Now, why would I say all that, and give it one star?  I'm pretty sure I even gave a place where I saw a cockroach two stars, out of mercy with their food being so good.  Here's why:

-- Free range kids.  Now, I'm not sure why anyone would bring their young children to a brewpub for a birthday party, but that is not the restaurant's fault.  How they handle it, on the other hand, is their problem.  First, if parents aren't doing their damn job, it is up to the restaurant to make sure other customers don't have to put up with your screaming crotchfruit running around.  There's also a safety issue, because you now have servers carrying trays and glasses of beer with this going on.  On top of both of those things, if other patrons ask you to do something (which we did), you talk to the parents, not ignore paying customers.

Seriously, kids should be encouraged to play around and have fun. . . at a Chuck E Cheese or similar place.  I'm sorry, but this is not a Chuck E Cheese.  Oh and, if you want your restaurant to resemble that, which it seems like you did by sitting every family in the entire place in one room, then don't sit the childless young couple there too.  There were plenty of other open rooms in the joint that I'd have been comfortable in.

-- Service.  Kids aside, our waitress was totally useless.  The place wasn't that busy, but she was nowhere to be seen for most of the night.  She screwed up at least one order, and was unresponsive at best when we did find her.  At least once, we had to flag down another server, who was harried from dealing with the birthday party parents.

-- The hamburger.  Now, if there's one thing I expect out of a brewpub, it's to have a decent burger.  I've never been to one that had a terrible burger, and frankly some of the best ones seem to come from brewpubs.  They jacked it up, though.  Badly.  "Medium" is a common way to cook a burger and does not translate to "Please burn the outside to a crisp, but leave raw meat in the center."  We considered sending it back, but well, given that we barely saw the waitress, and wanted to get out from Kid-Mageddon, I shared my sandwich and fries, and we got the hell out of there.

I *might* go back when I'm in the area again, but only for a beer at the bar, and only if someone else is buying.  You are dead to me, MBC. Dead.

~EEE~

Crooked Tree is a great addition to St. Charles.  It's been here for some time, but I was excited when it opened up about six years ago.  This coffee shop/eatery is located in midtown in an old building on First Capitol.  The ceiling is old with exposed duct work and the walls are brick.  I love old buildings that house businesses.  My personal favorite item here is the veggie wrap and it comes with a side of fruit.  Perfect!  Not too filling.  I also like the Thai peanut wrap.  For breakfast I like the Spin Veggie Sandwich with egg, mushrooms, feta and spinach served on a croissant.  The Breakfast Quesadillas are yummy too!   I really want to try the French toast because the syrup smells really good.  Don't forget to try the baked goods as well.  The blueberry scone is all I have to say.  

The coffee is fresh and the refills are free while you dine in and use the free WiFi.   The Iced Chai Latte is my favorite drink.  Get one!  If neither of those toot you whistle then they have have a variety of tea and smoothies.  The water is served from a neat contraption that fooled me at first, but once I figured it out I was on my way to hydration.  Crooked Tree is a really a well rounded coffee shop with great food and comfy atmosphere with inside and outside seating.  Go see for yourself.

I moved to Philly 8 years ago and thought I was safe from the tantalizing Krispy Kreme and i was until KK reappeared in the Philadelphia area right across the street from my office @ 17th & Market! Darn it! But, I signed up for email notices and have been here a few times.....I FINALLY got to try the original glazed hot from the oven with some dark roast coffee and yum! I like KK's dark roast coffee and LOVE their donuts....Whenever I go for the treat, the service is good and product is always the same D-I-V-I-N-E.....

After many, many more visits I am updating my previous  review.  I eat here at list once every week when I am working in downtown Indy.  It doesn't matter what I order, everything is always served fresh, hot, and exactly as ordered.

There is a real kitchen here.  All the ingredients are cooked and prepared on premises and you can definitely tell by the freshness and quality.

I have brought many out-of-town clients here and they all love it.  I have introduced coworkers and turned them into Fast Burrito regulars.  

My favorite here is the veggie burrito bowl with sautéed veggies, beans, fresh guac, lettuce, onions, sour cream and queso.  The nachos rock as well.

Employees are super friendly and personable.  They remember the regular customers and carry on friendly conversation through the line.

They have daily specials posted that come with a drink, chips, salsa, and even a homemade cookie.

You can't find a better life lunch in downtown Indy.  Fast, friendly, fresh and delicious plus a very good value.

Like other reviewer has mentioned, this place have the same worker who used to work at Young Bin Kwan. I'm not 100% sure whats the story behind it, like what's going on with the old place and who or why they bought off the place and such. So I won't talk about it.

Tasty as ever. Don't worry.

I have to take off 1 star because I'm not a fan of their new location. I felt unsafe, somehow. Maybe that was because I went there at night and its all dark.. I don't know. But yeah.. there's this .. 'light' disturbance when me and my friends was there. The back door, which I believe supposed to be a Fire Exit door, was either bang or slammed so loudly from outside.. like everything happen so random and so creepy. I had a feeling that it was from the kids in that neighborhood. Yes it was 8pm-ish and there's still a lot of neighborhood kids playing outside.

But yeah.. I'll definitely be back. Love them food very much.

I know I can love my dive bars, depending on my mood and situatio. Last night after a nice dinner out & a few errands, we decided it was time for an adult beverage. We had just finished at Big Lots, when we noticed Pit Stop Pub. On the Northwest cornor of Hillsborough Ave.  & Hanley Road is an L shaped strip mall where the pub is located.
Pit stop is an eclectic dive that comes complete with pool tables. As we entered, there was a sign outside saying it was ladies night and beer & wine were 50 % off. The establishment is rather long, narrow & dark. It is also quite smokey, I was glad they had the front door proper open.
The beer selection was adequate, but what these places do to wine is beyond my comprehension. Let me just say the wine is rough.
I had not played pool in a few years and enjoyed relaxing and playing a few games, quite enjoyable. The place was fairly deserted and as an ex - smoker,  I had, had enough of the smokey filled atmosphere.
I love dive bars, but am not quite as impressed with most dive pubs. I am sure we will be back to enjoy a few more games of pool & I may have to drink beer, the wine, just isn't for me.
What's a girl to do?  You happen upon a new dive, have a bit of time, so you check it out!

Loved the muffaletta, and I didn't think I would, because the individual parts aren't something I normally would enjoy, but I used the "when in Rome" mentality and just dug in, and was pleasantly surprised!

I split one sandwich with two other adults (my mother-in-law and father-in-law) and it was enough for lunch for the three of us, with one bag of chips to split. 

Delicious and definitely worth the wait in line!

I forking love this place.  It's a known fact that I have to take all of my new hires to this place because a) most of them have never had Thai (I was a Thai virgin previously myself), and b) what better place to go to on the Square than this?  I mean, don't get me wrong, I love me quite a few other restaurants, but when I think of Fountain Square, I think of Siam Square first!

Paid Thai, Sweet and Sour Chicken, Thom Thom Soup, Drunken Noodles.  The exploration of food opportunities is endless!  I typically never venture far from my Pad Thai, but when I do, it's always fantabulous.

Hints to newbies:  Don't go on a Friday during lunch- super busy, and if you do, go at 11:30 or 2:00!!  Also, they have an upstairs area.  If going with a work group- request the upstairs as the downstairs is super loud and can be hard to have a 'work meeting' (wink wink).

Other than that- I would LOVE to see a bar at this place.  That would definitely kick it up a notch, but even without the bar, it's my easy go to place in FS.

Selection of stores is great here!!! Ample parking!!! Holiday shopping is a nightmare! But everything else is great about this mall! Lots of stores to choose from. The bathrooms are being renovated now which has been long over due!!! Love shopping here!!!

My feelings about my experiences with Daleng are very mixed. I'm willing to chalk that up to the fact that I've only done takeout, while most of the reviews and photos (which heightened my expectations) were based on eat-in experiences. 

The pros: highly flavored, completely delicious on both entrees that I've tried, specifically the Eggplant and Veggie Curry and the Cambodian Stir Fry with Tofu. The sauce on the eggplant and veggie curry is so good that I could just pour that on a plate of brown rice and happily call it a meal. The tofu in the Cambodian Stir Fry is well prepared, there's lots of lemongrass, which I love, and the the vegetables in both are so thoroughly cooked that every bite is a melt-in-your-mouth party of tender vegetables, flavorful sauce and fluffy rice.
The service is friendly and quick, and for eat-in it looks like they have a good drink selection with really good prices. So I definitely want to have an eat-in experience here.

The not-so-pros: In spite of other reviews claiming the contrary here, the portion sizes are not really that generous. I feel like for the price, the portions might have been what you would expect for a lunch portion from a restaurant that was less "takeout-esque" (borrowing Karen X's brilliant wordplay there) than Daleng. They don't really pack the takeout containers, which is understandable because there's A LOT of sauce and it was spilling out even from the 3/4 filled containers. The amount of rice was a little harder to forgive though; the cup-sized cartons were only partially filled to the top, and there were gaps at the bottom of the container (so not even packed in). Again, probably not a problem if you were to do an eat-in meal, but not great for what I'd expect from a takeout carton of rice. When similar sized takeout containers from most places provide enough for two generous meals for me, and from here the containers provide about half of that, I can't help noticing.
 
All that said, I will almost definitely still be doing both takeout and eat-in here. My husband tried the vegetarian banh mi and was underwhelmed, so maybe I'll just stick to their stir fries (and gotta try the spring rolls too). That eggplant and vegetable curry will definitely be a permanent favorite.

Love this Museum. The displays are top notch and well done. As you walk in the lobby area is large with a theater and a grand staircase. This museum tells the story of the American Revolution. If I were you I would splurge for the audio system which gives you an in depth historical explanation of the life and times of what was happening. My one suggestion is to try to follow in order so you can get a chronological explanation of what you are seeing. When we went there was a large crowd of kids and to try to avoid the congestion we went to a different portion of the museum and we were a bit lost. Overall I would suggest this place as a "must see" when you travel to Philadelphia.

I love Arni's! I'm from Lafayette that houses the original Arni's and I am beyond thrilled to have a taste of home so close to me! I've never had a bad experience here. The food is always spot on. My favorite things are the Arni's jr, the salad that will make you rethink all other salads moving forward in life. The Stromboli, which in my opinion is one of the best sandwiches ever. It's on this bread that is like crusty yet soft, it's just amazing. And then of course the pizza! The ultimate thin crust with a great sauce and always great toppings. If you like great food and service go visit here! It'll make you say MEET YOU AT ARNI's !

I always seem to have an issue at this location, especially in the drive thru. I feel like I wait for such a long time and then there's always something missing or wrong with my order. I seriously don't understand how they could mess up items so simple like soups, salads, and sandwiches. I used to  go here a lot, but recently I feel like the service has gotten much worse and there always seems to be an error when I go through the drive thru. Also, one of the girls who is the cashier at the drive thru has been pretty rude with her attitude and facial expressions on more than one occasion. Although I loved the convenience of a drive thru Panera, I don't think it is worth continuously wasting my money here.

Oh Whisk... I can't tell you how much I love you. How much you make my taste buds happy. How much my treadmill loves you for all the action it's getting.

Seriously, Whisk is everything I love in a local bakery.

The staff is so sweet. I was stalking out some pumpkin snickerdoodles they posted a photo of on Facebook, and when I called and found out they were gone, I was sad. That's until the owner told me she'd pop some in the oven for me. They were out of this world.

The look of this place is so charming, comforting, colorful, and is such a great addition to Cherokee street. I can see myself spending some time working here with baked goodies and some local coffee (the only thing missing is wifi!)

Swing by when you can, seriously. I haven't had something I didn't like here. Vegans, there are options for you as well.

Thanks for just existing, Whisk!

Located in a tiny room next to deVine Wines and Spirits, Tzin Wine and Tapas literally has enough room for seven two-top tables (two people per table). That, plus a short bar, plus a corner kitchen area, constitutes the entire restaurant.

It's quite dark inside, with tabletop candles and Spanish music playing in the background - perfect for a first date, a hundredth date, or drinks with close friends and co-workers. Not, on the other hand, a family-friendly restaurant; I wouldn't recommend bringing any children here.

The wine list was quite extensive, as I expected it to be, and offered a variety of by-the-glass choices, and just as many by-the-bottle options. I tasted two red wines during my visit: the Ben Marco Malbec, Argentina (hints of blackcurrant and slightly acidic) and the Pasion Brava Tempranillo (Rioja), Spain (much sweeter, very smooth drinking). No matter your wine preference, Tzin has a variety of options to suit every taste, and the excellent service ensures that your wine glass is always topped up.

Tzin offers a typical tapas-style menu: a selection of small-ish dishes with a strong foundation in Spanish cuisine. Diners can either select several to share amongst their party, or choose one or two for themselves. Everything (and I mean everything) sounded delicious, so it was difficult to make a decision.

In the end, I decided to try the Olive Plate to start, since I love pairing marinated olives with wine. Alongside the olives, the plate boasted a selection of focaccia bread, olive tapenade, and a dish of olive oil and balsamic vinegar, all of which were delectable. The warm marinated olives were delicious and went extremely well with my glass of Ben Marco.

For dinner, we decided to order separate dishes, and opted for the Chorizo and Gnocchi Stew and the Chicken Breast Supreme. The stew, served with grilled flat bread, was absolutely heavenly and had a weighty tomato taste that complemented the manchego gnocchi and chorizo exceptionally well. The chicken breast dish was moist and tender, and was served on a bed of harissa couscous and dried apricots, with a dollop of minted yoghurt. Harissa is a Tunisian hot chili sauce, so the couscous understandably had a bit of a kick to it; if you don't like spicy foods, I'd advise you not to choose this dish. The spiciness isn't overpowering, but it'll set your mouth tingling if you eat enough of the couscous.

We had excellent service throughout our entire visit - the server was very friendly and accommodating - and enjoyed the chic décor, open-style kitchen, and gigantic wine rack (my next purchase).

One of the things I like best about Tzin is that they're all about the dining experience. This restaurant is about relaxing, enjoying a good glass of wine, and sampling delicious appetizers and tapas plates. They're a hole-in-the-wall restaurant simply for this reason; if they were to enlarge the space and cram in as many tables as possible, they'd lose much of the charm they get from the currently intimate, personal dining experience. 

If you work downtown, if you enjoy wine and tapas, or, hell...if you live in Edmonton...you need to make a date to visit Tzin sometime soon. As I've said, and as their website stresses, they're a small restaurant, so please make the most of OpenTable and book yourself a place. Then all you need to do is sit back, quaff some wine, nibble on an appetizer, and simply experience.

Thank goodness for The Lotus Room. I had a massage booked elsewhere, showed up and it had been mysteriously cancelled. I NEEDED a massage, my day depended on it. I called a couple places with good Yelp! reviews, and The Lotus Room was the only one to accommodate, adding a slot in their schedule at the end of the day. I was so thankful for masseuse Victoria for extending her work day for me. 

The building is off 18th Ave S, in a house-office building with single room offices which are mostly hair salons. There are a lot of these houses in the area and I love the eclectic mix of entrepreneurs who occupy them. Just drive through the alley to park behind the building and walk up the stairs to the second floor.

As soon as I laid down on the table, I was overtaken with relaxation. The full body massage was the perfect amount of pressure (medium-deep) and the room smelled wonderful. The buzz of the air conditioning unit did not even disturb me and the state I was in. I was offered an eye cover when I flipped over as it was sunset and there was still a bit of light in the room and it was perfect. 

I most certainly did not want it to be over when my hour was up.

Found this gem orignally from a coworker and went back a couple of times already. They literally have the BEST hummus in the city! The menu will change slightly each time I visit but I love trying all different kinds of hummus there. My favorite one is eggplant hummus. They are so generous with the portion too - I always leave with a full stomach! Since this place is so popular, it is always packed during lunch time! But you can do take out so not a biggie. I will recommend this restaurant to any hummus lovers!!! Please check it out ;)

If I were rating based on service, this would probably be a 4 or 5, but overall I don't think this is a must do in New Orleans. It's definitely an institution if you want to check it off your list, but for price and time, I'd probably prefer to check out other spots instead. We got the trio of soups to start (sampler of turtle, gumbo and soup du hour which was some vegetable soup for us). I think they were ok- but nothing memorable and honestly on the salty side. We both got fish dishes for our entree. I think my boyfriend's cast iron seared gulf fish was actually quite good- probably the best dish of the night. The pecan crusted fish was good, and supposedly one of their more popular, but I don't know if I'd order again. The desserts were actually pretty decent! My friend is obsessed with their creole bread pudding soufflé and may have raised our expectations too high...it was delicious and quite good! But not like mind blowing as he noted...but definitely worth a try if you're visiting the restaurant. The strawberry shortcake was actually my favorite between the two (we got both). I'll also say the cocktails were pretty decent and not too sweet. I got the sweet potato drink, which didn't taste much like sweet potato but reminded me a bit of a White Russian. Overall lovely staff and restaurant but not in my list of must-dos.

Update: after reading other reviews, I wanted to point out that I was NOT asked to leave a review. Or entering part of a raffle when doing this. This is truly a review I have been drafting since I moved in. I read horrible reviews and very few positive ones prior to moving in. I truly enjoyed my time here and want to leave a review that reflects that. 

This may be my longest review yet so hold on!

Before I moved in:
super easy website to navigate.  Liz was very friendly and helped out.  I was looking to move a few months out,  so I had time to do my research. 
 (I was looking during Covid - May/ June 2020) Liz worked with me to schedule an apartment tour. She left the door open and let me help myself to the apartment that I could tour. I mean it's a place to live,  I was just looking that we had 4 walls up.  I LOVED the closet, and decided that day that this would be my home. 

Application Process: 
Once again,  the website made everything very user friendly. I filled out the application,  submitted previous rental history and was pretty much approved.  I applied for a 1/1, one of their "older" (non-renovated) apartments. 

Move in: 
Picking up keys in the front office was simple. I got the keys and moved in!  My dog was obsessed with the dog park.  

First month: 
During move in,  I filled out paper work to have maintenance fix the bathtub strip, and they were out to my place within hours.  Honestly- impressed. 
I also had issues with our front door not locking.  Apparently another delivery vendor had the wires wrong.  The maintenance team came out 2 or 3 times until it was ultimately fixed. 
I loved my neighbors!  I had great neighbors who enjoyed my dog and were helpful when I did dumb things,  like leave my keys in my door one day! 
My apartment building was fairly quiet. 
The bad: some neighbors have dogs that bark ALL day and at any sound of movement.  (This is out of the offices control really). Luckily,  when your doors are closed,  you can barely hear your neighbors.
Internet through AT&T was great,  you do have to go on your own,  but with the fiberoptic cabled internet- it was amazing. 

The gym:
It's what you expect- a fitness center in an apartment complex.  I did use it when it was snowing outside and before I got my Y membership.  I was looking for a gym to swim in all year.  Otherwise,  it has a few weight machines,  treadmills,  bikes,  and free weights.

The dog park: 
Is great for my pup! He loves to go and really just runs around.  There are hoops to jump through and a tunnel.  My dog was more interested in other dogs and playing with the ball. 
The bad:  some people don't pick up their dogs poop, which is a bummer at the park!  The gates also had issues,  eventually the back one was fixed with a zip tie. The front 2 are still difficult to shut

Pets:
This is a dog friendly apartment complex!  And almost everyone has dogs.  I like that they have poop bags available throughout the complex in case you forget yours.  The only two problems are the few people who do not pick up their poop & the dog owners who let their dogs off leash.

Parking:  easy,  always parking available. 
The bad:  there is no security in place at all.  I had my catalytic converter cut out in the parking lot  I was also NOT the only one.  There were at least two other cars disabled for a couple months because of this.  I also heard of it happening to other people,  but didn't see their car disabled for long.  
It is not gated,  anyone can come in,  no security cameras. 

Neighbors:
There are kids from the next neighborhood over that come over often and drink and smash bottles in the parking lot.  It sucks because you never know what they are going to get into,  and my dog walks around and can step on the glass. Once again,  no real security here.

Trash, I think pick up is on Mondays and Thursdays. With it being an apt complex, many other people come here to dump their stuff,  so I recommend taking out your trash on Mondays or Thursdays after it's picked up. 

Winter: 
The Great: our sidewalks were always taken care of.  There was always a place to walk and it was great.  The roads had their moments,  and I think it may be a different group that comes in for the roads. I was amazed at how clean our sidewalks were after snowing for hours.

Payment:
I opted to use their app to pay.  There are different charges based on which route you go.  I liked being able to pay online whenever I wanted to.

Mail/ packages: 
I never had any issues with missing mail or packages. 

Bonus: 
The complex plays bingo for money off rent. They also host cute contests(seasonal / pet related). And really do some cool things for their residents.  
Checkout:  will update soon!  I move out in a couple months. 

Overall, I would recommend this apartment complex to any one.  I really had a great experience and never had huge issues that weren't dealt with immediately.  I worked with Liz & Erin for multiple items and only had great interactions.

Everyone is happy to finally have something here in Land O Lakes and it shows.  This place is always packed.  

Been to many other first watch locations and this one lives up to the rest.  Solid food and a nice atmosphere.  Love the get in line for a table feature they offer online.  

Took my two children for breakfast.  Three entrees and 3 drinks came to $52.  Personally, I feel that's a bit pricey for what you get but maybe that's just me.  

Will be back with the Mrs for Brunch and post more.

Love Love Love Blackstone.    Great beers (Black Belle at 13.2% ABV is so good), great outside spot to drink and enjoy sun with your doggy, super friendly staff and $2.50 beers on Sunday.  

Why are you here???

I am extremely overly impressed with my experience at Edge. The service was top-notch, and the food was incredible. I enjoyed a few of the new seltzer's, with the Orange being my all time favorite! The Steak Bowl was delightfully put together, with incredible flavor in every bite. I will definitely be coming back! Just a recommendation, but, In the future, I'd love to see the installation of some booths, instead of high tops.

This hotel is so beautiful from every angle, inside and out. The view on the rooftop is amazing. Loved the touch of the bus on the rooftop. I need to stay here one night!!!
They basically have like 3 restaurants in there, one once you enter to the left there is a dine in with patio seating. I didn't look at the menu since it was closing. They also have a food on the rooftop bar but the kitchen was closed there as well so we dined in the first floor of the hotel which is for the Tavern It was so beautiful. The food was good and we got lucky bc they made an extra shrimp and grits and gave it to our table. And let me tell you that was some good shrimp and grits!!! Steak was cooked perfect and the sides really complimented the entree. I will definitely have to try other foods. Everyone must come here at least once. You will not be disappointed.

We love this Starbucks for a few reasons: 
It is close to the blue route so we can get to it easily en route to and from work. The staff is always kind and welcoming. They are also most knowledgeable about their products' ingredients, and the ambiance is bright and the place is always clean! Keep up the great work, Starbucks!

There is no better lunch option on a Friday than the Assumption Greek Orthodox Church Lunch.  Homemade Greek food with love.  Every Friday from 11 am- 2 pm, you can be sure to enjoy true Greek hospitality.  Drive to the very back of the parking lot and enter the white doors where you see a set of small stairs and a wheelchair ramp.  If it is your first time, there are plenty of people to point you in the right direction.

The church does an amazing job of posting their whole month's menu online.  They even have a downloadable copy for offices and groups that order together.  Take Out here is a breeze.  You can call the kitchen and place your pick up order directly or wait in line to see the options.  If you choose to eat at the location there are plenty of round tables filling the entire auditorium space.  

On my last visit, I was thrilled to order Lobster Bisque ($4.00), Spanakopitia ($3.00), Greek Salad ($5.00) and Dolmathes (2 for $3.00).  I had so much left over it made a second lunch.  Over the years, I have probably ordered almost everything.  Every Week they offer a Baked Fish option.  I have gotten the Baked Fish and served it for Dinner before.  Everything is boxed nicely and holds well.  The homemade soups never disappoint.  Once a month or so they sever Lamb Shank, expect longer lines on these days.

You do not have to wait for the once a year Greek Festival for fresh and flavorful Greek food.  Plan a visit to this West County hidden treasure soon.

I have always liked the food at QSL. Great wings with a ton of variety and heat levels. Good burgers, chicken, and sandwiches. This time I got Thai "R" Cracker flavor. Wings were  not at all hot, but we're spot on as always. Great flavor  with some garlic and soy. Also got magma fries with bacon, cheese, scallions, and a side of ranch. Pure health food. ;-)) We were there on Bike Night, which I've loved for almost 20yrs. I'm glad I got to come here while on vacation. Our server, Jenny was EXCELLENT! I felt like Forrest Gump in the joint. She's quick, has a great memory, and excellent patience to put up with my questions and picky ordering. It was busy, bit she was rocking. It doesn't hurt that she's a knockout!

3.5- I kinda always felt compelled to go since moving to Philly, and finally got the chance this restaurant week winter 2017, and it was good! Not great, a good meal of simple traditional tapas. Especially good for the restaurant week price I paid! 

we had- 
-ham croquettes (good, but were cold when brought out to the table. probably because of the restaurant week factory assembling or some process going on but still) 
-cheese with lavender truffled honey (I'm not big on cheese so can't tell, but the honey was good! I was a little disappointed I couldn't taste the lavender) 
-shrimp (this was goooood. I wished there was more than 2!!) 
-pork sandwich (without this, I would've ended the meal hungry. Perfect texture, a faint mustard type taste, greens. delicious bread.) 
-cauliflower (very Mediterranean inspired. of course it was good, because how could grilled cauliflower taste bad?) 
-goat cheese (I didn't try this)
-egg cream (a good decadent end to the meal. I loved the foam on top!) 

A bit of a mixed bag, as you can see from my comments! If I craved tapas and if it's restaurant week again I'd come back. Not sure I'd pay Amada's usual prices.

WV is one of the many locations along my personal Bucks County Wine Tour - I visited because of the high ratings on Yelp! Thanks Yelp!

The wine is everything you'd expect for the region, and then some. They also feature free hors d'oeuvres that compliment the wine, and the venue is very nice as well. The staff is quite lovely and super super friendly - there was a large party off to the right so they CAN accommodate parties if that's your thing.

They also feature smoothies for those that want to indulge in something fun and different, especially on those warm Summer days!

It's a must visit and it'll be a must returned visit, for me!

THIS has been a review by Gaurav

Loved this place! Had an amazing selection of brats in all kinds of meats. Toppings were great, prices were great. And ohhhhh the fries. They have dipping sauces and all was just delicious. It was a close walk from our hotel the Canary which made it the perfect place to stop in for a beer and meal!

Decided to have this for lunch today and wasn't disappointed! I went before lunch time to beat traffic so I was in and out. I got a little fry and a little bacon cheeseburger. I loved that there was a bun less option so I ditched some carbs lol. When my order was being made the cook asked if my bun less option was due to an allergy and it wasn't. The fact I was asked was impressive but I guess for their sake they need to make sure. I got my burger in a tin bowl and the fries were in a separate bag. 
    I loved every bite! I don't come here often but today made me want to make another trip! Everything including service was great!

I don't think I can even begin to tell you how much I love this place.  LOVE IT.  Homemade sausage sandwiches.  Real homemade italian sausage.  My father started taking me here when I was a kid.
The owner is almost always there taking the orders-- and I would guess it was her family working.
Be warned.  If you plan to go there for lunch get there early or...well you will be screwed.

A fun story-- a friend of mine and I went--  a man was opening up shop near her and came in to ask if she would be okay with this.  She looked gravely serious at first and the guy got nervous--  and then with a huge smile she leaned back and said "Of course!  Good luck!"

Great place.  Great place. Great place.

Loooooove this place!!Delish choices,always bring in new flavors, and old ones too. My daughter loves the whole self serve concept, as many kids there. Come here all the time. I love that kids get some toys every time, really cute ones at times. The weekends are packed though, so we try to stick to weekdays.

Bam! This place is out of this world. I have never had a better dinning experience in my life. The steak is always flawless and as you cut it with your knife. It's just like cutting through soft butter and then you dip it in the sauce they give you. It's like an organism for your taste buds. I absolutely love this place. 

The staff is very well trained and caters to your every desire. I have never had a bad experience here and say that the place is first class. You never know who you will see in the place to include Emeril himself walking around his restaurant.

I am losing the love here for sure! 5 treadmills have been out of service for over a month so now, all the cardio equipment is over crowded from people using the other stuff since treadmills are down! Ridiculous that it is taking so long to fix this! Also, I am getting bored with all the steroid kings screwing up all the weight machines. They take all the pieces off the machines to use them for purposes they were not intended for and when I want to use the circuit machines, I have to go searching for the handles and clips!! Annoying!! It would be nice if the employees could do this throughout their shift, but they are too busy eating or playing on their phones to notice! This place needs an overhaul!!!!

So happy that we discovered this place. The progression of my taste preference with ciders has really changed over the years and the dryness of the ciders at Hale & True is perfect for my taste now. Get the flight and figure out which ones you really like. The standard and the lil sunshine are my favorites. (If you're looking for a strongbow or angry orchard like cider you won't find it here)

They're a smaller location so there's only maybe 4 or so ciders offered on draft, wish there was more at a time but that's my only complaint.

Aside from the great ciders, it's an nice cozy atmosphere! We love going and ordering some nomad pizza from next door to enjoy with our ciders. That being said, all of the bartenders and waitstaff we've met have all been extremely accommodating.

I came here to catch up with a friend and because I love Taste so, so much. We didn't try the food but each had two delicious cocktails. It didn't disappoint and the service was great! I love just telling the bartenders the flavors I'm into and letting them pick a drink for me. Both times the choices were great. I'm not a fan of Bourbon but they convinced me to try a Bourbon drink and it was the first one I actually enjoyed.
I think I prefer Taste a little more but that's also because it's much closer to where I live and it's more familiar to me, but this is such a great addition to this area. I would love to come sit on their patio next time!

Haddonfield looks like a lovely little town. Every store tends to cater toward what I would call the yuppie. The Chip Shop is a breathe of semi-fresh English air. I love fish and chips, and, though, this wasn't the best I've had (I prefer Cod to their Haddock), it made the top 3 or 4. The SF dive bar Edinburgh Castle is my all time favorite with delivery from a nearby shop. The fries were perfect. The thickness of the fish pieces overpowered the batter. Otherwise, everything was great. Sides of mushy peas and pickled vegetables. Tea sandwiches of cheddar and tomato. With beverages, all under 30 bux. About 20 minutes from the city, it's worth a check out. Skip the stores and take a drive by tour of the beautiful houses. 

They also serve brunch. The menu was extensive. 
You can also dine on the sidewalk. I believe that's called al fresco. 
And they don't serve Coca-Cola. Strictly British sodas. 
Their logo is pretty sweet, too.

it's almost great.  
to start, it's a byo that lets you make reservations for the weekend.  and even for larger parties!  imagine!  and the menu continues to change and evolve, love it!

the apps were so good, i could have stopped there.  especially the arancini.  a fried rice ball stuffed with short rib ragu?  i mean, how could you go wrong?  
i like the fact that you can order a half order of pasta so you can get a main course as well.  but, really i think i could have been happy with just the pasta in itself.  the light pillowy ricotta gnocchi are divine.  my tagliatelle with artichokes and lemons and mushrooms were perfect for the warm summer day.

and really, i could have stopped there.  my main course (swordfish) was good, but not spectacular.  it was cooked perfectly, but the light dusting of cinnamon and burrata just threw off my tastebuds.

the dessert (almond milk panna cotta) was some of the best i've ever had.

points off for the loud noise, and the 3 (!!!) requests for filling up my water glass before it was done.  maybe they could use a bit more than the 2 servers that they had for a saturday night...

The Bluebird Cafe has been on my list for some time! Its history, its intimate setting, its obscure location.... all adding to the appeal. 

Getting tickets online is a cluster, but not getting tickets in advance is a bigger cluster, or should I say huge line with limited chance of making it inside. We had three of us, and online ticketing split us into the tables. No biggie but not ideal. 

We arrived 40 minutes before the show and the staff was frazzled and not friendly. I am docking a star for that. It's intimate and they seat 75 guests for two nightly shows. Most of which are preassigned online. So why are you frazzled and short with us?

We ended up in the very back at a high top; the only seat that they don't have a waitress assigned to. Also annoying but the bar was close.

Now....onto the good stuff! The place is so cute and even in the far back, it was so intimate and enjoyable to see such talent on stage. It is clear that those on stage appreciate the Bluebird. As an audience member, being able to hear their music and stories in a lovely acoustic setting is very unique. I love live music and many genres, however "newer" pop-country is not one of them. The band we saw was a male/female country duo called Sons of Daughters. Because it was acoustic, it felt less country-ish...and I really enjoyed them! The male lead especially! I'm always rooting on these musicians working to really make it. 

Overall, the music and intimacy was excellent! And that helped ensure that the unsteady service didn't sour my long awaited night at the Bluebird!

What a lovely little place! The place was modern, yet homey, and the ambience was just friendly and relaxing. 

The food was great as well. I got the Thai tea which was absolutely scrumptious, with the country chicken. There was more than enough food on the plate, and it was also a great portion of chicken! The breading was just right--enough to add some flavor, not too much so as to be heavy. I forget what my s/o ordered, but I do remember clearly that he thought the coffee was exemplary, so another point in their book!

The only reason this place wasn't a 5-star was because we had some miscommunications with our waiter. Our waiter was perfectly professional and got everything fixed in the end, but it's always uncomfortable to have to correct your waiter and your bill.

I think Loveless is the first place I've visited twice in the same week while vacationing in a new city. But once you try the biscuits you'll understand why! I tried biscuits all over nashville and these were by far the best, and the trifecta of homemade jams doesn't hurt either! For breakfast I had the country ham (which I honestly didn't love) and a side of grits (which were amazing and cheesy). I tried bites of my friends' bacon (I'm not usually a bacon person but this was maple-y and smokey and awesome), sausage gravy, and hash brown casserole and I loved it all. We went back for dinner and the highlight was definitely the pulled pork/house BBQ sauce! The sweet potatoes and Mac and cheese balanced out the meal with all of my favorite sweet, savory, cheesy comfort foods. You 100% will be stuffed when you leave!

The food here is SO GOOD. I went back and forth between 3 or 4 stars for this place. Though the food here is legit, the service was just terrible. The server just seemed confused the whole time like as if it was her first day. 

I ordered the falafel appetizer for my meal with a side of rice. I specifically told the server I wanted it as my meal so that everything would hit the table along with my hubby's meal too. Hubby ordered the lamb gyro plate and he chose to have it with hummus instead of salad (came with the plate). My falafel came first and I had to wait about 7 minutes before my rice and hubby's plate came out. We had to ask for utensils. My falafel was hard on the outside but soft on the inside. The rice was very flavorful. Hubby lamb gyro... wow... was so juicy and amazing! After enjoying a couple of bites we realized that we hadn't gotten his hummus yet so we asked our server. She said hummus didn't come with the plate and she'd ask the back (?) when she herself asked at the time our order was taken if my hubby wanted hummus or salad. She disappeared, walked around the restaurant, cleaned another table and then opened a menu and read the plate section. She came back and stated that hummus did come with the plate (but we already knew this....) and we asked for it again. It was worth the wait. I LOVE their hummus.

Anyhow despite the service being pretty sad, the food will still call us back another time.

I'd like to give a 3.5 - very mixed feelings. 

PICK-UP AND PARKING: 
I love that you can order on their website and that they even offer curbside pick-up...BUT this part of downtown is so busy the is no designated pick-up spot! There ate two parking spaces in front of it and the other side is an alley...I pulled into the alley and heck no that wasn't good. Drunk dudes slapping my car as they walked by, then cars wanting to pull into the alley. I pulled forward and yanked my car over...it took them a long time to bring it out (maybe not that long but when you're stressed with angry people around you, it's forever). Luckily I was halfway down the alley and waved to the employee so I could get my food. 

There is a paid parking lot behind the hotel (where the restaurant is) and parallel paid spots in the alley and more...but dang I went on a Tuesday at 5pm and the area was packed with no parking. I would not want to try this again...

So besides parking, how is the food?

It's ok. 
Now my dining partner loved the veggie calzone and wants to go back again. 

I got a calzone with pepperoni and added mushroom...the dough was very soft. Which I often like soft pizza crusts but on a calzone the texture was weird - I expected it to be more crisp. The flavor was ok. 

Honestly it's not convenient to get over here and the food is only ok, so I probably won't come back except my dining partner really wants to get it again. Alas!

So I love local coffee shops. This place is tucked away and almost unnoticeable from the main street, but it is a must for Chai lattes and a quiet place to do some work with wifi. Due to the intimate space, I don't know if I would have louder work product or personal conversations here. The seats and tables are too close together, and there is very little white noise.

After a few unsuccessful attempts to try The  Trap (not open on my previous attempts), I was ecstatic to finally get a taste of that herb buttah goodness. No holding back on the seasonings here; everything is doused in it and I loved every bit of it. The $15 loaded shrimp tray included potatoes, broccoli & corn...enough to split and still feel satisfied, or have all to yourself and eat like a king (or queen).

The inconsistent hours are the only drawback. Check them out on FB to get sporadic updates about dates and times it's open before making a special trip, but if you're going to be in the area, it's worth just driving by to see if it's open.

I love drip coffee whenever I can get it.  In my opinion it's always a treat because you can taste the flavors of the coffee better.  The coffees are freshly made to order.  The barista was using the beehouse dripper that day.  I ordered the featured coffee but can't recall the name.  All I remember was it was a great cup of coffee.  I did add a bit of milk to soften the strong flavors a bit.  I wish there was one closer to me.

Philadelphia Yelp, I'm so disappointed. There should be some mechanism in place to keep visiting Yelpers away from this place, something like a Greek chorus. It should pop up via a hologram right inside the door, singing about how diners should beware instead of throwing themselves upon the rocks of terrible food. 

I will admit that I was a little wigged out by the reviews of my old favorite, the Midtown II. I thought, "Maybe my beloved Midtown II has gone downhill since I lived in Philly. Maybe I shouldn't take my sweet lover to a bad restaurant." AH HAHAHAHAHAHA. No. In my fear of taking my lover to have a bad meal, I took him to have a bad meal. 

The fact that the diner was completely empty at dinner hour should be a tip. 
Second tip: the kitchen had the griddle turned off halfway through dinner hours. 
Third tip: the server was deep in a Russian novel, and she admitted to just starting it two hours ago. (I asked. I like Russian novels, okay?) 

Not to belabor this point, but Yelp, it was bad. My partner ordered the only good thing on the menu. He got the seasonal vegetable salad, which had this lovely warm dressing and fresh squash mixed in with the usual salad fixings. Even the coke was flat and a little weak. Ouch. 

No point hammering on about a bad meal. I'm sad we ate here when the city has better to offer. 

Accessibility notes: no Braille menu or signage. Plenty of space for mobility devices. Can get loud during peak market hours.

A beautiful hidden gem nestled in the heart of Lambertville. My husband was so proud that he "found" this place, and I was happy to oblige in trying something new!  

We actually walked over from the Wine Cellar at Lambertville Station, it is super walkable (~7 mins). Anyways, once we walked in, we immediately knew we found our new favorite restaurant. The smells of the food were intense and super fragrant. The restaurant is a no-frills basic room, yet intimate and charming. Copper tables dotted the space in various configuration of 2's, 4's and even a party of 6.
