The seasoning is salt, pepper and oregano. I also add olive oil. 

I've brought a few people here and hey always say it's the best so don't just take my word for it. Come in for the challenge and you determine. I would advise to come with an appetite so you can be completely satisfied.

I had my first taste of Cali at an office work party. I believe they ordered the Cali Club Wraps. They were absolutely scrumptious. I've never had a wrap with so much flavor. I had to find out where they were from and go back to see what else was on the menu.

I took my hubby when we were in S. Tampa running errands and he loved it too. He tried the Spicy Rio Burrito and a side of broccoli--and was so happy with his selections.

I again had the California Club Wrap and it was just as delicious as I had remembered. They have a wide selection of healthy options. I would be interested in trying a flatbread or bowl next time.

If you're in the area, give them a try. Note: this is a sit-down restaurant. I thought it would be more like Chipotle or Panera.

Came here for the first time a few weeks ago and got the best pedicure of my life! Loved the leg massage that was followed up with hot stone and then towel. Also got a manicure. While sitting under the dryer, received complimentary full back massage which put this experience over the top. Will definitely return.

I love the tofu pad Thai here. The tofu is always made with a crunchy outside and soft inside. The level of spice I request is always perfect and my meals are always tasty. The staff is always pleasant and willing to serve. Parking is a bit tight, so if you don't find parking in front of the restaurant, there is a line of parking spaces across the street.

Had brunch with a friend at First Watch and we had a wonderful waitress, who's name I didn't catch. She was very attentive, engaged in a bit of conversation, and was friendly. We both had French toast which was very good, the energy bowl, and tomato soup. I'm excited to come back another time and try their veggie burger. I appreciate when a restaurant has vegan/vegetarian options. 

The only thing I'd really like to see is a non-dairy creamer or milk for coffee. Soy, almond, coconut, something to splash in my coffee would be lovely even though I've learned through experiences like this to enjoy black coffee...

Good experience. My friend and I agreed we'd come here again.

A delicious surprise but not unexpected. I read "Joe's Pizza" took over this place but I was still reticent but today I thought, why not? The delivery man was nice and the pizza came on time. 

I ordered a plain pizza which came hot and thin crusted and a cheeseburger hoagie because I haven't ever seen that on a menu up here in Philadelphia. The pizza was yummy and so was the cheeseburger hoagie. The pizza dough seemed lighter with a thinner crust than from Joe's (we both love thin crust pizza). Frankly we all enjoyed both items and I recommend you try this place because everything came hot, fresh and on time!

I come here all the time for grocery items that I seem to always forget until I'm making dinner. They're dog friendly and always have milkbone treats for my pup when I bring him with me. He LOVES coming into Jay's. Although I'm in the store part quite often, I hadn't tried their deli until last week and it was really good! I got their Italian hoagie which they make with Boar's Head meat and it came with a bunch of fresh toppings like peppers, pickles, lettuce, tomato, and onion. I usually can't eat a whole hoagie to myself but I could have with this one. I'll have to come back to try more of their sandwiches.

The crepe gods have answered my calls!!! 

The owners have years of experience and they're passionate and very particular about their ingredients.  You can just taste it.

I absolutely love their transparency... The fact that you can watch Yanna, the owner, work her magic at the crepe station behind glass is a great statement that they have nothing to hide. 

Yesterday, I sought out a hearty meal to refuel from holiday shopping and a hearty meal was exactly what I got at @kaffe_crepe , a restaurant on my list of favorite places to eat in Reno.  

I was drawn to their seasonal Reno Wonderland Breakfast Crepe- Cheddar cheese, smoked ham, bacon, scrambled eggs, roasted red potatoes, green onions, and sour cream.

My crepe was so satisfying and comforting.  

What made my crepe amazing:
*potatoes perfectly roasted
*eggs cooked fresh with perfect doneness and full of flavor
*Perfect amount of cheese
*Plenty of meat
*Green onions complimented and made other flavors pop
*Sour cream brought richness and tied everything together
*Cholula hot sauce (optional) for kick and spice
*Quality ingredients you can taste
*Perfect Crepe

Kaffe Crepe offers both savory and sweet crepes with seasonal specials so you'll never run out of options.  There's also room for endless customizations. 

Their sweet crepes are amazing as well, with many combinations offered.  A base of Nutella,  Biscoff, cream, and custard along with fresh fruits will cater to anyone's taste and make anyone happy.  

It gets really interesting when their sweet specials come along, including mouthwatering ingredients and flavor combinations like lemon curd and chocolate truffles with raspberries and condensed milk.  I remember a year when they offered apple pie crepes with cinnamon and whipped cream. 

They offer ice cream so if that's your jam, they've got you covered. 

Kaffe Crepe has thought of every aspect of the meal and offers a wide variety of drinks-  artisan coffees, teas, seasonal drinks, specialty drinks, and other bottled drinks.

Currently, their list of holiday drinks is the longest I've seen of any local business that I've visited this year. Nutty White Mocha, Cranberry Lemonade, or Almond Roca anyone?

The chef is passionate about her creations and sources the freshest local ingredients she can find.  

She's made a special restaurant with the perfect atmosphere, food, and drinks and I'm forever thankful that she chose our city to share her special talent with. 

P.S. gift cards available for the perfect gift

To me, there isn't a finer B&N on the planet. Four floors of books, coffee, magazines, all that... in a space that seems rather condensed. I've never expected to find something here that I haven't. Equally, they occasionally surprise me by what they do carry.

I love that Philadelphia has a bookstore across from its best park, and what that says. I never liked B&N growing up until I started frequenting this location.

The only thing I wish they'd do to improve is extend the magazine sections a bit... Tower always had the best, and somebody needs to compete.

Yes, Philadelphia has MANY great indie bookstores, and I can't underplay that, but this place deserves credit/recognition for its easy-to-find familiarity, great service, and extensive inventory.

Sunday brunch, first time visiting and wanted to try something new and local. This place was pretty busy when we first walked in most of the tables were already full but luckily I booked ahead and made a reservation for the six of us and I was glad that I did, we were seated right away and our waitress came over and took our drink order unfortunately she got a few of the drinks mixed up but that's okay we quickly got them all fixed the waitress was very friendly and very attentive in fact all of the staff were nice. for my personal thoughts on the buffet I felt they were a little lacking I was expecting a little bit more barbecue the only thing they had on the buffet was some pulled pork which is my favorite but I would have like to try it or at least sample of some of the other meat items. They did have a homemade Belgian waffle station where I was told that a famous baseball players brother is the one that actually made the waffles for us he was very funny . They had lots of toppings to choose from as far as syrups chocolate chips except they're missing peanut butter I love peanut butter on waffles but that's my personal preference. overall it wasn't that bad of a place to try I will certainly be back to try some of their regular meals and maybe not on a Sunday during a particularly busy lunch rush, overall I give it 2 thumbs up!

Ok I admit it.  I'm a fan of Starbucks!  I have a gold Starbucks card with my name on it.  At my favorite location they make my drink as soon as the Barista sees me pull into the lot.  

So why am I reviewing Old City Coffee?
1. I love the atmosphere.  Way better than that "chain look."
2. The location is great for people watching. (limited vehicle traffic)
3. The food is as good as or better than the chains.
4. The Baristas are knowledgeable.  
5. They roast their own beans in the café.
6. Oh, and the coffee is great!
Awesome food, good service! Bun bo hue is AMAZING! Love the pho, always get the crispy pork skin rolls, fresh and tasty. A must for Vietnamese cuisine

C'est fantastique!

My nicer half treated me here for my birthday dinner this year. 5 stars for ambiance and service! The rooftop patio is the bee's knees. I felt very carefree and happy just as a result of being up there. Our server, Charles, was very charismatic and fun. I like that he introduced himself and shook hands with everyone at all of his tables, and remembered mine and Devin's names throughout the meal. "Christine, my love, how are you doing?" Charming as hell. Loved it. The entire team of servers worked together seamlessly to clear plates in a timely manner and keep our water glasses full. Charles also put together a really adorable birthday card for me and had a bunch of staff members sign it. Awesome!

The food was pretty good. Not stellar, but definitely good. I liked the escargot but felt the puff pastry was kind of stale. The soup was not my style, but it was really my fault for ordering something when I didn't know what it was. Tip for the French cuisine-ignorant: vichyssoise is served cold. It would have been MUCH better hot. Like clam chowder, except smoked salmon. But I didn't really like it cold. The pork chop was good but didn't blow me out of the water. Devin got the monkfish special which was MUCH better. The star of my meal was the creme brulee! It was truly perfect.

I did the prix fixe menu which was reasonable at $38.99 for 4 courses, and they were full size - not tiny tasting plates - so it was a really great deal. 

I would be willing to try other things off the menu again, but I definitely want to come back to enjoy some of their delicious drinks (the cocktails were superb - I recommend the Summer Fashion - like an Old Fashioned with a peachy twist) and desserts on that lovely patio.

To be quite honest, before I walked in, I expected to see a lot more in here; however, the selection, though somewhat limited, is very unique and it does make me feel like I'm back "home" in Berkeley...small, independently owned organic mini-markets offering rare delicacies that you won't be able to find in your average supermarket.  When I have more time on my hands and possibly an insulated carrier with me, I would love to come back and pick up a few things.  Hold me to it.

When the food is good, you don't have to say many words. Just mmmhhh and nod. 

For the last couple of years, we visit Naptown for the Indiana Black Expo. Of course, for a foodie like me, one of the highlights is good soul food. Unfortunately, the Kountry Kitchen was not in attendance this year and it just threw our whole plan off and stomachs. 

Luckily we were able to visit the actually restaurant and I like this option better. You get the full menu unlike at the expo it's limited. 

Food @ Our Table:  2x Fried Chicken Wings, mac&cheese, greens, sweet potatoes, all good, along with fried shrimp...oh we also ordered two orders of fried green tomatoes which we will LOVE. 

Can't wait to go back next year to IBE and will probably visit the restaurant again.

The air conditioning wasn't working when we went here.  We didn't notice it when we walked in and were drinking some cold beverages and had ordered before we figured it out.  We were starving and didn't want to walk out, so we endured.  We asked about it and were told they had called someone.  Don't you think they could have told us first and let us decide if we wanted to stay?  Maybe the waitress was dying for some tips.

The food was pretty good, not so much for the service.  There were only 2 other occupied tables, so she could have spent the time, but I'm guessing she was too sweaty to want to move more.  She had on black tights (who wears that in St. Louis during the summer?) and it was obvious she was quite uncomfortable.

We didn't eat any breakfast food, had some burgers and they were pretty tasty.

Maybe you have to get breakfast food to feel the love.

Devon's for the 2nd time - still amazing! :)

This is for my birthday dinner - no restaurant week menu for us! And they sat us in front of the tv to watch the phillies game which was perfect! It was somewhat packed because of the game and we were sitting near the bar. So it felt like an expensive restaurant with sports bar feel. lol 

However, food was excellent! I ordered tuna tartar and this has got to the best tuna tartar I ever had! IT WAS DELICIOUS!! I could go for some now. But I swear, the best best best tuna tartar ever! I also ordered the baked salmon on flatbread, it was very good as well. Then ordered the salmon as an entree, yummy! One thing that was off was the biscuits that I had before. This time, it kind of fell apart and it didn't have that banging taste that I used to have the first time. Oh well, I still love it. Woohoo! :)

As much as I love the food at Pats, I can no longer continue to come here during normal business hours. Let me preface by saying, the food is exceptional. From pizza to cheesesteaks, anything you get is mind blowingly stellar. However, my issue is with how busy they are and how it affects service.
My job is a mile down the road and I usually order delivery. It takes no less than 45 minutes to arrive. So long! The other day, I decided to sit-in for lunch thinking it would be quicker. I was sadly mistaken! I came at 12 o'clock (typical lunch break time) and waited 35 minutes to get my food! What did I order you might wonder? A cheesesteak! That's it! I don't understand what took so long because when I came in, they're only three patrons seated in the whole restaurant. The phones were not ringing off the hook, either. When my food finally came I had to take it to go-to because so much time had passed. While I waited, the servers gave a half-hearted apology.. as though it was the norm. When I went to leave, there was a line almost to the door of people waiting to order.
For my cheesesteak and fountain soda I paid just under $16. Not worth it, too expensive and too long of a wait, I'll go elsewhere. 
Also, one time when I got delivery to my job, the delivery driver asked me, "why do you eat this junk?" Not cool. If you don't love your job, quit.

I got the Ricotta Cheese Cannoli from here and it was DIVINE. Easily the best cannoli I've ever had in my life. The shell was crispy and ultra thin. It was very well fried and not oily at all. The ricotta filling was one of the best substance I have ever tasted. It was creamy and smooth, with small chunks of chocolate chips. The flavor was well-balanced and complex. The cannoli was dusted with icing powder as the finishing touch.
I loved everything about the cannoli and couldn't help but be sad when I finished it.

Haters gonna hate. It's a mall, I personally hate all mall shopping but it's a great place to get decent deals without running all over town or wondering if super-cheap-clothes-fake-website .com just stole you money and credit card info. 

When you need a new hat I'm pretty sure there are at least 2 stores. 

Sephora, I don't even know if I'm spelling that right but my sisters love their make up so their gift cards are always an easy present.

Maybe I just have a higher standard of diner's growing up in New Jersey but this diner is not on my list of places to come back to anytime soon. I came here on a weekday morning with my nana. For what it's worth, she is a regular at this place and loves it here. We were seated right away but there was a decent crowd for a friday morning. 

I had my usual diner meal- bacon egg and cheese on a bagel and was kind of dissapointed. The bagel was small and seemed like it came out of a bag, while the cheese was still in cold square form and not melted at all. It came with home fries, and those were pretty decent. My nana got an omelet which actually looked pretty good and came with toast. She opted for some sort of cooked apples instead of homefries , which she enjoyed. 

Our waitress was good and attentive- refilling both my nana's tea and my coffee frequently. You pay at the front on the way out. Our meals were pretty inexpensive but I was overall unimpressed.

LOVE chick fil a! Great food! Quick service! Best staff!


Love their Cobb salad with the avocado lime ranch dressing!!!

This place is hard to love. Filthy is understated , chaotic certainly applies, zero curb appeal too, also impatient servers. BUT the food, it makes it all worth it. Bagels you can't get anywhere else, great shmeer, incredible pastrami and corned beef sandwiches, and on and on. And the crowds? They just keep on coming....

What I love most (besides the food obviously) are the people who work here! Lane and Lauryn took phenomenal care of me while I dined for breakfast. This place screams hippie and I absolutely love it! There's nothing but love in the air, good vibes and great music every time I walk in. You can tell the staff enjoys their job here!

Food  is  on  point! The chefs really..well, not really..put their foot in the food...there's soul and swag all through the food and you can taste it with every bite! And the cold pressed drinks is literally what your body needs! (My favorite is the Hoosier Heater).

Make your way to visit and tell them your favorite @travelingfoodieguyde sent you and tag me in the pics and videos!

I Love this place!  It is the cleanest water park I have ever been to.  The lounge chairs are very nice and very comfortable.  Life jackets are provided.  There is a gated water area for toddlers.  Having this area blocked off is a great idea.  There is a snack bar on the property but I saw others with small coolers.  Admission is $8 for adults and $5 for children.  You can stay all day.  I am not sure about passes out.  The lazy river and water slides were alot of fun.  It's a great place for parents to interact with their children.  Can't wait to go again!

What a great new lunch spot at the mall!!! Stopped in out of curiously today after shopping. First off, it's beautiful in there! Such a nice spot! The food was good also. I had a kale Cesar with shrimp that was very fresh. It's heavy on the lemon though which I enjoyed, but just be warned if that's not your thing. My husbands French dip was delicious! Kind of expensive, but hey, it's Green Hills mall so it's to be expected. Love to come back and have wine here before a movie.

Willie Mae's is known to serve one of "American's Best Fried Chicken's" and their James Beard Award is SO well deserved! 

I came here as a party of two in Oct 2021 around 12 and there was no line. Note that they did check for your vax card. The wait to get your food is kind of long, but it's well worth the wait. We got Fried Chicken with the green beans/rice side, and cornbread muffins. 

The fried chicken was SUPER juicy and flavorful. It didn't feel overly oily despite being fried and it was almost as if the breading was fluffy? It was super fresh and I'm still dreaming about Willie Mae's! I absolutely love southern green beans and theirs did not fail me - lots of flavors and there were a couple pieces of potatoes in the mix. The rice was delicious and had little pieces of meat. The cornbread muffins were slightly sweet and fluffy. Willie Mae's is absolutely food heaven!

I am not a fan of Buffets for several reasons.  Number one is feeling like you are in a contest to fill your plate with massive amounts of assorted foods out of huge vats.  One chomps down all on your plate with thoughts of picking the next quantitive amounts to fill a plate again.  I peer around to other tables amassed with hungry people doing the same thing we are.  Eating fast and then hurrying down to get to the vats of food that awaits them.  You eat faster than usual for some reason.  Number two is that eating this way is like a chore that must be done in an orderly fashion and not relaxing as a leisurely meal should be. This is just my opinion and means nothing to the variety, cleanliness of the place. Now, to the food itself.  There are several choices of soups and I mean several. I scooped out some won-ton soup.  I might add, very good.  There were staples, like lo-mein, orange chicken, pineapple sticky rice out of a real pineapple. Nice touch, beef with broccoli, fried rice.  They had a salad bar, filled with lobster salads, edomame, mussels in shells, crab salads and on and on.  I had some mussels and they were wonderful.  Then there is the Sushi bar which was loaded with very typical sushi.  I had a few pieces and they were OK.  Then comes the Hibachi bar, which as you know you pick the veggies and the meats and the chef cooks it up for you with a sauce of your choice.  I didn't try it because I was tired from running to get tastes of the food in the vats and eating so fast.  Also, I don't have the patience to pick veggies, meats and sauces and wait for the chef to mix this feast all together so I opted out of it.  Now, for the extensive dessert bar.  Hop on your roller skates to grab some culinary delights.  I had the coffee, carmelly little moist pastry which was so good.  There were so many to choose from all looking good and beautifully displayed.  And the best part, was the giant tubs of ice cream with about 6 choices.  I chose the very olive green ice cream which reminded me of Hawaii's azuki bean ice cream.  I loved it there and it was good here.   Of course, there was a section with all fruits, jellos,  I went to this place mostly because I found a 30% off coupon in the Az. Star newspaper.  I'm a coupon, groupon, living social consumer, so when I see a deal, I act on it.  $15.00 bucks for the two of us.  Now, that's a ganga in anyones book.  Another plus is the place is huge ( Once housed Factory-to-U ) on Speedway and Swan.  It is beautifully decorated and clean.  So far anyhow, it has recently just opened.  So you can ignore my being not a fan of buffets and give them a try.

If you need a Korean fix, the area of Chesterfield on Olive is the way to go. There are several grocery stores, restaurants, and then this bakery. I honestly don't know how authentic this bakery is, but there is a mix of Korean bakery items, more "Americanized items, and other random Asian desserts. But nonetheless, it's cute and delicious. 

First and foremost, I LOVE the creme puffs from here. They are not as sweet as what you thing a creme puff is in bite sizes. You can get a package of 10 and bring it to the Korean restaurants! They have mocha cakes, lots of sponge cakes in a variety of flavors, and general cakes. And if you want to get someone a gift who loves playing pokemon go, this is where you get your pokemon theme cookies. They also have Hello-Kitty cakes. 

Great place to just stop in and they open late for a bakery until 8pm. There are also a few tables for you to sit and enjoy your desserts too!

Ugh, I used to love White Castle. Their restaurant serves cheap food. But beware: their belly bombers meet up to their name. One night when I ate White Castle, I had the worst stomach ache known to man and I ended up staying in bed for three days. True story.
Enough about that event, I won't be reviewing the food this time, just the service. Not too long ago, I took my mom through the drive through at this location. Usually, the service is a quick in and out. But this time we had the worst experience, ever. 
For one, we had to wait over 30 minutes in queue in the drive through. (Why are my worst experiences with fast food are almost all in a drive through?) My mother ordered ten jalapeno sliders, an order of onion rings, and a large chocolate shake. Don't ask me how she eats all that, but that is what she ordered.
Again, we waited for a long period of time. Once we got to the drive through window, a teenager read my order completely wrong and we had to remind him what we did order. 
My mom was very upset and asked for this order to be free. The manager, who was extremely abrupt and rude beyond belief marched up to the register and pushed our food out the window. What was the worst part of the problem, my mother didn't get what we ordered. The manager forgot to give us our onion rings, in addition to not charging anything on her debit card.
Immediately, I dialed the customer service line and filed a complaint with the corporate office. In addition, I will not be visiting White Castle ever again, ever!

WING NIGHT is the night to come here. Great crispy flavorful wings and for half the price, even better. The fries were pretty crispy and came out piping hot, love it. The interior of this place isn't the most fancy but it's definitely where all the locals come out to watch a game or just to catch up. I'll definitely be back for another wing night

This is an amazing hotel. Located in downtown New Orleans, this hotel is everything we all love about the South. The lobby is breathtaking, especially during the holidays. It captures the beauty and traditions of the holiday season. The staff is well trained and very attentive to your needs. The rooms are very large with a very spacious sitting room, separate bedroom and bath along with a wet bar in the entry area of the room. Simply a wonderful experience every time I stay there.

Stopped in here on our way to our French Quarter Walking Tour. Didn't get a chance to look around, but it's a pretty large store with plenty of selection! My hubby got distracted by the samples up front. He tried the regular ghost pepper salsa and said it wasn't that bad. The guy behind the counter said, "Well, I got one for ya!" He challenged him to the real ghost pepper salsa, the one where you have to sign a waiver beforehand....

So he signed it. Tried the salsa, then didn't drink anything for a minute (part of the challenge). He got his pic on the Wall of Flame...but he was struggling with the heat, haha. Would love to shop around next time we're in NOLA...I'd buy all the chipotle products!!

One of the best service I've had in a while! My friend and I came here yesterday after a loooong day. It was our first time and we were happy to hear they serve happy hour. We got some drinks and ordered the filet mignon and chicken milanese which also came with some complimentary bread. Our mushroom soup appetizer had a rich and earthy taste. The steak was cooked to perfection and my friend enjoyed her meal. 

I heard rumors that they make the best key lime pie in TOWN. Now, we aren't huge key lime pie lovers, but we had to give it a try. It is definitely worth it if you don't hate key lime. The crust is made from scratch which makes everything come together and you can taste the delicious pecans mixed into it. 

A quick shout out to our waiter (Justin) and the manager here who made the end of a stressful day turn out great. Justin was very attentive, knew the menu well, and offered great recommendations. I even learned about their rewards program through their app on his recommendation too. If you make an account via facebook, you get a free 100 points! I am definitely coming back and I really enjoyed dining here. Huge thanks to all the staff for a great experience :)

Tips: Happy hour daily 4pm-7pm, Wednesday 4pm-Close (on drinks and small plates).
The porcini-crusted rib-eye is powder (not actual porcini mushrooms) just fyi.
Made from scratch key lime pie with home-made crust.

This new whole foods is a dream come true! Free indoor parking is a MAJOR plus, although if you do come in during rush hours be ready to get stuck a little bit. There is actually plenty of space in the back (the parking garage is deceptively large) - so it'd be very helpful if cars can keep moving instead of waiting of people to pull out!

I'm going to be honest - I usually don't buy groceries from whole foods because it is just too expensive for my budget, but I love coming to this location to indulge in Dizengoff with a good beer or two. Whole Foods bar prices are very reasonable, and I've gotten a chance to try beer on tap that I've never had elsewhere before! While I don't usually end up buying much in terms of groceries, I love wandering around and admiring how beautiful all the produce looks. Trader Joe's will still be my place for much more affordable groceries, but I love love hanging out at this Whole Foods location.

The downstairs coffee bar is a must for a coffee lover for me. I tried their nitro cold brew, and it was absolutely perfect. This whole foods location is a major improvement from their previous location just down the street.

I always love coming here. The food is really good and it's so much fun to order off of the carts!  This place has the best dim sum for Tucson hands down. My favorite dishes to order are the char siu bau (BBQ pork bun), har gow (shrimp dumpling), shumai (pork dumpling with mushroom and shrimp inside), bean curd (pork dumplings wrapped with bean curd skin), and the beef wrapped with rice noodles. They add cilantro to the beef wrapped rice noodles which really gives it a pop of freshness. The egg tarts for dessert are also really good. We typically spend about 10 dollars a person. It's better to go with a group of people because you get to try more things :) The only annoying part about this place which is why I gave it a 4 instead of a 5 is that sometimes the carts stop coming around or it takes a really long time for the cart to come back your way.

I go to Boca often as it is a few blocks from my house and had been meaning to review the place. 

The food is pretty good, I love the bone marrow, all of the flatbreads are awesome and the pickled board which is unique. 

The service on the other hand is typically very slow.  On my visit this week our service was so poor I felt it was time to review.  One server came over, brought menus, took our drink order and let us know he would not be our server but our server Jordan would be with us soon.  Our drinks took a good 15 minute to arrive.  All we ordered was beer and wine.  We then waited another 15 minutes for her to come back and take our food orders.  The food actually came quickly which is not typical for Boca.  Then she asked if she could bring our checks while one of the people at our table was still eating.  This is a major pet peeve of mine.  We did not mention that we were in a hurry and no one was concerned about our time when we were waiting on our drinks or waiting to order.   She quickly brought our checks but never came to pick them up.  We waited at least 10 minutes for her to pick up our checks until we just went inside and brought them to her.  Not once during the entire experience did she apologize for taking so long to provide service.

Wow! I am super impressed with this experience. I've been wanting to try hot pot for a while, but honestly I was a bit intimidated because I didn't know HOW to eat hot pot.

After reading some online articles and watching "how to hot pot" videos, I invited my family to celebrate my birthday this past weekend at Nine Spices (which has fantastic reviews).

First of all, the place was packed at 5:30 on a Sunday afternoon, so you know it's a popular place. I was a tad bit concerned due to COVID, but the booths are set up so that you are only facing your party (and we are all vaccinated).

We were sat at a six person booth next to the conveyor belt which continually circles with ingredients you can throw into your hot pot.

There were great options on broth choices. Unfortunately, our waiter wasn't able to explain them too thoroughly, but enough for my dad to figure out which one wasn't chicken, beef or pork based (Chinese herbal, in case you want to know).

We got the traditional, kimchee, spicy and Chinese herbal between the five of us. Then it came to ordering all of the goodies to put in your pot.

We mainly focused on seafood, dumplings and veggies. (Note: the baby octopus are truly small intact baby octopus. My mother-in-law was a little shaken by this.) Everything was super fresh!

The only meats we ordered were beef and pork dumplings. They gave us an exorbitant amount of beef. I think that must be a popular choice. Half of our table doesn't eat beef, though, so my husband really had to chow down.

The pork dumplings were amazing. I love the variety of mushrooms and greens to add. It was also fun to grab something off the conveyor and drop it into your little boiling pot.

Don't forget the sauces and sides bar which was stocked with approximately 20+ sauce choices and about 10 different sides (the squid salad is the bomb!). It also had add-ins for your soup like hot peppers, cilantro and green onions.

By the time we were done hot potting, we were all amazed at how fantastic the remaining broth was. Threw in some noodles and finished it off as a soup.

They have hand-dipped ice cream included for dessert as well. (Although we were too stuffed to indulge)

Everything was clean and the food was top quality. As another reviewer mentioned, some of the food may be out of your "comfort zone". However, that is not a reason to discount this fantastic spot. You choose what you want at your table. So, if baby octopus and pig's blood aren't your thing, you don't have to have them!

We didn't try the BBQ, but it seemed to be quite popular for most of the tables.

If you haven't tried hot pot before, I recommend looking up some tips before you go to make the experience more comfortable, because you don't get much guidance for first timers while you are there.

Set aside two hours to truly dine and enjoy with family and friends!

A Tucson tried and true!! If I'm ever unsure of where to eat out, I can always fall back on Seis. 
I love that they have tacos from different regions of Mexico. They're all so unique and I haven't found a taco that I didn't like. One of my personal favorites is the puerco verde, it's super flavorful and juicy! Also any breakfast item is bomb. Their drink selection is also great; you can get refreshing agua frescas or if you need some caffeine, you can opt for a cochata (coffee and horchata!) 
Overall, Seis is a perfect restaurant if you want some delicious tacos, great drinks, and chill atmosphere!

What a great museum! The architecture is beautiful. Love the sculptures and fountain in front of the museums. Also, the Rocky statue and the famous Rocky stairs!! This is a popular tourist attraction stop. All the hop-on hop-off tour bus stop at this location. 

Definitely a must visit place!

Let me start by saying that I'm totally addicted. I have passed this place a hundred times over the years and never stopped. I was convinced by a cousin of  mine to try it out.  I loved everything about the sample cakes, however, I was not aware the cakes in the dome were cold. So my experience was mixed as to what I had just tasted. This cold cake was nothing like what I had just experienced.  So I went home with the cake in bag sitting on the driver seat waiting to throw it out and I was upset. So I get home and right before I throw it out, I take a bite of the cake and it had warmed up and was just as good. So if you don't like cold cakes just let it sit and all those flavors will marinate into awesomeness. Oh and the uptown location has the best cakes.

This place is wonderful.

Everything I tried that night was so delicious!! As everyone else has stated, get the gnocchi. I'm not a fan of gnocchi but I loved it here. It was so soft and the sauce they had on top was amazing.

We will most definitely be returning. Soon.

One of my favorite parts of moving to a new neighborhood is getting a chance to explore all its corner bodegas and delis. So in my new space, Wawa is only a block away..... but if I'm going to level with you, it definitely isn't my favorite hoagie in the city. (Please don't throw batteries at me!!)

I've passed Jay's a bazillion times and finally looked it up on Yelp. I love you guys. You didn't steer me wrong. 

Ordered an Italian hoagie. Got a beautifully constructed sandwich. I'll post that cross section for y'all. See how they put the lettuce between the mayo and meats so the meat & cheese don't slip and slide right out the roll with your first bite? It's the little touches, man!

They also used some quality meats. The prosciutto was extra tasty.

Can't wait to order many, many more hoagies from Jay's.

Since our favorite place for a simple Gyro and Greek salad closed, we had searched for a new place. We love Athens on Fourth, but that entails a full meal, wine, etc. First of all, Greek House is stringently clean. They play charming Greek music and it's decorated in Greek fashion. The employees are very courteous and know their menu. We ordered Gyros (no fries) and a Greek salad to go. I was thrilled to see the Gyro meat roasting before our eyes and being freshly carved. I despise ordering a Gyro and being served pre-formed patties. The meat was perfectly carved and seasoned to perfection. The pita was wonderful, and the tomatoes were fresh and sweet. It was one of the best Gyros I've ever had. The Greek salad was huge! Enough for two people, easily. They serve a creamy feta dressing with it that is simply fantastic. We are used to a vinaigrette with a Greek salad, but this dressing puts them all in the shade. The olives were pitted, the tomatoes, onions and cucumbers fresh and the lettuce crispy. We are thrilled to find such a wonderful Greek restaurant so close to home. I must thank my fellow Yelpers, your reviews led us to try this gem!

This place is heaven for sports fans! Seriously, they will put on whatever game you ask them too! Whatever is in season is always on the big projector screens that gives good views regardless of where you sit. 

They've recently come under new management (owned by Rusty Nail peeps) so a few changes have been made. They've replaced the long string of tables close to the bar with high boys but the booths and the string of tables close to the big tvs are still there (great for large groups). They've added a number of dishes to their food menu. I can't remember if the oyster specials have always been there but oysters are half off from 10pm-close. I think there is a trivia and wings special on Wednesday. As always, their beer selection is phenomenal. 

We ordered the buffalo chicken sandwich and the pizza fries. The sandwich was good, not the best I've had, but it had to have been the most obtuse shaped chicken cutlet. Definitely would not recommend anyone to eat that if they're on a first date.The pizza fries were a heart attack on a plate; I love pepperoni but the pepperoni sticks are a strange consistency and make me think that's what beef jerky for dogs must taste like. When I placed the order, I was told it would be 30 minutes and it was a full 30 minutes--it takes restaurants less time to serve food and it wasn't even a crazy packed night! Just be aware of the wait time in case you suffer from chronic hangriness. 

Don't forget your ID unless you're 100!

I like the atmosphere. One section has high top chairs, another section has booth seats and regular tables, which can be romantic for couples. I love the posters throughout the restaurant. The food was good. I especially like the calamari. The sauce has a nice spicy kick. I would get the sauce on the side though. It's not a lot of sauce so it's okay. I didn't understand the cooked carrots. There were a good amount of it in two of the dishes. It's interesting. Overall, a good experience and would come back again.

Been here multiple times now and I really love this place.
The only reason I give it 4 out of 5 is because it is VERY loud in here during lunch hours. I cant hear the person saying the names for orders nor can I hear the person sitting across from me.
The food, however, is fantastic!
I have had the salmon, the chicken caesar wrap and the meatloaf. The salmon is by far my favorite item here. They have a vegetable casserole that tastes exactly like my grandmothers use to and its just a rush of memories every time I eat it.
Their deserts are phenomenal and you will want to grab a slice of cake or a cookie on your way out. You can not go wrong!

Trivia Tuesdays = win

I love Trivia and the Lodge just started doing trivia on Tuesdays.  There were only 4 teams and the top 3 teams got money off their tab.  I guess I shouldn't write too much about it or else it is going to get busier!

The sangria here is pretty good and only $5 during happy hour.  That can get pretty dangerous.

I also got the Seared Tuna Appetizer and it was delicious.  The cucumber salad underneath had a nice crunch and pickled taste.  I also got to try the Apple Cobbler with Ice Cream and it was pretty good.  My fiance got the steak skewer appetizer and loved it.  However, there are only 3 skewers to an order, so to really fill up he ended up ordering two.

The parking is kind of hit or miss.  Sometimes it is valet and there are not too many spots.  Luckily, at 6 p.m. on a Tuesday it is not valet and there was enough parking.  I honestly hate parking on SoHo, because I never know where people actually tow.  You can park all the way down in Hyde Park at the free parking garage and the walk is not terrible, if you want to put your mind at ease.

while i will say that overall the food was pretty decent, le cheri was a bit of a letdown after our whirlwind tour of philly's finest french bistros and restaurants these past couple of months.

pluses: the space is a nice mix of old world european flair (with its outdoor garden seating) and upscale fine dining. presentation is fabulous and portions are large. the bread basket and butter are melt-in-your-mouth amazing.

that being said..

mixed feelings: we shared all of our dishes, including duck terrine and the specials of the day-- stuffed quail and arctic char. the terrine was incredibly delicious at first, but with any sort of pate, there's a limit to how much you can eat before the taste becomes too saturating for your palate. this is where large portions works against them.

the same can be said of our entrees. the quail and fish were both equally good at the beginning, but were so over-flavored/seasoned that about 75% of the way through our respective half-portions, our taste buds gave out. imagine if you had to finish a single serving by yourself. for that reason, i didn't love the food.

also, the service (while nice) was a bit of a mismatch in my opinion. at an "upscale" french restaurant in rittenhouse, i expect white tablecloth standard of the upmost courteous and professional service. i do not expect someone to joke around with me or make almost quippy remarks about my dining experience. i felt like i was at a chain restaurant. maybe some people like that sort of casual service experience at a fine dining establishment. but personally, it's not my style. call me bougie?

We wanted Po Boys.  It was raining and this place was close to our hotel.  Reviews weren't great but we were hungry !!!   OK.......we should of known better.

I had a small fried shrimp Po Boy for $14.50.  The roll that the sandwich was served on  was like Jimmy Johns white bread.  There were some (not a lot!) of fried unseasoned shrimp on there with just a bit of slaw.  HUH !!!!!

I love to visit the local dive restaurants.  We ordered at the counter and someone brought our food to the table.  They luckily had several hot sauces on the table for us to use.  Otherwise the sandwich honestly wouldn't of had any taste.

I did love the area where this restaurant if located.  FAR from the hectic Bourbon St crowd.  Maybe we just ordered the wrong thing ???   Maybe you should try something else ?  Just don't get a 
Po Boy.

I have withheld a review on Cafe Poca Cosa for quite some time.  Quite simply, I don't know what to say.  I am simultaneously impressed and disappointed.  Let me state that my husband loves the place.  This is a restaurant that divides tastes and desires.

First, you must remove any preconception of Mexican food when you dine here.  Reviews that compare Cafe Poca Cosa to standard bearer Sonoron restaurants are missing the point.  You will not find burritos and tacos here.  That the menu is in Spanish is irrelevant.

Let's talk about the famous chalk board menu.  My husband likes it.  I find it slightly burdensome.  Some servers take it slowly and really describe the meals while others rush through.  A timid diner loses out. 

Let's get to the food.  Most of the dishes are a stew style, which is slowly cooked meats in a complex Mexican-inspired sauce.  They are rich in texture and some of them very much remind me of chicken cacciatore.  Most versions of meat have been flavorful, but some are better than others.  Cafe Poca Cosa is known for their mole sauce, but again it isn't directly comparable to the neighborhood Sonoran place down the street.  The tamale pie is always on the menu.  This is what my husband always orders.  It is sweet and the sauces rotate.  He loves the yellow bell pepper one.  It is not a tamale, however.

The salad on the plate is ridiculous.  I've only seen one person eat it.  Depending on the contents, my husband and I pick.  It is dominating and in my opinion silly.  There is a salad dressing on the table that is okay, but literally no server has ever explained it to us and it took me two or three visits to even notice it.  

The meal comes with tortillas and rice and beans.  I like them.  My husband does not.  They also give complementary chips and salsa.  He likes the salsa and the vinegary bite.  I do not.  One thing that REALLY upsets me is that they charge for refills of soft drinks.  When you're charging $15-$25 per plate, I expect you give me a refill of Coke for free.  Period.  So it goes with Cafe Poca Cosa.

In conclusion, this is an iconic restaurant that should be tried.  It is pricey, so lunch might be a better introduction.  If you go, however, you must do so with an open mind and remember it is not Sonoran Mexican food and isn't intended to be.  I would give it 3.5 stars if Yelp allowed it.

I needed a haircut BADLY, and since I was new to Broad Ripple, I took to Yelp to find a new salon.  A Sign of the Tymes popped up, and I figured I'd give them a try.  I called around noon, and they were able to get me in later that day: that is service!  I scheduled with Randi.  Due to work and traffic, I ended up showing about 20 minutes late (I called ahead and let them know), and Randi was really gracious about it.  NOTE: This place does not accept credit cards, only cash or check.  I wish I would have known about this!  Bring your checkbook!

The salon is in a really cute building, which looked like it used to be a house.  The salon was really clean and inviting.  They had a good selection of magazine, which I appreciate since so many salons only have hair magazines.  I didn't get a chance to look at them since Randi took me back so quickly.

Her booth was in what looked like it used to be a bedroom, so it was private and really spacious.  I explained to Randi what I wanted (trim off the dead ends, give me some bangs) and she gave me exactly what I wanted.  She even suggested she cut my hair a bit shorter to make it look healthier and fuller.  I was really happy with the cut I got.  She also styled it well which I liked, because I often don't leave the salon liking the style.  I have to re-style it when I get home, but I didn't have to with Randi.

Randi also does color, which made me happy since I was also looking for a new colorist.  She talked with me about different color options, and even offered to order the brand of color I prefer since a Sign of the Tymes didn't carry it.  That seems to me like going above and beyond, since I might have gone to another salon just to get the brand of color I love.

They had a check-in deal through Yelp where I got $10 off when I checked in.  It was a great deal, since my service ended up being $32 for a shampoo/cut/style.  Pretty reasonable for the service they provided.  I booked my next appointment with Randi because she told me she is moving to working only Tuesdays and I wanted to make sure I got in with her.  

All in all: cute salon, great service,fair prices.  You can't beat that!  Book with Randi!

The Arlington is more than just a venue where you can catch a flick.  The theater itself has character and charm, and I'd go out of my way to watch a movie here over a more convenient place with less of the above.

I watched Avatar in 3D at the Arlington and it was a very pleasant experience.  Because the theater is old, it only has one screen and a whole lot of seating, including a balcony, and this set-up gives the place a wide-open opulent feel.  The inside walls are built to mimic a quaint village and the ceiling is painted with stars.  The result, instead of being cheesy, is really just pretty.  The screen isn't the largest and the seats aren't the most comfortable around, but nothing is substandard and the loveliness of the place more than makes up for anything lost in the way of modern convenience.

The lobby and exterior are beautiful as well, with cute hand-painted signs, a courtyard, and a free-standing ticket booth.  If you're strolling through downtown Santa Barbara without the time to stop for a movie, the theater is still worth a peek.  It's a wonderful place, gorgeous and unique, and I'd love to come back and catch another movie under the stars.

I picked up a pizza for the kids here, so I was in and out pretty quickly. The kids loved the pizza and I thought it was good too. They were friendly on the phone, prompt with the pie, and reasonably priced! Thanks guys!

Pizza Hut Pan Pizza is my fiancées favorite chain-style pizza, and I love pizza generally, so whenever I ask for pizza she says "so long as it is Pizza Hut!" I like trying new places, but there is an ease and convenience that comes with the chain pizza experience.

We are location very difficult to find. It is tucked into a corner of a strip mall and the sign is very small with lots of other stores also listed, the Pizza Hut is written in black and white, no graphics. Parking is also difficult. 

Close enough to my house that delivery is prompt. Very few issues, other than parking in the strip mall being difficult. I usually park way around back for pick up. I also recall and employee joking around with me re: the price of the pizzas once and that irritated me. I have been back without further issue.

I really like the stuffed crust, but I was not a an of the bacon cheese stuffed crust. When I get stuff crust, I usually do pepperoni only or pepperoni and bacon as topping. My fiancée likes pineapple and sausage. I also like pineapple, and while I don't always like sausage pizza, I do like the Pizza Hut sausage. 

This location is A-OK, but they could do a better job at street presence.

I'm a fan of Orleans Grapevine. It's one of the nicer quaint little french quarter restaurants, with a small dining room and a lovely courtyard. 

 The food is all really good and when I crave a steak, I often think of theirs. The appetizers are really good as well and the wine menu is great too.

  The service has always been amazing and they are definitely kind to familiar faces.

I love this place.  Great environment.  Lots of activity.  It's definitely not a quiet place but it is extremely comforting. I mentioned to the bartender that the entire "vibe" of the restaurant would be lost if it wasn't for the 50+ real candles in place around the bar and restaurant.  He said that was their SIGNATURE detail. Add in a classic round gas fireplace (with seating area) and you've got a homey, classy inviting environment that just makes you happy.  

The bartenders and servers are always awesome and because of that, this place has always been busy when I've visited.  

There are only 2 bartenders on any busy night at the large bar (Our bartender said they tried to have 3 there but they just ran over each other.)  The bartenders also act as a bar backs and as food servers so although our bartender was awesome I can see how there could be frustration at the bar or slow service at times.   I observed a few people getting frustrated when the bartender left to retrieve more salsa and chips. 
 
Most food has been overwhelming excellent and memorable on all visits.  However, on my last visit, the New York strip fajitas left me puzzled.   The steak had absolutely no flavor.....I mean ZERO flavor.   It didn't taste like steak, like pork, like chicken, like nothing... It had no flavor.  I let my friend try it and he said the exact same thing.  I mentioned it to the bartender and he said that the London Broil is marinated but that the NY Strip is not. 

I'm going to chalk this up to a one time thing and not judge Matador on just one meal.  The Fajita dish as a whole was excellent. They just need to figure out the missing flavor issue on the New York strip.  

Four stars, still respectable, with an opportunity to improve on their steaks and bar service.  Matador is still one of my favorite places in Boise and I look forward to them returning to 5 stars soon

It is a chain yes but I have never been disappointed by this Smokey Bones or even the one that was close to UCF.  Consistency from one location to another is definitely admirable!
I love, love, love their beef brisket!!  And all their sides are cooked to perfection.
On my recent visit, I ordered their four cheese mac n cheese with toppings of carmelized onions, pepper jack and pulled pork.  Omg, say no more!!!  It was perfect and just the right serving.
Justin ordered the turkey and his, too, was awesome.
Out of the sauces, we both said we liked the Carolina Mopping sauce the best!  For less heat, the KC option was a fine choice as well.
I'm part of their Bones Club so I will definitely be coming back for me!

Starving last night and went out for a quick bite and decided to try Thai Basil (I wanted Five Guys!) I love Thai food so wasn't upset!  New to town so sampling the local flavor. 

My favorite is sweet and sour chicken made HOT and boy was this tasty!  He had drunken noodles made with pork made EXTRA HOT.  Also very good.  Great service, easy parking, clean, friendly staff.  Will definitely return

This was everything I hoped to experience for a quick weekend in St Louis. Came here on a Saturday night for some live music, which did NOT disappoint. It was February so we watched a band perform from the indoor stage (apparantly there's an outdoor stage?!) around 8pm-10pm for a $7 cover charge. Flawless music - great song picks, great energy, amazing vocals. Would've loved to stay for the second band that came on at 10:30, but we left to return to our hotel. We were able to get seats by the bar, but several people were standing. It got significantly more crowded around 10pm. I didn't think this was a "dingy hole in the wall" at all - venue felt clean, intimate and warm.

Machines are in great condition, but the prices and selection are AWFUL. The majority of the machines are 2010 and newer machines made by STERN (a subpar pinball company) and the majority of the machines are .75 cents. 
Per game.
That's completely ridiculous. The mid 90s games are .50 cents, and the older ones are a quarter. There's only 3 'classic' pinball machines, a couple decent ones from the 80s and early 90s, but nothing crazy.
On the plus side, the more vintage machines worked perfectly, with solid flippers and fast gameplay.
We drove about a hour to get here, thankfully Victory Brewing Company is right around the corner.
PLEASE fix your prices! I want to love this place!

I love Einstein's! I love their cold brew with vanilla sweet cream. I've tried a variety of bagels with shmear and bagel sandwiches. Everything is good. I promise. If you like breakfast sandwiches as much as I do, anything you order you will love. 

There was one incident where my sister was ordering a Chile verde bagel thru the drive thru and as much as she repeated herself, the cashier still did not hear my sister. We are hispanic. Make your own assumptions. 

My personal favorites: chocolate chip bagel with cream cheese and spinach and bacon egg sandwich with cold brew iced coffee

Sweet little tea shop that gives you a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the town square area.

Their teas come from all over the world and are different varieties so you have options.  You can also purchase tea accessories for that caffeine lover in your life.

Bubble tea is probably the most popular thing.  They have the oversized straws that you put in your tea cup that allows you to suck up the globby gooey flavored tea bubbles.  If you have glooby things you should stay away from bubble tea.

The prices are really affordable for the quality.  The staff is very knowledgeable so if you have tea questions don't hesitate to ask.

I get a mean craving for Vietnamese every once in a while, and I immediately thought of Pho Grand when the craving hit last because I always drive by it but never go. One of my favorite things to do on a weekend rainy day is pick up something delicious to go and bring it home while watching all of my shows on DVR... pure heaven. Pho Grand was a great addition to that equation.

I called Pho Grand and placed an order for pick up and the guy on the phone was really nice, and he gave me a wait time of about 15 minutes. I got there about ten minutes later and scored a parking spot right out front, walked in, and my order was already ready! Also, $13 for an appetizer and an entree? I'm definitely okay with that. 

When I got home I found that they packaged the food in a great way to where everything was still hot and nothing was running all over other things... that's a common problem when I get things to go! For an appetizer I got the veggie spring rolls, and wow. I know for sure that I'm going to be craving those again sometime this week. They were so fresh, so full of veggies and rice, and if you're a cilantro lover like me you'll be very happy with these. The sweet and sour sauce was pretty standard but a nice compliment, and the lady who gave me my food made it a point to tell me to use the s&s on both the rolls and my entree. For the main course I had the Ga Xao Xa Ot (stir-friend chicken with hot chiles and lemongrass) and it was just alright to me. It was kind of sweet which I didn't really like, and I wasn't crazy about the taste of the chicken. Luckily, the two huge spring rolls filled me up plenty.

I like this place quite a bit! Next time I'll try and dine in to see what else they have to offer. If you're craving a good spring roll or want Vietnamese with really fast service, Pho Grand is your place.

CASH ONLY!

The lines were super long, but they shortened super quickly! We only waited in line for about 30 minutes (roughly 20 groups ahead of us, so not too bad!)
Interestingly, I think they priced their menu in a way so that when tax is added, it becomes a complete number. An order of beignets (3 in total) cost $2.73, and the cafe au lait was also $2.73, so in total (plus tax), it came to an even $6!

TBH, I had never tried beignets before, and I had expected a different texture/taste/experience. I thought they would be fluffier, but they were just like regular donuts, buried in powdered sugar.

The cafe au lait though..... Oh my GOD the cafe au lait.

I LOVE coffee, and cannot live without a cup a day at least - and Cafe du Monde's cafe au lait was the best coffee I had ever tasted. We ended up buying a box of k-cups, and will be ordering these k-cups for life. LOL

Finding parking was so difficult (we were there in the last week of the year, so it was understandable there were barely any parking spots), but we really didn't mind walking to a faraway spot because there was so much to see and do in the city, and it was just so lively and energetic.

Be careful with the powdered sugar though; if you accidentally breathe in just a little bit, you're going to have a coughing fit lolol

"Did you lick it?"

"Ahhhhhh no I forgot!"

A couple of things I did not know about the St Louis Arch was that 
(1) It is huge!
(2) You can go inside it!

I was in town for a wedding and had decided to come a day early so I could see some of the sights. Boy, was it hot. One of the main things was to see the Gateway Arch. Most major cities have their iconic landmark - Paris has the Eiffel Tower, NY has.. a bunch of things, Seattle has the Space Needle, and St Louis has the Arch. The Arch is situated right next to the Mississippi River within an absolutely gorgeous park with broad walkways, benches, little lakes, and fields. 

Inside the Arch is the Museum of Westward Expansion, complete with animatronics. Historical figures move about and speak to certain historical events with a personal flair. 

A ticket to the top of the Arch can be paired with a Riverboat Cruise, a IMAX movie, or a documentary, but the main event is, of course, the Arch. 

Keep in mind, the Arch was built in 1965. What I'm trying to say is that elevator technology wasn't at it's peak.. If you're into science fiction, you'll love the starship escape pod 'feel' of the tram. The lurches and rumbling simply add to the realism. Otherwise, you're in for one claustrophobic experience. 

Once at the top, .. that's about it. Nothing too amazing about it. There are several slots of windows for visitors to peer down onto the city and the river. You can definitely feel the curvature of the peak of the arch and the sometimes swaying with a strong gust. It's also packed with other tourists, so finding someone to take your picture is a breeze. (haha). 

The Arch is one of those things you have to do if you're in St Louis, but not something to revisit again and again.

My wife and I went here because we had driven by it many times and have heard great things about it.  We were very excited because we have not found great bbq in the area since moving here 3 years ago.  We went on a Sunday afternoon and walked in.  They were not that busy, but it took us between 5 and 10 minutes to realize that we should seat ourselves because there are no signs anywhere (not that we could see anyways) and the employees just kept walking by us like we weren't there.  We sat down, looked over the menu, decided what we wanted, and waited.  And waited.  And waited.  10 minutes later, a guy comes over and says "Have you been helped yet?" We told him no and he took our drink order as well as our food.  Soon after, another lady comes over and says "Have you been helped yet?" My wife ordered the 3 Little Pigs (3 pulled pork sliders) and I had the Brisket plate. 

The pork was bland and dry, but the worst part was that when she bit into it, there was a huge hard piece, either gristle or bone, in the first bite.  We decided it must have been an accident and she took a bite from another of the sliders.  AGAIN! As for the brisket, I am not sure if it is because I am from Oklahoma where the BBQ style is different, but I hated it.  It had good flavor, but had tons of liquid and more than half of the substance served was inedible fat (I've heard of marbling, but this was fat marbled with some brisket).  The mashed potatoes I ordered were just that, potatoes.  No gravy, no salt.  Just potatoes with a hint of garlic.  The beans were the only thing that we both enjoyed from our meals.  The BBQ beans were very good, some of the best I have had in a long time. 

We stood up to pay, waited at the cash register for about 5 minutes with not so much as an "I'll be right with you" or "One moment please". When someone finally came over, he asked how everything was and I said "To be completely honest with you, it wasn't good.  The pork had gristle and the brisket had so much fat that it was hard to eat." His response? "Yeah we have that problem with our brisket.  that'll be $18.50." Honestly? You have that problem with your brisket? Then don't serve it!

We really wanted to like this place.  We wanted to love it.  Slow seating? Fine. Slow service? Fine. A little gristle in some pulled pork? It happens. The thing is, if the food was good other than these things, we would probably still love it. But, the quality of food was not to par, and we both felt sick a few hours after eating there. So, the search for good BBQ continues.

Books as far as the eye can see. It just keeps going and going...and then goes some more. This, my friends, is a bibliophiles dream. I spent an hour just taking it all in without a specific list of books I wanted but found some goodies that I couldn't leave without. If you love books and love to browse for books this is the place to be! 

It's very organized and everything is categorized well (especially for a used bookstore) so my OCD was happy, too. If you can think it, they have it.   

They also have games, old vinyl records and toys. I didn't have any interest in those as I was here for the books, but it all looked organized as well. 

Love, love, love the book exchange program and you can bet if I lived in Nashville this is where I would be 90% of the time!

Gather 'round, friends. I'd like to tell you the secret to finding decent Mexican food in Indianapolis. It all starts with finding a restaurant with a name that has nothing to do with anything remotely Mexican. Find a restaurant with a gringo name, and you might find someone in the kitchen making good Mexican food (i.e. Biscuits Cafe, Chris's Ice Cream). 

But let's focus on Biscuits Cafe. Does that sound like a good Mexican place to you? Of course not -- why would it? Mexicans don't eat biscuits. It's just not a thing. However, they make really good Mexican food at Biscuits Cafe, so you should visit to partake of their Mexican food. 

(Although, I've heard they make awesome biscuits and gravy, too, so you should come for that if you feel in the mood. They serve breakfast all day!)

We got the chicken tacos al pastor and fajita platter, and both were really good. To me, the sign of a good Mexican place is whether they have good rice and beans. Rice and beans are the backbone to any Mexican meal, so if they are good, then that sets the tone for the rest of the meal. Fortunately, they have excellent refried beans (covered with yellow cheese, as they should) and Mexican rice. The rice doesn't have peas and carrots in it, by the way. My chicken tacos were served with diced onions and cilantro, and I was given two huge bottles of house-made red and green salsa to use at my discretion. The green salsa was mild, and the red salsa had a chipotle bite to it and was a little more spicy. Both were really good and went well with the tacos. 

The fajitas platter comes out sizzling, so be careful when touching the plate! My husband said his fajitas were really good. 

My kids got pancakes and bacon. (I know, right? I mean, we're at a Mexican restaurant ... but what are you gonna do. Kids, dude.) They loved their pancakes! The pancakes come three to an order, but they are kid-sized and come with your choice of meat (bacon or sausage) and fruit. They even provide you with warm syrup to drizzle over your pancakes. My kids ate most of their meal, which is unusual because they usually leave at least 2/3 of it on their plate! Wasteful kids! (Heaven love them.)

Like most Mexican restaurants, Biscuits Cafe gives you complimentary chips and salsa when you sit down. Both are excellent and addicting, as chips and salsa at a Mexican restaurant should be.

Sawmill is near the top of Tucson's Sky Island. For long time Tucson residents it replaced the ramshackled but beloved "Pie Place".  They have a beautiful deck to enjoy in the summer and fall. During the winter months there's a fireplace inside to make it cozy! The food is good, but expect higher prices than in the valley. There's a cost to do business on the mountain, increased delivery charges and labor. Most employees have to commute, so please keep this in mind while tipping. The weekends are crazy but if you can get away during the week it's a delight. I really enjoy the Friday Fish Fry! Service is sporadic depending upon the staff. We have seen indifference to the amazing Josie. That girl could give lessons. She wasn't our server this visit but it was a joy to watch her non stop smile and her attention to details.

I so badly want to love this place. Convenient downtown location, beautiful open loft space, online scheduling, never loud or crowded, very friendly staff -- all great attributes in a salon. Getting a blowout in such a chic space just makes you feel fabulous. But I just cannot get any of the stylists to LISTEN to me. I know my hair, and I know that if a stylist uses too much product, my hair falls flat and greasy after a few hours. I might have a shot in hell at making a blowout last to the 2nd day if there is VERY little product in it. A simple blowdry is all I need.

I've gotten maybe 6 blowouts here at Wip, and each and every time, I've requested that the stylist use as little product as possible, explaining how my hair reacts. They always say yes and make me think they understand, yet they always add more more more. They promise to use "just one thing," then that one thing becomes root spray, shine serum, volumizer, straightening cream, hairspray, whatever. An hour later, and I have six different things in my hair, and it looks great, but I know I'll get only 6 hours out of it. So, $35 for one afternoon of fabulous hair. I'm not sure how else to communicate what I want, and I keep trying this place over and over with the same result, so I'll probably just stop trying.

Main thing in love about scoopers is family deal 4 burgers fries and drinks for little over 20. Other then that there beyond delicious burgers with the many flavor shakes. I myself love chocolate banana with double cheese. While my little ones love bubble gum ice cream. The misses on the other hand likes to only get banana split for late nice snack. Overall prices are fare and food is great.

Excited to try out the new restaurant in Broad Ripple. We found parking easily and were greeted right away. We were a little disappointed in the limited menu- 4-5 soup/salads, 4-5 flatbreads and 4-5 sandwiches plus some apps and desserts. That being said, I'd rather have a small menu where attention is paid and the items were done well than a many mediocre dishes. We chose the pepperoni flatbread, which had an amazing crust. The lemon ricotta cheese was a little different, but the bread was a hit. We had the fried fish sandwich, the best and the lobster roll- all particularly well-done. We were especially appreciative of the attention given to accommodate food allergies.

Only two real drawbacks- we aren't beer drinkers and while this is an offshoot of Sun King Brewery, we were disappointed that they only carried one Ash and Elm cider. That being said/ they had many other drink options, both with and without alcohol. The only dish that was a disappointment was the whooping pie. Lovely playing, made in house, but it was bland and dry. It wasn't made today, and it was just out of place with the excellence and care shown in the rest of the meal.

I love Oreganos, but I hate the wait! Maybe now that a second location is opening, yes a second one, finally!!!!, we won't have to wait 30-45 minutes to stuff our faces with their amazing cheese bread or delicious pasta. The Alfredo the Dark is an old favorite, however, the sauce has been reformulated and it is lighter and it makes for a lighter dish, but definitely takes away from the flavor of the dish.   The cheese bread is awesome on every level and huge, just like all of their portion sizes, so if you like to share, this is the place to do it!  My husband is a fan of the baked ziti and the meatballs, he thinks it is seasoned perfectly, the bread bowl is delicious (but dry at times) and the meatballs taste like the have been cooked for days, in a good way.  

Their chicken (the side) is huge and awesome, the seasoning makes it the perfect addition to any salad, especially the off the menu, old school salad.  Their ranch dressing is almost as good as Eegees and they also have a roasted red pepper Italian that is awesome!



***** Location two opens in March on Oracle and Orange Grove, where El Charro used to be.

We love fast casual. This Pei Wei has good service and has quick Asian inspired eats. The Ladue location sometimes can get crowded but then we just get takeout.  The veggies here always are fresh and crunchy.
The best thing here is the consistent quality of food, only takes about 45 minutes for a meal, it's inexpensive and they also have wine and beer. My favorites here are rice bowls and Pad Thai.
Just as good as the one on causeway. I brought first timers and they were in love with their first sno ball!  The flavors were great wait was a little long but it's closer to us so it was a win win.
Love this place! Got the kale Caesar and it was so good. I have tried the sweet potato hash in the past and also loved that as well as avocado toast. Have not had a bad meal here!

Oh man! I had a blast here! 

It's a nice historic place at the bohemian zone of Tucson! The show I attended to was super organized and the staff was informative and friendly!

Also at the bar I asked for a cocktail, even though they don't serve that kind of cocktails the bartender super improvised a nice piña colada and it was awesomely delicious! 

They also have free wifi so it's a nice plus! 

The stage has a good quality air conditioning so it's not hot even if it's crowded! Also they offer free water at the shows~ 

I loved this place and felt very comfortable the entire time! Definitely coming back!!!!

Best place for different kinds of hot sauces. Very unique place with all kinds of Tabasco items that you can use for cooking or for gifts. I loved that it was in the French Quarter and I was able to see other things close to it. 

I ended up buying the Sweet and Spicy Asian Tabasco sauce and I still have it to this day because a girl can't find it in her local store. I would have to order it online and well, who wants to pay for shipping taxes when I can just easily book another trip to NOLA and have a great time and get a bunch of hot sauces. lol I know its thinking outside of the box but it gives me hope to return to this beautiful city again.

Such a great addition to the food scene and Oro Valley area! And such a fitting name too! Love it. The menu features Banh Mi (aka French influenced Vietnamese sandwiches . There are  six different options ranging from 
 BBQ Pork, Grilled Chicken, Lemongrass Beef, Tofu. All Banh Mi are served with pate, jalapeno, cilantro, mayo, pickled daikon/carrots, cucumber.  You can opt out of pate and mayo to make the tofu vegan. 

We ordered three to try! Not sure when we'll have time to go back! We ordered the lemongrass beef, Grilled BBQ Pork and the Tofu.

Our favorite was the Grilled BBQ pork. The tofu tasted a little runny- not sure if that's the standard way of serving it. THe bread was warm and crispy and quite good. I hear it it sourced from Ghini's Le Baguette bakery...which is awesome! 

I enjoyed the rose milk tea for dessert. It was plenty sweet and extra floral! I have my eye on a few other boba items for my next visit. 

You can order online, here on Yelp or just call it in!


.

Tredici Enoteca is clearly the new hot place to be seen. On a Saturday, my bf and I bravely tried getting in. We arrived at 6:30 (seemed SO early for us on a Saturday) and told 30-45 min wait. No prob, we hit up a nearby happy hour and waited for a text. After 45 mins, we decided to go back and check in. Apparently our table was "running late," but we could be seated at the oyster bar for a drink. Unfortunately a couple had sat down without "clearing" it with the host (note: you need to clear with the host before sitting), and the hostess awkwardly had to bump them out and seat us. If I hadn't have had one glass of wine before hand I would have really been cringing at this awkwardness. An hour and a half after we arrived, we were seated at a table next to said oyster bar. However a group of wine-o-phile suburban soccer moms sat at the bar directly in front of us and were LOUDDDD. Like stomping, shouting, obviously having a damn good time. So our dinner was distracting to say the least.

All of the food was excellent.
Saffron rice balls - satisfying and warm. 
Israeli cous cous- light! 
Moroccan ribs- they fell right off the bone. They were my favorite.
Lasagna- Loved the juxtaposition of the crispy burnt edges and soft cheesy filling.  

My 1/2 glasses of wine were definitely overpoured and I did not mind one bit. 
I would give 5 stars if they had taken reservations, estimated our wait time more appropriately, and not sat us next to the ladies who clearly don't get out much. 
Food, wine, and decor are worthy of 5 stars! So, it is worth the hassle.

This is a great dog park centrally located in the west end park/centennial park neighborhood/area. 

It is a large park situated on a hill right across the street from the Parthenon. There are two fenced in areas, one for large dogs and one for small dogs. At each gate entrance there are tennis balls, poop bags, and trash cans which are all extremely useful. In the center of the park there is a water fountain for the dogs. 

All of the dogs and owners that we have met so far are extremely friendly. We love taking our dog here and he loves running around this nice fenced in area. It is such a dog oasis in a big city.

Amazing baklava, worth the visit for that dessert alone. I can't do it proper justice via written word, but the balance of sweetness and texture is probably best in town. Even if you don't traditionally go nuts over baklava, you owe it to your tongue to try this one.

Half price appetizers when we were there (late afternoon), so we loaded up with hummus, tzatziki, tyropita and spanakopita ... each was right at the "very good, order again" level. Tyropita was possibly the favorite of the bunch.

Specialty gyro was dang tasty but know that it's knife and fork, you're definitely not picking this monster up to eat it. Flavors were deliciously familiar yet also a bit different & distinctive. I'd be totally happy to get it again although I might save the extra dollar and just get the classic version next time.

Owners, if you're listening - please add a hummus and tzatziki combo appetizer plate to your menu. I'd happily pay in genuine United Statesian currency for it. I love tzatziki but having to get a giant portion of it all by itself (or as part of a $15 plate) was a bit of a bummer.

LOVE me some Bakery Bar! I go here way too often, but I love sweets and this is one of the only late night options! I have been going here since it opened when you could just casually walk in, grab a slice and play some board games. It's a little more upscale now with waiter service, but still quick! 

I have pretty much tried every cake flavor and all are delicious! Wedding cake can't be beat, but the Pina Colada is a close second!

The Last Twinkie On Earth came out a couple months back and I got it when it first launched and it was DELICIOUS! I even took multiple people there just to try it!
