Service was a bit slow, but friendly - only one person working the front and the kitchen took a while to get the food out. Server was very patient answering questions from every table.

Is it the "best" kabab in town? No. But we tried the lamacun ($3.25!!) which is a giant crispy flatbread with ground meat and herbs - kind of like a pizza. My new favourite thing!! So crispy! So flavourful! SO CHEAP!!  Loved everything about it. The rest of the food was just ok. They do serve the dinner platters with a garlic yogurt-y sauce that was also awesome. When we finished, we were each given a piece of fresh baklava, which was a really nice treat.

To recap, the lamacun and the garlic sauce were amazeballs. The rest is ok. Service was friendly but a bit slow. I'd totally go back for that flatbread though. Totally worth the trip for a million of those.

I LOVED this place. We stumbled upon this market randomly during our visit to New Orleans. Our Airbnb was about 10 blocks away and we came here as often as we could. 

This marketplace has a "communal" type setup. There are several little "restaurants" inside with each offering their unique and delicious menu options. The place is clean, super hipsterish and plenty of sitting. 

They have complementary water on the back which was a nice little extra. I tried several of the restaurants and will be posting my
Individual reviews under them. 

each little restaurant has their own yelp account so if you want to see their reviews and ratings you should do that as well.

My friends threw me a birthday dinner at R Bistro last night.  I had walked by it before and was eager to try it out (that little corner of Mass Ave has a bunch of gems, by the way).  I admire that R Bistro maintains their own little garden on a patch of land next to the restaurant.  Which of course was covered in snow last night :)

I agree with the other reviewers who have written about the warmth and beauty of the space.  We were seated around a large round table in the cozy-yet-spacious back corner of the restaurant.

We were served some delicious warm rolls with soft butter.  

I had a bowl of butternut squash soup (flavorful yet surprising in its lack of sweetness), a pear/pomegranate/blue cheese salad (wonderful), and shared the vegetarian spinach, goat cheese and mushroom frittata (beautifully presented, though a little on the bland side).  And then a slice from the gorgeous red velvet birthday cake they had brought in for the occasion.

The service was friendly, accommodating, and attentive.  Regina stopped by to say hello and check in on us.

Overall it was a lovely experience and I have warm memories of last night.

It should be noted that the prices are steep.  My frittata was $18.75, which is in line with the the other entrees (non-veg entrees were in the $20-$26 range).  When compared to Recess, which charges $50 per dinner, maybe it is reasonable for the fine dining experience.

Brow/Tint Service

I love yelp so much because everyone has such different experiences and it makes for honest real reviews. I saw Siojo on group on offering a brown tint and shaping for 9.00. of course I yelped and saw the not so positive reviews about hair services. I didn't see any for facial waxing so i decided to take a chance and blow the 9.00.
I arrived to a small salon that smelled amazing. There really is no where to sit or waiting area  so know this upon coming in if your a walk or have an apt and you arrive early. I explained to the receptionist/owner that i wanted to do the brown tint and waxing. She advised it would be about a 10 min wait and offered me a seat near the pedicure area. In less than 5 min i was greeted by Tasha who led me back to the waxing area. Its clean , sterile but very small. Tasha asked me about how i wear my brows, if i have ever been tinted and what look i wanted to achieve(pretty much every question someone who's a professional should ask) Since i had never been tinted she explained that each step and about the tint itself. After applying the tint she left me for about 15 min (thats how long it has to sit for ). She came back in exactly 15 min shaped my brows and discussed some of the other services they offer. Apparently there is a downstairs to this beauty boutique and they offer a full service spa in addition tho the salon. 
Tasha gave me a brochure and a 20% of coupon for my next visit. I saw some of the ladies getting blowouts and was very impressed.
I would definitely return to have the brow tint/ shaping done and maybe some additional services.

Have not been here often (don't live in the area) but I'm always glad when I do! This place is heaven for a person like me, who loves interesting food, sustainability and cool new things. The lower floor is a grocery store and the upper floor is a casual cafe. I tried a matcha latte, tiramisu and vegan cinnamon roll and they were all AMAZING. They really prioritize ingredients and everything is presented well (and usually very sustainably). For example, the tiramisu was stored in a reusable glass jar.

I love this place. I love all halal platters, but this place takes the cake. It's the "original" or at least this is what someone used to tell me. Anyways, I always go with the small chicken platter with rice and salad (hold the pita.. i don't need anymore carbs lol). White sauce is a must. Hot sauce.. man this stuff is spicy and it really depends on your spice level. They literally measure this stuff in lines. I go for about 3-4 and i love spicy.

2.5 Stars

Decent Thai food with some good items, and some fails.

Fried tofu to start with was marginal - it was very bland with almost no flavor, and didn't have the silky interior that I love. However, the Larb Gai appetizer, chicken mixed with chili powder, scallions, mint leaves, Thai herbs and lime juice served with sliced cabbage, was outstanding, with a fabulous, fresh flavor.

For my entrée I had the Amazing, which was anything but.  Served cool, with a cloying, sweet brown sauce on top, it was almost inedible.  I sent it back to be warmed up, but that just made it even worse. My boyfriend had their special fried rice which he liked, but they must have gotten their 'heat level' confused, because his ordered medium was extra fiery.

Service was just okay. They had two waiters in the restaurant, and while they were attentive at first, that dropped off as more tables arrived.  It's been ten or so years since I tried this place, and it will probably be that long before I go back.

I love this place. It's usually a stop to or from somewhere else but I love it each time. Very chill vibe. Great frozen libations. The atmosphere really makes this place - kinda feel like I'm in a pirate movie when im here.  Definitely worth a stop.

California girl searching for delicious tacos in the Midwest!  I definitely found it at Bakersfield Mass Ave.  My boyfriend and I were there on a Tuesday evening.  It wasn't too crowded, but the tables were packed.  Luckily, we walked in at the right time and a belly bar table opened up.  

I really liked the ambience.  It's noisy, but not so bad that you have to yell at each other across the table.  It's everything I expect a hip whiskey/tequila drinking institution to be.  Couple that with delicious street style tacos, BAM I'm sold! 

Service was excellent.  Our waitress was very sweet and offered lots of great suggestions.  Between the two of us, we got a couple drinks, Chips and Queso, and a few tacos each.

The Chips and Queso were yummy, but it got a little too heavy towards the end for me.  My boyfriend loved every last bite of it.  The chips were really addicting.

As for the tacos, we got Fish, Hongos, Pollo Rojo, Pork Belly Pastor, and Short Rib.  It's great that they make their corn tortillas in-house.  I loved loved loved the pork belly.  It was flavorful, slightly crispy, and cooked to perfection.  The short rib taco was delicious as well.  Highly recommended!  

I also ordered the sangria which was made with rose and a moscato.  It was refreshing, but a  little too sweet for my taste (should've known with the moscato).  

Other details:

Not a huge restaurant, but they can accommodate larger groups if you plan in advance. 

Clean bathrooms. 

Paid street parking.  Plentiful on a Tuesday evening, but may be a little difficult on weekends.

Located near tons of other shops, restaurants, and boutiques.

Overall, I had a positive experience.

Initially, I was very excited to check out the Japanese Festival at the Missouri Botanical Gardens, especially to take a tour of the Teahouse Island, which is only open once a year during this festival. Maybe I built it up too much in my head, but my experience there was okay. It wasn't amazing, but it wasn't too bad. 

The parking gets pretty crazy, so you may want to try to get there early so you don't have to walk as far. The gardens itself is large, though, so just know that you'll be doing a fair amount as walking regardless. 

Right near the entrance, there were food vendors set up (I'd say between 5-10), some of which are more authentic than others (as my husband also mentioned). However, the Japanese green tea and red bean shaved ice was super awesome! It reminded me of Taiwanese shaved ice. :] It was sweet and cold and a perfectly refreshing treat on a hot day! 

There seemed to be a lot of performances and demonstrations on the schedule, but none of them had the wow factor I was looking for. Maybe I'm just too spoiled because I grew up in Orlando and I'm used to productions at Disney and Universal Studios. :P Anyway, these are the things we ended up doing: 
- Sumo demonstration: It was entertaining and funny because they took several volunteers from the crowd to participate in a few matches. 
- Cooking demo where they were making sushi: The ladies were so sweet, but their accents were on the heavy side, making it difficult to understand their instructions. Plus, I didn't really learn anything new. 
- Bonsai exhibit: I love tiny things and I love trees, so this was awesome! 
- Teahouse Island tour: It was cool to see the island and to hear a little about the history of teahouse culture, but there were questions our tour guide couldn't answer because her familiarity with the teahouse was limited (as they only give these tours once a year). 
- Ice sculpture demo: The location they picked could be improved, since so many people were crowding around making it difficult to see. It was kind of cool to see a chainsaw being used to shape the ice, but it got boring after a while. 

All in all, I would go back next year, but I would do it with slightly lowered expectations. And make sure you bring a water bottle! They have water bottle filling stations throughout the park!

I've been wanting to try this place for a while in search for different varieties of dim sum. The place was pretty busy because it was lunch time. My server was very nice and helpful. 

I love dim sum so I was really excited to try some items on their vast menu. The tripe was okay, not really my favorite and wasn't spicy in my opinion. The rolled rice noodles were a bit too firm for my liking but the shrimp filling was good. I always get the steam spare ribs and they met my expectations, pretty good. The chicken feet was okay as well, not much flavor and it was broken up and soft. The pan fried shrimp dumplings were pretty good. My friend liked the tong chow chicken lunch plate. Over all not too bad but I think I would stick to panda king for dim sum.

Stein's is a hoppin' locals spot in an up and coming location on Magazine. They have a vast deli selection of meats and cheese plus loaded sandwiches and salads and the best NYC style bagels in town!!!! They have a great drink and beer selection too!! The ambiance is like NYC meets NOLA with large communal table tops inside and picnic seating outside. I get a toasted bagel with avo, lettuce, tomato, and capers! Sandwiches come with delicious pickles. My friend got the Rachel sandwich and loved it.  We had a bit of a wait but the service was great! They totally made up for it by offering my friend a free drink on account of his wait. Great deli!! Highly recommend Stein's for locals and tourists alike.

This was our first time here and I was surprised with the large, eclectic selection of furniture and home decor. They have a great selection of furniture for most homes from current trends through traditional. Every inch of the store has furniture, home accessories and accent pieces to compliment each room from ceiling to floor. 

We were immediately greeted as we entered the store. The saleswoman was friendly and asked if we were looking for anything in particular. We weren't at the time but I love browsing furniture and home decor stores. I love getting decorating ideas and adding a few pieces to update my own space.

Unfortunately when I did have a couple questions the salesteam was busy with others. I could have waited longer but they weren't life or death questions requiring answers that very minute. If I were purchasing I would have made a point to wait.

Prices varied from average prices to overpriced. There was a nice sale going on when we were there. I'm going to be in the market for new sofas soon so I'm going to begin following their sales. The eclectic selection made browsing fun for me and I look forward to returning in the future.

Pretty dissapointed in this experience. It was my first time having a cheesesteak in the city of brotherly love and it didn't live up to my expectations. i've had cheesesteaks here in DC that blow this away. 
 
It seemed like everything came from a can and the meat was severely lacking in flavor and juiciness. 

Won't be coming back again.

My first time here was great.  Beautiful outdoor seating (so dog friendly!) and great, attentive service.  Their beer list is great with great prices.  I LOVE their vegetarian friendly menu as well.  They're not your typical vegetarian selections but very unique (like a cauliflower crust pizza with mushrooms - delicious!).

I found this quaint little poke restaurant on Yelp and had a strong craving for some fresh food on my business trip. 

The restaurant is in a nice little strip mall and was very clean and bright inside. The menu was easy to understand and the staff were all so friendly and helpful. 

The poke choices all looked very fresh and clean. I loved the variety and definitely feel like there is something for everyone's taste preferences.

The boba tea was sooooo good and refreshing too!  You have to order it!

I would strongly recommend this restaurant. You won't go home hungry- and that, folks, is all she wrote.

I had a very enjoyable visit to Yogurt Mountain. They had some very fun, tasty and interesting flavors. It certainly helped that I was with Boon, Grace, Fernelly and Rachel who are always entertaining..

Nate was friendly and helpful and I started off with a few samples. Didn't love the pomegranate (not pomegrantey enough) but the cookies and cream, coffee, yellow cake, and birthday cake were all good. The original tart wasn't the best I've had, maybe on the sweet side? but it was fine. The watermelon is SUPER interesting and fun. 

The toppings are also very playful. lots of sweets like gummies, chocolate covered gummies, licorice strands, sour strips as well as fruit. The price seemed quite reasonable for what I got. The place was pretty busy even late and it's nice that it was open late enough for us to enjoy. Seating was comfortable and the decor is nice. Well lit. People were friendly. 

If they had mochi and the blackberries were a lil better looking I would give it five stars. No WiFi also a lil disappointing. And I like fresh mango and kiwi toppings. Makes me believe I am being healthy.. But otherwise it's definitely a super fun place with a lot of variety, taste and fun. Definitely go with Boon, Rachel, Grace, and Fernelly if you can.

Great experience here!  I heard the gnocchi was a must so I asked for an appetizer (on the menu as an entree) and they happily obliged. It was so good and satisfying that I was almost full!  It was warm and inviting comfort food. I had the seafood cannoli for my entree and it far exceeded my expectations. The outside was crispy but not too crispy and the seafood was abundant. My husband loved the caprese salad. I can't wait to go back when I can have wine...the selection was amazing. A must go for good Italian in Indy!

After attending many a movie in Germany at movies with assigned seating I was quite trepidatious. After just a few moments inside the spacious lobby we found the kiosk. I had an insider tip to skip the standard line and head straight to the kiosk. We chose our seats, printed our tickets and headed to the concession line. Concessions were standard price for a theatre visit. The addition of higher quality food and drink options was a nice touch - beer and an italian sausage while enjoying the movie was great!

We grabbed our snacks and hit the theatre. We were ushered to our seats, the policies of the theatre were explained and we sat down.

Then magic happened - I found the button to adjust the seat into full recliner mode. Instantly I was transported to my own couch just with a much larger screen. 

Instantly in love.

I've now been here every few weeks since opening and it is always my first choice for a theatre. I now find myself disappointed when I have to visit other theatres because this one is not offering the movie I want to see.

I'll be curious to see how well maintained this theatre will remain. It's brand new and shiny right now, but where will it be a in a few years. If it stays at a quality this high, I will stay a loyal patron. I shudder to think of returning to a theatre without fully reclining seats. Oh the dread... I need to patronize this, and only this, theatre forever.

The Dog Bar delivers a creative approach to alcohol consumption. 
Every dog owner loves their dog (except when they pee in the house), so why not spend some time with the pooch at the neighborhood bar?  There's plenty of water and ice on hand for the furry friends and a solid variety of taps available for those of us who walk on two legs.  
The Dog Bar also offers a full liquor bar.  

There are sections where you can drink and get severed along side your free ranging pup. There are also dog free zones.  
The artificial turf blankets an area for the dogs to play.

I'm sure my dog would encourage me to drink a lot more, but so far he can't come up with  the $40 annual membership fee to this country club.  Yes, dog membership is 40 dollars.  
That's the one draw back here. Most sidewalk bars through the city allow and encourage dogs. 

For now, I'll be drinking alone at the dog bar -- or at least not with my best friend.

I'm not the world's biggest barbecue fan, but when it's done right, I'll love it. In short, I loved Edley's. I ordered the chicken sandwich with macaroni and cheese and bean salad. Even sauceless, that was one of the best chicken sandwiches I've ever tasted! Hot BBQ damn.

I have been to Bridgestone many, many, many times for sporting events, concerts, entertainment shows, etc. I really love this venue. They recently updated some of their food stands (I think that's what they're called) and they are DELICIOUS. I think my fav item is the mashed potato bowl at the Chicken stand - oh my YUM. Bridgestone is massive so it's easy to get lost in but wherever you sit in the venue, you've got a great view. Love the atmosphere when a crowd is packed in there. Unfortunately, parking downtown sucks. I can never find somewhere close to park for less than $15-$20 bucks. Of course there are cheaper spots to park further away from the venue but if I'm meeting friends, and walking alone at night, I prefer to be closer to Bridgestone for safety reasons. 

If you haven't been to an event here, come. It's a great way to spend any day/night, the alcohol selection is wonderful and the food is yummy!

3 stars for food, 5 stars for service and atmosphere

2nd visit, similar thoughts as the 1st - great friendly service, cute 'old FL' atmosphere, food never wows me - good, but nothing amazing. Servers are always super personable and do a great job.

Ordered fish tacos - huge portion, fish was not really hot (warm but not hot) so kinda disappointing. BF ordered filet - also not super hot but still decent. My dad loved his bacon wrapped scallops.

Prices are high enough that when the food isn't awesome, it's not really on the top of my visit list.

I ate at Positano Coast last Saturday night with some friends.  I loved the atmosphere, and we had a great view from our table.  The staff was very attentive.  I ordered the Eggplant Napoleon and the Gnocchi Gorgonzola, and both were disappointing.  I was looking forward to two, very flavorful dishes, and both left much to be desired.  I had a drink (the name escapes me right now), and it was ok. I tasted one of my friend's crab cakes, and that was pretty good. For dessert, I had the Nutella Crepe, and I was also disappointed with that!  The crepe was tasty, but the chocolate tasted nothing like Nutella - it was more like a bitter chocolate sauce.  The crepe tasted ok, but I was looking forward to the Nutella (yum), so that definitely put a damper on the taste. 

Everything was presented beautifully, but everything I tasted lacked flavor.  I probably won't go back, and that stinks because the place just looks so cool!

Love love love the water ice and gelati here. The staff is usually friendly and are quick to get the lines down. It's a plus that they have a pretzel factory in the same strip mall so you can have pretzels too

I love that they only have healthy options and they manage to make it taste good. I like the hummus salad lunch plate. Its more food than you think. I was starving and I couldnt finish it all. If you are not watching your calories, ask for an additional cucumber raiki because thats what you use for salad dressing.  they also offer hibiscus tea:)
Try out their app and/or sign up for their email club and receive a free side item.

Our favorite on the beach Santa Barbara restaurant.  
There are tables on the sand and tables under a covered patio.  We love having weekday getaway brunch.   Plenty of parking and never a need for reservations.
This Wawa is a converted 7-11 so it does not have a public bathroom. Major problem after a long drive. Also the parking is awkward and limited. Love Wawa's in general but this one is lacking.

I've never shopped at Sprouts before, but chose to at this time based on their advertising this new location and the ads showcasing their produce selection. I was in love the second I saw the cotton candy grapes. They are super juicy and SO amazingly delicious! I've gone back again to grab more and more!

I've found pretty much everything I usually shop for here like I find at other stores, just a bit pricier. Good quality. Lots of vegan options. I'm not vegan at all, but I am working on eating healthier and what I need, I found here. And thankfully close to home.

Don't tell a soul...this is might be my new happy hour spot!  I LOVE SEAFOOD! So pair great seafood with a sexy sleek restaurant and you got Fin and Pearl.  I went there recently for happy hour.  The bartenders are truly friendly mixologists who are attentive and made me and my company feel welcomed.  We had oysters, of course!  The oyster guy (do they have a name for oyster specialists?...oyster connoisseur?) is the best! He will make oysters tasty yummy for the oyster virgins and brings a wealth of knowledge for the raw oyster fan. We also tried the ribs, very tasty!  I can't wait to go back and try more yummy stuff during dinner service.

The spinners at the counter are wobbly, and there is a photo of the marriage of JKF and Jackie O. on the wall, but Kitty's Luncheonette is as real as it gets for traditional breakfasts and lunches in this part of Philadelphia. They don't know from brunch, and they close before happy hour; so don't bookmark it for your weekend morning meal, nor try to stop in after work.  This is a 7 to 3:30 corner grill that had a few dozen thick scrapple slices frying to a dark brown while I drank their Ellis Coffee and awaited my first taste of their french toast.  

The house has about a dozen tables in two rooms and eight spinning stools along the counter that overlooks the chef workspace.  It was about half full of neighborhood personalities who seemed to know each other as they were greeted by name.  The server, a lovely young woman who is Kitty's niece, took care of me, and filled me in on the history of the institution, open since 1952! 

Yes. It looks its age, with family photos on the walls, and original floors, walls and stools.  Either you get the deeply rubbed in culture here, or you don't. With its gritty charm and surprisingly good food, it is easy to develop a crush on Kitty, and want to visit her often. She is as authentic as the day is long.  My three slices of thick egged toast were very good.  A little sweet from the vanilla and sugar in the mix, and a little crispy on the edges where the hot steel melted that sugar and left its hardened residue.  They know how to do FT here. $5.50 was a happy price. The java was strong and a little rough (bitter), but nothing to complain about. Again, her Joe is straight up Bunn-O-Matic.  No expresso options with Kitty. 

Kitty's is very close to I-95, and an easy on/off if you want to stop before reaching Center City from the north. Not sure she could handle becoming a hit on the breakfast bookmark circuit, especially on weekends, so if you want to check her out, come on a weekday morning when the regular crowd is thinner.  

But, if you like hard stop traditional breakfast without any frills, give this old girl a go.

We come here every  Monday for Moe's Monday: $5.99 for any burrito, chips, and a drink.

Food: I love it, we literally haven't missed a Monday in about a year. I can get a 'naked' Burrito, called an Ear Muffs - how clever, and get rice, no beans, 1/2 chicken, 1/2 steak, cucumbers, mushrooms, tomatoes, guac, cilantro, and salsa vinaigrette. Hubby gets the Joey burrito with about the same thing.

Service: At first the boys who worked here were very short and quick to make our order in the very beginning but now know who we are and know what we order every week!

Overall: We only come here on Mondays, of course, but the food is great at a good price so you can't ask for more than that!

a must see in STL. I went during the Ming Dynasty exhibit. It was cool that they gave you an ipod to listen to while you walked through and gave a bit of history of the items. Pucks is a very good restaurant. One of the statues i took a picture of is now the pic on my debit card. 

FREE to get in. gotta love free.

This park is beautiful! I came here while on a 3-hour bus tour of the entire city, so my time here was limited to only 30 minutes. Because of that, I feel like I didn't get enough time to really explore and see every landmark and highlight of City Park. I will say, though that I loved everything that I did get to see while here. I'm a sucker for a few things in a park: Architecture/ruins, unique pavilions, foliage, a place for a snack or beverage to break away from the heat, sculpture/artwork, and water. City Park has all of those things! I'm a sucker for Spanish Moss and Magnolia Trees, neither of which are common in my hometown of St. Louis, so just being able to be near an abundance of those things was a dream come true.

The sculpture garden here was a treat, and the Morning Call restaurant seems like a lovely place for lunch, ice cream, or a nice beverage.

I loved seeing that this park has many large oak trees with the branches low to the ground. Don't let the 4-star rating fool you, I really enjoyed my time being here, and hopefully on my next visit to NOLA (because I will definitely be back!), I will make plans to spend more time here and take in a lot more of it than 30 minutes. Upon which time, I have no doubt that an extra star will follow.

Service was quick and great. Love the way they checked and service everything. I went in for oil change but received top notch service. Wind shield wipers replaced, fluids topped off tires checked.  Best part no all day waiting

And everyone that touched my car was super nice and customer service focused.   Honk my horn so much that it blew away street traffic

I love this store. I usually come here to buy the giant sized sage for my house to smoke out ghosts and ghouls. Yes, I can go get sage anywhere, but I love to support my local businesses. Everyone should do this as much as possible. Besides that , I love browsing  in this store, and sometimes I get caught up and buy other things too. On my recent visit I bought a little monkey pipe . It had an eye on it so I knew I had to have it . Anything with an eye on it , I snatch up. Could be the Greek in me:-) I love it . It so small, cute, and gets the job done well. On my way out,  I was browsing the chronic pops, and the guy who runs the place, that let me add, is always very helpful & nice when I come in, told me to take a couple and let him know what I think . That was very nice of him. Thank you! I'll be back when in need of more Sage. Got to keep those ghosts at Bay.

Unless you're living under a rock, you've heard of The Cheesecake Factory. The restaurant very well known for its encyclopedic menu, but what about the food itself? I can't imagine being the chef/cook in that kitchen, as the responsibility of trying to replicate that many items day in and day out on a consistent basis must be daunting. Well, on a somewhat boring Friday night, I decided to see for myself (once again of course) how well they could do on my particular order. 
     Thinking Friday night, didn't feel like waiting an hour as this particular location is inside of the very popular local mall, so I used the online ordering site. Was easy to use, and let me check out as a guest instead of making me enter my life's story of information, so far so good. I ordered the club sandwich and fries (asked for extra crispy, which they delivered on, A+ on that), and the kids got a hamburger (the Original) with fries, and the Buffalo Wings appetizer (asked for all drumsticks but didn't get, as well as extra crispy fries fo both that also weren't). What I also really liked is that I ordered curbside pickup, and because this was in a mall, they actually have their own parking spots reserved for the restaurant (which is awesome because the mall is always a nightmare for parking), and you just call them and the employee comes right out, ingenious!
     I have to say, I was quite impressed. All of the food was delicious, kids really loved theirs and my sandwich was on point, really good. But I do have a gripe, and this is starting to become a theme for me lately. Maybe I'm just getting old, or maybe, just maybe, I'm exactly right (I'm thinking the latter of course), but for what I just ordered, what would you expect to pay? $30-$35? $40? How about $47.63 (throw in $5 for the tip), and we're at nearly $53 for what is really glorified diner fare. Does that sound sustainable to you? It must be standard for their business model, and it's obviously working as they've been around for quite a long time, but this isn't a place I can visit consistently without getting a raise at work. And yes, everything else on the menu is priced very aggressively, so buyer be ware. I really want to be a frequent guest of "The Factory", but I just can't justify the cost. If your wallet is fat, this is your place, otherwise it's just a once or twice a year "treat" for the rest of us (deplorables).

Pi has got it going on!  First off, their rendition of a deep dish pizza is straight yummy and much less greasy than Chicago deep dish (which can be amazing in its own right).  If you are familiar with Zachary's Pizza in Berkeley/Oakland, CA, then you will love Pi.  I believe Zachary's was inspirational in the creation of the Pi pizza style, hence the Bay Area references on the menu.  Pi definitely provides unique, quality vegetable and meat options for pizza, tasty salads, as well as interesting garlic bread served with actual whole roasted garlic cloves.  Plus, with the domestic draught and bottled microbrewery beer options and fun/hip ambiance, I feel like Pi is a complete win win dining situation.  A must eat/see in St. Louis in my mind.  Also, the establishment is smoke-free and advocates substainability.  Beautiful.

LOVED!

I'm a member so I purchased tickets at the discount price of $15. Money well spent! 

We all pondered how many lights there were total wrapped around tree trunks and branches and lights clinging to wrought iron fences. Has to be in the millions, easily.

The choreographed lights in front of Lilly House was a delight to watch. However I wished they had mixed up the music a bit, straying from the Nutcracker Suite (which I think they only played 'Waltz of the Flowers' over and over again). I think some more upbeat music every now and again would have added energy to the event.

I like the small details that went into creating this experience. One would be the warming stations that weren't generic gas lamps, but rather real stoves fueled by wood. Very nice touch and right next to the treat stand. Eat and be warm. Good combo.

The kissing arbor was a big hit! There was a volunteer standing by to assist with photos. How often does someone offer to take your pic!! 

My absolute favorite part was Snowflake Bridge, the first sight you see walking into the display. It was so angelic and lots of dimension. I wanted to stand there forever and look up at the trees. 

IF YOUR EYES HURT BY LOOKING AT BLUE LIGHTS, YOU HAVE AN OCULAR DISEASE... WARNING!!
There is a section near the big tree made of children's toys that is alllllllll blue lights. I literally couldn't even walk through that area. 

I could say about 20 more great things about the evening we spent at Winterlights, but I will leave some for your surprise and delight. Enjoy!

My wife and came here about 12:30pm on a Friday for lunch. She loves Mexican food and we have been to the location in Stead on several occasions. We have always enjoyed it. 

It was not too busy and we were told to have a seat where we liked. We chose a booth along the wall. The booth on my side of the table felt like the cushion was gone in the middle and my chin was on the table. I just moved a bit toward the wall, but my wife commented to me not to lean against the wall. I looked and it appeared to not have been cleaned in a while. There were all sorts of different colors and specks on it. I wish I took a picture but I did not.  The remainder of the restaurant looked clean but the booths along the side of the restaurant should be ripped out and replaced. 

The server brought us menus and took our drink orders. We were familiar with the menu since we have been to their other location. I chose the enchiladas lunch special and my wife likes their chimichangas so she ordered that. 

Our food arrived in a timely manner and looked yummy and the server was attentive. We enjoyed our meals and appreciated the fast service since we had to get back to work. 

Overall a good experience but next time we will definitely not sit in the booth.

This place could be THE go-to dinner spot on the fringe of Fishtown and Port Richmond.  Excellent burger (got to love a burger that comes with the option of pulled pork and/or a fried egg on top).  Fantastic onion rings.  Solid fries.  Cold beers and all the PWC favorites on draft.  I think everyone in my party of 4 was really was satisfied with the food.  The service was surprisingly helpful for a dive bar too.  

It's just everything else that's bringing the rating down....

No one wants to sit in the back of the room next to a cold drafty window with a giant neon Guinness sign 2 feet from their head.   Lose the neon beer signs and put up some Christmas lights and you really got something.  Get rid of the rickety tables and chairs and get something a little nicer and people will want to sit back there and eat.  Oh yeah, and let's try a little heat, it was freezing when we were in there.

Despite all that, it did have a really nice and well maintained bathroom.

I get it... it's a dive bar... but there are a few minor things they could do to make it more inviting.  

I will return for those onion rings.

After falling in love with the rum balls from the other location of the Italian Bakery, I had to give this location a shot as it's actually a lot closer to where I live. 

I definitely have picked up some rum balls here, but also other Italian fixings like cheese, pasta, sauces, pizza dough, olives, etc. They have a decent selection if you're looking for a quick Italian meal. They don't have the space that Spinelli's has, but they have quite a bit for their size. I tried a few of the other baked goods and that's where they really shine. 

It gets pretty busy on Saturdays and they aren't open on Sundays, which is the day we always do our grocery shopping. Service was a bit hectic a couple of times when it was really busy, but nice and friendly when it has been slower.

A little mellow for my taste. The skirt steak was a little bland and not spicy at all. When we asked for spicy salsa, they delivered, but the flavor wasn't really in the dish.

Also- the BEST margarita i've ever had, and that's saying something because i love tequila. It was freshly made and you could actually see the lime pieces. 

I ordered the empanadas- omg, perfect. The dough was slightly sweet which mixed perfectly with the chorizo and plantains. It was perfectly seasoned. I need to know how to make this for breakfast. The prices were a little high for the quality of food.  

Used the Taste coupon, which they graciously accepted even though it says no Saturdays, and I did appreciate that. Our waiter was really good, he recommended that we try the margarita (which we did not regret) and there when we needed refills and all that.

Suuuper trippy restaurant. Feels like you're eating in the Ocean. It's a great atmosphere, the waiter was really creepy, and the food was okay. This is an awesome place to bring kids (or ocean lovers)!

I stopped by after work and immediately loved the atmosphere and service. I got a cold beer (try their IPA!!) and mushroom and sausage pizza which was so divine. The cheese on the pizza was extremely fresh and the pizza crust was baked just right. It had lots of open seating so you could see everyone, but could also enjoy some privacy. Highly recommend it!

I have been coming to Harold's for 5 years.  They are amazing, this is the only place I buy my dog food in the area.  They carry the best brands and the employees are so hospitable.  I love that they carry local honey, rubs, beef jerky and smoker supplies.  There are so many pet supplies and treats as well.  Shop local as much as you can.  These are some great people.

Everything is better with Cheddar's Scratch Kitchen! This popular chain restaurant has a lot of great choices on their menu. The ribs are amazingly good! The burgers are cooked to perfection. The chicken tenders are the best. 

We love Cheddars! The service there is good and it's worth being the whole family to.

Eos Lounge was my favorite when I lived in Santa Barbara.  It was far enough from the main strip of obnoxious clubs, but close enough to end up here at the end of the night.  Although, I did used to start and stay here all night back when Bang Bang was held here.

The bouncers and bartenders are uber friendly especially if you get to know them by frequenting the place (as is always the case at any club).  

I also really love love love the set up.  The DJ booth sits high and pretty above the dance floor which is small, yet the perfect size.  I've spent many nights here dancing myself into oblivion on a packed dance floor as well as an empty one.  Maybe I'm just the weird girl that does that, but this dance floor is definitely very inviting.  Also, the back patio is a great size and reminds me of a Mediterranean villa.  There's a lovely fireplace and sometimes they have a DJ spinning out there too. 

The crowd is a bit older compared to some other downtown places and I've seen some fairly eclectic attire (love it).  Go here when you don't feel like dealing with sloppy sorority sisters falling all over the place and screaming, "WOOOOO!"  That's not to say I haven't had my share of attitude-filled sass coming from bimbos waiting in the lady's room line.

Oh, and no there isn't just one bathroom.  Look around people!!  There's another one outside.

I was really impressed by The French Press. They were the first spot I found that had free wifi, so I jumped in line and grabbed an oh-so-delicious almond milk latte. It had a heart on the top of it, because maybe the guy was in love. I enjoyed that coffee thoroughly.

I made my way to the back of the coffee house and found a lone table to work at for an hour. It was really packed there, including the outside, but it made for some good ol' distracting entertainment. A pair of lovers finding reasons to show far too much PDA a few tables over, a guy going crazy at the air outside, and one really annoying person smoking outside. I'm kinda surprised they allow smoking, or maybe no one saw him. I would've moved but there was no where to go. 

So a guy came around and asked how I was doing and how my coffee was. That was a really nice touch. He even took my cup and didn't seem irritated that he was working. Which is something I find frequently in this day and age, unfortunately. 

I will definitely visit this shop again next time I'm in town. Great experience!

Second Harvest seems to be a great food distribution center.  However I am reviewing the banquet room and catering staff.

I attended a wonderful party here last Friday evening.  The grounds around the place are lovely, and everything looks nice inside and out!  We entered and walked up a spiral staircase.  The banquet room was down the hall, and it overlooked the warehouse.  It was a nice room, and I thought it was cool to get to see the warehouse.  I believe the banquet room is used as a fund raising tool for the warehouse, which is wonderful.

The room was nicely decorated, the table center pieces were pretty potted flowers in recycled food cans.  I thought that was an awesome center piece (and I'm thinking about copying it for my upcoming wedding).

The bartenders were quick with the drink distribution.  The food was all refilled as soon as it got low.  The BBQ dishes were all tasty.  But my favorite part of the meal was the berry cobbler.   I love blueberry pie, but I am frequented extremely disappointed if the pie has canned filling.  But I was not at all disappointed with this cobbler.  The filling was fresh, and had a light lemon flavor to it.  Even though I was really full, I still had seconds of the cobbler.  Just thinking about it now makes me wish I had more!

This is a great place to host events!

Yum!!!! 

I thought my sirloin cheesesteak was really delicious! The meat was not over cooked at all and made to order. The fries were also really tasty and covered in parm cheese and some spices. Loved them. I also loved how fresh they tasted. 

I was also really into the fact that they make their own wiz BUT because of this, it gets hard really fast so I wouldn't order it with my fries again. That being said, it was great on my cheesesteak and the fries were great without the cheese so for the first time ever, I'm happy to skip cheese fries. :)

All in all, I will definitely order from them again!

Years ago, before the birth of many microbreweries, Saint Somewhere used to be in a warehouse. They would pour you some beer after you paid for a tour, as they couldn't sell beer and most certainly did not have a taproom.  

Three weeks ago, Saint Somewhere finally moved to their new location, inside a historic home right in downtown Tarpon Springs.  It's a lovely blue building, with a small front courtyard and a two rooms for enjoying your beer.  Unlike most breweries, and befitting their historic building status, they keep the interior homely and reminiscent of an earlier age, with fading photos (apparently some are of their ancestors.)  Upstairs will be guest rooms, as a new form of B&B - Beer and Bed.  Isn't it how things were hundreds of years ago?  

When we visited today, their beers are still fermenting after the move and won't be available for another week or two. They therefore offer several Belgian ales on tap, as well as some of their own brews, plus cider, non-alcoholic tonic water etc. in bottles and cans.  When fully operational, there will be 10 drafts.

It's great to grab a beer and sit inside by the big window for people watching.  Or sit outside by in their little yard.  Right next door is KC Cue, a great bbq place for grabbing some award winning ribs or pulled pork.  

They don't do flights, so the beers come in a full pour at around $6-8. They are nice enough to let you sample their beers, in the cutest miniature beer glasses though.

For months I have been craving some Chinese food. I began to research the area and after reading reviews I had to try this place! 

I drove out to the location and noticed the area it was in was actually an area I was familiar with! I entered the restaurant and was immediately greeted by the cashier! She was friendly and helpful. My "go to" dish at any Chinese restaurant is the sweet and sour chicken with fried rice; and so I didn't have to think about what I wanted to order. What I really enjoyed about this place was that instead of the egg roll as the traditional side, I could choose crab rangoon instead! I LOVE crab rangoon and had actually thought about ordering a side of them; but since they were included in the meal I had to get them. They were to die for! Creamy and delicious! The sweet and sour chicken was phenomenal and just the way I love it! Some places use chicken that I find to be too chewy, but this was tender and juicy! Just thinking about it is making me hungry again. 

I will be making another visit and have another dish I plan to try! I will let you know how that goes!

Guys, just go. The Franklin Institute is a lovely museum in Philly, right downtown by many other lovely museums and nerdy fun. The exhibits are so fun and interactive, and they're chock full of information that caters to all levels. So bring your kids, come on a date, or take your parents! There's something for everyone. I came here with my bestie, and some of the displays sparked a big discussion for us about the integration of history in science and how it influences the context of what was discovered. As you can see, this place just tickles my brain.

There is an area that has various exhibits that change from time to time. I visited for the Pixar exhibit, which was super cool, large, and informative, and most recently visited for the Game Master exhibit, a display containing tons of video games, both old and new! 100%, just go. Let me know what you think when you do.

I LOVED this place. My boyfriend and I came on a Saturday afternoon and it was bit crowded but we were able to find seating. The machines were cool! You could order pre-selected and add or just make your own salad. I got a delicious salad with roasted garlic balsamic vinaigrette on the side which I didn't even need because the salad was so delicious on its own. My boyfriend got a salad with noodles in it which were a bit spicy if you like that kind of thing. The salads were so fresh and the staff was pretty friendly. I would definitely come here again!

For a night time bite you can beat the low key, super chill staff and great eats at Tic Toc. It's nice not to have to go into the city. The food was delicious and they make it once you order so everything is hot and ready. There's parking but depending on where you come from there's a wicked like u turn to get into the lot. Fluffy pancakes and great service. Open late. What's not to love?

I didn't get to eat here on my last trip so I made it a point to make it this time around. The restaurant itself is beautifully decorated. You walk through the kitchen into a room full of bright colors. There's a bar upfront and some outdoor seats to the side of the main dining area. It gets absolutely packed and they don't take reservations for parties under 5, so be prepared.

My favorite dish may have been the fried eggplant appetizer with an oyster cream sauce and mushrooms. I'm a sucker for any cream sauce but this was amazing. Perfectly cooked eggplant smothered in a rich seafood based sauce, amazing. 

My friend ordered the eggplant perogue with shrimp, oysters, and fish in a cream sauce. She loved it but the sauce had some kind of cheese in it and I'm just not a fan of seafood and cheese.

I ordered the Godzilla, a seasonal special of fried softshell crab over fried green tomatoes with remoulade and a side of slaw. I'm not usually a fan of softshell crab (I know, I know) but this was the best I've ever had. The fried green tomatoes were on the soggy side, that may have been due to the remoulade or the crab sitting on top of them, I'm not sure but I left them alone in favor of their amazing slaw! Our entrees came with two sides and a salad. Unknown to us the salad also comes with a fried oyster. Why don't all salads come this way? 

Service was beyond fantastic, our waiter was extremely patient while we struggled to make our choices. Their Fi Na Ye and watermelon margarita drinks are delicious. Their creme brulee is also a winner. Check them out!

I wanted to love this little bakery by the river in middle of New Hope, but unfortunately the items I tried here were disappointing. On the plus side, service was very friendly - everyone I interacted with was genuinely nice, and they were offering some samples outside the bakery. The location by the river is also lovely, and there is a nice outside seating area. They also accept credit cards now.

I tried the mango mousse and the clafoutis, which were $5.50 each. The mousse was ok, very light and not too sweet, but the sponge beneath was more like a grainy wet cookie. The custard portion of the clafoutis was ok - very eggy and barely sweet - but I didn't like the tough crust underneath or the very bright and artificial cherries. I hope these two are exceptions and that the rest of the large selection is better, but I don't think I'll be stopping by again the next time I'm in the area.

Why, oh WHY is my stomach not big enough to be able to eat both a savory crepe for a meal and a sweet crepe for dessert? Why do I have to choose? It's just wrong.

Nothing beats 3 Days in Paris. I want them to franchise and be available everywhere I go. I love the iPad with Square credit card reader. I love the line up to the bar in the balcony so you can send a note down to 3DIP to place your order. It's exciting like camping in your basement as a kid. I love the devices that allow the crepe-juice to be dispensed on two different griddles. I want more and hate Jon A for always checking in here when I can't.

Totally just A-OK, not really feeling anything special about this relatively-new O'Reilly's spot. The last couple of times I've visited Indy my family ends up here as my aunt and uncle love coming here for dinner. It's a good location and has a nice indoor/outdoor setup, but that's about all that impresses me. They have a kiddie area both indoor and outdoor, but keep the kids away from the outdoor stuff especially after rain, it looked a little gross.

Every time we've been we've had to wait 15-20 minutes for someone to come by our table and greet us/take drink orders. It's not like they've been uber busy and had a line out the door. I can't even recall there being a hostess at the front to direct us where to sit. The most recent time, we had one girl finally come up to our table and take our drink orders, but then disappear for another 10-15 minutes before another lady came to our aid. Waitress #2 was the one who took our food order and drink refills. And then more waiting until our food slowly trickled to the table - just a few salads and some of the [nothing special IMO] fish n chips. The chips are good, but the fish is... meh. The girls were really good at drink refills once we got our food, weirdly enough. And then right when we're looking to get the check, they disappear again, and more waiting had to be done to get the bill. And more waiting to get the receipts/cards back. 

TLDR: Service needs improvement. The food is nothing special. Thank God they serve alcohol.

It was gross. Smelled funny. Was not clean. The bed was sunken in. The pictures are deceiving. It does not look as good as it does in the pics. 

My love fell out of the shower because it has weird curved edges with barely any flat surface to stand on.

Went here for an anniversary dinner on a weekday night. First, the service was unbelievable. Perhaps because there were such few tables but we were attended to in every corner and the food came out at a very quick pace. When I was unsure of what wine to order, the server allowed me to try my choice. Loved every dish that we ordered. Plentiful and seasoned mussels. My scallops were cooked to perfection. I tried the steak too and was pretty good! Would definitely recommend this restaurant!!

2nd of 3 lunch spots I hit this week with 2 co workers while working from home this week. Never one to turn down a good deal on a lunch buffet of authentic ethinic cuisine, I was in on a blink!

Not but 3 miles from home I joined my comrads about noon and found the  place pretty low key, not too busy at all.

For $11 bucks you have a big variety of legit Brazilian grub to pick from. Sorry for not knowing the names well but thats what the pictures are for right?

The pineapple and ham entree was legit, really good! The salads and marinated veggies were on point. I highly suggest trying the soup with bok choy and chicken! Super good! The one with bacon and okra was also really tasty. The tandori chicken they had was also fall off the bone good! They had a really good black bean and potato entree with a nice kick to it I enjoyed.

I need to take my 3 apartment friends who actually moved from Brazil to work at Wash U and Barnes on fellowships into this place to see how they rate the food on the buffet and the main menu. I love Brazilian food myself as they use spices, marinates and herbs so well to amplify the flavors of almost everything!
How is the F Concourse not connected to the other Concourses?! We had to take a bus across the blacktop just to get to B Concourse. I did love the free wifi though.

I LOVE lush!! I go here often to get face masks and cleansers :) The service is great, the prices are well set, and the products are always good. Additionally, I love that I can smell the store from around the corner. It smells like soap heaven!

I went to the original Cafe Spice in Olde City with my family for dinner one night. We were roaming the area and got hungry and since we all love Indian food we went there. It was honestly the best Indian food I have ever had. And this was like over five years ago. The only problem, Indian is not supposed to be expensive!!! I mean, the places by Penn are so much more reasonable, although they lack the luxurious ambience. 
But anyway, Cafe Spice Express is like the best of both worlds. I can get my delicious, most favorite foods in the entire world, Vegetable Samosas, and a side of garlic Naan (mm fresh from the oven and filled with flavorful bits of garlic...) for a reasonable price.
 I haven't ever had any of the entrees from here, but I am sure they are just as tasty. My favorite part of the Express is the location. After a day of roaming around or shopping with friends we can go to the food court at Liberty and all find something we like to eat. I will always, of course, choose Cafe Spice.

OH! Totally forgot-- Now Whole Foods carries Cafe Spice samosas to go! And I got some today and they were pretty tasty. Not as good as fresh from the restaurant but definitely an upgrade from the ones they were carrying before.

The best thing about Steam is the outdoor patio. It is big and the restrooms are right inside the door. Oh, and they were cool with our dog! The chop salad with falafel was awesome. I would love to eat that everyday. 

The crab quesadilla was pretty bad. It was the product of someone who has no idea what a quesadilla is or the characteristics of what a good one looks like, tastes like or feels like. This version was hard, dry and tasteless. The canned crab was no help. We each ate 1 of the 4 pieces and ditched the rest. 

Our last dish was the buffalo scallop and shrimp wrapped in prosciutto. The idea is great. The scallops and shrimp were good. Shrimp a little overcooked, but otherwise it was good. The prosciutto was a little dry and hard. The first few bites were great, but the buffalo sauce got a little old. 

The beer was good and the outdoor seating was spot on. Just don't get the quesadilla.

You know,  I liked Horizons. My gentleman friend and I went here for our anniversary last year, and it was lovely - the tapas were a highlight. I had a roasted beet thing that i loved. Then the main meal came, and while gentleman's meal was fantastic, mine was good. Which isn't to say i didnt enjoy it, because I did - It just didn't wow me in a way that i dream of it late at night (as other restaurants in the city have affected me in the past).  The wines were as delicious as the tapas, the service was fantastic, and i enjoyed the experience. I would go here again.

Great food with great prices. The service here is also really on point. We had 4 people and shared 2 plates with 3 sides. Plates included biscuits/gravy/eggs and egg/pancakes/sausage with 2 sides of hash brown and sourdough toast. Everything was super delicious and service was really quick! Would definitely love to come back again!!

This is one of those times where I'm like, "I could have sworn I wrote a review for this place", but honestly, I loved it so much that I'd write it over and over again if needed. I mean, who doesn't love ranch dressing? And, well, if you don't think is not the place for you.

I found myself in St. Louis and had been looking all over for random places to try. A friend of mine came up with this suggestion at the advice of a friend. I said, "how could this be bad with ranch in the title?" 

The biggest issue with dining here really was finding street parking. Well, also, the place is packed, but you can make it work like we did by sitting at the bar. Believe me, they can fit a lot of plates on that bar because we went to town on some food.

Also, I'd like to add- if you don't like French fries you're going to 1) be missing out 2) I guess order onion rings because how do you not get French fries with ranch dressing?

Okay, so the main attraction in my opinion, and I have to be in the majority here is the ranch this country flight. For $13 you get a mountain of fries and 13, yes 13 different type of ranch of your choosing. They have like 30 total so believe me, it's difficult. Not a glutton like us? Well you can do the ranch this country flight for $5 which has your choice of 5 ranch flavors.

Some of the flavors include: Twisted Ranch (original), Asian Zing, Avocado, Carter's Smoke (Smoke Paprika), Buttermilk Basil, Greek, Jack the Ripper (Pepper Jack), It Takes 2 to "Mango", Pesto, Red Billy Goat (Red Peppers & Goat Cheese), Roasted Garlic, Southwest, Ruffalo (Roasted Garlic & Buffalo), and Smoke Tomato Basil just to list off some of the choices.  The flight comes on essentially a lazy Susan that spins around delightful ranch dressing. The amount of fries is almost absurd. But the fries and every ranch dressing were delicious.

Being me, I got even more fries with my patty melt style burger which was cooked exactly how I wanted it to be, but again, you almost don't come here to eat anything other than ranch, but please do because the food was quality even if it is under the shadow of that ranch dressing which we were told was made in house.

The service was great. The staff behind the bar were super friendly and chatted with us a lot while we ate. It was a great experience. Something I didn't know I needed in my life and a place I have to get back to. It's one of those places you'd travel there just to go to, well, at least if you love ranch dressing as much as I do. And the prices are so unbelievably cheap too. It's definitely a win.

Loved this place! We basically ordered everything off of the menu to share among the table. Bone marrow-to die for, Brussels sprouts were amazing, poutine was also incredible. Highly recommend and we sat outside which was the perfect atmosphere.
Love it!  At the top of my list now with Tinker Street.  Great atmosphere, great cocktails, wine selection outstanding, and food quality is top notch.  Not much more to say, but bravo!

It was time for a work birthday party and we discussing cake. One of my co-workers, said how about trying, "The Cakery". I immediately light up and said, YES! YES! I grabbed my smartphone, and showed them reviews and pictures on Yelp to sell them on the idea of ordering the cake from, The Cakery. 

My enthusiasm sold them and we ordered the birthday cake. The honoree is a big candy lover, so we selected one topped in a variety of sweet treats. The cake was a two tiered chocolate separated by a vanilla butter creme. The top was close to a Tiffany Blue dripping down the sides. Beautiful presentation. 

Our birthday boy loved his cake and my co-workers who had never experienced, The Cakery were totally impressed. They loved the rich flavor and how moist the cake was. This was a total win. 

Perhaps we'll celebrate the next birthday with cupcakes from, The Cup. I already started singing the praises of their cupcake store. 

Would I go again? Yes, I always love a good cake. 

When: October 7, 2017
Why: Birthday Celebration

Oh god, have I not reviewed this Yats yet? Well, the Mass Ave location is definitely my favorite. Same awesome food, but it wins in the best decor and atmosphere department. If you don't know about Yats yet, then quit reading my review and go already. I would love to see this business blow up even bigger than it already has. Can I get a Plainfield Yats at some point? Pretty please?

Awesome new pizza spot in the 'hood!  I love Dolce and was excited to hear they opened up a pizza spot in Liberties Walk.

Since they've opened, I've been here a few times already, grabbing some slices for dinner.  They re-did the entire interior of what used to be another pizza place, upgrading the decor and making it look very pizzeria/sicilian-like.  They always have an array of pies, all with different toppings, for you to grab slices from - and plenty of vegetarian (and even a vegan option or two), as well!

The menu has so much more than pizza, such as burgers, salads, strombolis/calzones, and more.  I've only eaten a few slices, but they can custom-make any type of pizza you're looking for and the other items on the menu sound great too.  Given their initial cafe, I know the quality of the ingredients are going to be top-notch and the food will taste great.

Will be back a lot!  And they're BYOB!

Until today, I don' think I really knew what mediocre sushi tasted like. I went with a friend for a late lunch, about 2 pm but still within their lunch special window (11-3). For $10 I got two classic rolls and a salad. The rolls were about on par with grocery store sushi. My friend got one of the stirfrys and a roll and felt similarly lukewarm.

Our server was very attentive and friendly, and both the interior and patio were lovely. I would give both of these elements 4 stars, but with just meh sushi, I can't bring myself to muster an overall three stars. If I go back, I'll probably choose fried over "fresh."

I am a Sephora fan.  I LOVE Sephora as a store/brand.  I just do not like this particular Sephora location.  They have poor customer service.  One thing that attracted me to the Sephora stores years ago when I started using Sephora was the customer service.  Someone was always eager to help and excited to show me new products.  It was a great business tactic on their part because I may have gone in for mascara but I'd end up leaving with 4 things!  And I loved it because I love makeup!  

Since I moved to St. Louis and began coming to this Sephora location, I just haven't had that same positive experience.  They still have the product I want, so I shop here regularly, but their employees (and therefore, probably management) stinks!  Instead of being welcomed into the store, their employees can be found chatting amongst themselves.  I have to interrupt them when I have a question.  They are not usually eager to help me try on new products and find things that fit me.  

During my most recent experience the employee had no knowledge of the products I was asking about and barely helped me at all.  Each of the samples was worn down or dried out and I kept mentioning to this employee that this was the case.  She just offered a "yeah" but didn't do anything to get a fresh product sample.  

When I went to check out they were out of the 500 point rewards and had nothing to replace them.  

Honestly, what used to be my favorite store is now losing its appeal to me.  I feel like going to department stores instead of Sephora for my makeup.

Philadelphia has many of these cozy speakeasy concept bars popping up, some deserve the hype and others that fall painfully short. I also, as a Philadelphian, resent loving a Stephen Starr restaurant as much as I love Ranstead Room.

Whomever designed this concept for Starr left no detail to chance. It's warm, intimate, sexy and romantic. Soft portraits of beautiful women from yesteryear bring what I imagine to be the feel of an old gentlemen's lounge. The black damask wall paper leaves a dramatic impression in the small room and pulls together the elegant vintage aesthetic. Dim lighting and flickering candles tie together the room, perfect for sharing drinks and secrets with your companions.

Of course we don't go to these bars to get seduced by the decor, let's get down to cocktails. Vodka is a dirty word, if you want it go elsewhere. The mixologists working the bar here have the talent to turn the toughest spirits into tongue pleasing treats. If you don't know what you want or see it on the menu do yourself a favor and trust the talent here. Tell them the notes and flavors you enjoy most and they will deliver something you may have never even believed you would like. Be open minded and most of all be patient. True art takes time.

The service here is unmatched. I have enjoyed return trips to sit at the bar and watch Tang open up his little handwritten black book of drinks, dreaming of the treasures within. Alicia is a sweet gem whose personality makes it impossible to not to feel like you are welcome to stay the night and chit chat over drinks. Do yourself a favor and bring a date or your paying parents here. The staff will make you comfortable and make sure you're well attended while providing the best classic cocktail selection in the city.

I've visited the 12 South location and just love their donuts. They're fluffy, delicious and their flavor pairings are always interesting and on point. 

I didn't feel like fighting traffic for a donut, so I went to Franklin. The factory is so cute and I love that they has local Tennessee businesses. 

The staff was super friendly and wanted to chat. I welcomed it and appreciated the conversation because traveling alone gets quiet.

My heart says 5; my logic tells me 4.

Why 5?:
This is my absolute FAVORITE place to get breakfast on the weekends!  It is so reasonably priced and the food is outstanding!  My routine meal has grown to consist of a cup of coffee and the "Sunrise", which is a half order of biscuits & gravy, 2 eggs (any style) & 2 bacon strips or sausage links.  I just love it...not to mention it's easy on the bank; my entire meal typically stays right around $10, including a tip. 
There is absolutely something for everyone on the menu; they serve lunch and breakfast, and you really can't go wrong with either!

So, why a 4?:
Flap Jacks Pancake House is only open until 3pm.  This sounds okay at first, but I feel that they are busy enough to entertain crowds a little longer, especially on the weekends.  Furthermore, there have been multiple times when I wanted Flap Jacks on a Sunday afternoon, but it was too close to closing time for that to be a realistic option. 
Another reason for my 4 rating is because there are times when the service is sort of slow.  They absolutely do their best to provide great service, but they are always so busy!  I whole-heartedly believe that the slow service is due to how overwhelmingly busy they can be at times. 
Lastly, the place can feel a little crowded when there are a lot of people dining.  The tables are situated rather close to each other, and there is very limited standing space when waiting to be seated.

As a whole, I would recommend Flap Jacks to anyone!  In fact, it is typically my "go-to" recommendation when people ask about places to eat breakfast/brunch in the area.  It's really a "must try"!

I can not believe it, no one has written a review for this great co-op boutique. I was here for a Halloween party before their opening and just now got back to actually shop. I am now remorseful for not returning sooner. 

There are about 40+ vendors offering all sorts of goodies. Ranging from clothing for women and men, to hand made soaps, posters, candies, candles and so much more. One vendor offers some very creative and tasteful stationary. I'm a sucker for note cards and thank you cards. 

Next time you are downtown, make it a point to stop by and shop this "Collective" boutique. Chances are you will find something to your liking. I did. I love my new poster/map that shows all the neighborhoods in Saint Louis. Now I know where all the Yelp Dukedoms are located. Also, the Milk Chocolate Triple Dipped Malt Balls from, Oh Lolli Lolli melted in my mouth. Yes I am dieting, but I can still have a treat and these malt balls were truly a treat.

Finally a bagel place in town where they make real honest to goodness bagels and not those fake bready bagels.  I've eaten at their Mt Rose store when I've been in the area but have asked them time and time again to branch out closer to my side of Reno.  My favorite bagel is the rock salt bagel which should be eaten fresh as the next day it becomes a bit wet.  I guess it picks up some of the humidity in the air.  Chemistry anyone?  Still, I'll eat it.  They also serve sandwiches and drinks along with smears but the two times I've been there I've only picked up bagels by the dozen and pleasantly, they serve a baker's dozen!  They took over the old Starbucks building at the base of California Avenue and Virginia Street.  The only suggestion I have for them would be that I'd love to see egg bagels.  I haven't seen them anywhere since I left Hawaii so there must be something difficult about making them.  Please make them.  I will buy them... Regularly!  The bagels are priced at less than a dollar each.  Well worth it.
Just had lunch here. Best catfish in town. Cole slaw was good. The fries changes depending on your visitation but still good. Parking could be difficult but if you love catfish, it's worth it.

Ordered a pizza late last night--waitress said I only have 4 minutes left to order...and so I ordered and then waited.
The pizza ended up being a take out because I was wearing shorts and a t-shirt and they had all the windows open for whatever reason, it was 56 degrees outside and inside the bar.
I've concluded the pizza is probably more delicious if I had drank something much stronger than a Coke. 
I heard so many good things about their deep dish pizzas. For nearly $30, I was not impressed with their product. Although it was smothered in cheese, the pizza sauce was so thick it was caked in our teeth, and the crust was super crusty--like a biscuit that sat in the warmer way too long. 
Obviously they are selling pizza's, but I didn't love it.

I really like this place! It's located in a cozy neighborhood in North Philly and they are known to have some pretty unique lattes. As someone who loves the decadence of a latte, I ended up getting the London Tease (because it's early grey - I mean come on). It's a pretty cozy place to work, with great wifi, ample seating (though it's a small store). They are known to have some great seasonal flavors, and I think I would make the trip back just to try some more of their flavors.

Chinatown at night is a seedy and wonderful place usually visited in the twilight of judgement. 

It always feels wet. 

There's something about a place that always feels wet.... 

That's not the whole cake though... there's something else, something that can't really fit in it's flesh... the dirty neon windows, the steam, the sense of misgivings coming from every direction.... 

Its all oddly attractive. 

Either way, error-to-error, Yakitori boy is definitely the biggest shame-spray disaster of a drunken frenzy to be found amidst the filth that Chinatown offers in its open hands. 

You jonesin' to hear six-figures Japanese business men spitting out the best of George Thorogood and the Destroyers until your ears vomit? 

Interested in eating a suspicious melody of skewered chicken organs for a dollar a stick? 

Think its a well idea to serenade your soon to be lover in a private room with a wretchingly-passionate tribute to George Micheal featuring your personal rendition of Father Figure as the closer? 

Done. Done. More than Done. 

Much more than Done.

I can't believe I'm the first and only person to be reviewing El Maguey. This place is my new favorite Mexican place in Indy. I have been 3 times since finding it, and can't wait to go back. It came highly recommended by one of the Mexican employees with whom I work, and I would make the same recommendation! The service is excellent, the food is absolutely delicious, and the ambience is very nice. I can't think of anything that I don't really like about El Maguey. It is located in a relatively un-amazing strip mall on 38th street (though, how many places in Indianapolis aren't located in a crappy strip mall?) next to the Little Caesars and hiding behind the Steak and Shake. You'd never know that inside of the unassuming Mexican restaurant front is some seriously great food and great service.

A huge part of my Mexican restaurant experience is the chips and salsa served before the meal. Call me whatever you want, I love that stuff! The chips and salsa at El Maguey are the best I've had in town. I also keep ordering the huevos rancheros ($5 for the lunch plate... but it's enough food to feed 2!!) and it always makes me smile. You've gotta try this place!

Came based on a recommendation from a local friend when I said I wanted a greasy "in and out" burger. Came for The burgers but got distracted by all the other offerings and ended up getting 3 different things. Chicken pot pie soup from the Grilled Cheese and a burger from hughs and a chicken sandwich from there as well. The come back sauce is to die for. Love this little combo of offerings! Will recommend it to others.

I've been here twice and loved it both times. I've gotten a free taco twice with the coupon you get for checking in. I've also tried the burrito, which was MASSIVE, and the nachos, were also generously portioned. The carne asada is the juiciest I've ever had. The cook is really sweet and funny, and all of the employees have been very kind. It's a hole in the wall type of place, but very worth visiting.

A gem hiding out in the French Quarter! Croissant D'or is a must try for anyone craving a Parisian patisserie experience. The space is amazing and cute (love the tiles and row of big round light bulbs). And whoever dreamed up the bechamel croissant is a genius. Anything that is spun out of butter, stuffed with spinach then topped with bechamel and cheese is a deliciously fattening force to be reckoned with! Croissant is inexpensive to boot! This is my idea of (non-calorie counting) breakfast perfection.

I love coming here. Not only because it is really close to my house, but the food is fresh, fast and they have a great selection for groceries for when I need to pick up something. They are always friendly.

So far, I've had many of their standard sandwiches, paninis and salads. No complaints!

On the spur of the moment, we decided to stop in and check this place out.  We should have planned ahead and made a reservation, but that's our own fault.  The wait was about 30 minutes, so could have been worse.  There were quite a few large groups with reservations that came in while we were waiting which I'm sure made the wait a little longer than usual.

Me and my guy were both impressed with everything we had.  I had the Cesar salad and filet Mignon.  The salad was your traditional Cesar and the filet Mignon was truly tantalizing.  Melted in my mouth and I savored every bite.  He had the cauliflower and prime rib. He said the "mashed potato" cauliflower was delicious.  And his prime rib, even better.  We both loved the sauteed spinach with Parmesan.  Seriously, one thing was better than the next, but then it wasn't because the last item was so yummy.  

I have not yet enjoyed the patio, but I'm sure it will be amazing.  Fire pit and all!

When I saw The Quesadillas on Yelp, I was a bit unsure at first, coming across a Mexican place in Tucson that I'd never heard of before in a location where I'd never seen anything interesting. I have to say I was very pleasantly surprised! 

This little shop is reminiscent of a taco truck, with a permanent location. As with many local taco trucks, it serves up excellent tacos with high quality meat and flavors. I was very happy with the lunch special of two carne asada tacos and a quesadilla. The salsa options were great, as I love pouring on a few different kinds. I have to say that the tacos surpassed the quesadilla in taste, as the meat was fabulous but the tortillas may have been cooked a bit too long.

My one grievance may be that the menu is a bit limited, their tacos and quesadillas are great but that's all there is. They are definitely more of a lunch place, and probably not great for a group who may want something other than just tacos and quesadillas. Even so, I'll probably stop in again one day soon.

Love love love this place!!! Customer service is number 1! We were offered random flavors to try without even asking! Super duper fun!

When you walk in...it like a childhood dream! The smell of fresh baked waffle cones fills the air.  The unique chalk board menu immediately caught my eyes.  I wish I thought of this!   Love it. 

The flavors are abundant and chances daily! I was able to try Soo many flavors and my favorite so far is the coffee pecan pralines! It's rich and creamy, with a pecan praline crunch for added texture! I was not brave enough to try lavender honey. 

If you feel adventurous, take the Tchoupitoulas Challenge. 8 scoops and 8 toppings and be on their Hall of Fame Plaque if you choose to finish! 

This is a must try local joint!

I LOVED the atmosphere and ambiance of this bar; it was classy and the concept was unique. The seats around the bar actually move like a carousel very slowly. My friend and I shared the Monteleone and Fleur Des Lis, both signature drinks of the bar. The Fleur Des Lis has gin, ginger ale, cucumber, and a hint of a flowery taste.
